bcl:subsection.bcl:text: including extending a time period or establishing a new date in place of a date set under this Act or the Local Elections Campaign Financing Act and giving any other directions the minister considers appropriate in relation to this.

In relation to this Part, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the Interpretation Act, including regulations for any matter for which regulations are contemplated by this Part.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing information that must be included under section 55 in an application for registration as an elector, which may be different for resident electors and non-resident property electors;

prescribing classes of documents that may be accepted as evidence for the purpose of section 57 [how to register as a resident elector at the time of voting] or 57.1 [how to register as a non-resident property elector at the time of voting];
for the purposes of section 67,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: deeming a described class of persons to be employees of a municipality or regional district, and
excepting a described class of persons as excluded from the definition of "employee",

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: which may be different for different specified municipalities and regional districts;

prescribing information that must be included in the notice of nomination under section 70, which may be different for municipalities and regional districts and may be different for municipal elections at large and on the basis of a neighbourhood constituency;
prescribing additional information or material required to be provided under section 73.1 (1) (e) [other information to be provided by candidate];
prescribing matters that must be included in the solemn declaration under section 73.4 (1) (c) [endorsement documents];
prescribing additional information or material required to be provided under 73.5 (1) (f) [other information to be provided by elector organization];
establishing requirements, limits and conditions in relation to voting by mail ballot under section 100, which may be different for municipalities and regional districts;
establishing requirements, limits and conditions in relation to voting under section 102, which may be different for different specified municipalities and regional districts;
establishing requirements, limits and conditions in relation to municipal voting divisions under section 103, which may be different for municipalities of different population sizes;
prescribing one or more alternative forms in which a specified solemn declaration must be made.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The definitions in Part 3 apply to this Part and, in addition, in this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: assent voting means voting conducted for a municipality or regional district on a matter referred to in section 158;
voting area means an area for which the applicable assent voting is to be conducted.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Assent voting to be conducted in same manner as an election

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Part applies to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: voting on a bylaw or other matter for which assent of the electors is required;
voting on a bylaw or other matter for which the local government is authorized by this or another Act to obtain the assent of the electors, unless otherwise provided by the authorizing enactment;
voting on a referendum under section 797.3 [referendums regarding regional district services].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as otherwise provided, Part 3 [Electors and Elections] applies in relation to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: voting referred to in subsection (1) as if the assent voting for the voting area were an election for an election area, and
non-election assent voting advertising as if it were election advertising.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For certainty, Division 17 [Election Offences] of Part 3 applies in relation to assent voting.
Unless otherwise provided in this Act, assent of the electors to a bylaw or other matter is obtained only if a majority of the votes counted as valid are in favour of the bylaw or question.

If a bylaw that requires the assent of the electors does not receive that assent, a bylaw for the same purpose may not be submitted to the electors within a period of 6 months from the last submission except with the minister's approval.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Who may vote at assent voting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order to vote at assent voting, a person must meet both the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person must meet the qualifications of section 50 as a resident elector, or section 51 as a non-resident property elector, in relation to the voting area for which the assent voting is to be conducted;
the person must be registered in accordance with subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To vote in assent voting a person must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be registered, on or before the date established under subsection (1) (a) relate, or
register immediately before voting,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: as an elector of the municipality or electoral area to which the person's qualifications referred to in subsection (1) (a) relate, or
as an elector for the purposes of the assent voting only.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may vote only once on a question submitted for assent voting, even though the voting is conducted in more than one voting area and the person is entitled to vote in relation to more than one voting area.
Registration referred to in subsection (2) (b) (ii) is effective only for the assent voting being conducted at that time.

If assent voting is not being held at the same time as an election for a municipality or electoral area in which the assent voting is to be conducted and advance registration for the municipality or electoral area is available under section 56,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the chief election officer must establish a date after which registration as an elector of the municipality or electoral area will not entitle the person to vote at the assent voting and the person must instead register under subsection (2) (b) of this section in order to vote, and
65 [resolving objections] do not apply to the municipality or electoral area in relation to the assent voting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If subsection (5) applies, at least 6 but not more than 30 days before the date established under paragraph (a) of that subsection, the chief election officer must give notice in accordance with section 44 of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: how a person may register in advance, and
the date after which advance registration will not apply for the purposes of the assent voting.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General voting day for assent voting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An authority in or under this or any other Act for the Lieutenant Governor in Council, a minister or the inspector to require a bylaw or other matter to be submitted for assent of the electors includes the authority to set a general voting day for obtaining that assent, subject to the restriction that general voting day must be on a Saturday.
Unless general voting day is set under subsection (1), the chief election officer must set general voting day for assent voting to be on a Saturday in accordance with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a bylaw that is directed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council, a minister or the inspector to be submitted for the assent of electors, not more than 80 days after the date of the direction;

in the case of a bylaw or other matter for which an alternative approval process was provided, not more than 80 days after the deadline for receiving elector responses under section 86 [alternative approval process] of the Community Charter;

subject to paragraph (b), in the case of a bylaw requiring the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, the inspector or a minister, not more than 80 days after the day of the approval or, if there is more than one approval required, of the last approval;
in the case of other bylaws, not more than 80 days after the day the bylaw receives third reading;
in the case of another matter, not more than 80 days after adoption of the authorizing bylaw or resolution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order for a bylaw under this Part or a bylaw referred to in section 39 to apply in relation to assent voting, the bylaw must be adopted at least 6 weeks before general voting day for the assent voting.
Unless subsection (3) or (4) applies, voting opportunities for the assent voting are those established under Part 3 for the assent voting.
Voting opportunities in a voting area for assent voting must be the same as those for an election being held at the same time as the assent voting if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the municipality or regional district for which the election is being held is conducting the assent voting for the voting area, and
the voting area for the assent voting is all or part of the election area for the election.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception to section 97 (2) (a) if all the following circumstances apply to the assent voting:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mail ballot voting is available under section 100 (3) (b);
the area specified for the purposes of section 100 (3) (b) includes all of the voting area for the assent voting;
the voting area is part but not all of an electoral area;
the assent voting is not being held at the same time as an election for the electoral area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In place of a notice of election under section 77, at least 6 but not more than 30 days before general voting day for assent voting, the chief election officer must issue a notice of assent voting under this section in accordance with section 44.
In addition to subsection (1), throughout the period between the 30th day before general voting day and general voting day, the notice of assent voting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be available for public inspection in the local government offices, during their regular office hours, of each municipality or regional district in which the assent voting is to be conducted, and
may be made available at other locations and times as the chief election officer considers appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice of voting must include the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the question that is to be voted on;
the voting area;
the qualifications required to be met in order to vote as an elector for the assent voting;
the date of general voting day, the voting places established under section 95 for that day and the voting hours for those places;
the documents that will be required in order for a person to register as an elector at the time of voting;
the place where persons may apply on general voting day for non-resident property elector certificates required in order to register at the time of voting;
if applicable, information required to be included under section 103 (5) regarding municipal voting divisions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the assent voting is on a bylaw submitted for the assent of the electors or is authorized by a bylaw, the notice of voting must also include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: either a copy of the bylaw or, if approved by the local government, a synopsis of the bylaw in accordance with subsection (5);
if a synopsis of the bylaw is included, a statement that the synopsis is not an interpretation of the bylaw;
the dates, times and places at which the bylaw may be inspected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A synopsis under subsection (4) (a) must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in general terms, the intent of the bylaw,
the area that is the subject of the bylaw, and
if applicable, the amount of the borrowing authorized by the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If subsection (4) applies, a full copy of the bylaw must be available for inspection by electors

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the local government offices, during their regular office hours, of each municipality or regional district in which the assent voting is to be conducted, and
at each place where voting is conducted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice of voting may also include any other information the chief election officer considers appropriate.
A ballot for assent voting must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: indicate the appropriate mark to make a valid vote indicating assent or dissent, and
be in a question form to which the elector may indicate assent or dissent by making the appropriate mark opposite the word "Yes" or the word "No".

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise provided under this or another Act, separate ballots must be prepared for each question that is to be voted on.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When counting for assent voting is to be done

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception to section 123, the counting of the vote for assent voting may be held at a later time set by the chief election officer, as long as the ballots are counted before the date of the declaration of the assent voting results under section 136.

If a later time for counting is set under subsection (1), the presiding election official must ensure that the ballots are sealed in ballot boxes in accordance with section 111 and are delivered to the chief election officer with the materials referred to in section 133.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special procedures if voting is conducted by more than one local government

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to assent voting on a regional district bylaw or other regional district matter that is to be conducted by more than one local government.
The regional district board must, by bylaw,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish the question to be used for all the voting, and
if applicable, set the date for the required advance voting day under section 97 (2) (b) for all voting areas other than a voting area referred to in section 163 (3) or (4).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except for a voting area referred to in section 163 (3), the bylaws under sections 96, 98 and 99 of a local government other than the regional district board do not apply and, instead, the regional district may, by bylaw, establish voting opportunities under those sections for one or more voting areas for the assent voting.
The regional district board must appoint

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a regional voting officer for the assent voting, and
a deputy regional voting officer for the assent voting who, if the regional voting officer is absent or unable to act, must perform the duties and has the powers of the regional voting officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The regional voting officer has the following duties and powers:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to arrange for the coordination of the proceedings throughout the regional district;
to set the general voting day for all voting throughout the regional district;
to arrange for the preparation of the ballots for the voting;
to direct the chief election officers for the local governments regarding the form and manner of notices that are required or authorized by this Act regarding the voting;
to make the final determination and declaration of assent voting results under sections 135 and 136 based on the results determined by the chief election officers of the local governments;
to appoint the scrutineers for the final determination of assent voting results and any judicial recount in accordance with section 172 (4) and (5);
to apply to the minister for an order under section 155.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If there is a conflict between this section or an authority under this section and another provision of this Act or an authority under this Act, this section or the authority under it prevails.
Notices under this Part may be combined with notices under Part 3, as it applies to elections or to assent voting, as long as the requirements of all applicable sections are met.
Section 149, requiring the publication of election results in the Gazette, does not apply to assent voting.
Regulations under section 156, as it applies to assent voting, may be different for different types of assent voting.

Scrutineers for the question in assent voting and scrutineers against the question must be appointed under section 172 if applications in accordance with section 171 are received from persons who wish to volunteer for the positions.

Only persons entitled to vote as electors in the assent voting are entitled to act as scrutineers for the assent voting, but election officials must not be appointed as scrutineers for the assent voting.

Unless a bylaw under subsection (4) applies, only one scrutineer for the question and one scrutineer against the question may be present at each place at which scrutineers are entitled by Part 3 to be present.
A local government may, by bylaw, permit additional scrutineers to be present at proceedings referred to in subsection (3), subject to any restrictions and conditions in the bylaw.
As a limit on the authority under subsection (4), a bylaw under that subsection may not provide for different entitlements for scrutineers for the question and scrutineers against the question.
The absence of a scrutineer from a place where proceedings for assent voting are being conducted does not invalidate anything done in relation to the other voting.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of applications to volunteer as a scrutineer

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Not more than 30 days before the application period begins, the chief election officer must issue a notice under this section in accordance with section 44.
The notice must include the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the question that is to be voted on;
the dates, times and places at which applications for scrutineers will be received;
how interested persons can obtain information on the requirements and procedures for making an application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice may include any other information the chief election officer considers appropriate.

In addition to subsection (1), from the sixth day before the application period begins until the close of the application period, the notice must be available for public inspection in the local government offices, during their regular office hours, of each municipality or regional district in which the assent voting is being conducted.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applications to volunteer to act as scrutineer for assent voting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chief election officer must establish a 10-day time period during which applications to act as a scrutineer will be received, in order that appointments may be made before the first voting opportunity.
As an exception to subsection (1), if general voting day for assent voting is the general voting day for an election, the period for receiving applications

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may be established under subsection (1), and
if it is not established under subsection (1), is the nomination period referred to in section 69.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application to act as a scrutineer for assent voting must be signed by the applicant and contain the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the full name of the person applying;
the address to which the person applying wishes to have notices sent;
if required by the chief election officer, a telephone number at which the person applying may be contacted;
a statement that the applicant is entitled to vote as an elector in the assent voting and is entitled to act as a scrutineer for the assent voting;
a statement as to whether the applicant is in favour of the question or opposed to the question;
any other information required to be included by a regulation under subsection (4).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order to be appointed as a scrutineer, the application to volunteer as a scrutineer must be received by the chief election officer, or a person designated by the chief election officer for this purpose, before the end of the application period under subsection (1).
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing information that must be included in an application under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appointment of scrutineers for assent voting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chief election officer must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the basis of the applications received in accordance with section 171, appoint applicants in favour of the question as scrutineers for the question and applicants opposed to the question as scrutineers against the question, and
assign scrutineers to each place at which scrutineers are entitled to be present under Part 3.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the number of applicants on one side of the question is fewer than the maximum allowed under section 169,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all these applicants must be appointed as scrutineers in accordance with subsection (1), and
a scrutineer may be assigned to more than one place if the hours or days of the proceedings at which scrutineers are entitled to be present allow this.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If there are more applicants on one side of the question than the maximum allowed under section 169, the following rules apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the scrutineers for that side must be determined by lot in accordance with the procedure used in section 107 (4) (a) to (d);
the chief election officer must notify all applicants of the date, time and place of the determination by lot and these applicants are entitled to be present;
names are to be drawn until the number of names drawn is equivalent to the number of scrutineers to be appointed;
the persons whose names are drawn must be appointed as scrutineers in accordance with subsection (1);
in the discretion of the chief election officer, additional names may be drawn of persons who may be appointed if applicants appointed under paragraph (d) are unable to act as scrutineers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the appointments under subsection (1), one scrutineer for the question and one scrutineer against the question is entitled to be present at the final determination under section 135 of the assent voting and at any judicial recount of the assent voting.
Scrutineers referred to in subsection (4) must be appointed in accordance with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the appointment must be made from among those persons who acted as scrutineers under subsection (1) and who indicate that they wish to be considered for the appointment;
if, for a side of the question, more than one person wishes to be considered for appointment, the choice must be made by lot in accordance with subsection (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A scrutineer appointment must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be made in writing,
state the name and address of the person appointed,
state the proceedings to which the scrutineer has been assigned under this section and the dates, times and places where these are to be conducted, and
be signed by the chief election officer.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Regional District Corporate Powers and Their Use

bcl:section.bcl:text: Each regional district is a corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The governing body of a regional district is its board.
The powers, duties and functions of a regional district are to be exercised and performed by its board unless this or any other Act provides otherwise.
A board, in exercising or performing the powers, duties and functions conferred on it by an enactment, is acting as the governing body of the regional district.
Despite any change in its membership, the board of a regional district is a continuing body and may complete any proceedings started but not completed before the change.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A board may only exercise or perform its powers, duties and functions within the boundaries of the regional district unless authorized under this or another Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the specific limitations and conditions established under this or another Act, the corporate powers of a board include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to make agreements respecting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the regional district's services, including agreements respecting the undertaking, provision and operation of those services, other than the exercise of the board's regulatory authority,
operation and enforcement in relation to the board's exercise of its regulatory authority, and
the management of property or an interest in property held by the regional district;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to make agreements with a public authority respecting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: activities, works or services within the powers of a party to the agreement, other than the exercise of regulatory authority, including agreements respecting the undertaking, provision and operation of activities, works and services,
operation and enforcement in relation to the exercise of regulatory authority within the powers of a party to the agreement, and
the management of property or an interest in property held by a party to the agreement;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to provide assistance for the purpose of benefiting the community or any aspect of the community;
to acquire, hold, manage and dispose of land, improvements, personal property or other property, and any interest or right in or with respect to that property;

to delegate its powers, duties and functions, including those specifically established by an enactment, to its officers and employees, its committees or its members, or to other bodies established by the board;
to engage in commercial, industrial and business undertakings and incorporate a corporation or acquire shares in a corporation for that purpose;
to establish commissions to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: operate regional district services,
undertake operation and enforcement in relation to the board's exercise of its regulatory authority, and
manage property or an interest in property held by the regional district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In exercising its powers under subsection (1), a board may establish any terms and conditions it considers appropriate.
The powers of a board under subsection (1) may be exercised outside the boundaries of the regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Disclosure of information relating to agreements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an agreement is proposed or made in relation to a matter that requires approval of the electors or assent of the electors,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the agreement, and
all records relating to the agreement that are in the custody or under the control of the regional district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must be available for public inspection at the regional district offices during the time when the approval or assent process is underway.
Subsection (1) does not apply to records that must not be disclosed under the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act.
Notices under

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 164 [notice of assent voting], or
section 86 (2) [alternative approval process — notice] of the Community Charter

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: in relation to the agreement must state that the agreement and the records relating to it are available for public inspection in the regional district offices during their regular office hours.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Approval for out-of-Province and out-of-country agreements with public authorities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An agreement between a board and a public authority in another province respecting the provision and operation of works and services has no effect unless it is approved by the minister.

An agreement between a board and a public authority in another country respecting the provision and operation of works and services has no effect unless it is approved by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 176 (1) (c) [corporate powers — assistance] and this Division, assistance means providing a grant, benefit, advantage or other form of assistance, including

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an exemption from a tax, fee or charge, and
the forms of assistance referred to in section 185 (1) [publication of intention to provide certain kinds of assistance].

bcl:section.bcl:text: As a limitation on section 176 (1) (c), a board must not provide assistance to an industrial, commercial or business undertaking.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exception for assistance under partnering agreements
bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 182 and in addition to the power under section 176 (1) (c), a board may provide assistance under a partnering agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may provide assistance for one or more of the purposes referred to in section 25 (2) [heritage assistance] of the Community Charter.

A board may, by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the votes cast, provide assistance for the conservation of property referred to in section 25 (3) [heritage property assistance] of the Community Charter.
The powers under this section are in addition to the power under section 176 (1) (c) [corporate powers — assistance] and apply despite section 182 [prohibition against assistance to business].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limitation on assistance by means of tax exemption
bcl:section.bcl:text: As a limitation on sections 176 (1) (c) and 183, a board may provide a property tax exemption only in accordance with Part 24.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Publication of intention to provide certain kinds of assistance

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board must publish in a newspaper its intention to provide any of the following assistance:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: disposing of land or improvements, or any interest or right in or with respect to them, for less than market value;
lending money;
guaranteeing repayment of borrowing or providing security for borrowing;
assistance under a partnering agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice must be published before the assistance is provided and must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the intended recipient of the assistance, and
the nature, term and extent of the proposed assistance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a board intends to dispose of land or improvements, it must make the land or improvements available to the public for acquisition.
Subsection (1) does not apply if the disposition is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a not for profit corporation,
to a public authority,
to a person who, as part of the consideration for the disposition, will exchange land or an improvement with the regional district,
to a person under a partnering agreement that has been the subject of a process involving the solicitation of competitive proposals, or
a disposition of land to an owner of adjoining land for the purpose of consolidating the lands.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board intending to dispose of land or improvements must publish notice of its intention in a newspaper in accordance with (3), as applicable.
If the disposition is a disposition referred to in section 186 (2), the notice must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a description of the land or improvements,
the person or public authority who is to acquire the property under the proposed disposition,
the nature and, if applicable, the term of the proposed disposition, and
the consideration to be received by the regional district for the disposition.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For all other dispositions, the notice must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a description of the land or improvements,
the nature and, if applicable, the term of the proposed disposition, and
the process by which the land or improvements may be acquired.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of money from sale of land or improvements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to (3), all money received by a regional district from the sale of land or improvements must be placed to the credit of a reserve fund.

If, after money is received under subsection (1), a debt incurred by the regional district for the purchase or management of the land or improvements remains, there must be set aside all or part of the proceeds of the disposition, as required to repay the debt as it matures together with interest.

Except as required by subsection (2), in the case of a sale of park land, a regional park or a regional trail, the proceeds of the disposition must be placed to the credit of a reserve fund established for the purpose of acquiring park lands.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Disposal of utilities and water and sewer systems

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a limitation on section 176 (1) (d) [corporate powers — property], the following works may only be disposed of in accordance with this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: works for the supply, treatment, conveyance, storage and distribution of water;
works for the collection, conveyance, treatment and disposal of sewage;
works for the supply and distribution of gas or electrical energy;
works for a transportation system, telephone system, closed circuit television system or television rebroadcasting system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The works may be disposed of only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the works are no longer required for the purpose described,
the works are disposed of to a municipality in the regional district,
in the case of works referred to in subsection (1) (a) or (b) that are used by the regional district to provide a water or sewer service,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: before the disposition occurs there is in effect an agreement under which the water or sewer service will continue for a period specified in the agreement, and
the intended disposition receives the assent of the electors, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of works not referred to in paragraph (c), the board has obtained the approval of the electors in relation to the proposed disposition.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (2) (c) (ii),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the notice under subsection (2) (c) (i), and
section 177 [disclosure of information relating to agreements] applies to that agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a limitation on section 176 (1) (e) [corporate powers — delegation], a board may not delegate the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the making of a bylaw;
a power or duty exercisable only by bylaw;
a power or duty to appoint, suspend or terminate a regional district officer;
a power or duty established by an enactment that the board hear an appeal or reconsider an action, decision or other matter;
a power or duty established by this or any other Act that the board give its approval or consent to, recommendations on, or acceptance of an action, decision or other matter;
the power to impose a remedial action requirement under Division 12 [Remedial Action Requirements] of Part 3 of the Community Charter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The authority under section 176 (1) (e) [corporate powers — delegation] does not include authority to delegate to a corporation.
Subject to section 193, a board may delegate a power, duty or function only by bylaw adopted by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the votes cast.
A board may, by bylaw adopted by a majority of votes cast, amend or repeal a bylaw referred to in subsection (1) to reduce or revoke the delegation.
This section applies to the delegation of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: board hearings that are required by law or authorized by an enactment, other than hearings referred to in section 191 (1) (d), and
board proceedings in which a person is entitled under this Act to make representations to the board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following rules apply in relation to a delegation referred to in subsection (1):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the delegation may be made specifically, by class of hearings or proceedings, or generally;
the delegation may only be made to one or more directors;
if a board decision is to be made following a delegated hearing or proceeding, the authority to make the decision may only be delegated to the directors to whom the matter is delegated;

if a board decision referred to in paragraph (c) is not delegated under that provision, the board must not make the decision until the applicable directors report to the board the views expressed at the hearing or proceeding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception to section 192 (1), a board may delegate the holding of a hearing by bylaw or resolution adopted by a majority of votes cast.

For certainty, if a delegation has been made under this section, the board may exercise its authority under this section to revoke that delegation or change the delegation to a different delegation in relation to a specific hearing or proceeding.
If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a board delegates a power to make a decision, and
in relation to that delegation, an enactment establishes a right to have a delegated decision reconsidered by the board,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the board must, by bylaw, establish procedures for such a reconsideration, including how a person may apply for the reconsideration.
In undertaking a reconsideration referred to in subsection (1), a board has the same authority as that conferred on the delegate.
If there is a right of reconsideration, the person making the decision must advise the person subject to the decision of this right.
A regional district may only

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: incorporate a corporation other than a society, or
acquire shares in a corporation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: with the approval of the inspector or as authorized by regulation.
An incorporation or acquisition under subsection (1) applies as an exception to the restriction under section 183 [investment of municipal funds] of the section 814 of this Act.
A board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must, by bylaw, establish officer positions in relation to the powers, duties and functions under sections 198 [corporate administration] and 199 [financial administration], with titles it considers appropriate,
may, by bylaw, establish other officer positions for its regional district, with titles it considers appropriate, and
may, by bylaw or resolution, assign powers, duties and functions to those officer positions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For certainty,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a board may assign to an officer position powers, duties and functions in addition to those required or permitted to be assigned by this Act or another enactment, and
the same person may be appointed to 2 or more officer positions.

bcl:section.bcl:text: One of the officer positions established under section 196 may be assigned the chief administrative responsibility, which includes the following powers, duties and functions:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: overall management of the administrative operations of the regional district;
ensuring that the policies and directions of the board are implemented;
advising and informing the board on the operation and affairs of the regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:text: One of the officer positions established under section 196 must be assigned the responsibility of corporate administration, which includes the following powers, duties and functions:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensuring that accurate minutes of the meetings of the board and board committees are prepared and that the minutes, bylaws and other records of the business of the board and board committees are maintained and kept safe;
ensuring that access is provided to records of the board and board committees, as required by law or authorized by the board;
certifying copies of bylaws and other documents, as required or requested;
administering oaths and taking affirmations, declarations and affidavits required to be taken under this or any other Act relating to regional districts;

accepting, on behalf of the board or regional district, notices and documents that are required or permitted to be given to, served on, filed with or otherwise provided to the board or regional district;
keeping the corporate seal, if any, and having it affixed to documents as required.

bcl:section.bcl:text: One of the officer positions established under section 196 must be assigned the responsibility of financial administration, which includes the following powers, duties and functions:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receiving all money paid to the regional district;
ensuring the keeping of all funds and securities of the regional district;
expending and disbursing money in the manner authorized by the board;
investing funds, until required, in authorized investments;
ensuring that accurate records and full accounts of the financial affairs of the regional district are prepared, maintained and kept safe;
exercising control and supervision over all other financial affairs of the regional district.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Regional District Officers and Employees Generally

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting section 176 [corporate powers], a board may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide for the appointment of officers and other employees for the regional district, and

subject to the Employment Standards Act, establish the terms and conditions of their employment, including terms and conditions respecting their remuneration, benefits, expenses, hours of work and manner of appointment, promotion, discipline and dismissal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the event of a conflict between terms and conditions of employment established by bylaw, resolution or policy and those established by contract of employment or collective agreement, the contract or agreement prevails.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Prohibition against interfering with regional
district officers and employees
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not interfere with, hinder or obstruct a regional district officer or employee in the exercise or performance of his or her powers, duties or functions.

Before taking on the duties of office, a person appointed to an officer position for a regional district must swear or affirm an oath of office in the form prescribed by regulation or established by bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to a contract of employment and subject to providing the officer with an opportunity to be heard, the appointment of a regional district officer may be terminated by the board as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of termination for cause, by immediate termination without any period of notice;
in any other case, by termination on reasonable notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A termination under subsection (1) (b) may only be made by the affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of all directors.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A board may, by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the votes cast, provide for the inclusion of its regional district in an employers' organization under the Labour Relations Code.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: There is to be a board of examiners for the purposes of this Division, composed of 3 members appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council on the recommendation of the minister, of whom

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one must be nominated by the Union of British Columbia Municipalities,
one must be nominated by the Local Government Management Association of British Columbia, and
one must be nominated by the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The members of the board hold office for a term of 3 years or until their successors are appointed.
If a vacancy occurs because of the death or resignation of a member, the member's successor must be nominated and appointed in the same manner as the member originally nominated and appointed.

The members of the board must not receive remuneration for their services, but must be paid by the minister the amount of their travelling and other personal expenses necessarily incurred by them in the discharge of their official duties.
A member of the board may be nominated and reappointed for further terms.
The board may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish qualifications and standards for municipal, regional district or improvement district employment according to office and grades;
grant certificates according to grades and skill to persons possessing the qualifications and meeting the standards;
set and hold examinations for, or pass on the credentials of, a person who is a candidate for a certificate;
cancel a certificate on proof of dishonesty or gross negligence on the part of the holder.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The powers and duties of the board must be exercised and performed in accordance with any applicable regulations made by the board.
The records of the board and the administrative duties in connection with them are the responsibility of the inspector.

bcl:section.bcl:text: With the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council on the recommendation of the minister, the board may make regulations respecting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the exercise and performance of its powers and duties,
examinations and certificates, and
any other matter within the jurisdiction of the board.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Division applies to the City of Vancouver.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Regional District Boards and Their Proceedings

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Oath of office for board members

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person elected or appointed to office on a board must make an oath or solemn affirmation of office within the following applicable time limit:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an electoral area director elected by acclamation, within 50 days after the date set for general voting day had an election by voting been required;
in the case of an electoral area director elected by voting, within 45 days after the declaration of the results of the election;
in the case of a person appointed to an electoral area under section 78 [appointment if an insufficient number of candidates are elected], within 45 days after the effective date of the appointment;
in the case of a person appointed as municipal director, within 45 days after the effective date of the appointment;

in the case of a person appointed as an alternate director, within 45 days after the effective date of the appointment or the first board meeting or board committee meeting at which the person acts in that capacity, whichever is latest.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person required to make an oath or solemn affirmation of office under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must make the oath or solemn affirmation before a judge of the Court of Appeal, Supreme Court or Provincial Court, a justice of the peace, a commissioner for taking affidavits for British Columbia, the regional district corporate officer or the chief election officer, and
must obtain the completed oath or solemn affirmation, or a certificate of it, from the person administering the oath or affirmation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person takes office on a board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the time the term of office begins if, at this time, the person produces or has produced the completed oath or solemn affirmation of office, or the certificate of it, to the regional district corporate officer, or
at any later time that the person produces the completed oath or solemn affirmation of office, or the certificate of it, to that officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person, other than a person appointed as an alternate director, does not make the required oath or solemn affirmation of office within the time limit established by subsection (1), the person is disqualified from holding office

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a local government,
on the council of the City of Vancouver or on the Park Board established under section 485 of the Vancouver Charter, or
as a trustee under the Islands Trust Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: until the next general local election.
A board may, by bylaw, establish an oath or solemn affirmation of office for the purposes of this section, which may be different for different types of office.
If no bylaw under subsection (5) applies, the oath or solemn affirmation of office to be made is that prescribed by regulation.
A person taking office on a board may also make an oath of allegiance.

Once a board member takes office, the member is entitled to hold that office through its term and to vote and otherwise act in the office during that time unless the member resigns or becomes disqualified.
A board member may resign from office only by delivering a written resignation to the regional district corporate officer.
A resignation becomes effective when it is received by the corporate officer, even if a later date is set out in the resignation, and may not be revoked after the time it is received.

The corporate officer must notify the board of a resignation at the next meeting of the board after the resignation is received or, if there are no other board members, the corporate officer must notify the minister.
The chair is the head and chief executive officer of the regional district.
In addition to the chair's powers and duties as a board member, the chair has the following duties:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to see that the law is carried out for the improvement and good government of the regional district;

to communicate information to the board and to recommend bylaws, resolutions and measures that, in the chair's opinion, may assist the peace, order and good government of the regional district in relation to the powers conferred on the board by an enactment;
to inspect and direct the conduct of officers and employees, to direct the management of regional district business and affairs and, if considered necessary, to suspend an officer or employee;
so far as the chair's power extends, to see that negligence, carelessness and violation of duty by an officer or employee is prosecuted and punished.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Every suspension of an officer or employee by the chair under this section must be reported to the board at the next meeting of the board, and the board may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: reinstate the officer or employee,
confirm the suspension,
confirm and extend the suspension, or
dismiss the officer or employee.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Chair may require board reconsideration of a matter

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair of a regional district has the same authority as a mayor under section 131 [mayor may require council reconsideration of a matter] of the Community Charter.

In exercising the power under subsection (1), the chair may return the matter for reconsideration at the meeting of the board following the original vote, whether or not this is within the 30 day period referred to in section 131 (2) of the Community Charter.
A board must meet

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regularly in accordance with its bylaw under section 794 [procedure, bylaws and enforcement], and
as it decides and as provided in this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A special board meeting is a board meeting other than a statutory, regular or adjourned meeting.
If permitted under subsection (5), a board meeting or a board committee meeting may be conducted by means of electronic or other communications facilities.
Members of the board who are participating under this section in a meeting conducted in accordance with subsection (3) are deemed to be present at the meeting.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations permitting meetings under subsection (3) and prescribing conditions, limits and requirements respecting such meetings.
Subject to subsection (8), if a board member is absent from board meetings for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a period of 60 consecutive days, or
4 consecutive regularly scheduled board meetings,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: whichever is the longer time period, the board member is disqualified from holding office in accordance with subsection (7).
Disqualification under subsection (6) is disqualification from holding office

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a local government,
on the council of the City of Vancouver or on the Park Board established under section 485 of the Vancouver Charter, or
as a trustee under the Islands Trust Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: until the next general local election.
The disqualification under subsection (6) does not apply if the absence is because of illness or injury or is with the leave of the board.
The chair, if present, must preside at board meetings.
Section 132 [authority of presiding member] of the section 791 [voting on resolutions and bylaws] of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Minutes of board meetings must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: legibly recorded,
certified as correct by the designated regional district officer, and
signed by the chair or other member presiding at the meeting or at the next meeting at which they are adopted.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Minutes of a board committee meeting must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: legibly recorded, and
signed by the chair or member presiding at the meeting.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Meetings and hearings outside regional district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If authorized under subsection (2), the following meetings, hearings and other proceedings may be held, and all powers, duties and functions may be exercised in relation to those proceedings, outside the boundaries of the regional district:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: board meetings;
board committee meetings;
other public meetings conducted by or on behalf of the board or a board committee;
board hearings that are required by law or authorized by an enactment;
board proceedings in which a person is entitled under this Act to make representations to the board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may do either or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by bylaw, provide that meetings, hearings or other proceedings referred to in subsection (1) may be held outside the boundaries of the regional district;
by resolution in a specific case, allow a meeting, hearing or other proceeding to be held outside the boundaries of the regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division, bylaw includes an order or resolution.
A bylaw, contract or other proceeding of a council must not be set aside or declared invalid if the only reason for doing so is that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person sitting or voting as a council member was not qualified to be a council member at or before the time of the proceeding,
a council member renounced claim to office on council,
an election for council was set aside or declared invalid after the proceeding, or
an election of a council member was set aside or declared invalid after the proceeding.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application to court to set aside bylaw

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application of an elector of a municipality, or of a person interested in a bylaw of the council, the Supreme Court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set aside all or part of the bylaw for illegality, and
award costs for or against the municipality according to the result of the application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply to a security issuing bylaw providing for the issue of debenture or other evidence of indebtedness to the Municipal Finance Authority of British Columbia.
Notice of an application to set aside a bylaw, stating the grounds of the application, must be served on the municipality as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the bylaw is a bylaw requiring the assent of the electors that the council purported to adopt without assent, the notice may be served more than one month after the adoption of the bylaw, but must be served at least 10 days before the hearing;
subject to subsection (3.1), in any other case, the notice must be served at least 10 days before the hearing and not more than one month after the adoption of the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Notice of an application to set aside a security issuing bylaw of a regional district, stating the grounds of the application, must be served on the regional district at least 5 days before the hearing and not more than 10 days after the adoption of the bylaw.
Except for a bylaw referred to in subsection (3) (b), an order under this section relating to a bylaw must not be made unless the application is heard within 2 months after the adoption of the bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Assessment or rate stands unless bylaw set aside
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person assessed under or subject to a rate under a bylaw by which an assessment is made or a rate is imposed is not entitled to plead a defect in the bylaw as a defence to a claim for payment of that rate except by application to set aside the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application for a declaratory order relating to a bylaw must not be entertained more than one month after the adoption of the bylaw, if the application is brought on the ground of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: irregularity in the method of enactment, or
irregularity in the form of a bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except for a bylaw referred to in section 262 (3) (b), a declaratory order relating to a bylaw must not be made unless the application is heard within 2 months after the adoption of the bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Right of action on illegal bylaw

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all or part of a bylaw is illegal, and
anything has been done under the bylaw that, because of the illegality, gives a person a right of action,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the action must not be brought until the end of the time period under subsection (2).
An action referred to in subsection (1) must not be brought until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one month after all or part of the bylaw has been set aside, and
one month's notice has been given to the municipality.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An action referred to in subsection (1) must be brought against the municipality only, and not against a person acting under the bylaw.
A board may make bylaws for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the purposes of enforcing the bylaws of the regional district by fine, by imprisonment or both, and
imposing fines, penalties and costs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 261 [payment of fines and other penalties] of the Community Charter applies to regional districts.
Division 3 [Ticketing for Bylaw Offences] of Part 8 of the Community Charter applies to regional districts.
For the purpose of subsection (1), a reference in section 265 [penalties in relation to ticket offences] of the section 266 (1) of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of the Local Government Bylaw Notice Enforcement Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the regulations under the Local Government Bylaw Notice Enforcement Act, a regional district bylaw may be enforced by bylaw notice under and in accordance with that Act.

If a matter is prescribed for the purpose of section 4 (2) of the Local Government Bylaw Notice Enforcement Act, a board that adopts or has adopted a bylaw in relation to the matter may only enforce the bylaw by bylaw notice under that Act.

If a bylaw establishes a regulation or requirement to be observed in a regional district, a person who contravenes the regulation or requirement commits an offence that is punishable in the same manner as if the bylaw had expressly forbidden persons from doing or refraining from doing the act.

In a prosecution for an offence against a regional district bylaw, the justice or court may impose all or part of the penalty or punishment authorized by the bylaw, this Act or the Offence Act, together with the costs of prosecution.

If a penalty, or part of a penalty, and all costs imposed are not paid promptly, the justice or court may, by order, authorize all or part of the penalty and costs to be levied by distress and sale of the offender's goods and chattels.

If there is no distress out of which the penalty and costs or part of the penalty and all of the costs can be levied, the justice or court may commit the offender to imprisonment for the term, or part of the term, specified in the bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional sentencing powers in relation to Offence Act prosecutions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person is convicted of an offence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under subsection (3), or
against a regional district bylaw in a prosecution commenced by an information in Form 2 under the Offence Act,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: in addition to the penalty established in accordance with section 266, the court may, having regard to the nature of the offence and the circumstances surrounding its commission, make an order

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prohibiting the person from doing any act or engaging in any activity that may, in the court's opinion, result in the continuation or repetition of the offence, and
directing the person to take any action the court considers appropriate to remedy the harm that resulted from the commission of the offence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order under subsection (1) must specify the duration of the order, which may not exceed one year.

A person who fails to comply with an order under subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $10 000 or to imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or both.
For the purposes of section 43 (3) of the subsection (3) is deemed to be a fine imposed for the contravention of a bylaw of the regional district.

If a person is convicted of an offence referred to in subsection (1) (a) or (b), on application by the regional district or another person for compensation, the court must give consideration to the application and, in addition to any penalty imposed, may order the convicted person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to pay to the regional district or to the other person compensation, in an amount that is not more than the monetary limit specified under the Small Claims Act, for any damage or loss sustained by the regional district or other person because of the commission of the offence, and

in accordance with the schedule of costs prescribed under section 132 (2) (h) of the Offence Act, to pay to the regional district the costs incurred by the regional district in investigating and prosecuting the person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the case of a dispute, the amount of compensation payable under subsection (5) (a) must be proven on a balance of probabilities by the regional district or the other person.
An order under subsection (5) may be enforced as a judgment of the court for the recovery of a debt in the amount stated against the person named.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Inspections to determine whether bylaws are being followed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a board has authority to regulate, prohibit and impose requirements in relation to a matter, the board may, by bylaw, authorize officers, employees and agents of the regional district to enter, at all reasonable times, on any property to inspect and determine whether all regulations, prohibitions and requirements are being met.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regional district action at defaulter's expense

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The authority of a board under this or another Act to require that something be done includes the authority to direct that, if a person subject to the requirement fails to take the required action, the regional district may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fulfill the requirement at the expense of the person, and
recover the costs incurred from that person as a debt.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: subsection (1) that is incurred for work done or services provided in relation to land or improvements.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Division 4 [Enforcement by Civil Proceedings] of Part 8 of the Community Charter applies to regional districts.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Recovery of utility rates by legal remedy of distress

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to other remedies in this Act for the collection and recovery of gas, electrical energy or water rates authorized by this Act, the payment of those rates may be enforced by distress and sale of the goods and chattels of the person owing the rates wherever those chattels are found in the regional district.
The costs chargeable in relation to distress under this section are those payable under the Rent Distress Act, unless another scale is provided under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, regulate and alter the scale of costs payable in cases of distress under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limitation period for actions against municipality
bcl:section.bcl:text: All actions against a municipality for the unlawful doing of anything that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is purported to have been done by the municipality under the powers conferred by an Act, and
might have been lawfully done by the municipality if acting in the manner established by law,

bcl:section.bcl:text: must be commenced within 6 months after the cause of action first arose, or within a further period designated by the council in a particular case, but not afterwards.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Immunity unless notice given to municipality after damage

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A municipality is in no case liable for damages unless notice in writing, setting out the time, place and manner in which the damage has been sustained, is delivered to the municipality within 2 months from the date on which the damage was sustained.
In case of the death of a person injured, the failure to give notice required by this section is not a bar to the maintenance of the action.
Failure to give the notice or its insufficiency is not a bar to the maintenance of an action if the court before whom it is tried, or, in case of appeal, the Court of Appeal, believes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there was reasonable excuse, and
the defendant has not been prejudiced in its defence by the failure or insufficiency.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Immunity for individual municipal public officers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, municipal public officer means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a member of a council;
a director of a regional board;
a trustee of an improvement district;
a member of a commission established under section 176 (1) (g) [corporate powers] of this Act or section 143 [municipal commissions] of the Community Charter;
a member of a library board under the Library Act;
a commissioner for a local community commission under section 838;
a member of any greater board or of any board that provides similar services and is incorporated by letters patent;
a member of an advisory planning commission under section 898;
a member of a board of variance under section 899;
a member of the Okanagan-Kootenay Sterile Insect Release Board or an officer or employee of that board;
a member of the Okanagan Basin Water Board;
a trustee of a body of the Islands Trust under the Islands Trust Act;
an officer or employee of a municipality, regional district, improvement district, library board under the Islands Trust Act or the Okanagan Basin Water Board;
an election official and a regional voting officer under section 167;
a volunteer firefighter or a special constable;

a volunteer who participates in the delivery of services by a municipality, regional district or a body referred to in (k) under the supervision of an officer or employee of the municipality, regional district or any of those bodies;
a member of a board of trustees established or appointed by a municipality under section 37 of the Cremation, Interment and Funeral Services Act;

a member of a municipal committee, of a board committee, or of a committee under section 740.1 [appointment of select and standing committees] who is not also a member of the council, board or board of trustees, as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: No action for damages lies or may be instituted against a municipal public officer or former municipal public officer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for anything said or done or omitted to be said or done by that person in the performance or intended performance of the person's duty or the exercise of the person's power, or
for any alleged neglect or default in the performance or intended performance of that person's duty or exercise of that person's power.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) does not provide a defence if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the municipal public officer has, in relation to the conduct that is the subject matter of the action, been guilty of dishonesty, gross negligence or malicious or wilful misconduct, or
the cause of action is libel or slander.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) does not absolve any of the corporations or bodies referred to in subsection (1) (a) to (k) from vicarious liability arising out of a tort committed by any of the individuals referred to in subsection (1) for which the corporation or body would have been liable had this section not been in force.

bcl:section.bcl:text: It is a good defence to any action brought against the local government financial officer for unlawful expenditure of local government funds if it is proved that the individual gave a written and signed warning to the council or board that, in his or her opinion, the expenditure would be unlawful.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: indemnification means the payment of amounts required or incurred

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to defend an action or prosecution brought against a person in connection with the exercise or intended exercise of the person's powers or the performance or intended performance of the person's duties or functions,
to satisfy a judgment, award or penalty imposed in an action or prosecution referred to in paragraph (a), or
in relation to an inquiry under the Public Inquiry Act, or to another proceeding, that involves the administration of the municipality or the conduct of municipal business;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: municipal official means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a current or former council member,
a current or former municipal officer or employee, or

a person who is or was a person referred to in section 287 (1) [immunity for individual municipal public officers], but only in relation to the exercise of powers or the performance of duties or functions for or on behalf of a municipality.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A council may, do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by bylaw, provide for the indemnification of municipal officials in accordance with the bylaw;
by resolution in a specific case, indemnify a municipal official.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a limit on indemnification under subsection (2), a council must not pay a fine that is imposed as a result of a municipal official's conviction for an offence that is not a strict or absolute liability offence.
Sections 100 [disclosure of conflict] and 101 [restrictions on participation if in conflict] of the subsection (2).
Subject to subsection (6), a council may not seek indemnity against a municipal official in respect of any conduct of the person that results in a claim for damages against the municipality.
The restriction under subsection (5) does not apply if the court makes a finding in the action that the person has been guilty of dishonesty, gross negligence or malicious or willful misconduct.

This section applies to a greater board, the trust council under the section 287 (1) [immunity for individual municipal public officers], but only in relation to the exercise of powers or the performance of duties or functions for or on behalf of that corporation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A municipality, council, regional district, board or improvement district, or a greater board, is not liable in any action based on nuisance or on the rule in the Rylands v. Fletcher case if the damages arise, directly or indirectly, out of the breakdown or malfunction of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a sewer system,
a water or drainage facility or system, or
a dike or a road.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Immunity in relation to failure to enforce building bylaws
bcl:section.bcl:text: A municipality or a member of its council, a regional district or a member of its board, or an officer or employee of a municipality or regional district, is not liable for any damages or other loss, including economic loss, sustained by any person, or to the property of any person, as a result of neglect or failure, for any reason, to enforce, by the institution of a civil proceeding or a prosecution,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a bylaw under Part 21,
a bylaw under section 8 (3) (l) [fundamental powers — buildings and other structures] of the Community Charter, or
a bylaw under Division 8 [Building Regulation] of Part 3 of the Community Charter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limitation on municipal liability regarding building plan approval

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a municipality issues a building permit for a development that does not comply with the Provincial building regulations or another applicable enactment respecting safety, the municipality must not be held liable, directly or vicariously, for any damage, loss or expense caused or contributed to by an error, omission or other neglect in relation to its approval of the plans submitted with the application for the building permit if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person representing himself or herself as a professional engineer or architect registered as such under Provincial legislation certified, as or on behalf of the applicant for the permit, that the plans or the aspects of the plans to which the non-compliance relates complied with the then current Provincial building regulations or other applicable enactment to which the non-compliance relates, and
the municipality, in issuing the building permit, indicated in writing to the applicant for the permit that it relied on the certification referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply if a municipality knew that the person making the certification referred to in that subsection was not, at the time of certification, registered as a professional engineer or architect under Provincial legislation.

If a municipality makes an indication in accordance with subsection (1) (b), the municipality must reduce the fee for the building permit to reflect the costs of the work that would otherwise be done by a building inspector to determine whether the plans or the aspects of the plans that were certified to comply do in fact comply with the Provincial building regulations and other applicable enactments respecting safety.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Proceedings against municipality in relation to actions of others

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to a proceeding brought against a municipality to recover damages sustained by reason of an obstruction, excavation, cellar or opening in or adjoining a street, lane, square, public highway or bridge placed, made, left or maintained by a person other than an employee or agent of the municipality.

The municipality has a remedy over against the person referred to in subsection (1), and may enforce payment accordingly of any damages and costs that the plaintiff may recover against the municipality.
The municipality is only entitled to the remedy over if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person referred to in subsection (1) is made a party to the proceeding, and

it is established as against that person that the damages were sustained because of an obstruction, excavation, cellar or opening placed, made, left or maintained by the person added as a defendant or third party.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person referred to in subsection (1) may defend the proceeding against the plaintiff's claim and that of the municipality.
The court may order costs to be paid by or to any party or on any claim set up as in other cases.
A writ of execution against a municipality may be endorsed with a direction to the sheriff to levy its amount by rate, and the proceedings on it are to be as provided in this Division.
A writ of execution against a municipality must not be issued without leave of the Supreme Court, which may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: permit its issue at a time and on conditions the court considers proper, or

refuse to permit it to be issued or suspend action under it on terms and conditions the court thinks proper or expedient, having regard to the reputed insolvency of the municipality and the security afforded to the person entitled to the judgment by the registration of the judgment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On being satisfied by affidavit by a competent person on behalf of the municipality that the municipality intends to appeal with due diligence from the judgment, the court may refuse to permit a writ of execution for costs to be issued unless security is given to the satisfaction of the court by the person to whom the costs are payable for their repayment to the municipality in the event the judgment is reversed or varied on appeal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Copy of writ to be left with municipal officer
bcl:section.bcl:text: The sheriff must deliver to the municipal corporate officer, or leave at the office or dwelling house of that officer,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the writ of execution and endorsement, and

a statement in writing of the sheriff's fees, and of the amount required to satisfy the execution, including in the amount the interest calculated to a day as near as is convenient to the date of the delivery.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax to be imposed if amount not paid

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the amount, with interest on it from the day mentioned in the statement under section 294, is not paid to the sheriff within one month after service under that section, the sheriff must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: examine the assessment rolls of the municipality, and
establish a rate sufficient to cover the amount due on the execution, with an addition to it that the sheriff believes sufficient to cover the interest and the sheriff's own fees.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A rate under subsection (1) must be established in the same manner as a rate under section 197 (1) (a) [municipal property value taxes] of the Community Charter.
After establishing the rate, the sheriff must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: issue a direction to the collector of the municipality,
attach to the direction either the roll of the rate or particulars of it, and
after

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: stating the writ,
stating that the municipality had neglected to satisfy it, and
referring to the roll or the particulars,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: direct the collector to levy the rate promptly.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If at the time of levying a rate under a direction of the sheriff the tax demand notices for that year have not been issued, the collector must add a column on the notices, headed "Execution Rate in A.B. v. the Corporation", and must insert in it the amount required to be levied under the direction.
If subsection (1) does not apply, the collector must proceed to issue separate tax demand notices for the execution rate.
The collector must with all due diligence return to the sheriff the direction with the amount levied.
After satisfying the execution and all fees on it, the sheriff must pay any surplus within 10 days after receiving it to the municipal financial officer, for the general purposes of the municipality.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Officers of municipality as officers of court

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For all purposes connected with carrying into effect, or permitting or assisting the sheriff to carry into effect, the provisions of this Act for executions, the municipal corporate officer, the municipal financial officer and the collector are deemed to be officers of the court in which the writ was issued.
