As officers of the court, the officials referred to in subsection (1) are amenable to the court, and may be proceeded against by attachment, or otherwise, to compel them to perform their duties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Certain municipal property exempt from seizure
bcl:section.bcl:text: The corporate seal, tools, machinery, equipment and records, office furniture, fixtures and fittings of a municipality are exempt from forced seizure or sale by any process of law.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, local authority means a municipality, a regional district or an improvement district.
A local authority may, with one or more other local authorities,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enter into a scheme of self insurance protection under section 187 of the Insurance (Captive Company) Act, or
with the consent of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions, enter into a joint scheme of self insurance protection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For a regional district, a scheme under subsection (2) may have a single deductible for any number of services.

The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing the modifications considered necessary or advisable for applying this Part for the purposes of paragraphs 133, 135 and 138 of the Nisg̱a'a Government Chapter of the Nisg̱a'a Final Agreement.
The authority to make regulations in subsection (2) applies to provisions of the Community Charter enacted in substitution for or replacement of provisions of this Part.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How Part applies to treaty first nations
bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing modifications considered necessary or advisable for applying this Part for the purposes of a final agreement that provides the treaty first nation or its government with some or all of the same protections, immunities, limitations in respect of liability, remedies over and rights provided to a municipality and its council and public officers under this Part.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Reservation and Dedication of Regional District Property

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Power to reserve and dedicate regional district land for public purpose
bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 30 [reservation and dedication of municipal property] of the Community Charter applies to regional districts.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Control of Crown land parks dedicated by subdivision

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If land outside a municipality is dedicated to the public for the purpose of a park or a public square by a subdivision plan deposited in the land title office, by which title is vested in the Crown, the regional district in which it is located is entitled to possession and control of the land for that purpose.

If land referred to in subsection (1) was dedicated as referred to in that subsection before this Act came into force, the regional district is deemed to have had possession and control of it for that purpose from the date it was dedicated, and continues to have that possession and control.
Section 27 [exchange or other disposal of park land] of the Community Charter applies to land

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: referred to in section 303 [Crown land parks dedicated by subdivision],
vested in a regional district under section 936 (5) (a) [park land in place of development cost charges], or
vested in a regional district under section 941 (14) [park land in relation to subdivision].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All land taken in exchange under this section is dedicated for the purpose of a park or public square and the title to it vests

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of land referred to in subsection (1) (a), in the Crown with right of possession and control in the regional district, and
in the case of land referred to in subsection (1) (b) or (c), in the regional district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A transfer under this section of land referred to in subsection (1) (a) has effect as a Crown grant.

Despite this Act or any law, a council may, by bylaw adopted with the assent of the electors, set aside as a municipal forest reserve land owned by the municipality that the council believes is suitable for reforestation purposes.

A council may, by bylaw adopted by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of its members but without the assent of the electors, set aside and include within a municipal forest reserve established under this section any land owned or held by the municipality.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Sale or lease of municipal forest reserve

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a limitation on section 8 (1) [natural person powers] of the Community Charter, a council must not sell or lease land set aside as a municipal forest reserve except as provided in this Division.
A council may, by bylaw adopted with the approval of the electors, withdraw land from a municipal forest reserve.
In addition to the information required by section 86 (2) [alternative approval process — notice] of the subsection (2) of this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describe the purpose for which the council intends to withdraw the land from the municipal forest reserve, and
in the case of a sale of the land, state the price that is to be received.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A council may, by bylaw adopted with the assent of the electors, lease for a term not longer than 99 years, all or part of a municipal forest reserve, subject to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the agreement must make adequate provision for the protection of the municipal forest reserve on a sustained yield basis and for protection from fire;
the annual rental agreed on must be based on area and current values of the annual cutting;
the lessee must covenant to pay normal municipal taxes on the land, and on any structure erected or placed on the land either temporarily or permanently;
the agreement must be embodied in the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting section 8 (1) [natural person powers] of the Community Charter, a council may cut, sell, remove or otherwise dispose of any timber or other products from a municipal forest reserve.
An agreement between a municipality and a person for the cutting and removal of timber from a municipal forest reserve must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide that only selected trees may be cut,
provide for the protection of young growth and other trees and timber, and
provide for protection from fire.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of exercising or performing its powers, duties and functions, a regional district may expropriate real property or works, or an interest in them, in accordance with the Expropriation Act.
Without limiting subsection (1), in addition to the rights conferred on licensees under sections 27 and 28 of the Water Act, a regional district may expropriate

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a licence authorizing the diversion of water from a stream, as defined in the Water Act, that is suitable for a water supply for the regional district, and
any work constructed or used under the authority of the licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The powers under (1.1) also apply to property outside the regional district for the purposes of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a service provided by the regional district to an area outside the regional district, or
establishing and managing quarries, sand pits or gravel pits to acquire material for regional district works.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting section 309 [expropriation power], a regional district may, for the purposes of one or more of its services, enter on, break up, alter, take or enter into possession of and use real property.

If a regional district exercises an authority to provide a service outside the regional district, the power under subsection (1) applies to property outside the regional district in relation to that service.

The authority under this section may be exercised without the consent of the owner of the property, subject to the restrictions established by section 16 [authority to enter on or into property] of the section 314.1 [authority to enter on or into property] of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Entry on land to mitigate damage

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a board considers that real property may be injuriously affected by the exercise of a board power, the regional district may enter on real property and undertake works of construction, maintenance or repair in mitigation of injury done or anticipated, or in reduction of compensation.

The authority under this section may be exercised without the consent of the owner of the property, subject to the restrictions established by section 16 [authority to enter on or into property] of the section 314.1 [authority to enter on or into property] of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Compensation for expropriation and other actions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless expressly provided otherwise, if a regional district expropriates real property or works under this or any other enactment, compensation is payable to the owners, occupiers or other persons interested in the property for any damages necessarily resulting from the exercise of those powers beyond any benefit that the person claiming the compensation may derive from the work resulting from the expropriation.
If a regional district

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exercises a power to enter on, break up, alter, take or enter into possession of and use any property, or injuriously affects property by the exercise of any of its powers, and
exercises a power referred to in paragraph (a) that does not constitute an expropriation within the meaning of the Expropriation Act,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: compensation is payable for any loss or damages caused by the exercise of the power.
For the purposes of subsection (2), compensation must be paid as soon as practicable in an amount set

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by agreement between the person claiming the compensation and the regional district, or
if no agreement is reached, by the Supreme Court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Power to accept property on trust

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting section 176 [corporate powers], a board may accept any property devised, bequeathed, conveyed or otherwise transferred to the regional district, subject to any trusts on which the property is transferred.
If the sale of property is necessary to carry out the terms of a trust under which it was transferred, a board may sell the property despite any limitations or restrictions in this Act.

All money held by a regional district subject to a trust, until required for the purposes of the trust, must be invested in accordance with section 183 [investment of municipal funds] of the section 814 (3) of this Act.

If, in the opinion of a board, the terms or trusts imposed by a donor, settlor, transferor or will-maker are no longer in the best interests of the regional district, the board may apply to the Supreme Court for an order under subsection (5).

On an application under subsection (4), the Supreme Court may vary, by order, the terms or trusts that the court considers will better further both the intent of the donor, settlor, transferor or will-maker and the best interests of the regional district.
Section 87 [discharge of trustee's duty] of the subsection (5).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Authority to enter on or into property

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 16 (1) to (5) [authority to enter on or into property] of the section 268 [inspections to determine whether bylaws are being followed] of this Act.

Without limiting the matters to which this section applies, a regional district may enter on property for the purpose of taking action authorized under section 269 [regional district action at defaulter's expense].
If a municipal bylaw establishes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: taxes or fees for the supply of water for irrigation, or
other terms on which the service may be supplied or used,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the bylaw overrides the terms of any agreement respecting the carriage or supply of water for irrigation entered into by a company or other person from whom the municipality has acquired a water licence or works.

An extension to a system for supplying water for irrigation must not be made for the purpose of supplying water to other land if the extension will prejudicially affect the prior rights of any parties to the use of the water intended to be conveyed and distributed by the extension.
A district municipality may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: collect the water from any highway by means of drains or ditches, and
convey the water to, and discharge the water in, the most convenient natural waterway or watercourse.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A municipality proposing to construct drains or ditches authorized by subsection (3) in a newspaper once a week for 4 consecutive weeks.
The notice under subsection (2) must state that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the municipality intends to undertake the works,
plans and specifications of the works may be inspected at the municipal hall, and

all claims for damages or compensation arising out of the construction, maintenance, operation or use of the works must be filed with the municipality within one month from the date of the fourth publication of the notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: No person has a claim for damages or compensation arising out of or by reason of the construction, maintenance, operation or use of the drains or ditches unless the person has filed a claim referred to in subsection (3) (c) within the time period established by that subsection.
If the municipality proceeds with the works or a portion of them, every claim must be determined in accordance with Division 4 [Expropriation and Compensation] of Part 3 of the Community Charter.

If the construction of the drains or ditches is not started within one year from the date of the fourth publication of the notice under subsection (2), the construction must not proceed unless new notice is given in accordance with that subsection.

No action arising out of, by reason of or in respect of the construction, maintenance, operation or use of a drain or ditch authorized by this section, whenever the drain or ditch is or was constructed, may be brought or maintained in a court against a district municipality.
This section does not restrict the powers of the municipality under this Act or another enactment and, in the case of a conflict, this section prevails.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Further powers in relation to assets
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may confer on a local government further powers to manage and dispose of assets, including taxation revenue, that the minister considers necessary or advisable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite this Act or the Community Charter.
The exemption provided by section 15 (1) (l) of the Community Charter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Taxation of certain utility company property

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: utility company means an electric light, electric power, telephone, water, gas or closed circuit television company;
specified improvement means an improvement of a utility company that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a pole line, cable, tower, pole, wire, transformer, equipment, machinery, exchange equipment, main, pipe line or structure, other than a building,
erected or placed in, on or affixed to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: land in a municipality, or
a building, fixture or structure in or on land in a municipality, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: used solely in the municipality or a group of adjoining municipalities by the company for local generation, transmission, distribution, manufacture or transportation of electricity, telephonic communication, water, gas or closed circuit television.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A utility company that is carrying on business in a municipality in which it has specified improvements must be taxed annually by the municipality at the rate of 1% as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a telephone or closed circuit television company, on the gross rentals received in the second preceding year from its subscribers for telephone or television service located in the municipality, including telephone interexchange tolls for calls between exchanges in the municipality;

for any other utility company, on the amount received in the second preceding year by the company for electric light, electric power, water or gas consumed in the municipality, other than amounts received for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: light, power or water supplied for resale,
gas supplied for the operation of motor vehicles fueled by natural gas, or
gas supplied to any gas utility company, other than a government corporation as defined in the Financial Administration Act or a subsidiary of a government corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Tax under subsection (2) is subject to the same remedies and penalties as taxes under Part 7 [Municipal Revenue] of the Community Charter.
A utility company liable to tax under subsection (2) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by October 31 in each year, for the purpose of determining the tax payable in the next year, file with the collector a return of the revenue referred to in that subsection that was received in the preceding year, and
pay the tax imposed under subsection (2) in accordance with Division 10 [Property Tax Due Dates and Tax Notices] of Part 7 of the Community Charter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception to (4), in the case of a company to which this section applies for the first time in the municipality,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the company must pay the tax imposed under subsection (2) in the second year of its operation on the basis of revenue earned in the first year, and
the report of revenue earned in the first year must be filed before May 8 of the second year of operation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Tax imposed on a utility company under subsection (2) is in place of tax that might otherwise be imposed on the specified improvements under section 197 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes] of the Community Charter.

For certainty, all land and improvements of a utility company in a municipality, other than specified improvements, are subject to tax under section 197 [annual property tax bylaw] of the Community Charter.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Regional District Fees, Charges and Interest

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, impose a fee or charge payable in respect of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all or part of a service of the regional district, or
the use of regional district property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), a bylaw under this section may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the bylaw is in relation to an authority to provide a service or regulate outside the regional district, apply outside the regional district;
base the fee or charge on any factor specified in the bylaw, including by establishing different rates or levels of fees in relation to different factors;
establish different classes of persons, property, businesses and activities and different fees or charges for different classes;
establish terms and conditions for payment, including discounts, interest and penalties;
provide for the reduction, waiving or refund of a fee or charge if, as specified in the bylaw, a person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has already paid towards the costs to which the fee or charge relates,
does not require the service to which the fee or charge relates,
no longer undertakes the activity or thing for which a licence, permit or approval was required, or
has prepaid towards the costs of the service to which the fee or charge relates and use of the service by the person is discontinued;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish fees for obtaining copies of records that are available for public inspection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception, a board may not establish a fee or charge under this section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in relation to Part 3 [Elections] or 4 [Assent Voting], or
in relation to any other matter for which another provision of this Act specifically authorizes the imposition of a fee or charge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regional district must make available to the public, on request, a report respecting how a fee or charge imposed under this section was determined.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A regional district may, by bylaw, establish the manner in which interest is calculated if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this or another Act provides a requirement or authority to apply interest to an amount owed to, or owing by, the regional district, and
the manner in which interest is calculated is not otherwise provided for.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special fees and charges that are to be collected as taxes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regional district fees or charges imposed under this Act for work done or services provided to land or improvements;
fees imposed under section 726 (1) (b) [fire and security alarms systems];

amounts that a regional district is entitled to recover for work done or services provided to land or improvements under any provision of this Act that authorizes the regional district to recover amounts in the event of default by a person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an amount referred to in subsection (1) is due and payable by December 31 and is unpaid on that date,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount is deemed to be taxes in arrear,
the regional district financial officer must promptly, after December 31, forward a statement showing the amount of the fee or charge

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to the Surveyor of Taxes in the case of real property that is not in a municipality, or
to the applicable municipal collector in other cases, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Surveyor of Taxes or collector must add the amount of the fee or charge to the taxes payable on the property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an amount is added to taxes under subsection (2) (c),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount is deemed to be a Provincial or municipal tax, as applicable, and must be dealt with in the same manner as taxes against the property would be under the Community Charter, and
when it is collected, the Minister of Finance or collecting municipality must pay the amount to the regional district to which it is owed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an amount is added under subsection (2) (c) and is not paid at the time the property is sold by tax sale,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the upset price is obtained at the time of the tax sale, the minister or municipality referred to in subsection (3) must pay out of the proceeds of the sale the amount due under this section to the regional district to which it is owed, or
if the upset price is not obtained and subsequently the property is sold, the proceeds of the sale must be applied according to the respective interests in the upset price.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite (4), the regional district to which the amount is owed may bring action in a court of competent jurisdiction to recover that amount.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special fees and charges that are liens against property

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to amounts that are referred to in section 363.2 [special fees and charges that are to be collected as taxes].
An amount referred to in subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is a charge or lien on the land and its improvements in respect of which the charge is imposed, the work done or services provided,
has priority over any claim, lien, privilege or encumbrance of any person except the Crown, and
does not require registration to preserve it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An owner of land or real property aggrieved by the creation of a charge or lien under this section may, on 10 days' written notice to the regional district, apply to the Supreme Court for an order that the charge be removed or that the amount for which it was imposed be varied.

On an application under subsection (3), if the court is satisfied that any of the amount for which the charge or lien was created was imposed improperly, it may order that the charge or lien be removed or that the amount be varied, or make another order it considers proper.

At 10 a.m. on the last Monday in September, at the council chambers, the collector must conduct the annual tax sale by offering for sale by public auction each parcel of real property on which taxes are delinquent.
If the last Monday in September is a holiday, the tax sale must instead be held on the next Monday that is not a holiday.
The collector may adjourn the tax sale to the same hour on the following day, and from day to day until each parcel is disposed of.
The collector may act as auctioneer at the tax sale.
The collector may also offer for sale at the tax sale the other improvements on the real property that are taxable under this Act or the Community Charter and on which taxes are delinquent.
A sale under subsection (5) must be in accordance with section 252 [recovery of taxes by the legal remedy of distress] of the Community Charter.
The sale of real property under this section is not a bar to a sale under section 252 [recovery of taxes by the legal remedy of distress] of the Community Charter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemption of Crown land from tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A council may, by bylaw, exempt from the tax sale the sale of any real property owned by the Provincial government.
An exemption under subsection (1) does not relieve the real property from taxes lawfully imposed or prejudice the right of the collector to offer it for sale in a succeeding year.
Notice of the time and place of the tax sale and the description and street address, if any, of the property subject to tax sale must be published in at least 2 issues of a newspaper.
The last publication under subsection (1) must be at least 3 days and not more than 10 days before the date of the tax sale.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Municipality may bid at tax sale
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person authorized by the council may bid for the municipality at the tax sale up to a maximum amount set by the council.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Upset price and conduct of tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The collector is authorized to receive from the proceeds of a sale under section 403 the following amounts for the use of the municipality:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of delinquent taxes, taxes in arrear and interest to the first day of the tax sale for which the parcel of land and the improvements are liable for sale;
the taxes, including penalties incurred, for the current year on the land and improvements;
5% of the amounts under (b);
the fees prescribed under the Land Title Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The total of the amounts under subsection (1) is the upset price and the lowest amount for which the parcel may be sold.
The highest bidder above the upset price or, if there is no bid above the upset price, the bidder at the upset price, must be declared the purchaser.
If there is no bid, or no bid equal to the upset price, the municipality must be declared the purchaser.
If the municipality has been declared the purchaser of a parcel, the collector may offer the parcel for sale again later at the tax sale on the same conditions as before.
If a purchaser fails to immediately pay the collector the amount of the purchase price, the collector must promptly again offer the parcel for sale.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Purchaser to give authority to register tax sale title

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At the time of the tax sale and before the purchaser is given the certificate of sale, a purchaser other than the municipality must provide a statement, signed by the purchaser or the purchaser's agent,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: setting out the purchaser's full name, occupation and address, and
authorizing the collector to make the application referred to in section 420 (2) to register at the appropriate time the purchaser's title to the real property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A statement under subsection (1) must be preserved with the records of the sale.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Collector to provide certificate of sale
bcl:section.bcl:text: After a sale to a person other than the municipality, the collector must sign and give to the purchaser a certificate

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describing the parcel sold,
stating the sale price, and

stating that an indefeasible title will be applied for on the purchaser's behalf at the end of one year from the date of sale unless the property is redeemed or the sale is cancelled under section 423.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax sale of Crown land subject to an agreement to purchase

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The collector may, by sale held at the annual tax sale, sell land, the fee simple of which is vested in the Provincial government, but held by a person under an agreement to purchase.

A sale under this section is subject to the interest of the Provincial government and the collector must expressly state at the sale that the interest of the Provincial government is prior to all claims and is not affected by the sale.
Sections 420 do not apply to a sale under this section.
The collector must sign and give the purchaser of land at a sale under this section a certificate that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describes the land sold,
states the price at which the land was sold,
states that the interest of the Provincial government has priority over all claims and is not affected by the sale, and
states that the sale is made under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The collector must promptly provide to the minister responsible for the administration of the Land Act

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the certificate under subsection (4), and
the address of the purchaser.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Provincial government may accept tax sale purchaser

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister responsible for the administration of the Land Act may accept the tax sale purchaser as purchaser of the land and may deal with that purchaser to the exclusion of the person whose interest was sold at the tax sale and of all persons claiming under that person.
If that minister accepts the tax sale purchaser as purchaser of the land, the minister must notify the collector of this.

If that minister does not accept the tax sale purchaser as purchaser of the land or does not notify the collector within 6 months from the date of sale that the minister has accepted the purchaser, the purchaser is entitled to a refund from the municipality of the amount the purchaser paid together with interest at the rate prescribed under subsection (4).
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe a rate of interest for the purposes of subsection (3).
If a refund is made under subsection (3), the collector must promptly replace the amount of the upset price, together with the interest paid to the purchaser, as delinquent taxes on the land.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Resale of land purchased by municipality at tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If property is purchased by a municipality under section 407 and is not sold later at the tax sale, within 9 months after the purchase, the council may sell the property to any person for not less than the upset price plus interest accrued from the date of purchase at the rate prescribed under section 11 (3) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act.
On a sale under this section, the council must direct the collector to give the purchaser a certificate similar to that under section 409.
A sale under this section does not affect the period for or the right of redemption by the owner under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of tax sale must be filed in land title office
bcl:section.bcl:text: Promptly after selling property for taxes, the collector must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file in the proper land title office the notice of the tax sale, and
pay the fees prescribed under the Land Title Act for filing the notice and making the proper references.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Owners must be given notice of tax sale and redemption period

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Not later than 3 months after the sale of property at the tax sale, the collector must give written notice of the sale and of the day the redemption period ends, either by serving the notice or by sending it by registered mail, to persons registered in the land title office

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as owner of the fee simple of the property, or
as owner of a charge on the property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application, the Supreme Court may order that the notice under subsection (1) may be served by substituted service in accordance with the order.
No liability or responsibility other than as set out in subsection (1) rests with the collector or municipality to give notice of the sale for taxes.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Assessment and taxes during redemption period

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the period allowed for redemption, real property sold at the tax sale must continue to be assessed and taxed in the name of the person who at the time of sale appeared on the assessment roll as owner and that person is liable for taxes accruing.
The accruing taxes continue to be a special lien on the property under section 250 [taxes are a special charge on the land] of the Community Charter.
The purchaser at the tax sale may pay the taxes that become due during the period of redemption, and the amount paid must be added to the amount required to redeem.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of surplus from tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the property is not redeemed, money received by the collector at the tax sale above the upset price must be paid without interest to the owner at the time of the tax sale, on written application to the council.

The money must not be paid to the owner if a claim to the surplus is made by another person on the ground that the property belonged to the other person, or that the other person is otherwise entitled to the surplus.
If a claim referred to in subsection (2) is made, the money must, without leave, be paid into the Supreme Court, accompanied by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the certificate of sale under section 409, and
a statement of the municipal corporate officer setting out the facts under which the payment into court is made and the names of both the owner at the time of the tax sale and the claimant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Money paid into court under subsection (3) is payable out of court to the party entitled on a court order to be made on application in a summary manner and subject to the giving of the notices directed by the court.
If surplus money remains unpaid 6 months after the end of the redemption period, in the next month the council must have published in a newspaper a notice stating

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name of the owner to whom the surplus is payable,
the date it became payable, and
the amount of the surplus.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the surplus remains unclaimed 3 months after publication under subsection (5), it must be transferred to the administrator under the Unclaimed Property Act.
Money transferred under subsection (6) is deemed to be an unclaimed money deposit under the Unclaimed Property Act.
A parcel of property sold at a tax sale may be redeemed in accordance with this section by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an owner or registered owner in fee simple of the parcel,
an owner of a registered charge against the parcel, or
another person on behalf of a person referred to in (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The time limit for making a redemption is one year from the day the tax sale began, or a further time allowed by bylaw under subsection (6).
A redemption is made by paying or tendering to the collector for the use and benefit of the purchaser under section 407 the total of the following amounts:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the upset price of the parcel at the time of the tax sale;
all costs of which the collector has had notice that have been incurred by the purchaser in maintenance of the real property and in prevention of waste;
taxes advanced by the purchaser;

interest to the date of redemption on any amount in excess of the upset price and on the total amount expended by the purchaser under paragraphs (a) to (c) during the period for redemption, at the rate prescribed under section 11 (3) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: So much of the amount received by the collector at the sale for land title fees as is not required must be deducted.

On redemption of a parcel, the purchaser is entitled to receive from the municipality all amounts paid by the purchaser, together with interest to the date of redemption at the rate prescribed under section 11 (3) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act.
If the municipality has been declared the purchaser and the property has not been subsequently sold under section 407, the council may, by bylaw, extend for one year only the period for redemption.
This section applies in the case of land of which the municipality has been declared the purchaser under section 407 if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there are improvements on the land,
the land has not been subsequently sold under 412, and
the municipality has not adopted a bylaw under section 417 (6).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person empowered under section 417 to redeem the land and improvements referred to in subsection (1) is entitled to redeem them under subsection (3) if the person pays to the collector, on or before the latest date allowed under this Act for redemption, 50% of the total of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of the upset price for which the land and improvements were offered for sale, and
interest on the amount under paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who makes a payment under subsection (2) may redeem the land and improvements by paying to the collector the remainder of the total referred to in that subsection at any time within 11 months and 21 days from the latest date otherwise allowed for redemption.
In the circumstances described in this section, the time for redemption is extended accordingly.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of redemption must be filed in land title office
bcl:section.bcl:text: If real property sold for taxes is redeemed within the time allowed for redemption, the collector must promptly send to the registrar of land titles for filing the notice required by section 273 of the Land Title Act, together with any applicable fee under that Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a parcel of land sold for taxes is not redeemed as provided in this Act, at the end of the redemption period, the collector must forward a notice to that effect to the registrar of land titles.
The notice under subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: show the full name, occupation and address of the purchaser, and
be accompanied by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the fees payable under the Land Title Act, and
an application in the form approved under the Land Title Act for registration of title in fee simple in the name of the purchaser.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: It is not necessary with the application referred to in subsection (2) (b) to produce an outstanding absolute certificate of title or duplicate, or interim certificate of indefeasible title.
On forwarding the notice referred to in subsection (1) to the registrar of land titles, the municipality must immediately notify the administrator under the Property Transfer Tax Act.
The notice referred to in subsection (1) operates

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as a conveyance to the purchaser from the registered owner in fee simple, without proof of the signature of the collector and without an attestation or proof of execution, and

as a quit claim in favour of the purchaser of all right, title and interest of every previous owner in fee simple of the parcel, or of those claiming under any previous owner, and of all claims, demands, payments, charges, liens, judgments, mortgages and encumbrances of every type, and whether or not registered in accordance with the Land Title Act, subsisting at the time the application to register was received by the registrar, except

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the matters set out in section 276 (1) (c) to (g) of the Land Title Act, and
any lien of the Crown or an improvement district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: One application may be made under this section on behalf of a purchaser for registration of any number of parcels contained in the same block and listed on the one notice produced for registration, but subject to the requirements of section 158 of the Land Title Act.

If the registrar of land titles refuses to register the title in the name of a purchaser of property at a tax sale and no appeal is made under section 311 of the Land Title Act, or if an appeal has been made and the decision of the registrar sustained, the municipality is deemed to have been declared the purchaser of the property at the tax sale, and the municipality must refund the purchase price, without interest, to the purchaser.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of tax sale on rights of owner

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When real property is sold at a tax sale under this Act, all rights in it held by the person who at the time of the sale was the owner, the registered owner in fee simple or the registered owner of a registered charge on the property, immediately cease to exist, except as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the property is subject to redemption as provided in this Act;
the right to possession of the property is not affected during the time allowed for redemption, subject, however, to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: impeachment for waste, and
the right of the purchaser at the tax sale to enter on the property sold to maintain it in a proper condition and to prevent waste;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: during the period allowed for redemption, an action may be brought under section 422 to have the tax sale set aside and declared invalid.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the period allowed for redemption, subsection (1) does not operate to affect in any way the rights of the owner, the registered owner in fee simple or the owner of a registered charge, among or as between themselves.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Action by owner to have tax sale set aside

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who at the time of a tax sale was the owner, the registered owner in fee simple or the registered owner of a charge on the real property may bring an action in the Supreme Court to have the sale set aside and declared invalid.
An action under subsection (1) may only be brought on one or more of the following grounds:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the property was not liable to taxation during the years in which the taxes for which the property was sold were imposed;
the taxes for which the property was sold were fully paid;
irregularities existed in connection with the imposition of the taxes for which the property was sold;
the sale was not fairly and openly conducted;
the collector did not give to that person the notice required by section 414.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An action under this section may not be brought until one month after written notice has been given by the person to the council stating in detail the grounds of complaint.

During the period allowed for redemption, subsection (1) does not operate to affect in any way the rights of the owner, the registered owner in fee simple or the owner of a registered charge, among or as between themselves.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Reinstatement of taxes if sale set aside

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the court declares that a tax sale is set aside or invalid for a reason referred to in section 422 (2) (c) or (d), the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide that the amount of unpaid taxes on the real property at the date of sale, together with interest from that date, is a lien on the property as if the tax sale had not taken place, in which case that amount is deemed to be delinquent taxes,
provide for the immediate payment of those taxes, or
otherwise deal with those taxes according to the circumstances.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the period allowed for redemption, if the council finds a manifest error in the tax sale or in the proceedings before the sale, it may order that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the purchase price be returned to the purchaser together with interest at the rate prescribed under subsection (3), and
the taxes be dealt with as the circumstances require, either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by restoring the taxes as they were before the sale, or
otherwise as directed by the council.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe a rate of interest for the purposes of subsection (2) (a).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restrictions on legal actions in relation to tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After the end of the period allowed for redemption, no action may be brought to recover the property sold or to set aside its sale.
No action may be brought

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: against the registrar of land titles, the minister charged with the administration of the Land Title Act, the Land Title and Survey Authority of British Columbia or the collector in respect of the sale of the property or the registration of an indefeasible title to it, or
against the municipality in respect of any loss or damage sustained by reason of the sale, except as provided in this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who at the time of the tax sale was an owner of, a registered owner in fee simple of or an owner of a registered charge on the property must be indemnified by the municipality for any loss or damage sustained by the person on account of the sale of the property if the circumstances referred to in section 422 (2) (a), (b) or (e) existed.
As limits on subsection (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: no action may be brought to recover indemnity or compensation under this section after the end of one year from the time allowed by this Act for redemption of the real property, and

there is no right to indemnity or compensation under subsection (3) if it is shown that the person claiming indemnity or compensation was aware at the time of tax sale that the property was offered for sale, or was aware during the period allowed for redemption that it had been sold.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If land that became the property of a municipality as a result of tax sale has been sold by agreement for sale or subject to mortgage and is repossessed by the municipality for satisfaction of amounts due, the land is deemed to be again tax sale land.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Procedure on default of purchaser under agreement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The collector must send a notice in accordance with subsection (2) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land becomes the property of the municipality as a result of tax sale or failure to pay taxes and is sold by agreement for sale, and
there is default in the payment to the municipality of any instalment or interest.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be sent to the purchaser

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by personal service on the purchaser, or
by registered mail to the purchaser at the purchaser's address named in the agreement for sale, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be to the effect that, if the amounts in default are not paid within 90 days from the date of the service or mailing,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: all the right, title and interest of the purchaser in and to the agreement for sale, the amounts paid under it and the land referred to in it will cease and determine, and
the amounts paid under the agreement for sale will be forfeited to the municipality.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application, the Supreme Court may order that a notice under subsection (1) may be served by substituted service in accordance with the order.
If the purchaser fails to pay or cause to be paid the amounts in default within the period referred to in subsection (2) (b),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all that person's right, title and interest in and to the agreement for sale, the amounts paid under it and the land referred to in it cease and determine,
the land immediately revests in the municipality, free from all claims in respect of the agreement for sale, and
all amounts paid under the agreement are forfeited to the municipality.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite the Law and Equity Act or any rule of law or equity to the contrary, a person may not commence or bring an action against the municipality for relief against forfeiture or otherwise in respect of the cancellation of the agreement for sale or the retainer of the money paid to the municipality under the agreement for sale.

On the collector filing in the land title office an affidavit of the continuation of the default after the expiration of the 90 day period, together with evidence of notice or service, the registrar of land titles must cancel all charges or encumbrances, of any type, appearing in the records of the land title office against the land.

The registrar of land titles may require evidence of sufficiency of service and, if not satisfied, the service must be effected in the manner the Supreme Court may direct on an application by the municipality without notice to any other person.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Redemption by municipality of land sold for Provincial taxes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land in a municipality has become subject to forfeiture to the Provincial government or has been sold by the Surveyor of Taxes or by the Inspector of Dikes to a person under any statute for the recovery of Provincial taxes, or school taxes, or diking assessments, or other charges in arrear, and
there are taxes in arrear due to the municipality in respect of the land.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the circumstances referred to in subsection (1), the council may redeem the land at any time during the period allowed for redemption by paying to the Surveyor of Taxes or the Inspector of Dikes, as applicable, the amount required to redeem it as provided in the Act under which the land became subject to forfeiture or was sold.

On the redemption of land by a council under this section, it may add the amount of the redemption payment made by it to the amount of municipal taxes in arrear in respect of the land, and the amount added is deemed to be delinquent taxes under this Act.

If land subject to forfeiture referred to in subsection (1) has not been redeemed, but has been forfeited to and vested in the Provincial government, the council may purchase the land under the terms of any Act that provides for sale of the forfeited land to the municipality.

Despite the sale of land referred to in subsection (1) by the Surveyor of Taxes or by the Inspector of Dikes for the recovery of taxes, assessments or other charges in arrear, the land continues to be liable to taxation by the municipality in which it is located.
Subject to the Fire Services Act and the regulations under it, a board may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorize the fire chief to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: enter on property and inspect premises for conditions that may cause a fire, increase the danger of a fire or increase the danger to persons or property from a fire,
take the measures described in the bylaw to prevent and suppress fires, including the demolition of buildings and other structures to prevent the spreading of fire, and
exercise some or all of the powers of the fire commissioner under section 25 of the Fire Services Act, and for these purposes that section applies;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require the owners or occupiers of real property to remove from a building or yard anything that, in the opinion of the fire chief, is a fire hazard or increases the danger of fire;

if property is endangered by debris caused by lumbering, land clearing or industrial operation, require the person who is carrying on or who has carried on the operation, or the owner or occupier of the land on which the debris exists, to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: dispose of the debris, and
undertake any other actions for the purpose of removing or reducing the danger

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as directed by the bylaw or by the fire chief;
deal with any matter within the scope of the Fire Services Act in a manner not contrary to that Act or the regulations under it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The authority of the fire chief under a bylaw under subsection (1) may be exercised by a person under the authority of the fire chief or by another person designated in the bylaw.
Subject to the Public Health Act, a board may, by bylaw,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regulate and prohibit for the purposes of maintaining, promoting or preserving public health or maintaining sanitary conditions, and
undertake any other measures it considers necessary for those purposes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 9 [spheres of concurrent authority] of the subsection (1).
As a further limit on subsection (1), a board must not fluoridate the water supply unless the bylaw has received the assent of the electors.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regulate and prohibit the design and installation of drainage and sewerage works provided by persons other than the regional district, and
require owners of real property to connect their buildings and structures to the appropriate sewer or drain connections in the manner specified in the bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Watercourse may be included in drainage system
bcl:section.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, make a watercourse part of the regional district drainage system, whether the watercourse is on a highway or on regional district or private land.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section and section 543, stream means a stream as defined in the Water Act.
A board may, by bylaw,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish requirements that must be met by persons undertaking the construction of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: dikes,
works to maintain the proper flow of water in a stream, ditch, drain or sewer in the regional district, or
works to reclaim or to protect part of the land mass of the regional district from erosion by action of the sea or a stream, or any other cause, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish requirements that must be met by owners of dikes.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appropriation of stream channel or bed

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of constructing works referred to in subsection (2), a board may appropriate the land that constitutes the channel or bed of a stream that passes through the regional district, without compensation to the owner.
The power under subsection (1) may be exercised in relation to one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: dikes;
works to maintain the proper flow of water in a stream, ditch, drain or sewer in the regional district;
works to reclaim or to protect part of the land mass of the regional district from erosion by action of the sea or a stream, or any other cause;
works to protect all or part of the banks of the stream from erosion or damage;
works to make a watercourse part of the regional district drainage system, whether the watercourse is on a highway or regional district or private land;
works through, under or over land adjoining a highway to protect the highway from damage by water.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before exercising the power under subsection (1), the board must, by bylaw, define the channel or bed of the stream.

A certified copy of every bylaw under subsection (3), together with a plan showing the channel or bed of the stream as defined in the bylaw, must be filed in the land title office of the district in which the land affected is located.
This section applies if a board considers that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the drainage of surface water from outside the regional district into or through an area inside the regional district should be prevented, diverted or improved, or
drainage of or from an area in the regional district should be prevented, continued beyond the regional district, diverted or improved,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and proposes to undertake works for these purposes.
Before undertaking the proposed works, notice must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: given to any other local government whose area may be affected, and
served on all owners of land that may be affected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice under subsection (2) must state

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the place in the regional district where details of the project may be inspected, and
the date by which objections to the project must be received by the regional district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The date under subsection (3) (b) must be at least one month after the date on which the notice is given under subsection (2).
On application, the Supreme Court may order that the notice under subsection (2) (b) may be served by substituted service in accordance with the order.
The designated regional district officer must make a full report to the inspector on all objections received.
On the application of a board, the minister may authorize works proposed under this section on the terms of compensation and cost to owners of land affected that the minister considers proper.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Remedial authority in relation to drainage and dikes
bcl:section.bcl:text: Division 12 [Remedial Action Requirements] of Part 3 of the Community Charter applies to regional districts in relation to matters referred to in section 75 [harm to drainage or dike] of that Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a dike is crossed by a highway or private road, the level of the dike must not be interfered with.

If the top of a dike forms a portion of a highway, it is the duty of the board to maintain it at a constant level, and to repair all injury directly or indirectly caused to the dike by its use as a highway.

For certainty, a board's duty under subsection (2) is limited to the highway as a highway and, except as otherwise required, does not extend to or include repair or maintenance of the dike as distinct from the highway.
As an exception, subsection (2) does not apply if the board has granted a diking commission the privilege of using the existing road for a dike.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A board may make agreements with adjoining municipalities or regional districts, and also with the owner of any land, through, on or in which runs a natural stream or watercourse, for one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: constructing, enlarging or maintaining a culvert, ditch, flume, embankment or other work;
removing obstructions from the stream or watercourse to lessen or prevent the danger of flooding from it;

the granting, expending or accepting of money for the purposes referred to in (b), even though the work may not be located in the municipality or regional district granting, expending or accepting the money or entering into the agreement.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Authority in relation to waste disposal and recycling services
bcl:section.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require persons to use a waste disposal or recycling service, including requiring persons to use a waste disposal or recycling service provided by or on behalf of the regional district;
require owners or occupiers of real property to remove trade waste, garbage, rubbish and other matter from their property and take it to a specified place;
require the emptying, cleansing and disinfecting of private drains, cesspools, septic tanks and outhouses, and the removal and disposal of refuse from them.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the Transportation Act, a board may, by bylaw, regulate the erection, placing, alteration, maintenance, demolition and removal of a sign, sign board, advertisement, advertising device or structure, or any class of them.
For the purpose of subsection (1), a board may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: classify structures, things and the whole or a portion of a highway, and
make different regulations for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: different zones established under a zoning bylaw, and
different classes of highways and portions of them.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A board may require a person using a local government right of way other than a highway to provide the regional district, if reasonably possible, with accurate plans and profiles of any of their works and facilities using the right of way.
Section 315.1 [irrigation services] applies to regional districts.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The authority of a regional district under the following provisions is subject to the applicable provisions of the Water Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 541 [watercourse may be included in drainage system];
section 542 [requirements respecting drainage works];
section 543 [appropriation of stream channel or bed];
section 544 [control of drainage];
section 548 [interjurisdictional watercourses].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition, the following authorities of a regional district are subject to the applicable provisions of the Water Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the authority to acquire, manage, extend and remove

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: works to maintain the proper flow of water in a stream as defined in the Water Act, ditch, drain or sewer in the regional district,
dikes, or
works to reclaim or to protect part of the land mass of the regional district from erosion by action of the sea or a stream as defined in the Water Act, or any other cause;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the authority to regulate a wharf, dock, warehouse or slip owned, held or managed by the regional district.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Regulation of Carriers and Commercial Vehicle Licensing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A council may, by bylaw, regulate carriers of persons or things to the extent to which they are not subject to regulation or order under another Act.
Without limiting subsection (1) or section 8 (6) [fundamental powers — business] of the Community Charter, a bylaw under this section may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish the maximum and minimum charges that may be made by carriers, which may be different for different zones or areas of the municipality designated by bylaw;
establish and alter routes to be taken by carriers;
limit the number of vehicles with respect to which persons may be licensed in a class of carrier.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under this section may establish different classes of carriers and make different provisions for different classes.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: commercial vehicle means a vehicle used by a person on a highway in a participating municipality, if the vehicle is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a commercial vehicle as defined by and licensed under the Commercial Transport Act, or
a vehicle not licensed as referred to in paragraph (a), but used for the collection or delivery, or both, of merchandise or another commodity in the ordinary course of a business;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: licence plate includes licence decal;
licence year means a calendar year;
municipality includes the City of Vancouver;
participating municipality means a municipality in which a bylaw is in force declaring that this Division applies in that municipality.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to the Passenger Transportation Act and despite any other Act relating to a municipality, this Division applies to all municipalities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A council may, by bylaw, declare that this Division applies to the municipality, and in that case it applies in the municipality from and after the start of the licence year that begins at least 3 months after the adoption of the bylaw.
A bylaw under subsection (1) must make provision not inconsistent with this Division for the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the imposition and collection of licence fees;
the issue of licences and licence plates;
the transfer of licences and licence plates, and transfer fees.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (1) may be repealed or amended at any time, but a repeal does not take effect until the end of the licence year in which the repealing bylaw is adopted.
A municipality that is not a participating municipality may not impose a licence fee under this Division or issue a class of licence under this Division.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following commercial vehicles are exempt from this Division:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a commercial vehicle licensed as a farm vehicle under the Commercial Transport Act, except when used for the collection or delivery, or both, of merchandise or another commodity not required in the ordinary course of the farm undertaking of the owner of the vehicle;
a commercial vehicle owned and operated by an improvement district;
a commercial vehicle not requiring a licence fee under section 3 (8) of the Motor Vehicle Act;
a commercial vehicle licensed under the Commercial Transport Act that is not being used by a person for the purpose of the person's business or by an organization for profit;

a commercial vehicle licensed under the Commercial Transport Act that is owned by a farmer and used only to transport the produce of the farmer's farm to market and to transport supplies required for the farmer's farm;
a commercial vehicle owned by the Provincial government.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Unless exempted under section 667 [exemptions from licensing requirements], a commercial vehicle must not be operated on a highway in a participating municipality unless there is displayed on the vehicle a valid and subsisting licence plate issued in accordance with this Division for the vehicle.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Issue and transfer of licence plates

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application for a licence under this Division for a commercial vehicle and payment of the licence fee, a licence plate must be issued for the vehicle.

On application for a licence under this Division for a commercial vehicle operated under an agreement under section 10 of the Commercial Transport Act and payment of the licence fee, a licence plate must be issued and is valid for display on any commercial vehicle operated under the agreement.

Subject to the requirements of a bylaw under this Division, on payment of the prescribed fee together with any sum representing the difference in licence fee required for the transfer of a licence plate to a commercial vehicle of greater gross vehicle weight, a licence plate may be transferred

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: from one person to another person for the same commercial vehicle, or
from one commercial vehicle to another commercial vehicle for the same person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing fees for the purposes of this section and, in relation to fees under (2), may prescribe different fees for commercial vehicles of different gross vehicle weight.
For the purposes of subsection (3) in addition to the prescribed fee is deemed to be a licence fee.
A licence issued under this Division by a municipality is valid in every municipality for the current licence year.
A licence issued during November or December must be issued for the following licence year and is a valid and subsisting licence from the date of issue until the end of the following licence year.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Fees to be paid to UBCM

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After deducting any licence transfer fee under section 669 (3) and the prescribed administration fee, a municipality must pay the remainder of the fees it collects under this Division to the Union of British Columbia Municipalities.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing administration fees for the purposes of subsection (1).

Money received by the Union of British Columbia Municipalities under subsection (1) must be placed in a separate licence fee account, and the money may be paid out of the account for any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: licence plate production expenses;
the expenses of conducting the audit under subsection (4);
other related expenses;
payments to participating municipalities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The licence fee account must be audited at the times and in the manner directed by the minister.

The owner or operator of a commercial vehicle, other than a vehicle exempted under section 667 [exemptions from licensing requirements], who operates or uses or causes the vehicle to be operated or used on a highway in a participating municipality without holding and displaying a valid and subsisting licence plate for the vehicle is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $50.

A person who displays or causes to be displayed a licence plate on a commercial vehicle not authorized to have it displayed on the vehicle is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $200 and the confiscation of the licence plate.
A fine imposed under this section does not remove any liability for a prescribed licence fee under this Division.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Building Code and Other Building Regulations

bcl:marginalnote.in:green: Application of Administrative Tribunals Act to appeal board

bcl:text.in:green: The following provisions of the Administrative Tribunals Act apply to the appeal board:
Part 2 [Appointments], except section 9 [responsibilities of the chair];
section 11 [general power to make rules respecting practice and procedure];
section 18 [failure of party to comply with tribunal orders and rules];
section 32 [representations of parties to an application];
section 44 [tribunal without jurisdiction over constitutional questions];
section 46.3 [tribunal without jurisdiction to apply the Human Rights Code];
section 56 [immunity protection for tribunal and members];
section 58 [standard of review with privative clause];
section 60 (1) (g) to (i) and (2) [power to make regulations].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Division applies only to a regional district that provides a service referred to in section 797.1 (1) (a) [building inspection].

As a further restriction, section 9 [spheres of concurrent authority] of the Community Charter applies in relation to a regional district bylaw under this Part respecting matters referred to in subsection (1) (d) [building regulation] of that section.
Subject to the subsection (1.1), by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regulate the construction, alteration, repair or demolition of buildings and other structures;

regulate the installation, alteration or repair of plumbing including septic tanks and sewer connections, heating, air conditioning, electrical wiring and equipment, gas or oil piping and fittings, appliances and accessories of every kind;

require contractors, owners or other persons to obtain and hold a valid permit from the board, or the authorized official, before starting and during the construction, installation, repair or alteration of gas or oil pipes and fittings, plumbing, heating, sewers, septic tanks, drains, electrical wiring, oil burners, tanks, pumps and similar works and buildings and other structures of the kind, description or value described in the bylaw;

require that, before occupancy of a building or part of it after construction, wrecking or alteration, or a change in class of occupancy of a building or part of it, an occupancy permit be obtained from the board or the authorized official;
prescribe conditions generally governing the issue and validity of permits, inspection of works, buildings and other structures;
establish areas to be known as fire limits and, for those areas,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: regulate the construction of buildings in respect of precautions against fire, and
discriminate and differentiate between areas in the character of the buildings permitted;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regulate the seating arrangements and capacity of churches, theatres, halls and other places of public amusement or resort;
regulate or prohibit the moving of a building from one property to another in the regional district;
require the fencing of private swimming pools or other pools, existing or prospective, according to specifications set out in the bylaw;
regulate the construction and layout of trailer courts, manufactured home parks and camping grounds and require that those courts, parks and grounds provide facilities specified in the bylaw;
provide that a trailer or manufactured home must not be occupied as a residence or an office unless its construction and facilities meet the standards specified in the bylaw;

require the installation of smoke alarms in existing buildings and other structures and, in relation to this, establish standards and specifications for required smoke alarms and their installation, to the extent that the requirements of the bylaw do not exceed those established by the Provincial building regulations;

require the maintenance of smoke alarms installed as required by the Provincial building regulations or by bylaw under paragraph (l) and, in relation to this, establish standards for their maintenance;

require the maintenance of "rental units" and "residential property", as defined in the Residential Tenancy Act, that are subject to a "tenancy agreement" as defined in that Act, in accordance with the standards specified in the bylaw, to the extent that the standards do not exceed those established by the Provincial building regulations;

require the maintenance of "manufactured homes", "manufactured home sites" and "manufactured home parks", as defined in the Manufactured Home Park Tenancy Act, that are subject to a "tenancy agreement" as defined in that Act, in accordance with the standards specified in the bylaw, to the extent that the standards do not exceed those established by the Provincial building regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may exercise the powers conferred by subsection (1) for the following purposes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the provision of access to a building or other structure, or to part of a building or other structure, for a person with disabilities;
the conservation of energy or water;
the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions;
the health, safety or protection of persons or property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If requested by an applicant, the building inspector must give written reasons for his or her refusal to issue a building permit required under this section.
An occupancy permit required under subsection (1) (d) may be withheld until the building or part of it complies with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Provincial building regulations;
bylaws under this section;
any other health and safety requirements established by bylaw;
any other federal or Provincial enactment in relation to health or safety.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if, under section 694.
The person who is subject to the requirement may, at that person's option, provide the security by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a cash deposit,
an irrevocable letter of credit, or
another form of security satisfactory to the board or the person who imposed the requirement for security.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Interest on the security becomes part of the security.
The security may be used by the regional district only to repair or replace

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a highway, including sidewalks and boulevards,
a public work, or
other regional district property

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: that has been altered or damaged by an activity related to the subject matter of the permit or authorization.
Any amount of the security that is not required for a purpose referred to in subsection (4) must be returned to the person who provided it.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following provisions of the Community Charter apply to regional districts:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 55 [requirement for professional certification];
section 56 [requirement for geotechnical report];
section 57 [note against land title that building regulations contravened];
section 58 [cancellation of note against land title].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the Fire Services Act and the regulations under that Act, a board may, by bylaw, compel the provision of and regulate the location, number, style and size of doors and emergency exits in churches, theatres, halls or other places of public resort or amusement, and the posting in them of notices of the emergency exits.
A bylaw under subsection (1) must provide that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all doors in churches, theatres, halls and other places of public resort or amusement must be hinged so that they may open freely outwards, and

all gates or outer fences if not hinged as referred to in paragraph (a), must be kept open by proper fastenings during the time the buildings are publicly used to facilitate the exit of people in case of alarm from fire or other cause.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Congregations having corporate powers, trustees holding churches or buildings used for churches, and incumbents and church wardens holding or using churches or buildings used for churches, are severally liable for the acts and omissions of any society or congregation on the matters referred to in (2).

A person owning or possessing a church, theatre, hall, school or other building used for public meetings, or as a place of public resort or amusement, who contravenes this section or a bylaw adopted under it is liable on conviction to a penalty not greater than $50.
A convicted person is liable on conviction to a further penalty of $5 for every further week during which the violation continues.
A penalty under (5) is a charge on the real property of the person convicted, and may be imposed, collected and recovered in the manner provided for taxes.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regional district may adopt national codes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To the extent not inconsistent with this Act, either in place of or supplementary to regulations made under this Division, a board may, by bylaw, adopt one or more of the following as regulations:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to the Electrical Energy Inspection Act, all or part of the Canadian Electrical Code;
subject to the Gas Safety Act, all or part of the standards of the Canadian Gas Association;
subject to the Fire Services Act, all or part of the National Fire Code of Canada.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A code, standard or part referred to in subsection (1) may be adopted by reference to a particular date of issue or a specified issue of the code or standard.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Remedial authority in relation to hazardous conditions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Division 12 [Remedial Action Requirements] of Part 3 of the Community Charter applies to regional districts in relation to matters referred to in section 73 (1) (a) and (b) [structures, excavations and similar matters or things that are unsafe or contravene building bylaws] of that Act.
In relation to section 73 (2) (b) [matter contravening Provincial building regulations or bylaws] of the Division 2 of this Part.

In relation to sections 77 (3) (b) [remedial action after date specified for compliance] and 80 (4) and (5) [recovery of municipal costs through sale of property — distribution of proceeds] of the section 269 of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application in relation to regional district animal control service
