provide an alternative review process that is different than the service review process established by Division 4.5 [Dispute Resolution in Relation to Services];
establish terms and conditions for withdrawal from the service;
include any other provisions respecting the establishment and operation of the service that the board considers appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a limit on subsection (1) (b), each director for a participating area must be entitled to at least one vote.

If a proposed establishing bylaw includes provisions referred to in subsection (1) (d), each participant must consent to the provisions before the bylaw is submitted for participating area approval under section 801.
An establishing bylaw has no effect unless, before its adoption, it receives

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the approval of the inspector, and
participating area approval in accordance with this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Participating area approval under this section may be obtained as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in any case, by assent of the electors in accordance with section 801.2 [approval by voting];
if permitted under section 801.3 (1) [approval by alternative approval process], approval given in accordance with that section;
if permitted under section 801.4 [consent on behalf of municipal participating area] for a proposed municipal participating area, consent given in accordance with that section;
if permitted under section 801.5 (1) [consent on behalf of electoral area electors] for a proposed electoral participating area, consent given in accordance with that section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless authorized under subsection (4), participating area approval must be obtained separately for each participating area in the proposed service area.

If approval is to be obtained under subsection (2) (a) or (b), the board may, by resolution adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, provide that the participating area approval is to be obtained for the entire proposed service area.

As an exception, subsections (1) to (4) do not apply to an establishing bylaw for a service referred to in section 800 (2) (a), (b) or (d) [services for which establishing bylaw not required — general administration, electoral area administration and regional hospital district services] and, instead, section 802 applies to the bylaw as if it were a bylaw amending an establishing bylaw.
If participating area approval is to be obtained for the entire service area,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the board may choose the method,
in the case of approval by alternative approval process, the board is responsible for obtaining the approval, and
in the case of approval by assent of the electors, at the option of the board,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the board is responsible for conducting the voting throughout the proposed service area, or
the board and councils are responsible for conducting the voting in the same manner as under subsection (2), with the results of the voting in these areas added together.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If participating area approval is to be obtained separately for each participating area,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to subsection (3), for a municipal participating area, the council may choose the method and is responsible for obtaining the approval, and
for an electoral participating area, the board may choose the method and is responsible for obtaining the approval.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, within 30 days after third reading of the establishing bylaw, a council

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has notified the regional district that it is refusing to seek participating area approval, or
fails to give any notice to the regional district with respect to how participating area approval is to be obtained,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the board may adopt a resolution under section 801 (4) [approval of establishing bylaws — entire area] to have participating area approval obtained for the entire service area.

Despite section 801.4 [consent on behalf of municipal participating area] but does not exercise this authority, the municipality is responsible for the costs of obtaining the participating area approval.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Approval by assent of the electors

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Participating area approval through assent of the electors under Part 4 [Assent Voting] is obtained if,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of approval under section 801 (3) [each participating area separately], for each proposed participating area, a majority of the votes counted as valid is in favour of the bylaw, or
in the case of approval under section 801 (4) [entire service area], a majority of votes counted as valid is in favour of the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the case of approval under section 161, the voting area is deemed to be all the proposed participating areas.
Participating area approval may be obtained by alternative approval process if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the maximum amount that may be requisitioned for the service is the amount equivalent to 50¢ for each $1 000 of net taxable value of land and improvements included in the service area, or
the bylaw relates to a service for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the collection, conveyance, treatment or disposal of sewage,
the supply, treatment, conveyance, storage or distribution of water, or
the collection, removal or disposal of solid waste or recyclable material.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the information required by section 86 (2) of the Community Charter, the notice of an alternative approval process under this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: include a copy of the bylaw, or
include a synopsis of the bylaw that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: describes in general terms, the intent of the bylaw,
describes the proposed service area, and
indicates the date, time and place for public inspection of copies of the bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consent on behalf of municipal participating area
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a proposed participating area is all of a municipality, the council may give participating area approval by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consenting on behalf of the electors to adoption of the proposed bylaw, and
notifying the board of its consent.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consent on behalf of electoral participating area electors

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For a proposed electoral participating area, the board may authorize participating area approval to be given under this section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the board receives a sufficient petition under section 797.4 [petition for electoral area services], or
in the case of an establishing bylaw for a service referred to in section 800.1 (2) [no requisition limit required], if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the participating area includes all of the electoral area, and
the service can be established without borrowing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Participating area approval under this section may be given by the electoral area director consenting in writing to adoption of the bylaw.

If a director refuses to give consent under subsection (2), the board may, by a resolution adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, dispense with the consent of the electoral area director and give participating area approval by consenting to adoption of the bylaw on behalf of the electors in the proposed participating area.

If a board consents under subsection (3), the director for the participating area may, within 14 days after the resolution, appeal to the minister for a review, and the minister may, after that review, order

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the consent of the board under subsection (3) stands,
that participating area approval must be obtained under section 801.2 [approval by assent of the electors], or
that participating area approval must be obtained under section 801.3 [approval by alternative approval process].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a board proposes to borrow money for the start of a service, the establishing bylaw and the loan authorization bylaw must, for the purposes of obtaining participating area approval, be dealt with as if they were one bylaw.
The regional district corporate officer must file with the inspector a copy of each establishing bylaw after it has been adopted.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amendment or repeal of establishing bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to an order under (5), an establishing bylaw may be amended or repealed, at the option of the board,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with the requirements applicable to the adoption of the bylaw that it amends or repeals, or
with the consent of at least 2/3 of the participants.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections subsection (1) (b) of this section.
A bylaw amending or repealing an establishing bylaw has no effect unless it is approved by the inspector.

The minister may order that a bylaw amending or repealing an establishing bylaw may only be adopted in accordance with the requirements applicable to the adoption of the bylaw that it repeals or amends.
In addition to the requirement under (4), as applicable, the minister may order that, before the bylaw is adopted, it must receive the approval of the electors

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in one or more specified participating areas, or in specified parts of one or more participating areas, or
in the entire service area,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: obtained in accordance with section 801.2 [approval by assent of the electors] or 801.3 [approval by alternative approval process], as specified by the minister.
Section 137 (2) [minister may waive requirement for elector assent or approval] of the Community Charter does not apply to a bylaw amending or repealing an establishing bylaw.
The regional district corporate officer must file with the inspector a bylaw amending or repealing an establishing bylaw after it has been adopted.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Changes to participating and service areas

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw amending an establishing bylaw may provide for changes to the boundaries of a service area, including merging 2 or more service areas.

If a bylaw amending an establishing bylaw extends an existing service to a new participating area, the proposed participating area must be included as a participating area and the participant for the proposed participating area must be included as a participant for the purposes of section 802.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amending bylaws that are needed for authority to borrow

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a bylaw amending an establishing bylaw, or
a conversion bylaw under section 774.2 (3)

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: is required in order to borrow money for a service, the amending or conversion bylaw and the loan authorization bylaw may, for the purposes of obtaining participating area approval under sections 801.5, be dealt with as if they were one bylaw.
The minister may order that participating area approval of an amending or conversion bylaw referred to in subsection (1) must be obtained separately from the approval of the loan authorization bylaw.

If a bylaw adds, repeals or amends provisions of an establishing bylaw referred to in section 800.2 (1) (d) [terms and conditions for withdrawal], each participant must consent to the changes before the bylaw is submitted for approval in accordance with the requirements of section 802.

If a bylaw repealing an establishing bylaw is submitted to the inspector for approval and the inspector is not satisfied that all participants in a service have reached agreement respecting the termination of a service, the inspector must refer the matter to the minister, who must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: direct the participants and the board to undertake negotiations on the matters related to terminating the service, or
if the minister is satisfied that agreement under paragraph (a) is unlikely, direct that the parties proceed to mediation or arbitration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may specify the length of time that negotiations under subsection (2) (a) must continue and may extend this time period before or after it has expired.
The participants and board must conduct negotiations under subsection (2) (a) in good faith, making reasonable efforts to reach an agreement that will permit resolution of the matters.
If the parties have not reached agreement by the end of the time period for negotiations under subsection (2) (a), the minister must direct that the parties proceed to mediation or arbitration.
For the purposes of subsections (2) (b) and (5), subject to any regulations under subsection (7),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sections Division 4.5 [Dispute Resolution in Relation to Services] of this Part, and
section 813.03 [costs of process] applies as if this were a service review process under that Division.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may make regulations respecting mediation and arbitration under this section, including regulations providing exceptions to or modifications of a provision referred to in subsection (6) or a regulation under section 813.19.
A regional district may recover the costs of its services by one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: property value taxes imposed in accordance with Division 4.3 [Requisition and Tax Collection];
subject to subsection (2), parcel taxes imposed in accordance with Division 4.3 [Requisition and Tax Collection];
fees and charges imposed under section 363 [imposition of fees and charges];
revenues raised by other means authorized under this or another Act;
revenues received by way of agreement, enterprise, gift, grant or otherwise.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Parcel taxes may not be used to recover all or part of the costs of a regulatory service.

In the case of a service for which an establishing bylaw is required, if all or part of the costs are to be recovered by one or more of the methods referred to in subsection (1) (a) to (c), the establishing bylaw must indicate which methods are to be used.
All costs incurred by a regional district in relation to a service, including costs of administration attributable to the service, are part of the costs of that service.
Subject to subsection (3), the amount required by a board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a payment authorized under section 287.2 [indemnification against proceedings],
to satisfy a judgment or other order of a court against the regional district, or
to satisfy an award or other order of an arbitrator against the regional district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: is deemed to be costs of the service out of which the action arose.
If the legal action or other proceeding arose from the negligence of the board, the amount is deemed to be costs of the general administration service referred to in section 800 (2) (a).
If a regional district undertakes a service after conducting a feasibility study in respect of the service, the costs of that study are deemed to be costs of that service.

If a referendum under section 797.3 [referendums regarding services] is limited to all or part of the service area for an existing service, the costs of the referendum are deemed to be costs of the service.

For the purposes of apportionment under this Division and requisition under Division 4.3 [Requisition and Tax Collection], the costs of providing a service are deemed to be the costs that are to be recovered by means of property value taxes or parcel taxes.
If the establishing bylaw sets the method for apportioning the costs of providing a service, those costs must be apportioned among the participating areas in accordance with the bylaw.

If the method of apportionment is not set by establishing bylaw, the costs of providing a service must be apportioned on the basis of the converted value of land and improvements in the service area as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if there is an establishing bylaw but it does not set out the method of apportionment, among the participating areas for the service;

if there is no establishing bylaw and the method of apportionment is not otherwise set under this or another Act, among all the municipalities and electoral areas, with the service area deemed to be the entire regional district;
in the case of electoral area administration,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: subject to subparagraph (ii), among all the electoral areas, with the service area deemed to be all the electoral areas, and

if the board provides that some or all of the costs are to be apportioned among the electoral areas that the board considers benefit from the administration, those costs must be apportioned among those electoral areas, with the service area deemed to be all those electoral areas;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of feasibility studies in relation to proposed services, if no service is established and the board provides that the costs are to be apportioned among the electoral areas, among all the electoral areas, with the service area deemed to be all those electoral areas;

in the case of services related to an approving officer, if the board is authorized to appoint the approving officer under section 77.1 of the Land Title Act, among all the electoral areas, with the service area deemed to be all those electoral areas;

in the case of a service that is in relation to a regional growth strategy for an area that is less than the entire regional district, among the areas for which the regional growth strategy is initiated or adopted, with the service area being all those areas;
in the case of assistance under section 176 (1) (c) [corporate powers — assistance], other than assistance under a partnering agreement referred to in section 183, at the option of the board,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in accordance with paragraph (b), or
among the municipalities or electoral areas benefiting from the assistance, with the service area deemed to be all those areas;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a referendum under section 797.3 [referendums regarding services] that is not limited to all or part of the service area for an existing service, among the municipalities and electoral areas in which the referendum is held, with the service area deemed to be all those areas;
in the case of a local community commission under section 838, entirely from the local community, with the service area deemed to be that local community;

in the case of a business improvement area under section 215 [business improvements areas] of the Community Charter in relation to a mountain resort, entirely from that area, with the service area deemed to be the business improvement area;
in the case of services under Part 26, in accordance with section 804.1 [cost sharing for Part 26 services].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The costs of services under Part 26 [Planning and Land Use Management] must be apportioned on the basis of the converted value of land and improvements in the service area as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if no municipality has entered into an agreement under subsection (3), among all the municipalities and electoral areas, with the service area deemed to be the entire regional district;

subject to paragraphs (c) and (d), if one or more municipalities have opted out under subsection (3) and are no longer participants, among the electoral areas and any municipalities that have not opted out, with the service area deemed to be those areas;

if one or more municipalities have entered into an agreement under subsection (2) to share only some of the costs, those costs are to be recovered in accordance with the agreements and the remaining costs are to be apportioned among the other participants;
if a municipality is liable for costs under (7), those costs are to be recovered from the municipality and the remaining costs are to be apportioned among the other participants.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board and a municipality may enter into an agreement that the municipality is to share in some but not all of the costs of services under Part 26, to the extent set out in the agreement and in accordance with the terms and conditions for the municipality's participation established by the agreement.

Subject to subsection (4), a municipality may opt out of participation in services under Part 26 by giving notice to the board, before August 31 in any year, that until further notice it will no longer share the costs of services under Part 26.
A municipality that is a party to an agreement under subsection (3) only in the last year of the term of the agreement.
After notice is given under subsection (3), the municipality ceases to be a participant in the services, effective at the start of the following year.

As an exception to subsection (5), if a municipality that is not a party to an agreement under subsection (2) gives notice under subsection (3) after a board has passed a resolution authorizing the preparation of an official community plan or bylaw under Part 26, the municipality continues as a participant and must share the costs in that preparation until the earlier of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date the plan or bylaw is adopted;
2 years after the date the resolution is passed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (6) also applies to a municipality that is a party to an agreement under subsection (2) if the official community plan or bylaw is in relation to the Part 26 services for which the municipality shares costs under the agreement.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exclusion of property under creditor protection from apportionment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: determined value means the value of an eligible property determined by using the valuation basis described in the method of apportionment for the applicable eligible service;

eligible property means property located within the service area of an eligible service that is owned or occupied by an insolvent person who is liable for property value taxes or parcel taxes referred to in Division 4.3 [Requisition and Tax Collection] with respect to that property;
eligible service means a regional district service with respect to which all or part of the method of apportionment is based on the assessed value, net taxable value or converted value of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land,
improvements, or
land and improvements,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: or on a similar method of apportionment that uses property values;
insolvent person means a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: who has filed for and been granted protection under the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act (Canada),

who has filed an assignment or a proposal or a notice of intention to make a proposal under the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act (Canada) or against whom a bankruptcy order or an order appointing an interim receiver has been made under that Act,
in respect of whom a winding-up order has been made under the Winding-up and Restructuring Act (Canada) based in whole or in part on the person being insolvent, or
who has made an application to the administrator undersection 5 of the Farm Debt Mediation Act (Canada) and who has been found by the administrator to be eligible to make that application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite sections 804.1, the board annually may exclude the determined value of an eligible property from the apportionment for an eligible service.

In order to be effective for the requisition in the current year, the board must make an exclusion referred to in subsection (2) before the requisition in respect of the eligible service for that year is sent to municipalities and the Surveyor of Taxes under sections 806.
As soon as practicable after the relevant information is available, the British Columbia Assessment Authority must provide to the designated regional district officer and to the inspector

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the net taxable value of land and improvements, and
the converted value of land and improvements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: in each municipality, electoral area and participating area.
If adjustments are made under the subsection (1), the British Columbia Assessment Authority must provide particulars to the designated regional district officer and to the inspector.
If, in respect of a year,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjustments referred to in subsection (2) are made, and

the share of the cost of all the services of the regional district that was apportioned to and borne by a municipality or an electoral area in that year would, had those adjustments been taken into account, have increased or decreased by more than $1 000,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the share of the cost apportioned to and borne by the municipalities and electoral areas must be adjusted in a manner directed by the minister in the next requisition after the adjustment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax base for property value taxes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the case of a participating area for a service for which no establishing bylaw is required, property value taxes must be imposed on the basis of the net taxable value of land and improvements in the participating area.

In the case of a municipal participating area for a service for which an establishing bylaw is required, the establishing bylaw may provide that property value taxes must be imposed on the basis of one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the assessed value of land and improvements in the participating area, other than land and improvements exempt from taxation for municipal purposes;
the assessed value of land in the participating area, other than land exempt from taxation for municipal purposes;
the assessed value of improvements in the participating area, other than improvements exempt from taxation for municipal purposes;
the net taxable value of land and improvements in the participating area;
the net taxable value of land in the participating area;
the net taxable value of improvements in the participating area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception to subsection (2), for a municipal participating area that is all or part of the City of Vancouver, property value taxes may be imposed on the basis set out in the establishing bylaw for the service.

If a board fails to exercise its authority under (3), property value taxes must be imposed on the basis of the assessed value of land and improvements in the participating area, other than land and improvements exempt from taxation for municipal purposes.

In the case of an electoral participating area for a service for which an establishing bylaw is required, the establishing bylaw may provide that property value taxes must be imposed on the basis of one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the net taxable value of land and improvements in the participating area;
the net taxable value of land in the participating area;
the net taxable value of improvements in the participating area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a board fails to exercise its authority under subsection (5), property value taxes must be imposed on the basis of the net taxable value of land and improvements in the participating area.

On or before April 10 in each year, the designated regional district officer must send to each municipality a requisition in respect of each service stating the amount required from the municipality for the service during the year.
An amount requisitioned under this section is a debt due by the municipality to the regional district, and the council must pay it to the board on or before August 1 of the current year.
If a requisition is delivered to a municipality, the amount requisitioned must be collected by the municipality as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an amount to be recovered by means of a property value tax, by imposing the tax in accordance with Division 3 [Property Value Taxes] of Part 7 of the section 804.3 [tax base for property value taxes] of this Act;
in the case of an amount to be recovered by means of a parcel tax, by imposing the tax in accordance with Division 4 [Parcel Taxes] of Part 7 of the Community Charter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Part 7 [Municipal Revenue] of the Community Charter applies for the purposes of taxation under this section.
If a participating area is only part of a municipality, taxes under this section in respect of the service may only be imposed in the municipal participating area for the service.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requisition of funds for electoral areas

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On or before April 10 in each year, the designated regional district officer must deliver to the Surveyor of Taxes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a requisition in respect of each service, stating the amount required during the year in respect of each electoral participating area, and
that officer's certification

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that the amount requisitioned is included in the financial plan for that year, and
of any other matter in relation to the requisition that is required to be certified under subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing matters that must be certified under subsection (1) (b) and establishing requirements respecting such certifications.
The amounts requisitioned under this section may be paid by the Minister of Finance from the consolidated revenue fund.
If a requisition is delivered to the Surveyor of Taxes, the amount requisitioned must be collected by the Provincial government as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an amount to be recovered by means of a property value tax, by imposing the tax within the electoral participating areas in accordance with the Taxation (Rural Area) Act, having due regard to the tax base authorized under section 804.3 [tax base for property value taxes];

in the case of an amount to be recovered by means of a parcel tax, by imposing the tax on the appropriate parcels within the electoral participating areas, on the basis of the assessment roll under subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a parcel tax is to be imposed under this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the board must, by bylaw, provide for the preparation of a parcel tax roll for the service area, and for these purposes Division 4 [Parcel Taxes] of Part 7 of the Community Charter applies,
the authenticated parcel tax roll for the tax must be forwarded to the Surveyor of Taxes before February 28 in each year, and
the authenticated parcel tax roll is to be used as the basis for the tax, subject to any deletions required to reflect deletions from the supplementary roll used under the Taxation (Rural Area) Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: [Repealed 2003-3-19.]

An amount to be recovered under this section must be imposed by the Provincial government as if it were a tax under the Taxation (Rural Area) Act, and the provisions of that Act respecting assessment, levy, collection and recovery of taxes and the addition of penalty and interest on unpaid taxes apply to taxes imposed under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amounts to be paid over to regional district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On or before February 1 in each year, the amount received by a municipality, or by the Surveyor of Taxes for an electoral area, by way of a grant in place of taxes for regional district purposes within the regional district under the Payments in Lieu of Taxes Act (Canada) in the immediately preceding year must be paid to the board.

The amount received by a municipality by way of a grant in place of taxes for regional district purposes within the regional district under the Municipal Aid Act or from a Crown corporation or agency must be paid to the board promptly after receipt.
An amount paid under (2) must be applied proportionately to the accounts for the services in respect of which the grant is paid.

In this section, variable tax rate system means a system under this section by which individual tax rates for a specific taxation year are determined and imposed for each property class to which the system applies.

Despite section 806.1 [collection in electoral areas] but subject to the regulations under this section, a board may, by bylaw, establish an annual variable tax rate system for a specified taxation year.
A variable tax rate system

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may only apply to tax rates for one or more of regional district services,
may only vary tax rates for property classes 2, 4 and 5, and
must not result in the ratios between the tax rate for a property class referred to in paragraph (b) and the tax rate for property class 1 exceeding either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the applicable ratio prescribed under subsection (6), if any, or
the applicable ratio under section 20 (2) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For each service subject to a variable tax rate system, the bylaw must set out the ratio between the tax rate for each property class subject to the system and the tax rate for property class 1.
A bylaw under subsection (2) must be approved by the inspector and, for this purpose, must be submitted to the inspector by January 31 in the taxation year for which it is to apply.
Subject to subsection (8), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting variable tax rate systems, including regulations doing one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing limits on tax rates;
prescribing ratios between the tax rate for a property class and the tax rate for property class 1;
prescribing formulas for calculating the limits or ratios referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Regulations under subsection (6) may prescribe different tax limits, ratios or formulas in relation to one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different property classes;
different regional districts;
different services;
different service areas;
different types of participating areas.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regulation under subsection (6) may not prescribe a ratio for the purposes of subsection (3) (c) that would exceed the applicable ratio established under section 20 (2) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act.

Land and improvements owned or held by a regional district within the boundaries of the regional district are exempt from taxation when used for its own purposes, but otherwise are subject to taxation, as applicable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under section 229 [taxation of municipal land used by others] of the Community Charter as if the property were owned by a municipality, or
under section 18 (4) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act as if the property belonged to the Crown.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), the owner of land or improvements, or both, leased or rented to the regional district is liable for the payment of taxes that would otherwise be imposed with respect to that property under any Act.
On or before October 31 in any year, a board may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, exempt the property described in subsection (4) from taxation under this Part for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the next calendar year, or
with the assent of the electors, a specified period not longer than 10 years.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following property that is in an electoral area may be exempted from taxation under subsection (3):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land or improvements, or both, owned or held by, or held in trust by the owner for, an athletic or service organization and used principally for public athletic or recreation purposes;

land or improvements, or both, used or occupied by a church as tenant or licensee for the purpose of public worship or for the purposes of a church hall that the board considers necessary to the church;
an interest held by a non-profit organization in school buildings that the organization uses or occupies as tenant or licensee of a board of school trustees;
land that is owned and used exclusively by an agricultural or horticultural society and that is in excess of the area exemption under section 15 (1) (j) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act;
an interest held by a francophone education authority in school buildings that the francophone education authority uses or occupies as licensee of a board of school trustees;
an interest held by a non-profit organization in school buildings that the organization uses or occupies as tenant or licensee of a francophone education authority;
land or improvements that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: are owned or held by a municipality, regional district or other local authority, and
the board considers are used for a purpose of the local authority.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An exemption under subsection (3) may be limited to a specified portion of the net taxable value of the property to which the exemption applies.

If, because of a change in the use or ownership of property exempted from taxation by bylaw under subsection (4), the bylaw ceases to apply to that property and the property is liable to taxation effective from the time of the change.

Assent of the electors as required by subsection (3) (b) is obtained if, by voting conducted throughout the regional district, a majority of the votes counted as valid in all voting on the bylaw is in favour of the bylaw.
Part 4 applies to voting for the purposes of subsection (7), with voting to be conducted either, at the option of the board,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by the board throughout the regional district, or

by the council of each municipality and by the board for that part of the regional district that is not in a municipality, with the results of voting in these areas totalled to determine whether assent has been obtained.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section and section 810.1, eligible heritage property means property in an electoral area that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: protected heritage property,
subject to a heritage revitalization agreement under section 966, or
subject to a covenant under section 219 of the Land Title Act that relates to the conservation of heritage property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (3) of this section, for the purposes of supporting the conservation of an eligible heritage property, on or before October 31 in any year, a board may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempt from taxation under this Part all or part of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the eligible heritage property, and
if the eligible heritage property is a building or other improvement so affixed to the land as to constitute real property, an area of land surrounding the eligible heritage property;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: limit an exemption under paragraph (a) to a specified portion of the net taxable value of the property to which the exemption applies;
make an exemption under this subsection subject to specified conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (2) may provide a tax exemption

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the next calendar year, or
if the bylaw has received the approval of the electors, for a specified period not longer than 10 years.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the information required by section 86 (2) [alternative approval process — notice] of the subsection (3) (b) of this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify the eligible heritage property that would be subject to the bylaw, and
describe the exemption that would be made for the eligible heritage property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 30 days after adopting a bylaw under this section, the board must give notice of the bylaw to the minister responsible for the Heritage Conservation Act in accordance with section 977.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repayment requirement in relation to heritage exemptions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (2):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the eligible heritage property is destroyed, whether with or without proper authorization under the requirements of the heritage protection of the property;
if the eligible heritage property is altered by or on behalf of the owner without proper authorization under the requirements of the heritage protection of the property;
if any other circumstances specified in the bylaw occur.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount that may be required under subsection (1) is the amount equivalent to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total taxes exempted under the bylaw under section 810

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: plus

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: interest from the time at which the exempt taxes would otherwise have been payable, compounded annually at the rate referred to in section 245 [taxes in arrear] of the Community Charter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under section 810 that includes a provision under subsection (1) may only be adopted with the consent of the current owner of the eligible heritage property to which the bylaw applies.

If a bylaw under section 810 includes a provision under subsection (1), within 30 days after the bylaw is adopted, the board must have notice of the bylaw filed in the land title office, and for this purpose section 976 [notice on land titles] applies.
If a bylaw under section 810 includes a provision under subsection (1) and a circumstance specified in the provision occurs, the board may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require the owner to pay the amount referred to in subsection (2), or
waive the obligation of the owner to pay all or part of the amount referred to in subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a board does not adopt a bylaw under subsection (2).
If a board adopts a bylaw under subsection (6), the board may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require the Surveyor of Taxes to add the amount referred to in subsection (2) to the taxes payable on the eligible heritage property, in which case section 363.2 [special fees and charges that are to be collected as taxes] applies, or
make an agreement with the current owner regarding payment of the amount referred to in subsection (2) as a personal debt to the regional district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section and section 811.1:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: eligible riparian property means property that meets all the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the property must be riparian land;
the property must be subject to a covenant under section 219 of the Land Title Act that relates to the protection of the property as riparian property;
the regional district granting the exemption under this section must be a covenantee in whose favour the covenant referred to in paragraph (b) is made;
any other requirements prescribed under subsection (6);

bcl:definition.bcl:text: eligible value means the portion of the net taxable value of the parcel of land in relation to which an exemption under subsection (2) is made that is equivalent to the ratio of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area of the eligible riparian property that is exempted under subsection (2) (a)

bcl:definition.bcl:text: to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area of the parcel of land in relation to which the exemption is made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite (4) of this section, for the purposes of supporting the conservation of an eligible riparian property, on or before October 31 in any year a board may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempt all or part of the eligible riparian property from taxation under this Part;
limit an exemption under paragraph (a) to a specified portion of the eligible value of the property to which the exemption applies;
make an exemption under this subsection subject to specified conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An exemption under subsection (2) may apply only to that part of the eligible riparian property that is a riparian area.
A bylaw under subsection (2) may provide a tax exemption

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the next calendar year, or
if the bylaw has received the approval of the electors, for a specified period not greater than 10 years.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the information required by section 86 (2) [alternate approval process notice] of the subsection (4) (b) of this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify the eligible riparian property that would be subject to the bylaw, and
describe the exemption that would be made for the eligible riparian property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, establish additional requirements for property to be considered eligible riparian property.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repayment requirement in relation to riparian exemptions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under section 811 may provide that, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is a contravention of any of the conditions of the covenant under section 219 of the Land Title Act in relation to which the exemption is given,
the covenant is discharged before the end of the period of the exemption, or
any other circumstances specified in the bylaw occur,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the board may require the owner of the eligible riparian property at that time to pay to the regional district the amount referred to in subsection (2).
The amount that may be required under subsection (1) is the amount equivalent to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total taxes exempted under the bylaw under section 811

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: plus

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: interest from the time at which the exempt taxes would otherwise have been payable, compounded annually at the rate referred to in section 245 [taxes in arrear] of the Community Charter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under section 811 that includes a provision under subsection (1) may only be adopted with the consent of the owner of the eligible riparian property to which the bylaw applies.

If a bylaw under section 811 includes a provision under subsection (1), within 30 days after the bylaw is adopted the board must have notice of the bylaw filed in the land title office, and for this purpose section 976 [notice on land titles] applies.
If a bylaw under section 811 includes a provision under subsection (1) and a circumstance specified in the provision occurs, the board may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require the owner to pay the amount referred to in subsection (2), or
waive the obligation of the owner to pay all or part of the amount referred to in subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a board does not adopt a bylaw under subsection (5) (a) within one year after it becomes aware of the circumstance in relation to which the bylaw could be adopted, the board is deemed to have waived all obligation of the owner to pay the amount referred to in subsection (2).
If a board adopts a bylaw under subsection (6), the board may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require the Surveyor of Taxes to add the amount referred to in subsection (2) to the taxes payable on the eligible riparian property, in which case section 363.2 [special fees and charges that are to be collected as taxes] applies, or
make an agreement with the owner regarding payment of the amount referred to in subsection (2) as a personal debt to the regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax exemptions under a partnering agreement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, exempt from taxation under this Part, all or part of the land, improvements or both, owned or held by a party to a partnering agreement with the regional district, during all or part of the term of the agreement.
An exemption under this section may only be provided for that portion of the land or improvements used for a public purpose.

If the term of the exemption authorized in the bylaw is for greater than 5 years, or for a period that by exercising rights of renewal or extension could exceed 5 years, the bylaw may be adopted only with the approval of the electors.
An exemption under this section takes effect as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the bylaw under subsection (1) is adopted by October 31 in a year, the exemption takes effect for the following calendar year;
if the bylaw under subsection (1) is adopted after October 31 in a year, the exemption takes effect for the year following the next calendar year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, because of a change in the use or ownership of property exempted from taxation by bylaw under this section the property no longer meets the requirements for exemption, the bylaw ceases to apply to that property and the property is liable to taxation effective from the time of the change.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Dispute Resolution in Relation to Services

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: final resolution means the establishment of the terms and conditions for withdrawal from a service by an arbitrator's decision under section 813.13 [arbitration process] or 813.15 [direction to further arbitration in certain cases];
initiating participant means a participant who gave notice under section 813.04 [initiating a service review] or 813.08 [initiating service withdrawal], as applicable;
notice of withdrawal means notice under section 813.14 (1) (d) (i) [initiating participant decision to proceed with withdrawal];
service review means a review of participation in one or more services in accordance with the process under sections 813.07;
service withdrawal means proposed withdrawal from participation in one or more services in accordance with the process under sections 813.19.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may appoint facilitators for the purposes of this Division, whose responsibilities are to monitor service reviews and service withdrawals, and to assist the parties in reaching agreement in those processes, by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: facilitating negotiations,
facilitating resolution of issues, and
assisting in setting up and using mediation or other non-binding resolution processes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On receiving a notice under subsection (1) as the facilitator responsible to assist the parties in relation to the matter.
Subject to subsection (1) if requested to do so by a party.
The authority for the facilitator to provide assistance in relation to a service withdrawal ends at the time an arbitration referred to in section 813.13 begins.

Once a facilitator becomes involved under this section, the parties must provide information as requested by the facilitator and must otherwise cooperate with the facilitator in fulfilling his or her responsibilities.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Parties to a service review or service withdrawal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The parties to a service review or service withdrawal are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the initiating participant,
any other participant in the service, and
the board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The representatives for the parties to a service review or service withdrawal are the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a municipal participating area,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a council member appointed by the council, or
if no appointment is made, the mayor;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an electoral participating area, the director of the electoral area;
in the case of the board,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a director appointed by the board, or
if no appointment is made, the chair.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board and any municipal participant may make an appointment referred to in subsection (2) and, if this is done, must notify the other parties as to the person who is to be their representative in the service review or service withdrawal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Costs of service review or service withdrawal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Costs incurred by a party in respect of their own participation in a service review or service withdrawal may only be recovered as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of costs incurred by a municipal participant, the costs must be recovered from the municipal participating area on the same basis as other costs of the service are recovered from that participating area;

in the case of costs incurred by an electoral area participant, the costs are deemed to be costs of the service and must be recovered from the participating area on the same basis as other costs of the service are recovered from that participating area;

in the case of costs incurred by the board, the costs are deemed to be costs of the service and must be apportioned and recovered from the service area on the same basis as other costs of the service.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise agreed by the parties to a service review or service withdrawal or, in the case of arbitration, unless otherwise directed by the arbitrator,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the fees of any mediator or arbitrator engaged to conduct or participate in the process, other than the fees of a facilitator under section 813.01 [minister may appoint facilitators],
the administrative costs of the process, other than costs incurred by the parties in respect of their own participation in the process, and
any other costs with respect to the service review or service withdrawal that are not costs referred to in subsection (1)

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: are deemed to be costs of the service and must be recovered in accordance with subsection (3).
The costs to be recovered under subsection (2) must be assigned, apportioned and recovered as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a service review that dealt with only one service, the costs must be apportioned between and recovered from the participating areas on the same basis as other costs of the service;
in the case of a service review that dealt with more than one service, the costs must be

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: assigned proportionately between the services under review at the time those costs were incurred, on the basis of the relative expenditures provided for the services in the previous year's financial plan, and
for each service, apportioned and recovered in accordance with paragraph (a);

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a service withdrawal that dealt with only one service, subject to a regulation under subsection (4), the costs must be

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: assigned proportionally between the service area and the participating area for the initiating participant, on the basis of the converted value of land and improvements in those areas,
for costs assigned to the service area, apportioned and recovered in accordance with paragraph (a), and
for costs assigned to the initiating participant, recovered on the same basis that other costs of the service are recovered from the participating area;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a service withdrawal that dealt with more than one service, subject to a regulation under subsection (4), the costs must be

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: assigned proportionately between the services under review at the time those costs were incurred, on the basis of the relative expenditures provided for the services in the previous year's financial plan, and
for each service, assigned, apportioned and recovered in accordance with paragraph (c).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations providing how costs are to be assigned under subsection (3) (c) and (d) in cases where there is more than one initiating participant.
A participant may initiate a service review under this Division if all the following circumstances apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the participant has been a participant in the service for at least 5 years or, if applicable, the shorter time period provided in the establishing bylaw for the service;
the service has not been subject to a service review that was initiated within the past 3 years;
the establishing bylaw does not include provisions under section 800.2 (1) (c.2) establishing an alternative review process;
the participant considers that the terms and conditions of participation in the service are not satisfactory.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To initiate a service review, a participant must give written notice to the board, all other participants in the service and the minister.
The notice under subsection (2) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describe the terms and conditions of participation in the service that the participant finds unsatisfactory,
give reasons, relating to those terms and conditions, as to why the participant wishes to initiate the service review, and
describe how the participant has previously attempted to resolve the issues.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant who wishes to initiate service reviews for more than one service must give separate notice under this section for each service.

In the case of a service review in relation to the exercise of authority under letters patent, the minister may determine what is to be considered a separate service under that authority for the purposes of this Division.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Other issues and services may be dealt with in one service review

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following issues may be addressed by a service review:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the issues raised by the notice under section 813.04 [initiating a service review];
any other issue respecting the service raised by a party at a preliminary meeting under section 813.06 [preliminary meeting];
if the other parties agree, an issue respecting the service raised by a party after the preliminary meeting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the issues under subsection (1), if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the same time or after the service review is initiated, another service review is initiated by notice under section 813.04 [initiating a service review] in respect of the same or another service,
the other parties to the initial service review agree, and
if applicable, any participants in the other service who are not parties to the initial service review also agree,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the service reviews may be combined and dealt with in the same service review.
Within 120 days after receiving a notice under section 813.04 [initiating a service review], the board must arrange a preliminary meeting of all party representatives for the purpose of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: reviewing the terms and conditions of the service, and
establishing a negotiation process for addressing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the issues raised in the notice, and
any other issues raised by a party during the meeting,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with a view to reaching an agreement on the negotiation process and the issues to be addressed in the negotiations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a facilitator has been designated under section 813.01 [minister may appoint facilitator], the board must give notice of the preliminary meeting to the facilitator.
The requirement for a meeting under subsection (1) does not apply to a service review that is combined under section 813.05 with another service review that was previously initiated.

Within 60 days after the preliminary meeting under section 813.06 [preliminary meeting] was convened, or the first such meeting was convened if there is more than one, the parties must begin negotiations for the purpose of reaching agreement on the relevant issues.
All parties must negotiate in good faith, making reasonable efforts to reach an agreement respecting the issues being addressed in the service review.
At any time after receiving a notice under section 813.04 [initiating a service review], the minister may specify a time period within which the parties must conclude negotiations.
The minister may extend a time period established under subsection (3) before or after it has expired.
A participant may initiate service withdrawal if all the following circumstances apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the service has been subject to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a service review that was initiated within the past 3 years, or
an alternative review process in accordance with establishing bylaw provisions under section 800.2 (1) (c.2) that was started within the past 3 years;
the first meeting respecting the review, which in the case of a service review is the first preliminary meeting under section 813.06 [preliminary meeting], was convened more than 8 months ago;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the service is not

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a service referred to in section 800 (2) [services for which no establishing bylaw required],
a regulatory service, or
a service prescribed under subsection (5).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A participant may initiate service withdrawal under this Division even if the establishing bylaw provides terms and conditions for withdrawal under section 800.2 (1) (d).
To initiate service withdrawal, a participant must give written notice to the board, all other participants in the service and the minister.
The notice under subsection (3) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describe the terms and conditions of participation in the service that the participant finds unsatisfactory, and
give reasons, relating to those terms and conditions, as to why the participant wishes to withdraw from the service.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite Division 4.1 of this Part or the establishing bylaw, at any time after receiving a notice under subsection (3) of this section, the minister may determine that a part of the service must be considered a separate service for the purposes of sections 813.09 to 813.19.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations excluding services from withdrawal under this Division.
Regulations under subsection (5) may be different for different regional districts and different circumstances.
After receiving a notice under section 813.10, the minister must do one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the establishing bylaw provides an alternative review process and the minister considers that agreement may be reached by a service review under this Division, terminate the service withdrawal and direct the parties to engage in a service review;
direct the parties to engage in further negotiations respecting continued participation in the service, specifying a time period within which the parties must conclude negotiations;
direct the parties to engage in negotiations respecting the terms and conditions for withdrawal, specifying a time period within which the parties must conclude negotiations;
direct the parties to engage in mediation under section 813.12 [mediation] respecting the terms and conditions for withdrawal, specifying a time period within which the mediation must be concluded;

if satisfied that agreement is unlikely under paragraph (a), (a.1), (b) or (c), direct that the terms and conditions for withdrawal from the service be resolved by arbitration under section 813.13 [arbitration].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may extend a time period established under subsection (1) (a.1), (b) or (c) before or after it has expired.
If no agreement is reached from negotiations under subsection (1) (b) to (d).
If no agreement is reached from negotiations under subsection (1) (c) or (d).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Addition of further initiating participants or further services

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, at the same time or after a service withdrawal is initiated, the minister receives another notice under section 813.08 [initiating service withdrawal] respecting the same or any other service of the same regional district,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a service withdrawal that is in negotiation under section 813.09 (1) (b) or mediation under section 813.12, the minister may direct that the matter be dealt with as part of the initial service withdrawal, and

in the case of a service withdrawal that is in arbitration under section 813.13, the minister must refer the matter to the arbitrator who may direct that it be dealt with as part of the initial service withdrawal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before making a direction under subsection (1), the minister or arbitrator must consult with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the parties in the initial service withdrawal,
if applicable, the mediator, and
if applicable, any participants in the other service who are not parties to the initial service withdrawal.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A service withdrawal may be ended at any stage of the process

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by agreement between the parties,
if there is only one notice under section 813.08 [initiating service withdrawal] in respect of the process, at the option of the initiating participant, or
if there is more than one notice under section 813.08 [initiating service withdrawal] in respect of the process, by agreement between the initiating participants.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If mediation is directed under section 813.09 (1) (c) [minister's direction on process], the mediator must be selected

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by agreement between the parties, or
if the minister considers that the parties will not be able to reach agreement, by the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The mediation is to be a process of negotiation by the parties, undertaken with the assistance of a neutral and impartial person, for the purpose of reaching a mutually acceptable resolution of the relevant issues.
The mediator must give notice to the minister when the mediation is concluded.

Subject to subsection (5), if agreement on the terms and conditions for withdrawal is not reached during the mediation or within 60 days after the mediation is concluded, the terms and conditions for withdrawing from the service must be resolved by arbitration under section 813.13 [arbitration].
The minister may extend the time period under subsection (4) before or after it has expired.
If agreement in relation to service withdrawal cannot otherwise be reached under this Division, the terms and conditions for withdrawal must be resolved before a single arbitrator by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: final proposal arbitration in accordance with subsection (4), or
full arbitration in accordance with subsection (5).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The choice of process under subsection (1) (a) or (b) is to be determined by agreement between the parties but, if the minister considers that they will not be able to reach agreement, the minister must direct which procedure is to be used.
The arbitrator is to be selected from a list prepared by the minister in consultation with the Union of British Columbia Municipalities, and is to be selected

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by agreement between the parties, or
if the minister considers that the parties will not be able to reach agreement, by the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to any regulations under section 813.19, the following apply to final proposal arbitration under this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the arbitrator must conduct the proceedings on the basis of a review of written documents and written submissions only, and must determine each disputed issue by selecting one of the final written proposals submitted by the parties respecting that issue;
in making a determination under paragraph (a), the arbitrator must consider any terms and conditions established under section 800.2 (1) (d) [establishing bylaw provisions respecting withdrawal];
the terms and conditions for service withdrawal must be resolved by the arbitrator after incorporation of the final proposals selected under paragraph (a) in respect of each issue;
no written reasons are to be provided by the arbitrator.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to any regulations under section 813.19, the following apply to full arbitration under this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the arbitrator may conduct the proceedings at the times and in the manner he or she determines;
the arbitrator must consider any terms and conditions referred to in section 800.2 (1) (d) [establishing bylaw provisions respecting withdrawal];
the terms and conditions for service withdrawal must be resolved by the arbitrator, who is not restricted in his or her decision to submissions made by the parties on the disputed issues;

for an arbitration involving more than one initiating participant, the final resolution may establish different terms and conditions for service withdrawal depending on which participants decide to withdraw under the final resolution;
the arbitrator must give written reasons for the decision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Arbitration Act does not apply to arbitration under this Division.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Initiating participant must respond to final resolution

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within one year after final resolution under subsection (2) of this section, each initiating participant must do one of the following and must notify the minister and board as to whichever applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: agree to continue as a participant on the current terms and conditions;
agree with the board and the other participants on new terms and conditions for continued participation in the service;
agree with the board and the other participants on terms and conditions for withdrawal that differ from the final resolution;
seek approval in accordance with subsection (4) regarding withdrawal from the service in accordance with the final resolution and, as applicable,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if that approval is obtained and the participant decides to proceed with withdrawal, agree to withdraw from the service in accordance with the final resolution, or
if that approval is not obtained, or the approval is obtained but the participant decides not to proceed with withdrawal, agree to continue as a participant on the current terms and conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may extend the time period under subsection (1) before or after it has expired.

If the board and the participants do not adopt the bylaws and take the other actions required to implement an agreement referred to in subsection (1) (a) unless it has given notice of withdrawal before the end of that period.
Approval required under subsection (1) (d) is obtained by one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assent of the electors in the participating area in accordance with section 801.2 [approval by assent of the electors];
in the case of a service referred to in section 801.3 (1) [approval by alternative approval process], by approval in accordance with that section;

in the case of a municipal participating area that is all of the municipality, consent given on behalf of the electors in accordance with section 801.4 [consent on behalf of municipal participating area].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the service withdrawal is related to more than one service,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: approval must be sought in respect of all services considered together, which are deemed to be a single matter requiring approval,
approval under subsection (4) (b) may only be used if each of the services are services referred to in section 801.3 (1) (a) or (b) [approval by alternative approval process], and
approval under subsection (4) (c) may only be used if the municipal participating area for each of the services is all of the municipality.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Direction to further arbitration in certain cases

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister must direct that a new arbitration under section 813.13 [arbitration] be undertaken, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a service withdrawal involved more than one initiating participant,
only some of the initiating participants give notice of withdrawal, and
the final resolution does not include applicable provisions under section 813.13 (5) (d) [arbitration — separate terms and conditions].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of arbitration under subsection (1), the participants who gave the notice of withdrawal are deemed to be the initiating participants.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A final resolution becomes binding on all parties as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a service withdrawal involving only one initiating participant, if the initiating participant gives notice of withdrawal, the final resolution becomes binding when that notice is given;

in the case of a service withdrawal involving more than one initiating participant, if all initiating participants give notice of withdrawal, the final resolution becomes binding when the last of these notices is given;
in the case of a service withdrawal involving more than one initiating participant, if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: one or more initiating participants give notice of withdrawal, and
the final resolution includes applicable provisions under section 813.13 (5) (d) [arbitration — separate terms and conditions],

bcl:section.bcl:text: the applicable provisions of the final resolution become binding when all of the initiating participants have given notice under section 813.14 (1) (a) or (d) or at the end of the time period under that section, whichever is earlier.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Implementation of final resolution by bylaw

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board and the participants must adopt the bylaws and take the other actions required to implement the terms and conditions of a final resolution within 90 days after it becomes binding under section 813.16 [when arbitrator's decision becomes binding].
Despite any other provision of this Act, approval of the electors is not required for a bylaw referred to in subsection (1).
The minister may extend the time period under subsection (1) before or after it has expired.

If the board or a municipal participant does not adopt the bylaws required under section 813.17 [implementation by bylaw], on the recommendation of the minister, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by order, implement the terms and conditions of the final resolution.
An order under subsection (1) is deemed to be a bylaw of the applicable local government.
The minister may make regulations respecting arbitrations under this Division and, without limiting this, may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting matters that an arbitrator must or may consider;
respecting the authority of an arbitrator to resolve the terms and conditions for withdrawing from a regional district service;
respecting the authority of an arbitrator to require the cooperation of local governments and electoral area directors in relation to the arbitration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Regulations under this section may be different for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: final proposal arbitration, full arbitration and arbitration directed under section 813.15 [direction to further arbitration in certain cases],
different regional districts, and
different circumstances.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The regional district financial officer must keep separate financial records for each service that include full particulars of assets and liabilities, revenues and expenditures, information concerning reserve funds and other pertinent financial details.
The fiscal year for a regional district is the calendar year.
The following provisions of the Community Charter apply to regional districts:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 167 [annual financial statements];
section 168 [reporting of council remuneration, expenses and contracts];
section 183 [investment of municipal funds];
Division 2 of Part 6 [Audit];
Division 4 of Part 6 [Reserve Funds];
Division 5 of Part 6 [Restrictions on Use of Municipal Funds].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In relation to the application of Division 4 [Reserve Funds] of Part 6 of the Community Charter,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the provisions apply as though each service were the only service provided by the regional district,
all accounting and other matters relating to a reserve fund must be kept separate for each service, and

a board may adopt a bylaw under section 189 (3) [reserve fund used in relation to expropriation or damage to property] of the section 311 [entry on land to mitigate damage] of this Act, but only with the approval of the inspector.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (4) (a) and (b), section 189 (4.1) and (4.2) of the Community Charter [use of money in a reserve fund for the purposes of another reserve fund] applies to reserve funds established by a board for capital purposes for the same service or for different services.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Annual reporting on regional district finances

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: By June 30 in each year, a regional district must hold a board meeting or other public meeting for the purpose of presenting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the audited financial statements of the preceding year, and
the report under section 168 [reporting of remuneration, expenses and contracts] of the Community Charter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board must give notice of the meeting by publication in a newspaper, including

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date, time and place of the meeting, and
a statement that the financial statements and any reports to be presented at the meeting are available for inspection at the regional district offices.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A copy of the financial statements and reports must be available for public inspection at the regional district offices during their regular office hours from the time the notice under subsection (2) is given until June 30 in the following year.
A regional district must have a financial plan that is adopted annually, by bylaw, by March 31.
For certainty, the financial plan may be amended by bylaw at any time.
The planning period for a financial plan is 5 years, that period being the year in which the plan is specified to come into force and the following 4 years.
The financial plan must set out the following for each year of the planning period, shown separately for each service:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proposed expenditures for the service;
the proposed funding sources for the service;
the proposed transfers between funds in respect of the service.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For any year, the total of the proposed expenditures and transfers to other funds in respect of a service must not exceed the total of the proposed funding sources and transfers from other funds for the service.
The proposed expenditures for a service must set out separate amounts for each of the following as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount required to pay interest and principal on regional district debt;
the amount required for capital purposes;
the amount required for a deficiency referred to in subsection (11);
the amount required for other purposes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The proposed funding sources for a service must set out separate amounts for each of the following as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: revenue from property value taxes;
revenue from parcel taxes;
revenue from fees and charges;
revenue from other sources;
proceeds from borrowing, other than borrowing under section 821 [revenue anticipation borrowing].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The proposed transfers between funds in respect of a service must set out separate amounts for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: reserve funds, and
accumulated surplus.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a limit on expenditures, the amounts that may be included in a financial plan as expenditures respecting assistance to be apportioned under section 804 (2) (g) [assistance other than under a partnering agreement] must not, in total, exceed the amount that would be obtained by a tax of 10¢ per $1 000 on the net taxable value of land and improvements in the regional district.
As a limit on revenues,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if subsection (7) (a) and (b) for the service must not exceed the maximum amount set under that section, and
