bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Temporary protection under section 957 (5):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the day after a report of the results of the heritage inspection is delivered to a regular meeting of the local government;
the day the local government or its delegate informs the owner that the heritage inspection is completed or is no longer required;
30 days after the day on which the heritage inspection was ordered.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not interfere with the conducting of a heritage inspection.

A person conducting a heritage inspection may perform tests and remove material samples that are necessary for the purposes of the heritage inspection, but must do this in such a manner that any alterations are as minor and inconspicuous as reasonably possible given the requirements of the heritage inspection.
On completion of a heritage inspection, the local government must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notify the owner of the property that a heritage inspection has been conducted, if the owner was not notified of the heritage inspection before the heritage inspection, and
make a report to the owner of what was done if, as a part of a heritage inspection, an alteration is made or material is removed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person whose property is damaged by a heritage inspection under subsection (1) is entitled to have the damage repaired at the expense of the local government or, if the damage cannot be repaired, to compensation from the local government.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Entry authority for a heritage inspection

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order under section 956 (1) authorizes a person conducting the heritage inspection to enter land or premises identified in the order at any reasonable time for the purposes of the heritage inspection.

Before or when entering land under subsection (1), the person conducting the heritage inspection or heritage investigation must make a reasonable attempt to notify the owner or occupier of the land and, if requested, present a copy of the order to the owner or occupier.
Except as provided in section 956 authorizes entry into a building without the permission of the owner or occupier.
A justice may issue a warrant authorizing a person to enter land or a building to conduct a heritage inspection ordered under section 956 (1) if the justice is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there are reasonable grounds to believe that entry is required to achieve the purposes of the heritage inspection, and
there are reasonable grounds to believe that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an emergency exists,
the person conducting the heritage inspection or heritage investigation has been unable to notify the owner or occupier after making a reasonable attempt to do so,
admission has been refused or refusal is anticipated, or
notification may defeat the object of the entry.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A warrant under section 956 (2) (d) and continues in force until the purpose for which the entry is required has been satisfied.
If a heritage inspection is conducted under a warrant under subsection (4), the person conducting the heritage inspection must be accompanied by a peace officer.

If, in the opinion of the local government or its delegate, an approval may affect protected heritage property, the local government or delegate may require the applicant for the approval, before the approval is issued,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to provide the local government or delegate, at the expense of the applicant, with information regarding the possible effects that the activity or action enabled by the approval may have on the heritage property, or

to permit the local government or delegate to undertake, at the expense of the local government, studies regarding the matters referred to in paragraph (a) provided that those studies are undertaken promptly.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A requirement under subsection (1) must be communicated to the applicant in writing and include specifications of the information to be provided and of the qualifications of any persons undertaking studies to produce the information.
Specifications referred to in subsection (2) must not be changed by the local government or its delegate without the agreement of the applicant.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Local government requests for Provincial protection

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, in the opinion of a local government, real property owned by the Provincial government has heritage value or heritage character, the local government may, by resolution, request that Provincial protection be provided for the property.
Within 5 days after a resolution under subsection (1) is adopted, the local government must convey the resolution to the minister responsible for the Heritage Conservation Act.

Once a request has been made under subsection (1), the property for which the protection is requested is subject to temporary protection in accordance with section 965 until the earlier of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the end of 30 days after the resolution authorizing the request was adopted;
the minister responsible for the Heritage Conservation Act notifies the local government in writing that the temporary protection is ended.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 14 (2) of the subsection (3) applies to the Provincial government.
No more than one request may be made under subsection (1) with respect to any particular building, structure or site during any one 10 year period.

A local government may, by bylaw, direct or authorize the officers or employees of the local government who issue approvals to withhold the issuance of any approval for an action that, in the opinion of the person responsible for issuing the approval, would alter or cause an alteration to any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: protected heritage property;
property subject to temporary heritage protection under another section of this Part;
property in a community heritage register.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (1) may establish restrictions, limits or conditions on the duty or power to withhold approvals.
If an approval is withheld under subsection (1), the matter must be referred to the local government at its next regular meeting after the approval is withheld.

If an approval is referred to the local government with regard to property referred to in subsection (1) (a) or (b), the local government may authorize that the approval continue to be withheld until an action referred to in subsection (5) occurs.
An approval must not be withheld under this section if one or more of the following occurs:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a heritage alteration permit is issued authorizing the alteration to which the approval applies;

the applicant agrees to terms and conditions satisfactory to the local government or its delegate to prevent or mitigate circumstances that may detract from the heritage value or heritage character of the property;
in the case of property subject to temporary heritage protection, the protection expires;

in the case of property that appears to the person responsible for issuing the approval to be protected under the Heritage Conservation Act, the local government is notified by the minister responsible for that Act that the requirements of that Act have been met or do not apply.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided in subsection (3).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Withholding of demolition permits until other approvals issued

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting section 960, a local government may, by bylaw, direct or authorize the officers or employees of the local government who issue permits for demolition to withhold approval for demolition in the following circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of protected heritage property, until a heritage alteration permit and any other necessary approvals have been issued with respect to alteration or redevelopment of the site;

in the case of real property identified in a community heritage register established under section 954, until a building permit and any other necessary approvals have been issued with respect to the alteration or redevelopment of the site.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may establish restrictions, limits or conditions on a duty or power under subsection (1).
Nothing in this section authorizes the withholding of any approvals other than permits for demolition of heritage property.
A local government may order that real property is subject to temporary protection in accordance with section 965 if the local government considers that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the property is or may be heritage property, or
protection of the property may be necessary or desirable for the conservation of other property that is heritage property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must specify the time period during which the temporary protection applies, which time period may not be longer than 60 days unless the owner of the property agrees to a longer time period, and
must not be made more than once in a 2 year period without the agreement of the owner of the property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order under subsection (1) may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify landscape features that are subject to the order;
specify types of alterations to property that are allowed without obtaining a heritage alteration permit;
establish policies regarding the issuance of a heritage alteration permit in relation to the property.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Temporary protection by introduction of a continuing protection bylaw

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For a period of 120 days beginning on the date of first reading of a bylaw to adopt an official community plan that designates a heritage conservation area, section 971 (1) applies to all properties in the area as if the bylaw had already been adopted.
For a period of 60 days beginning on the date of the first reading of a heritage designation bylaw, section 967 (3) applies as if the heritage designation bylaw had already been adopted.

If the owner of property to which subsection (2) applies agrees, the local government may, by bylaw, extend the protection referred to in that subsection for a specified period longer than the 60 days referred to in that subsection.

If the issue of compensation for designation is submitted to arbitration under section 969 before the heritage designation bylaw is adopted, the time period under subsection (2) is extended by the time between the submission of the matter to arbitration and the delivery of the arbitration report to the local government.
If a local government defeats or decides not to proceed with a bylaw, the protection under this section ends.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Heritage control periods for temporary protection

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of heritage conservation planning for an area identified in the bylaw, a local government may, by bylaw, declare a heritage control period with respect to the area.
A bylaw under subsection (1) must specify the length of the heritage control period, which period may not be longer than one year from the date of adoption of the bylaw.
A bylaw under subsection (1) may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify types of landscape features that are included in the protection under this section;
specify types of alterations to property that are allowed without obtaining a heritage alteration permit;
establish policies regarding the issuance of a heritage alteration permit in relation to property within the area covered by the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During a heritage control period under subsection (1), property within the area covered by the bylaw is subject to temporary protection in accordance with section 965.
A heritage control period under this section may be declared once only during any 10 year period for an area or portion of an area.

While property is subject to temporary protection in accordance with this Division, except as authorized by a heritage alteration permit or as referred to in subsection (2), a person must not do any of the following to the property:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: alter the exterior of a building or structure;
make a structural change to a building or structure;
move a building or structure;
alter, move or take an action that would damage a fixture or feature identified in the authorizing resolution, order or bylaw for the temporary protection;
alter, excavate or build on the property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The prohibition under subsection (1) does not apply to alterations that are, by the authorizing resolution, bylaw or order for the temporary protection, allowed to be made without a heritage alteration permit.
A local government may, by bylaw, enter into a heritage revitalization agreement under this section with the owner of heritage property.
A heritage revitalization agreement may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: include provisions regarding the phasing and timing of the commencement and completion of actions required by the agreement;
vary or supplement provisions of one or more of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a bylaw under Division 7, 10 or 11 of Part 26;
a permit under Division 9 of Part 26;
a bylaw or heritage alteration permit under this Part;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: include other terms and conditions that may be agreed on by the local government and the owner.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A heritage revitalization agreement prevails over a bylaw or permit referred to in subsection (2) (b) to the extent of any conflict.
A heritage revitalization agreement may only be amended by bylaw with the consent of the owner.

A local government must not require an owner to enter into or consent to the amendment of a heritage revitalization agreement as a condition of issuing any permit, licence or other authorization that may be required to enable the heritage property to be used or developed in accordance with the applicable bylaws.
A local government must not enter into or amend a heritage revitalization agreement unless the agreement or amendment is approved as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by the minister responsible for the administration of the Transportation Act;
by the minister, if circumstances prescribed under subsection (7) apply.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may, by regulation, prescribe circumstances in which approval under subsection (6) (c) is required.

Before entering into or amending a heritage revitalization agreement, a local government must hold a public hearing on the matter if the agreement or amendment would permit a change to the use or density of use that is not otherwise authorized by the applicable zoning of the property and, for these purposes, sections 890 to 894 apply.
Despite section 135 [requirements for passing bylaws] of the subsection (8), the local government may adopt the bylaw under this section at the same meeting at which the bylaw passed third reading.
Within 30 days after entering into or amending a heritage revitalization agreement, the local government must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a notice in the land title office in accordance with section 976, and
give notice to the minister responsible for the Heritage Conservation Act in accordance with section 977.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a notice is filed under subsection (9) (a), the heritage revitalization agreement and any amendment to it is binding on all persons who acquire an interest in the land affected by the agreement.
A local government may, by bylaw, on terms and conditions it considers appropriate, designate real property in whole or in part as protected under this section if the local government considers that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the property has heritage value or heritage character, or
designation of the property is necessary or desirable for the conservation of a protected heritage property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A heritage designation bylaw may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: apply to a single property or to part of a property;
apply to more than one property, including properties owned by different persons;
apply to affixed interior building features or fixtures identified in the bylaw;
apply to landscape features identified in the bylaw;
establish policies or procedures regarding the provision of financial or other support for the conservation of the heritage property;
specify types of alterations to the property that are allowed without a heritage alteration permit;
establish policies regarding the issuance of heritage alteration permits in relation to property covered by the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as authorized by a heritage alteration permit or allowed under subsection (2) (f), a person must not do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: alter the exterior of a building or structure protected under this section;
make a structural change to a building or structure protected under this section;
move a building or structure protected under this section;
alter, remove or take an action that would damage an interior feature or fixture that is identified under subsection (2) (c);
alter, remove or take an action that would damage a landscape feature that is identified under subsection (2) (d);
alter, excavate or build on land protected under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before a heritage designation bylaw is adopted, the local government must hold a public hearing on the proposed bylaw for the purpose of allowing affected parties and the general public to make representations respecting matters contained in the proposed bylaw.
Sections 890 (2) to (3.1) and (5) to (9), 891 and 894 apply with respect to the public hearing and enactment of the heritage designation bylaw.
At least 10 days before the public hearing, a notice in the prescribed form must be given in accordance with section 974 to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all persons who, according to the records of the land title office, have a registered interest in real property that would be designated, and
all occupiers of real property that would be designated.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice in the prescribed form must also be published in at least 2 consecutive issues of a newspaper, with the last publication to be at least 3 days but not more than 10 days before the public hearing.
The local government must have a report prepared regarding the property to be designated that includes information respecting the following matters:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the heritage value or heritage character of the property;
the compatibility of conservation with the official community plan and any other community planning objectives in the area in which the property is located;
the compatibility of conservation with lawful uses of the property and adjoining lands;
the condition and economic viability of the property;
the possible need for financial or other support to enable appropriate conservation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At least 10 days before the public hearing, the report under subsection (5) must be available for public inspection at the local government office during its regular office hours.

No heritage designation bylaw is invalid for inadvertent and minor non-compliance with this section or Division 6 of this Part, or for an error or omission in the report required under subsection (5).

Within 30 days after a local government adopts or defeats a heritage designation bylaw or determines not to proceed with the bylaw, the local government must give notice of this in the prescribed form to the owners entitled to notice under subsection (3) (a).
Within 30 days after adopting a heritage designation bylaw, the local government must give notice of this

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to the land title office in accordance with section 976, and
to the minister responsible for the Heritage Conservation Act in accordance with section 977.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a designation by a heritage designation bylaw causes, or will cause at the time of designation, a reduction in the market value of the designated property, the local government must compensate an owner of the designated property who makes an application under subsection (4).
The owner of a designated property may apply to the local government for compensation for the reduction in the market value of the designated property.
An application under subsection (2)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be made, in order for the owner to be entitled to compensation under this section, no later than one year after the heritage designation bylaw is adopted, and
may be made before the heritage designation bylaw is adopted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the local government and an owner are unable to agree

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the owner is entitled to compensation, or
on the amount or form of compensation,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: then either the local government or the owner may require the matter to be determined by binding arbitration under the Arbitration Act.
An arbitration under this section must be by a single arbitrator unless the local government and the owner agree to the appointment of an arbitration panel.
The arbitrator or arbitration panel, in determining whether the owner is entitled to compensation and the amount or form of compensation, must consider

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: financial and other support available for conservation of the designated property, and
any other benefits that are available because of the designation of the property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Compensation must not be paid, and an arbitration must not continue, if the local government defeats, or decides not to proceed with, the designation bylaw.

Nothing in this section authorizes the local government to give any financial or other benefit to an owner except that which is commensurate with the reduction in the market value of the designated property caused by that designation.

This section does not apply with respect to property that, immediately before the adoption of the heritage designation bylaw, is already designated under a heritage designation bylaw or under section 9 of the Heritage Conservation Act.
A local government may, by bylaw, establish minimum standards for the maintenance of real property that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: designated as protected by a heritage designation bylaw, or
within a heritage conservation area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Different standards may be established under subsection (1) for different areas or for different types or classes of property.
For the purposes of heritage conservation, an official community plan may designate an area as a heritage conservation area to which section 971 (1) applies.
If a heritage conservation area is designated under subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the official community plan must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: describe the special features or characteristics that justify the designation, and
state the objectives of the designation, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: either the official community plan or a zoning bylaw must specify guidelines respecting the manner by which the objectives are to be achieved.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a heritage conservation area is designated under subsection (1), the official community plan may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specify conditions under which section 971 (1) does not apply to property within the area, which may be different for different properties or classes of properties;
include a schedule listing buildings, structures, land or features within the area that are to be protected heritage property under this Act;
for the purposes of section 971 (3), identify features or characteristics that contribute to the heritage value or heritage character of the area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At least 10 days before the public hearing on an official community plan that includes a schedule under subsection (3) (b), the local government must give notice in accordance with section 974 to the owner of each property that is to be included in the schedule, unless the property was already included in the schedule.
Within 30 days after the adoption of a bylaw that includes a property in or deletes a property from a schedule under subsection (3) (b) to an official community plan, the local government must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a notice in the land title office in accordance with section 976, and
give notice to the minister responsible for the section 977.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an official community plan designates a heritage conservation area, a person must not do any of the following unless a heritage alteration permit authorizing the action has been issued:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subdivide land within the area;
start the construction of a building or structure or an addition to an existing building or structure within the area;
alter a building or structure or land within the area;
alter a feature that is protected heritage property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply if conditions established under section 970.1 (3) (a) apply.
If a heritage alteration permit is required by subsection (1), a delegate may only act in relation to such a permit if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the property is protected heritage property, or
the permit relates to a feature or characteristic identified under section 970.1 (3) (c).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government or its delegate may issue a heritage alteration permit authorizing alterations or other actions if the authorization is required by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this Act or by a bylaw or order under this Act,
a heritage revitalization agreement, or
a covenant under section 219 of the Land Title Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The heritage alteration permit may, in relation to protected heritage property or property within a heritage conservation area, vary or supplement provisions of one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a bylaw under Division 7, 10 or 11 of Part 26;
a permit under Division 9 of Part 26;
a bylaw or heritage alteration permit under this Part.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A permit issued under this section prevails over a bylaw or permit referred to in subsection (2) to the extent of any conflict.
The following restrictions apply to subsection (2):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the use or density of use may not be varied;
a flood plain specification under section 910 (2) may not be varied;
in relation to property within a heritage conservation area, the permit must be in accordance with the guidelines established under section 970.1 (2) (b) for the heritage conservation area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government or its delegate may refuse to issue a heritage alteration permit for an action that, in the opinion of the local government or delegate, would not be consistent with the purpose of the heritage protection of the property.

If the refusal to issue a heritage alteration permit prevents the use of land that is allowed under the applicable zoning bylaw or the development of land to the density that is allowed under the applicable zoning bylaw in respect of that permitted use, the local government or delegate must inform the applicant of the requirements or conditions under which a use or density proposed by the applicant in accordance with section 948 (3) would be allowed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirements and conditions in a heritage alteration permit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A heritage alteration permit may be made subject to the terms, requirements and conditions that the local government or its delegate considers consistent with the purpose of the heritage protection of the property.
Without limiting subsection (1), a heritage alteration permit may include one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: conditions respecting the sequence and timing of construction;
conditions respecting the character of the alteration or action to be authorized, including landscaping and the siting, form, exterior design and finish of buildings and structures;

if the permit is required by this Part or a bylaw or order under this Part, a requirement that the applicant provide a specified amount of security, in a form satisfactory to the local government, to guarantee the performance of the terms, requirements and conditions of the permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Interest earned on security under subsection (2) (c) becomes part of the amount of the security.

If a local government considers that the holder of a heritage alteration permit has contravened or failed to comply with a term, requirement or condition of the permit, the local government may undertake and complete the works required to satisfy the term, requirement or condition, or to ameliorate the effects of the contravention or noncompliance, at the cost of the holder of the permit.

The local government may recover the cost of the work undertaken under subsection (4) and the cost of incidental expenses incurred by the local government by applying the security provided under subsection (2) (c) in payment for the cost of the works and incidental expenses, with any excess to be returned to the holder of the permit.

If there is no security deposit or the amount of security is insufficient, the local government may add the cost of works undertaken and incidental expenses, or the remaining costs, to the taxes payable to the local government with respect to the property for the year in which the work is performed.

When a permit lapses or the actions it authorizes are completed, the local government must, subject to subsection (5), return any security provided under subsection (2) (c) to the person who provided it.

If a local government delegates the power to require security under subsection (2) (c), the delegation bylaw must include guidelines for the delegate as to how the amount of security is to be determined.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Giving notice to owners and occupiers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any notice required to be given to an owner or occupier under section 970.1 (4) [designation of heritage conservation area] or this Part must be given to the owner or occupier in accordance with this section.
A notice to an owner is sufficiently given to the owner if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is served personally on the owner,
it is sent by registered mail, or by a method of delivery that provides proof of delivery, to the person's actual or last known address,
in the circumstances described in subsection (4), it is published in accordance with that subsection, or
it is given as authorized by regulation under section 978.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice to an occupier is sufficiently given to the occupier if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the notice is given individually to each occupier in accordance with subsection (2), or
the notice is posted on or near the property in accordance with section 975.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a notice cannot be served personally on an owner or occupier and the person's actual or last known address cannot be determined after reasonable steps for the purpose have been taken, the notice may be given by publication in 2 issues, at least one week apart, of a newspaper having general circulation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the area where the owner or occupier to be given notice was last known to reside or carry on business according to the information available to the person giving the notice, or
in the area where the land to which the notice relates is situated.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice given in accordance with subsection (2) (b) is deemed to be received on the earlier of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date the person to whom it is sent actually receives the notice, and
the end of 10 days after the date on which the notice was sent.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Posting notice on protected heritage property

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may authorize a person to post one or more notices on or near

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: protected heritage property, or
real property subject to temporary heritage protection under section 956, 959, 962, 963 or 964.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before or when entering land to post a notice, the local government must make a reasonable effort to inform the owner or occupier of the land.
Except as authorized by the local government, a person must not alter or remove a notice posted under the authority of this section.
A local government must file a written notice in the land title office with respect to the following real property:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: property that is subject to a provision under section 810.1 (1) [repayment requirement in relation to regional district heritage exemptions];
property that is subject to a provision under section 225 (6) (c) [repayment requirements in relation to tax exemptions] of the Community Charter in relation to heritage property;
property that is subject to a heritage revitalization agreement;
property designated by a heritage designation bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On receipt of a notice under subsection (1), the registrar must make a note of the filing on the title of the affected land.
If a provision, agreement or bylaw referred to in subsection (1) no longer applies to property for which a notice was filed under this section, the local government must notify the land title office.
On receipt of a notice under subsection (2).
Notification to the land title office under (3) must be made in a form satisfactory to the registrar.
The protection of property under this Act is not affected by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an inadvertent and minor error or omission in a notice given by a local government to the registrar in relation to a note on a land title,
an error or omission in a note on a land title, or
a failure by the registrar to make a note on a land title.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the event of any omission, mistake or misfeasance by the registrar or the staff of the registrar in relation to the making or cancelling of a note under this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrar is not liable and neither the Provincial government nor the Land Title and Survey Authority of British Columbia is liable vicariously,
the assurance fund or the Land Title and Survey Authority of British Columbia as a nominal defendant is not liable under Part 19.1 of the Land Title Act, and
the assurance fund or the minister charged with the administration of the Land Title Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe fees for the filing of notices under this section, and section 386 of the Land Title Act applies in respect of those fees.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice to minister responsible for the Heritage Conservation Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government must notify the minister responsible for the Heritage Conservation Act with respect to the following real property:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: heritage property for which a tax exemption is provided under section 810 [regional district exemptions for heritage properties];
heritage property for which a tax exemption is provided under section 225 [municipal exemptions for heritage properties] of the Community Charter by reason of it being heritage property;
heritage property included under section 970.1 (3) (b) in a schedule to an official community plan;
heritage property identified in a community heritage register under section 954;
heritage property that is subject to a heritage revitalization agreement;
property designated by a heritage designation bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the provisions that require that notice must be given under subsection (1) no longer apply to any real property, the local government must notify the minister responsible for the Heritage Conservation Act.
Notices to the minister under subsections (1) and (2) of this section or section 959 (2) must be made in a form satisfactory to that minister.
The protection of property under this Act is not affected by an error or omission in a notice given under this section.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the form, content and means of giving notice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under this Part,
under section 810 (5) [regional district exemptions for heritage properties] of this Act, or
under section 225 [partnering, heritage, riparian and other special exemption authority] of the Community Charter in relation to heritage property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Regulations under subsection (1) may be different for different types of notices and for different types of properties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Civil remedies in relation to heritage property

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may apply to the Supreme Court for an order for compliance or restoration if a person does one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without the authority of a heritage alteration permit, does anything for which a heritage alteration permit is required under this Act;
fails to comply with the requirements and conditions of a heritage alteration permit;
fails to comply with a direction of the Ombudsperson under section 952 (4);
fails to bring property up to the standards established under section 970.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order under subsection (1) may include one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a requirement that, on terms and conditions the court specifies, the person restore the property to which the matter relates to its condition before the contravention;

a requirement that the person undertake compensatory conservation work as the court considers appropriate on the property that was affected or on other property, or that conservation work be performed by others at the expense of that person;
a requirement that the person comply with a direction under section 952 (4) or with the requirements and conditions of a heritage alteration permit;
a requirement that the person carry out measures specified by the court to ameliorate the effects of the contravention or non-compliance;
an authorization that the local government may, by its employees or others at the expense of the owner, perform work regarding a matter referred to in this subsection;
any other requirement the court considers advisable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an order is made under subsection (2) (e), the court may specify how and when the person will reimburse the local government for the cost of the work performed and the cost of incidental expenses accruing under the order.

Without limiting subsection (3), the court may authorize the local government to add the cost of the work undertaken and the cost of incidental expenses under the order to the taxes payable to the local government with respect to the property for the year in which the work is performed.
An order may be made under this section whether or not a person is charged with an offence under section 981 in relation to the matter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of contravention may be filed in land title office

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An officer or employee of a local government may recommend to the local government that a notice be filed in the land title office if the officer or employee discovers in the course of duties that any of the following has occurred:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: something for which a heritage alteration permit is required under this Act has been done without the authority of a heritage alteration permit;
a person has failed to comply with the requirements and conditions of a heritage alteration permit;
the terms and conditions of a heritage revitalization agreement have been contravened;
a covenant registered by the local government under section 219 of the Land Title Act in relation to heritage property has been contravened.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 57 [note against land title that building regulations contravened] and 58 [cancellation of note against land title] of the Community Charter.
The authority under subsection (1) is in addition to any other action the person or local government is authorized to take in relation to the matter.
A person who does any of the following commits an offence:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without the authority of a heritage alteration permit, does anything for which a heritage alteration permit is required under this Act;
fails to comply with the requirements and conditions of a heritage alteration permit;
alters property in contravention of a heritage revitalization agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person convicted of an offence under subsection (1) is liable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person is an individual, to a fine of not more than $50 000 or to imprisonment for a term of not more than 2 years, or to both, or
if the person is a corporation, to a fine of not more than $1 000 000.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a corporation commits an offence under subsection (1), an employee, officer, director or agent of the corporation who authorized, permitted or acquiesced in the offence also commits the offence and is liable to the penalty set out in subsection (2) (a) whether or not the corporation is convicted of the offence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: common mass means the common mass of property referred to in section 986 (1);
district means a part of a municipality defined by the council under section 984;

former parcel means a parcel existing before the completion of a replotting scheme, and includes any portion of land formerly a portion of a highway, park or public square, or of land indicated as such on a plan of subdivision deposited in the land title office;

new parcel means a parcel created or intended to be created by a replotting scheme, and includes a portion of land created or intended to be created as a portion of a highway, park or public square, or of land indicated as such on a plan of subdivision deposited in the land title office under this Part;

owner means a purchaser of real property under an unregistered agreement for sale and purchase, a registered owner of an estate in fee simple, a registered owner of a charge or a tax sale purchaser during the redemption period, and includes the Provincial government, a Provincial government corporation and the municipality.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Part applies to Crown land in a district held by purchasers from the Provincial government and in that case both the Provincial government and the purchasers are deemed to be owners for the purposes of this Part.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A council may, by bylaw adopted by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of all its members,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: define a part of the municipality as a district for the purpose of replotting, and
authorize the preparation of a scheme, including incidental preliminary surveys, for the replotting of the district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A replotting scheme must indicate the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proposed relocation and exchange of parcels of real property in which the Provincial government or the municipality has no estate or interest;
whether compensation is to be proposed to the respective owners and its amount;
the value of any surplus real property;
the new location of a building, structure, erection or utility that is to be moved.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A replotting scheme may set out an apportionment of the net cost of the scheme between the municipality and the owners, consideration being given to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the saving that the scheme may effect in the expenditure of the municipality for highways and municipal utilities, and
the increased taxation that may be derived by the municipality from the increased value of the real property in the district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An apportionment under subsection (2) may or may not be as provided by section 1011.
For the purpose of a replotting scheme, all the parcels and highways and all other real property in the district at the initiation of the scheme form one common mass of real property.

From the common mass is to be taken the real property necessary for highways, parks or public squares, which stands in the place of and compensates the Provincial government, the municipality and the public for the surrender of all former highways, parks or public squares.

The remainder of the common mass must be divided into parcels for allotment to the owners in a fair and equitable manner, so that as far as possible the value of new parcels allotted to them are equal to the value of their former parcels.
An allotment, decision, award, consent or other proceeding under this Part is binding on and inures to the benefit of the person who owns the real property affected.
In a replotting,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: effort must be made to allot to owners new parcels in approximately the same location as their former parcels, and
parcels with buildings, structures, erections or utilities erected on them, subject to the necessary adjustment of boundaries, must be returned to their former owners wherever practicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The allotment of new parcels in exchange for former parcels must be carried out as far as practicable with the consent of the respective owners.

Failing consent of an owner, there may be allotted to the owner a new parcel or parcels of value equal as nearly as possible to the value of the owner's former parcel or parcels, or compensation in money may be made to the owner instead of an allotment of real property.
Unavoidable differences of value between former parcels and new parcels may be equalized by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: granting money compensation, or
with the owner's consent or agreement, allotting to the owner of a new parcel of greater value than the owner's former parcel for a cash payment or on terms.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a new parcel is allotted under subsection (4) (b) on terms, the municipality may take a mortgage, with agreed interest, from the owner for payment of the difference in value.
Any real property not allotted as provided above may be allotted to any owner at an agreed price, the amount of which must be paid to the municipality.
The whole of the real property remaining unallotted must be allotted to the municipality and is surplus real property.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to making compensation for a charge against a former parcel, the municipality may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: acquire such a charge and hold it as a charge against a new parcel allotted to the owner of the former parcel, and
take all necessary proceedings for the collection of the amount due under and by virtue of the charge or for the sale, transfer or realization of the security created by it.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice requirements for initiation of a scheme

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before initiating a replotting scheme, the council must have notice of the scheme published in a newspaper.
Also before initiating a replotting scheme, the council must have the following sent to each owner of a parcel in the district, in the manner provided for the giving of notice under section 414:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a plan showing the real property in the district as presently subdivided and a plan showing that property as if replotted under the proposed scheme, with both plans having marked on them

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the dimensions of the boundaries of each parcel shown, and
the scale of the plan, which must be the same for both plans and which must not be smaller than 1 to 1 000;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a statement of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the estimated total cost of the scheme,
the cost to be borne by the municipality,
the total cost to be borne by all the owners, and
the portion of the cost for each new parcel;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a statement showing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the number of instalments by which the owner's share of the cost may be paid,
at what interval after completion of the scheme the first instalment will be due, and
at what intervals any remaining instalments will be due;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proposed allotment of new parcels for former parcels;
a form of consent to the replotting proposed by the scheme as it affects the owner's property, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the details of

bcl:clause.bcl:text: any compensation proposed to be paid by the municipality for the real property as a result of the scheme, or
any sums requested to be paid to the municipality for the real property as a result of the scheme, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a space in which, if the owner signs the consent and returns it to the municipality, the owner must set out

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the market or true value of the real property, and
the amount or proportion the owner considers to be the value of the owner's interest.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General consent of owners to scheme

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The council may, by resolution, authorize the initiation of the replotting scheme without further consent by other owners in the district if the owners of parcels of real property, the assessed land value of which is at least 70% of the total assessed value of all the land in the district according to the last revised real property assessment roll, consent to the replotting set out in the scheme.
A consent referred to in subsection (1) must be in writing in the form referred to in section 989 (2) (e).
The calculation of the 70% of the assessed value referred to in subsection (1) must be determined as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land only, without improvements, is to be considered for the purpose of this section;
the value of an owner's interest in a parcel is the assessed value of the parcel if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the parcel is owned in fee simple, free of charges,

the parcel is owned by a purchaser from the Provincial government or from a Provincial government corporation and the purchaser has completed the payments but the Crown grant, order in council or conveyance has not been delivered to or registered by the purchaser, or
the parcel has been purchased at a tax sale and the period for redemption has not expired;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the cases of parcels of real property held subject to one or more charges,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the value of the charges and of the estate in fee simple must be determined by multiplying the assessed value of the land by the true or market value of the particular interest in the parcel and dividing the resulting product by the true or market value of the parcel, and

if the true or market values of an interest in real property cannot be determined from the information supplied by owners of a parcel under section 989 (2) (e), the designated municipal officer must assess and determine the values for the purposes of subparagraph (i) from whatever records or information are available to that municipal officer;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a parcel of real property is held by a tenant for life,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the true or market value of the life estate is its present worth as determined by using the official Statistics Canada Tabulations of British Columbia life expectancy in effect when the valuation is made, and
the true or market value of the estate in remainder in fee simple is the resulting balance, after subtracting the true or market value of the life estate from the true or market value of the parcel;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the cases of multiple ownership of estates in fee simple and charges,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: each tenant in common must be considered to consent to the proportion of the whole estate in fee simple or charge held by the tenant's proportion in the tenancy, and
each joint tenant must be considered to consent to an equal share with each of the tenant's co-joint tenants in the whole estate in fee simple or charge.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consents binding on owners once given

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At any time before the commissioner gives his or her decisions under section 1007 (3), the designated municipal officer must receive from any owner the consent in writing referred to in section 989 (2) (e).
An owner who mails or delivers a consent to the municipality is bound by it, and no claims against the municipality may be allowed on matters specifically agreed to in the consent.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Alterations to scheme may require new consents

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Alterations may be made in the replotting scheme before its completion.
If alterations affect the owners who have consented, the consent of all the affected owners is again required.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Initiation of scheme by registration of resolution

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A copy of the resolution referred to in section 989 (2) (a), must be filed in the land title office.

When the resolution is filed under subsection (1), the registrar of land titles must cause a note of it to be made in every place in the records under the care of the registrar where title in fee simple to a parcel located in the district is registered.
The note under subsection (2) must be by the filing number and series, and the series may be the same as the series that includes caveats.
The replotting scheme is initiated when the note under subsection (2) is made.

A note under section 993 is notice to all persons having any right, title, interest, charge, claim or demand in, to or on the affected parcels, and to all persons subsequently dealing with them, that a scheme for their replotting has been initiated, and those persons are bound by all proceedings under this Part taken before and after that notice.

A person who has a right, title, interest, charge, claim or demand in, to, or on real property in the district that is not duly registered before the initiation of the scheme is not entitled to notice of proceedings under this Part, unless the person is a purchaser

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: from the Provincial government,
from the municipality, or
at a tax sale.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person subsequently dealing with an affected parcel is not entitled to notice unless the person has

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: given the designated municipal officer written notice of the person's purchase or claim and evidence of its registration, and
provided that municipal officer with an address to which notices may be mailed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Resolution to complete or discontinue scheme

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 4 months after the initiation of a replotting scheme, the council must, by resolution, either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: discontinue the replotting scheme, or
authorize the completion of the replotting scheme and put it into effect.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a council resolves to discontinue a replotting scheme under subsection (1) (a),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the municipal corporate officer must file in the land title office a copy of the resolution to discontinue, certified under that officer's signature, and
the registrar of land titles must then cancel the note under section 993 (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the council resolves to authorize the completion of the scheme under subsection (1) (b), the municipality must make application in accordance with section 996 to have title to the common mass registered in fee simple in trust for the owners of the new parcels.

An application to have title to the common mass registered in fee simple in trust for the owners of the new parcels must be in the form approved under the Land Title Act and must be accompanied by the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a reference plan defining the common mass, signed by the municipal corporate officer, and complying with the requirements of the Land Title Act for reference plans, other than the requirements of section 103 of that Act;
a certificate signed by the municipal corporate officer, setting out

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the 1st column, compiled in numerical or alphabetical order, the description of each new parcel,
in the 2nd column, opposite the description of the relevant new parcel, the description of the former parcel or parcels in respect of which the allotment of the new parcel has been made,
in the 3rd column, opposite the description of the relevant new parcel, the name and address of the owner in fee simple to whom each new parcel has been allotted,

in the 4th column, opposite the description of the relevant new parcel, the names of owners of all charges and their addresses and the nature and serial registration numbers of the charges registered against the former parcel or parcels in respect of which the allotment of the new parcel has been made, and
in the 5th column, opposite the description of the relevant new parcel,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the names and addresses of any

bcl:subclause.bcl:text: claimant of a lien filed under the Builders Lien Act,
person who has registered a certificate of pending litigation under the Land Title Act,
caveator under the Land Title Act,
person taking a security interest in fixtures under the Personal Property Security Act, or
spouse claiming the benefits of the Land (Spouse Protection) Act, and

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the description of any former parcel or parcels in respect of which no allotment of a new parcel or parcels has been made;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a subdivision plan defining the new parcels, complying with the requirements of the Land Title Act and bearing the title "prepared under the replotting provisions of the Local Government Act";
an application in the form approved under the Land Title Act to deposit the subdivision plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar of land titles must examine the application forms, reference plan, subdivision plan and certificate and, if satisfied that they are in order and in compliance with this Part and the Land Title Act, must deposit the reference plan and assign to it a serial deposit number.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of deposit of reference plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The deposit of a reference plan under section 996

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: vests in the municipality the title of the common mass, in trust as stated, in fee simple, free from all charges registered against former parcels, and
extinguishes all highways, parks or public squares within the common mass.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) binds the Provincial government.

On finding a good safe holding and marketable title in fee simple to the common mass, the registrar of land titles must register the title claimed by the municipality, and the Land Title Act then applies.

The municipality need not produce any former absolute, interim or duplicate indefeasible title to any former parcel, but on the issue of the indefeasible title to the municipality in trust all of those certificates are deemed to be cancelled.

After the registration under subsection (3), the registrar of land titles must deposit the subdivision plan, assign to it a serial deposit number, and issue any new indefeasible titles for the new parcels that are necessary.

The indefeasible titles under subsection (5) must be noted or endorsed, as the case may require, with all claims, demands or notices as set out in the 5th column of the certificate referred to in section 996 (1) (b).
The replotting scheme is completed when the requirements of subsection (6) are met, and after this the Land Title Act applies.

In addition to the application of the section 996 (1) (b) according to the estate, title or interest disclosed by the certificate, but subject to all claims, demands or notices set out in the fifth column of the certificate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registration for owners of new parcels

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As soon as practicable after the completion of the replotting scheme, the municipality must apply under the Land Title Act for registration on behalf of the persons who own the new parcels.

The registrar of land titles, in his or her discretion, may summarily reject or may refuse to register any application on behalf of an owner unless there is produced to the registrar any duplicate indefeasible title, or interim or absolute certificate of title to a former parcel that had not been produced before registration of the common mass under section 996.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Rights of ownership and charges transferred
bcl:section.bcl:text: On completion of the replotting scheme,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: except as otherwise dealt with under this Part, all rights, obligations and incidents of ownership of the owner of a former parcel or of an interest in it, and all public and private legal relationships with a former parcel, are deemed to be transferred to and exist in the new parcel allotted to the owner of the former parcel to the same extent and in the same manner as with the former parcel,

all conveyances, agreements, mortgages and other instruments, including grants of probate or grants of administration, in respect of parcels of real property described in them by a description appropriate to a former parcel and in respect of which registration of title had not been applied for before the completion of the replotting scheme must be construed as if the estate or interest passing or created or vested by them was in the new parcel, and

the new parcels and their respective owners are subject to and liable for all municipal charges, rates, taxes and assessments levied against their former respective parcels, and are subject to all proceedings taken and to be taken for the collection of municipal charges, rates, taxes and assessments in any manner provided for by law.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Allotments binding, although owners may complain regarding compensation
bcl:section.bcl:text: On completion of the replotting scheme, the allotments of real property under it are absolutely binding to all intents and purposes on all the owners in the district, subject to the right of those owners who do not consent to the scheme to complain as to the adequacy of compensation proposed or the failure to propose compensation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An owner who does not consent and who gives notice of complaint as provided in section 1004 has the right to compensation in money for the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any loss of value of the former parcel, in so far as adequate compensation is not afforded by the new parcel allotted;
any loss of, damage to or the cost of moving buildings or improvements on the former parcel;
any loss of income from the use of buildings or the special condition or use of the former parcel caused by the replotting scheme.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In determining the amount of compensation,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a former parcel must be valued at its market value at the time of the initiation of the replotting scheme, but an increase in its value caused by the anticipation or initiation of the scheme must not be taken into consideration, and
a new parcel must be valued at its market value on completion of the replotting scheme.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is not entitled to compensation for any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: costs, expenses, loss, damage or inconvenience incurred or sustained in investigating the replotting proceeding or in presenting a complaint or making an appeal, or caused by the initiation of or delay in or discontinuance of the replotting scheme;
an actual or anticipated loss or inconvenience of access to new parcels or of use of a municipal or public utility or service due to the new highways not being open for traffic;
an actual or anticipated loss, damage or inconvenience suffered in common with all or with the major part of other owners;

a building or structure constructed, erected, placed or altered, or an improvement made to land after the initiation of the replotting scheme or an actual or anticipated loss, damage or expense incidental to it, or incidental to the removal of that building or structure;
a reduction in or loss of value due to reduction in area within the limits of a right to take land for highway purposes contained in the Crown grant of or statute applying to the land.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within one month after completion of the replotting scheme, the council must apply to the Supreme Court for the appointment of a commissioner to hold a public hearing of and to decide any complaints under sections 1000 and 1001 and the court must appoint a commissioner.
An application under subsection (1) may be made without notice to any other person.
If the council does not apply under subsection (1), any owner who did not consent may apply on notice to the council.
A person who is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a member of the council,
an owner within the district, or
the spouse of an owner within the district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: must not be appointed or act as a commissioner.
Before entering on the duties of office, the commissioner must subscribe and take the following oath before the municipal corporate officer:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: (a) I will truly and faithfully, and without fear, favour or partiality, execute the powers and trusts of a commissioner under Part 28 of the Local Government Act, according to the best of my knowledge and judgment, and
(b) I am not disqualified from acting as a commissioner under that Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The municipality must pay the commissioner remuneration at a rate agreed between the commissioner and the council, and in the event of failure to agree, a reasonable remuneration set by the Supreme Court on summary application by the municipality or the commissioner.
If a commissioner

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: dies, resigns, refuses to act or is absent, or
is incapable of acting because of sickness, disability or misconduct,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: on the application of the municipality, the Supreme Court must appoint another person as commissioner.
An application under subsection (1) may be made without notice to any other person.

In the circumstances referred to in subsection (1), proceedings or decisions had, taken or arrived at by the commissioner before the vacancy are not in any way affected, but are valid and effectual, and must be and continue to be acted on,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: even though the vacancy has occurred and the other commissioner has been appointed, and
without any necessity for recommencing the proceedings or reconsidering any matter or thing that has arisen or been considered or decided before the vacancy occurred.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice to owners who do not consent

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On an appointment being made, the designated municipal officer must give to each of the owners who did not consent whose name appears on either of the lists referred to in section 1016 a notice in writing including the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a statement that a replotting scheme has been put into effect;
a description of the owner's former parcel;
a statement

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: of the allotment of new parcel made,
of the compensation proposed to the owner, and
that, if a parcel is improved, that the owner's buildings may be affected;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a statement that the scheme and the allotments under it are absolutely binding on the owner to all intents and purposes, excepting only the owner's right to complain against

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the adequacy of compensation proposed, or
the failure to propose compensation;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the time and place appointed by the commissioner for hearing complaints;
a statement that, if the owner intends to complain, the owner must give written notice with the grounds of the complaint to the designated municipal officer 10 days before the hearing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Notice under subsection (1) may be given by any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by personal service on the person to whom it is directed;
by registered mail addressed to the person at that person's address

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: as shown on a list provided under section 1016,
as shown on any record in the land title office relating to the person's ownership of or interest in the former parcel, or
as last known to the assessor for the municipality;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on application to the Supreme Court, by substituted service in accordance with the order of the court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The designated municipal officer may, in his or her discretion, send with any one or more of the notices a copy of the plan of replotting or any portion of it on the same or a different scale.

The designated municipal officer must keep a record of all notices given under this section by showing, opposite the names of the owners of the parcels in the district, the names of the persons to whom notices were sent and the parcels concerned and the date and method of giving each notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time and place to hear complaints
bcl:section.bcl:text: The commissioner must appoint a time and place for the hearing of complaints as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the place must be at the municipal hall or another suitable place in the municipality;
the time must be not less than 40 days and not more than 90 days after the designated municipal officer has given the notices referred to in section 1004.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The commissioner must sit at the time and place appointed, and must hear complaints of which notice has been given.
The proceedings before the commissioner must be public.

The commissioner must inquire into and pass on the sufficiency of all notices required to be given under section 1004 and, in the commissioner's sole discretion, may direct further notices and hear any complaint made.
If the commissioner thinks fit in the interest of justice, the commissioner may hear a complaint made to the commissioner at any time before the conclusion of the hearing.
The municipality may complain to the commissioner on its own behalf or on behalf of any other person.
The following rules apply respecting evidence that may be accepted by the commissioner:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the commissioner may receive any evidence that the commissioner thinks proper to admit and may take a view and examine on oath any person interested and the witnesses that appear before the commissioner;
the commissioner may act on, accept or adopt the evidence the commissioner considers sufficient, whether on oath or not and whether written or oral;
the commissioner has the right to insist on evidence being given or submitted orally under oath or by affidavit, but need not require any evidence to be so given;
the strict rules of evidence do not apply.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The commissioner may, at the request of any complaining owner or on the commissioner's own initiative, summon in writing any person to attend at the hearing, give evidence and produce any documentary evidence.
The commissioner may order reasonable fees and expenses to be paid to a witness summoned on the commissioner's own initiative, which must be paid by the municipality.
A person who fails to respond to a summons under subsection (7) commits an offence, and is liable on conviction to a penalty not greater than $100 and costs.

The commissioner or, in the absence of the commissioner, the municipal corporate officer may adjourn the hearing from time to time and from place to place, whether or not any person interested is present at the time of the adjournment.
The powers of the commissioner are confined to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: passing on the sufficiency of all notices required to be given under section 1004, and
hearing and deciding complaints under sections 1000 and 1001.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The commissioner must cause to be kept a record of each complaint made to the commissioner and of the commissioner's decision on it.
On the conclusion of the hearing, the commissioner must announce a date on which the commissioner's decisions will be given.
Promptly after giving his or her decisions, the commissioner must report to the council the complaints made to the commissioner and the decision on each.
The report under subsection (4) must be open for examination by any complainant or the solicitor or agent of a complainant.
A decision of a commissioner may be appealed to the Supreme Court.
An appeal under subsection (1) is to be an appeal by way of rehearing.
The person appealing must, within 10 days after the decision complained of, serve on the municipality a written notice of intention to appeal, setting out the grounds of appeal.
The appeal must be made on petition and 5 days' notice of the time for hearing the appeal must be given to the municipality.

The municipality may appeal from a decision of a commissioner, in which case it must give to the owner affected the notice of intention under subsection (3) and the notice of the hearing must be given the owner, both of which notices may be given in any manner provided in section 1004.
The powers of the Supreme Court on appeal are confined to hearing and deciding appeals from the decision of the commissioner on complaints under section 1001.
In term or during vacation, the court must hear the appeal in a summary manner and on the rules of evidence that govern a commissioner.
The court may adjourn the hearing from time to time and defer judgment at pleasure, but judgment must be given within 6 weeks from the time limit set by subsection (3) for giving notice of appeal.
If judgment is not given by the court within the time period under subsection (8), the commissioner's decision stands.
Persons making or opposing an appeal must pay their own costs and expenses and no costs as between party and party may be awarded by the court.
A decision of the Supreme Court under this section may be appealed to the Court of Appeal with leave of a justice of the Court of Appeal.
The municipality must pay

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amounts of compensation proposed by the replotting scheme within 3 months after its completion, or
if a complaint has been made, the compensation awarded by the commissioner, or the Supreme Court on appeal, within 3 months from the date of the award.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Either of the periods referred to in subsection (1) may be extended by the Supreme Court on application by the municipality without notice to any other person.
The compensation stands in the place of the land for which it was proposed or awarded, and is subject to any limitations and charges to which the land was subject.
The municipality may, without leave or order in any case it believes expedient, pay into the Supreme Court the amount of any compensation proposed or awarded.

Payment into court under subsection (4) must be accompanied by a certificate of the municipal corporate officer giving particulars of the person to whom and the land for which the compensation was proposed or awarded, and the district registrar must give that corporate officer a receipt, attached to or endorsed on a copy of the corporate officer's certificate.
Compensation paid into court under subsection (4) must be paid out of court to the person entitled to it on the order of the court.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The municipality may, by its employees, workers or contractors, move any building, structure, erection or utility required to be moved under the replotting scheme, or do any work or thing on private property in satisfaction of awards of compensation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The municipality must keep a proper account of all money paid by it in connection with a replotting scheme, and on its completion and the payment of all compensation and incidental expenses must prepare a statement showing the net cost.

In the statement under subsection (1), the municipality must be debited with the value of all surplus land allotted to it and any money receivable under section 987 or otherwise on account of the replotting scheme.
If applicable, the net cost shown by the statement under subsection (1) must be apportioned between the municipality and the other owners in the manner set out in the replotting scheme.
If the replotting scheme does not mention an apportionment, the net cost shown by the statement under subsection (1) must be apportioned as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the municipality's portion of the cost is that portion of the total net cost which bears the ratio that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the sum of the areas of the highways and public grounds and unsold land of the municipality at the completion of the replotting scheme

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: bears to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the whole area of the district;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the remainder is the owners' portion of the cost.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The net cost of the replotting scheme may be raised as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the municipal portion of the cost may be raised by a special rate levied and collected on and from all the taxable land or land and improvements in the municipality;

the owner's portion of the cost may be raised by a special rate levied and collected on and from the taxable land in the district, according to the respective values of that land as shown in the first revised real property assessment roll of the municipality containing the new parcels.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an alternative to subsection (5), the net cost of the replotting scheme may be paid by borrowing the required amount on debentures issued under the same provisions as if the scheme had been carried out as a local area service under the Community Charter, with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the municipality's portion of the cost being raised by a special rate levied and collected annually on and from all the taxable land or land and improvements in the municipality, and

the owners' portion of the cost being raised by a special rate levied and collected annually on and from the taxable land in the district according to the respective values of that land as shown in the revised real property assessment rolls for the years during which the special rates are levied.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Debentures under subsection (6) must be repayable within 10 years of the date of issue.
A special rate levied under (6) must be due and payable to the municipality at the same time as other annual municipal rates and taxes, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Part 7 of the (6) (a), and
Division 5 [Local Service Taxes] of Part 7 of the (6) (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the 6 months after the completion of a replotting scheme, so far as the new highways are not constructed and open for traffic, the former highways and all public utilities and other works on them, if they do not interfere with or disturb the reasonable and necessary use and occupation of new parcels, may be maintained, and no person has a right to compensation or a right of action for damages against the municipality or against any other person for that reason.
During the period referred to in subsection (1), the municipality or its licensees may remove the public utilities and works.
A person unreasonably obstructing the use of a former highway during the period referred to in subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a penalty not greater than $100.
