subsection.subsectiontext: As a limitation on section 176 (1) (e) [corporate powers — delegation], a local government may not delegate the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the making of a bylaw;
a power or duty that is only exercisable by bylaw;
a power or duty to appoint, suspend or terminate a local government officer;
a power or duty established by an enactment that the local government hear an appeal or reconsider an action, decision or other matter;
a power or duty established by this or any other Act that the local government give its approval or consent to, recommendations on, or acceptance of an action, decision or other matter.

subsection.subsectiontext: The authority under section 176 (1) (e) does not include authority to delegate to a corporation incorporated by the local government or to a corporation in which the local government acquires shares.
Subject to section 193, a local government may only delegate a power, duty or function by bylaw adopted by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the votes cast.
A local government may, by bylaw adopted by a majority of votes cast, amend or repeal a bylaw referred to in subsection (1) to reduce or revoke the delegation.

If a local government is required by law or authorized by an enactment to hold a hearing in relation to a bylaw, action or other matter, the holding of the hearing may only be delegated, either specifically, by class of hearings or generally,

paragraph.paragraphtext: in the case of a council, to one or more council members, and
in the case of a board, to one or more directors.

subsection.subsectiontext: As an exception to section 192 (1), a local government may delegate the holding of a hearing by bylaw or resolution adopted by a majority of votes cast.

If a hearing in relation to a matter is delegated under subsection (1), a delegation of the power to make the local government decision in relation to the same matter may only be delegated to the person or persons to whom the holding of the hearing was delegated.

If the holding of a hearing is delegated under subsection (1) and the power to make the local government decision in relation to the same matter is not delegated under subsection (3), the local government must not make the decision until the delegate reports to the local government, either orally or in writing, the views expressed at the hearing.
This section does not authorize the delegation of the holding of a hearing referred to in section 191 (1) (d) [appeals and reconsiderations].

For certainty, if a delegation has been made in relation to hearings, the local government may exercise its authority under subsection (1) to change that delegation to a different delegation in relation to a specific hearing.
If

paragraph.paragraphtext: a local government delegates a power to make a decision, and
in relation to that delegation, an enactment establishes a right to have a delegated decision reconsidered by the local government,

section.subsandwich: the local government must, by bylaw, establish procedures for such a reconsideration, including how a person may apply for the reconsideration.

subsection.subsectiontext: In undertaking a reconsideration referred to in subsection (1), a local government has the same authority as that conferred on the delegate.

change.changenote: Section 195 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-200, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: A local government must not incorporate a corporation or acquire shares in a corporation without first receiving the approval of the inspector.

change.changenote: Part 5.1, heading BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-201, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).
Division 1 of Part 5.1, sections 196 to 199 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-202, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A local government,

paragraph.paragraphtext: must, by bylaw, establish officer positions in relation to the duties under sections 198 [corporate administration] and 199 [financial administration], with titles it considers appropriate,
may, by bylaw, establish other officer positions for its municipality or regional district, with titles it considers appropriate, and
may, by bylaw or resolution, assign powers, duties and functions to those officer positions.

subsection.subsectiontext: For certainty,

paragraph.paragraphtext: a local government may assign to an officer position powers, duties and functions in addition to those required or permitted to be assigned by this Act or another enactment, and
the same person may be appointed to 2 or more officer positions.

section.sectiontext: One of the officer positions established under section 196 may be assigned the chief administrative responsibility, which includes the following powers, duties and functions:

paragraph.paragraphtext: overall management of the administrative operations of the municipality or regional district;
ensuring that the policies and directions of the local government are implemented;
advising and informing the local government on the operation and affairs of the municipality or regional district.

section.sectiontext: One of the officer positions established under section 196 must be assigned the responsibility of corporate administration, which includes the following powers, duties and functions:

paragraph.paragraphtext: ensuring that accurate minutes of the meetings of the local government and its committees are prepared and that the minutes, bylaws and other records of the business of the local government and its committees are maintained and kept safe;
ensuring that access is provided to records of the local government and its committees, as required by law or authorized by the local government;
certifying copies of bylaws and other documents, as required or requested;
administering oaths and taking affirmations, declarations and affidavits required to be taken under this or any other Act in relation to local government matters;

accepting, on behalf of the local government, municipality or regional district, notices and documents that are required or permitted to be given, served on, filed with or otherwise provided to the local government, municipality or regional district;
keeping the corporate seal, if any, and having it affixed to documents as required.

section.sectiontext: One of the officer positions established under section 196 must be assigned the responsibility of financial administration, which includes the following powers, duties and functions:

paragraph.paragraphtext: receiving all money paid to the municipality or regional district;
ensuring the keeping of all funds and securities of the municipality or regional district;
expending and disbursing money in the manner authorized by the local government;
investing funds, until required, in investments referred to in section 336 [investment of municipal funds];
ensuring that accurate records and full accounts of the financial affairs of the municipality or regional district are prepared, maintained and kept safe;
compiling and supplying information on the financial affairs of the municipality or regional district required by the inspector.

change.changenote: Division 2, heading, of Part 5.1 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-203, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).
Section 200 (1) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-204, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Without limiting section 176 [corporate powers], a local government may

paragraph.paragraphtext: provide for the appointment of officers and other employees for its municipality or regional district, and

subject to the Labour Relations Code and the Employment Standards Act, establish the terms and conditions of their employment, including terms and conditions respecting their remuneration, benefits, expenses, hours of work and manner of appointment, promotion, discipline and dismissal.

change.changenote: Section 200.1 was enacted by 2012-9-8, effective May 14, 2012 (Royal Assent).
Section 201 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-205, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: Before taking on the duties of office, a person appointed to an officer position for a municipality or regional district must swear or affirm an oath of office in the form prescribed by regulation or established by local government bylaw.

change.changenote: Section 202 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-205, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: Subject to a contract of employment, the appointment of a local government officer may be terminated by the local government as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: on reasonable notice, if the termination is approved by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the votes cast;
without notice, for cause, if the termination is approved by a majority of the votes cast.

change.changenote: Section 203 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-205, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: A local government may, by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the votes cast, provide for the inclusion of its municipality or regional district in an employers' organization under the Labour Relations Code.

change.changenote: Section 204 (1) (b) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-206, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

paragraph.paragraphtext: one must be nominated by the Municipal Officers' Association of British Columbia, and

change.changenote: Section 205 (1) (a) BEFORE amended by 2002-12-21, effective April 11, 2002 (Royal Assent).

paragraph.paragraphtext: establish qualifications and standards for municipal or regional district employment according to office and grades;

change.changenote: Section 206.1 was enacted by 2006-3-9, effective March 28, 2006 (Royal Assent).
Part 5.2, heading and Division 1, heading BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-207, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).
Section 207 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-208, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Except as established under subsection (2) or by the effect of section 209 [term of office for council members], the council size for municipalities must be as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: for a city or district having a population of more than 50 000, the council is to consist of a mayor and 8 councillors;
for a city or district having a population of 50 000 or less, the council is to consist of a mayor and 6 councillors;
for a town or village, the council is to consist of a mayor and 4 councillors.

subsection.subsectiontext: The council of a city, district or town may, by bylaw, establish the number of council members as a mayor and 4, 6, 8 or 10 councillors.
A bylaw under subsection (2) must provide for an uninterrupted transition from the previous council.
A bylaw under subsection (2) that would reduce the number of council members must not be adopted unless it receives the assent of the electors.

change.changenote: Section 208 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-208, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Except as established by a temporary order under section 37 (6) (a) [minister's order if local government reduced to less than a quorum], the quorum for a council is as follows:
The acts done by a quorum of council are not invalid by reason only that the council is not at the time composed of the required number of council members under this Act.

change.changenote: Section 209 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-208, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Term of office for council members

subsection.subsectiontext: The term of office for a mayor elected at a general local election

paragraph.paragraphtext: begins on the first Monday after December 1 following the election or when the person takes office in accordance with section 210 (3), whichever is later, and
ends immediately before the first Monday after December 1 in the year of the next general local election or when the mayor's successor takes office, whichever is later.

subsection.subsectiontext: The term of office for a councillor elected at a general local election

paragraph.paragraphtext: begins on the first Monday after December 1 following the election or when the person takes office in accordance with section 210 (3), and

ends immediately before the first Monday after December 1 in the year of the next general local election or when a sufficient number of council members have taken office to make up a quorum, whichever is later.

change.changenote: Section 210 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-209, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Oath of office for council members

subsection.subsectiontext: A person elected or appointed to office on a council must make a prescribed oath of office, by oath or solemn affirmation, within the following applicable time limit:

paragraph.paragraphtext: in the case of a person elected by acclamation, within 50 days after the date set for general voting day had an election by voting been required;
in the case of a person elected by voting, within 45 days after the declaration of the results of the election;
in the case of a person appointed to office, within 45 days after the effective date of the appointment.

subsection.subsectiontext: The oath must be made before a judge of the Court of Appeal, Supreme Court or Provincial Court, a justice of the peace or the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration], and the person making the oath must obtain the completed oath or a certificate of it from the person administering it.
A person takes office on a council

paragraph.paragraphtext: at the time the term of office begins if, at this time, the person produces or has produced the completed oath or certificate to the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration], or
at any later time that the person produces the completed oath or certificate to that officer.

subsection.subsectiontext: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, establish one or more alternative oaths of office for the purposes of this section, which may be different for different types of office.
A person taking office on a council may also make an oath of allegiance.

Once a council member takes office, the member is entitled to hold that office through its term and to vote and otherwise act in the office during that time unless the member resigns or becomes disqualified.

change.changenote: Section 210 BEFORE re-enacted by 2014-19-83, effective May 29, 2014 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Oath of office for board members

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person elected or appointed to office on a board must make a prescribed oath of office, by oath or solemn affirmation, within the following applicable time limit:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an electoral area director elected by acclamation, within 50 days after the date set for general voting day had an election by voting been required;
in the case of an electoral area director elected by voting, within 45 days after the declaration of the results of the election;
in the case of a person appointed to an electoral area under section 78 [appointment if an insufficient number of candidates are elected], within 45 days after the effective date of the appointment;
in the case of a person appointed as municipal director, within 45 days after the effective date of the appointment;

in the case of a person appointed as alternate director, within 45 days after the effective date of the appointment or the first board meeting or board committee meeting at which the person acts in that capacity, whichever is latest.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The oath or solemn affirmation must be made before a judge of the Court of Appeal, Supreme Court or Provincial Court, a justice of the peace, a commissioner for taking affidavits for British Columbia, the regional district corporate officer or the chief election officer, and the person making the oath must obtain the completed oath or a certificate of it from the person administering it.
A person takes office on a board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the time the term of office begins if, at this time, the person produces or has produced the completed oath or certificate to the regional district corporate officer, or
at any later time that the person produces the completed oath or certificate to that officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, establish one or more alternative oaths of office for the purposes of this section, which may be different for different types of office.
A person taking office on a board may also make an oath of allegiance.

Once a board member takes office, the member is entitled to hold that office through its term and to vote and otherwise act in the office during that time unless the member resigns or becomes disqualified.

change.changenote: Section 211 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-210, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Disqualification from office for failure to make oath or attend meetings

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person elected or appointed to office on a council does not make the required oath under section 210 within the time limit set by that section, the office is deemed to be vacant and the person is disqualified from taking and holding office on a local government or on the council of the City of Vancouver until the next general local election.

If a council member is continuously absent from council meetings for a period of 60 consecutive days or 4 consecutive regularly scheduled council meetings, whichever is the longer time period, unless the absence is because of illness or with the leave of the council, the office of the member is deemed to be vacant and the person who held the office is disqualified from holding office on a local government or on the council of the City of Vancouver until the next general local election.

change.changenote: Section 212 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-211, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council member may resign from office only by delivering a written resignation to the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration].
A resignation becomes effective when it is received by the municipal officer, even if a later date is set out in the resignation, and may not be revoked after the time it is received.

The municipal officer must notify the council of a resignation at its next meeting after the resignation is received or, if there are no other council members, the municipal officer must notify the minister.

change.changenote: Section 213 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-212, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Application to court to declare council member disqualified

subsection.subsectiontext: An application to the Supreme Court for a declaration that a council member is disqualified from holding office and that the office is vacant may be made in accordance with this section.

Except as provided in this section, Division 15 of Part 3 [Declaration of Invalid Election], other than section 143 (7) [time for hearing application], applies in relation to an application under this section.
An application may only be made by at least 4 electors of the municipality.

An application may be made at any time during the challenged person's term of office, but must be made within 30 days after the alleged basis of the disqualification comes to the attention of any of the persons making the application.
Within 7 days after the petition commencing an application is filed, it must be served on the person whose right to hold office is being challenged and on the municipality.
On the hearing of an application, the court may

paragraph.paragraphtext: declare that the person is confirmed as qualified to hold office, or
declare that the person is not qualified to hold office and that the office is vacant.

change.changenote: Section 214 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-212, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: If the council considers that one of its members is disqualified from holding office, the council may adopt a resolution declaring that the office is vacant.
Before taking action under subsection (1), the council must notify the person affected of the proposed action.
Unless an application to the Supreme Court is made under subsection (4), an office declared vacant under subsection (1) becomes vacant 6 days after the resolution is adopted.

A person whose office is declared vacant under subsection (1) may apply to the Supreme Court for a determination of whether the person is qualified to hold the office, but the application must be commenced within 5 days after the resolution is adopted.
Within 7 days after the petition commencing an application under subsection (4) is filed, it must be served on the municipality.
On the hearing of an application under subsection (4), the court may

paragraph.paragraphtext: declare that the person is confirmed as qualified to hold office, or
declare that the person is not qualified to hold office and that the office is vacant.

subsection.subsectiontext: Section 147 [status of an elected candidate] applies in relation to an application under subsection (4) of this section.

change.changenote: Heading, to Division 2 of Part 5.2 BEFORE amended by 2003-52-213, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).
Section 218 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-214, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: They mayor is the head and chief executive officer of the municipality.
In addition to the mayor's powers and duties as a council member, the mayor has the following duties:

paragraph.paragraphtext: to see that the law for the improvement and good government of the municipality is carried out;

to communicate information to the council and to recommend bylaws, resolutions and measures that, in the mayor's opinion, may assist the peace, order and good government of the municipality in relation to the powers conferred on the council by an enactment;
[Repealed 2000-7-21.]
to inspect and direct the conduct of officers and employees, to direct the management of municipal business and affairs and, if considered necessary, to suspend an officer or employee;
so far as the mayor's power extends, to see that negligence, carelessness and violation of duty by an officer or employee is prosecuted and punished.

subsection.subsectiontext: Every suspension of an officer or employee by the mayor under this section must be reported to the council at its next sitting, and the council may

paragraph.paragraphtext: reinstate the officer or employee,
confirm the suspension,
confirm and extend the suspension, or
dismiss the officer or employee.

subsection.subsectiontext: The powers and duties set out in subsections (2) (d) and (3) are subject to sections 200 [appointment of officers and employees] and 202 [termination of officer].

change.changenote: Section 219 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-214, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Mayor may return bylaw for reconsideration by council

subsection.subsectiontext: At any time within one month after a bylaw, resolution or proceeding of the council is adopted, the mayor may return it for reconsideration if it has not

paragraph.paragraphtext: had the assent of the electors,
been reconsidered by the council under subsection (3), or
been acted on by an officer, employee or agent of the municipality.

subsection.subsectiontext: The mayor may give reasons for returning a matter to the council and the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration] must record in the minutes the mayor's reasons, suggestions or amendments.
As soon as convenient, the council must consider the mayor's reasons and either reaffirm or reject the bylaw, resolution or proceeding.
If a bylaw, resolution or proceeding is rejected, it

paragraph.paragraphtext: is deemed to be repealed and is of no effect, and
must not be reintroduced to the council for 6 months except with the unanimous consent of the council.

subsection.subsectiontext: The conditions that applied to the adoption of the original bylaw, resolution or proceeding apply to its rejection.

change.changenote: Section 220 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-215 effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may appoint one of its members to be deputy mayor and one of its members to be acting mayor.
If the office of mayor becomes vacant, the council must appoint a member to be acting mayor, and the acting mayor is to continue in office until another mayor is elected or appointed.
During the absence, illness or other disability of the mayor, the acting mayor has all the powers of and is subject to the same rules as the mayor.

change.changenote: Section 221 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-215, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: Except where otherwise provided, all questions arising between municipalities must be decided by the mayors of the municipalities or, if they cannot agree, by the Supreme Court, whose decision is final.

change.changenote: Heading for Division 3 of Part 5.2 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-216, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).
Section 222 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-217, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: First council meeting after general local election

subsection.subsectiontext: Following a general local election, the first council meeting must be on the first Monday after December 1 in the year of the election.

If a quorum of council members elected at the general local election has not taken office by the time referred to in subsection (1), the first council meeting must be called by the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration] and held as soon as reasonably possible after a quorum has taken office.

change.changenote: Section 222.1 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-218, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: After its first meeting under section 222, a council must meet

paragraph.paragraphtext: regularly in accordance with its bylaw under section 235 [procedure bylaw], and
as it decides and as provided in this Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of this Act, a special council meeting is a council meeting other than a statutory, regular or adjourned meeting.
If permitted under subsection (4), a council meeting may be conducted by means of electronic or other communications facilities.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations permitting meetings under subsection (3) and prescribing conditions, limits and requirements respecting such meetings.

change.changenote: Section 222.1 (3) BEFORE amended by 2006-3-10, effective March 28, 2006 (Royal Assent).

subsection.subsectiontext: If permitted under subsection (5), a board meeting may be conducted by means of electronic or other communications facilities.

change.changenote: Section 222.1 (6), (7) and (8) were added by 2014-19-84, effective May 29, 2014 (Royal Assent).
Section 223 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-219, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A notice of the day, hour and place of a special council meeting must be given at least 24 hours before the time of meeting, by

paragraph.paragraphtext: posting a copy of the notice at the regular council meeting place, and
leaving one copy for each council member at the place to which the member has directed notices to be sent.

subsection.subsectiontext: The notice must be signed by the mayor or the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration].
Notice of a special council meeting may be waived by unanimous vote of all council members.

change.changenote: Section 224 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-219, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Council members may request special meeting

subsection.subsectiontext: Two or more council members may, in writing, request the mayor to call a special council meeting.
Two or more council members may call a special council meeting if

paragraph.paragraphtext: within 24 hours after receiving a request under subsection (1), the mayor refuses or neglects to arrange for the special council meeting to be held within 7 days after receiving the request, or
the mayor is absent.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a special council meeting is called under subsection (2), the council members calling the meeting must sign the notice under section 223.

change.changenote: Section 227 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-220, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Mayor to preside at council meetings

subsection.subsectiontext: The mayor, if present, must preside at council meetings.
If the mayor, deputy mayor and the acting mayor are absent from a council meeting,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the members present must choose a member to preside, and
the presiding member has, for that purpose, all the powers of and is subject to the same rules as the mayor.

subsection.subsectiontext: Any council member may preside in committee of the whole.

change.changenote: Section 228 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-221, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: The mayor or the member presiding at a council meeting must preserve order and decide points of order that may arise, subject to an appeal to the other council members present.

change.changenote: Section 229 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-221, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Appeal from decision of mayor or member presiding

subsection.subsectiontext: On an appeal by a council member from a decision of the mayor or the member presiding at a council meeting, the question as to whether the chair is to be sustained must be immediately put by the mayor or presiding member and decided without debate.
The mayor or presiding member must be governed by the vote of the majority of the other council members present.
If the votes are equal, the question passes in the affirmative.
The names of the council members voting for or against the question must be recorded in the minutes.
If the mayor or presiding member refuses to put the question under subsection (1),

paragraph.paragraphtext: the council must immediately appoint another member to preside temporarily,
that other member must proceed in accordance with subsection (1), and
a resolution or motion carried under this subsection is as binding as if carried under subsection (1).

change.changenote: Section 230 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-221, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies to council members in relation to

paragraph.paragraphtext: council meetings, and
meetings of committees referred to in section 235 (1) (b) [standing, select and other council committees].

subsection.subsectiontext: A council member present at the meeting at the time of the vote who abstains from voting is deemed to have voted in the affirmative.
If the votes of the council members present at the meeting at the time of the vote are equal for and against a question, the question is negatived and the presiding member must declare this result.

change.changenote: Section 231 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-221, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Council member declaration if not entitled to vote

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies to council members in relation to

paragraph.paragraphtext: council meetings,
meetings of committees referred to in section 235 (1) (b) [standing, select and other council committees], and
meetings of bodies that are subject to section 242.7 [application to other municipal bodies].

subsection.subsectiontext: If a council member attending a meeting considers that he or she is not entitled to

paragraph.paragraphtext: participate in the discussion of a matter, or
vote on a question in respect of a matter

section.subsandwich: because the member has a direct or indirect pecuniary interest in the matter or for any other reason, the member must declare this and state the general nature of why the member considers this to be the case.

subsection.subsectiontext: After making the declaration, the member

paragraph.paragraphtext: must not take part in the discussion of the matter and is not entitled to vote on any question in respect of the matter,
must immediately leave the meeting or that part of the meeting during which the matter is under consideration, and
must not attempt in any way, whether before, during or after the meeting, to influence the voting on any question in respect of the matter.

subsection.subsectiontext: When the declaration is made,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the person recording the minutes of the meeting must record the member's declaration, the reasons given for it and the times of the member's departure from the meeting room and, if applicable, of the member's return, and
the person presiding at the meeting must ensure that the member is not present at the meeting at the time of any vote on the matter.

subsection.subsectiontext: Whether or not a declaration is made under subsection (2), if a council member has a direct or indirect pecuniary interest in a matter, the member must not

paragraph.paragraphtext: participate in the discussion of the matter,
vote on a question in respect of the matter, or
attempt in any way, whether before, during or after the meeting, to influence the voting on any question in respect of the matter.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subsection (5) does not apply

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the pecuniary interest of the council member is a pecuniary interest in common with electors of the municipality generally,
if the matter relates to remuneration or expenses payable to one or more council members in relation to their duties as council members, or
if the pecuniary interest is so remote or insignificant that it cannot reasonably be regarded as likely to influence the member in relation to the matter.

subsection.subsectiontext: A person who contravenes subsection (5) is disqualified from continuing to hold office as a council member unless the contravention was done inadvertently or because of an error in judgment made in good faith.

If otherwise qualified, a person disqualified under subsection (7) is qualified to be nominated and elected in the by-election to fill the vacancy created by this disqualification and, if elected, is qualified to hold the office.
The council may apply to the Supreme Court for an order under subsection (10) if, as a result of subsection (2), the number of council members who may discuss and vote on a matter falls below

paragraph.paragraphtext: the quorum for the council, or
the number of council members required to adopt the applicable bylaw or resolution.

subsection.subsectiontext: An application under subsection (9) may be made without notice to any other person.
On an application under subsection (9), the court may

paragraph.paragraphtext: order that all or specified council members may discuss and vote on the matter, despite the other provisions of this section, and
make the authority under paragraph (a) subject to any conditions and directions the court considers appropriate.

change.changenote: Heading for Division 4 of Part 5.2 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-222, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).
Section 232 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-223, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Exercise of powers by bylaw or resolution

subsection.subsectiontext: If an enactment provides that a council is required or empowered to exercise a power by bylaw, that power may only be exercised by bylaw.
Except as restricted by subsection (1), the powers of a council may be exercised by resolution or bylaw.
An act or proceeding of a council is not valid unless it is authorized or adopted by bylaw or resolution at a council meeting.

change.changenote: Section 233 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-223, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: General rule that matters be decided by majority of members present
section.sectiontext: Unless otherwise provided, all acts to be done by the council, and all other questions, including adjournment, that may come before the council must be done and decided by a majority of the council members present at a meeting.

change.changenote: Section 234 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-223, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: A requirement in this Act for an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of all members of a council means an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the number of members of which the council consists under this Act.

change.changenote: Section 235 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-223, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: The council must, by bylaw, do the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: establish the procedures that are to be followed for the conduct of its business, including the manner by which resolutions may be passed and, in accordance with section 258 [establishment of procedures for adopting bylaws], by which bylaws may be adopted;
establish the procedures that are to be followed in conducting meetings of

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: select and standing committees of council, and
any other committee composed solely of council members acting in that capacity;

paragraph.paragraphtext: establish the time and place of regular meetings of council;
require advance public notice respecting the time, place and date of council and committee meetings and establish the procedures for giving that notice.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under this section must not be altered except by a bylaw passed at a regular council meeting in accordance with a notice in writing given and openly announced at an earlier regular meeting.

change.changenote: Section 236 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-224, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Minutes of council meetings must be

paragraph.paragraphtext: legibly recorded,
certified as correct by the designated municipal officer,
signed by the mayor or other member presiding at the meeting or at the next meeting at which they are adopted, and
open for public inspection at the municipal hall during its regular office hours.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subsection (1) (d) does not apply to minutes of that part of a council meeting from which persons were excluded under section 242.2 [closed meetings].

change.changenote: Section 237 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-224, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: Minutes of a committee referred to in section 235 (1) (b) [standing, select and other council committees] must be

paragraph.paragraphtext: legibly recorded,
signed by the chair or member presiding at the meeting, and
open for public inspection as provided for council minutes under section 236.

change.changenote: Section 237.1 was enacted by 2006-3-11, effective March 28, 2006 (Royal Assent).
Section 238 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-225, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may appoint a select committee to consider or inquire into any matter and to report its findings and opinion to the council.
Subject to subsection (3), persons who are not council members may be appointed to a select committee.
At least one member of a select committee must be a council member.

change.changenote: Section 239 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-225, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: The mayor may establish standing committees for matters the mayor considers would be better dealt with by committee and may appoint persons to those committees.
Subject to subsection (3), persons who are not council members may be appointed to a standing committee.
At least half of the members of a standing committee must be council members.

change.changenote: Section 240 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-225, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Witnesses at council or committee meetings

subsection.subsectiontext: A council, a standing committee or a select committee

paragraph.paragraphtext: has power, under the signature of the mayor, to summon witnesses for examination on oath for matters about the administration of the municipality, and
has the same power to enforce the attendance of witnesses and compel them to give evidence as is vested in a court of law in civil cases.

subsection.subsectiontext: A member of council or of a standing or select committee or the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration] may administer the oath to a witness.
A witness may be examined, cross examined and re-examined according to the rules and practice of the Supreme Court in civil cases.

change.changenote: Section 241 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-225, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies to petitions to council, other than counter petitions under Division 5 of Part 4 [Other Voting — Counter Petition Opportunities].
A petition to a council must include the full name and residential address of each petitioner.
A person may not withdraw their name from the petition or add a name to the petition

paragraph.paragraphtext: if no time has been set under this Act for submission of the petition, after the petition has been certified as sufficient, and
in other cases, after the time set for submission of the petition.

subsection.subsectiontext: Except as otherwise provided, the sufficiency and validity of a petition to a council must be determined by the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration], who must certify this determination.
A determination under subsection (4) is final and conclusive.

change.changenote: Division 4.1 of Part 5.2, sections 242.1 to 242.8 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-226, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).

section.marginalnote: General rule: meetings must be open to the public
section.sectiontext: Subject to section 242.2 [closed meetings], a council meeting must be open to the public.

section.marginalnote: Meetings that may or must be closed

subsection.subsectiontext: A part of a council meeting may be closed to the public if the subject matter being considered relates to one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: personal information about an identifiable individual who holds or is being considered for a position as an officer, employee or agent of the municipality or another position appointed by the municipality;
personal information about an identifiable individual who is being considered for a municipal award or honour, or who has offered to provide a gift to the municipality on condition of anonymity;
labour relations or employee negotiations;
the security of property of the municipality;
the acquisition, disposition or expropriation of land or improvements, if the council considers that disclosure might reasonably be expected to harm the interests of the municipality;
law enforcement, if the council considers that disclosure might reasonably be expected to harm the conduct of an investigation under or enforcement of an Act, regulation or bylaw;
consideration of whether paragraph (e) or (f) applies in relation to a matter;
litigation or potential litigation affecting the municipality;
the receiving of advice that is subject to solicitor-client privilege, including communications necessary for that purpose;
information that is prohibited from disclosure under section 21 of the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act;
a matter that, under another enactment, is such that the public may be excluded from the meeting;
a matter prescribed by regulation under section 242.8.

subsection.subsectiontext: A part of a council meeting must be closed to the public if the subject matter relates to one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a request under the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act if the council is designated as head of the local public body for the purposes of that Act in relation to the matter;
a matter that, under another enactment, is such that the public must be excluded from the meeting.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the only subject matter being considered at a council meeting is one or more matters referred to in subsection (1) or (2), the applicable subsection applies to the entire meeting.

section.sectiontext: Before a meeting or part of a meeting is closed to the public, the council must state, by resolution,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the fact that the meeting is to be closed, and
the basis under section 242.2 on which the meeting is to be closed.

section.marginalnote: No bylaw votes in a closed meeting
section.sectiontext: A council must not vote on the reading or adoption of a bylaw when its meeting is closed to the public.

section.marginalnote: Expulsion from meeting for improper conduct
section.sectiontext: If the mayor or other person presiding at a meeting of the council considers that a person is guilty of improper conduct, the person presiding may expel and exclude the other person from the meeting.
This Division applies to meetings of committees referred to in section 235 (1) (b) [select, standing and other council committees].
Subject to the regulations under section 242.8, this Division and section 237 [minutes of council committees] apply to meetings of the following

paragraph.paragraphtext: a body that under this or another Act may exercise the powers of the municipality or council;
a board of variance;
a local court of revision;
an advisory committee, or other advisory body, established by council under this or another Act;
a prescribed body.

section.sectiontext: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations to do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: prescribing a matter for the purposes of section 242.2 (1) (l) [meetings that may be closed];
prescribing a body or class of body for the purposes of section 242.7 (e) [application to other bodies];
in relation to section 242.7, excluding a specified body from the application of this Division or section 237 [minutes of council committees], or both;
modifying any of the provisions of this Division or section 237 [minutes of council committees], or both, in relation to a body that is subject to this Division under section 242.7.

change.changenote: Division 5 of Part 5.2, sections 243 to 256 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-226, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Persons may be honoured with freedom of the municipality

subsection.subsectiontext: To honour a distinguished person, by unanimous vote of its members, a council may confer freedom of the municipality on that person.
Until the council revokes the honour, a person given freedom of the municipality

paragraph.paragraphtext: is deemed to be an elector of the municipality and is eligible to be registered as such and to vote in an election for mayor or councillor, and
despite any other enactment, if the person is a Canadian citizen, is deemed to be qualified to be nominated, be elected and hold the office of mayor of the municipality.

subsection.subsectiontext: To honour a distinguished unit of the armed forces of Canada, the United Kingdom or another nation of the Commonwealth, by unanimous vote of its members, a council may confer freedom of the municipality on that unit.
The commanding officer of a unit honoured with freedom of the municipality has by virtue of office the same qualifications and privileges of a person honoured with freedom of the municipality.

section.sectiontext: A council may declare that a public holiday is to be observed in the municipality, either on a day named by the council or on a day determined and proclaimed by the mayor.
A council may, by bylaw, provide for a referendum to obtain the electors' opinion on a question that affects the municipality and with which the council has power to deal.

section.marginalnote: Joint exercise of powers with other municipalities

subsection.subsectiontext: A municipality may join with another municipality to exercise a power conferred by this Act.
An agreement under this section is not valid until ratified by a bylaw adopted by each council.
For the purpose of this section,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the powers of a municipality extend beyond the boundaries of the municipality, and
"municipality" includes the City of Vancouver.

section.sectiontext: The council has all necessary power to do anything incidental or conducive to the exercise or performance of its powers, duties and functions.

section.marginalnote: Further powers in relation to municipal assets
section.sectiontext: In addition to the powers of a council under this Act, the minister may confer on the council further powers to manage and dispose of municipal assets that the minister considers necessary or advisable.
On request by a council, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, to the extent not inconsistent with the purposes of this or any other Act, confer further powers on the council necessary to

paragraph.paragraphtext: preserve and promote the peace, order and good government of the muni-cipality and the health, safety, morality and welfare of its citizens, and
provide for protection of persons and property.

section.sectiontext: If the powers conferred on a council are inadequate to deal with an emergency that is not an emergency within the meaning of the Emergency Program Act, the council may, by bylaw adopted by a vote of at least 2/3 of the council members, declare that an emergency exists and exercise powers necessary to deal effectively with the emergency.

section.marginalnote: Additional powers and exceptions may be granted to municipalities

subsection.subsectiontext: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, do one or more of the following in relation to a specified municipality or a described class of municipalities:

paragraph.paragraphtext: grant a power to the municipality or class;
provide an exception to or a modification of a requirement established by an enactment;
establish any terms and conditions the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers appropriate regarding

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the grant of a power under paragraph (a) or the exercise of it, or
an exception or modification under paragraph (b) or the taking of its benefit.

subsection.subsectiontext: A regulation made under this section must not do any of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: confer an authority otherwise available to a municipality, including any power that may be granted or exercised under

section.subparasandwich: section 248 [further powers in relation to municipal assets],
section 249 [further powers for public good], or

paragraph.paragraphtext: override an absolute prohibition contained in an enactment;
confer an authority to impose a new tax;
confer an authority to grant a new tax exemption;
eliminate a requirement for obtaining the assent of the electors;
any other thing prohibited by regulation under subsection (3).

subsection.subsectiontext: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, prescribe additional limitations on the authority conferred under this section.

change.changenote: Heading for Part 6 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-227, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).
Division 1 of Part 6, sections 257 to 259.3 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-228, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Before a bylaw is adopted by a council, it must be given 3 readings by the council.
There must be at least one day between the third reading and the adoption of a bylaw.
If this or another Act requires that a bylaw receive

paragraph.paragraphtext: approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, a minister or the inspector, or
approval of the electors through a counter petition opportunity or assent of the electors,

section.subsandwich: the approval must be obtained after the bylaw has been given third reading and before it is adopted.

subsection.subsectiontext: If this or another Act requires that a bylaw receive both

paragraph.paragraphtext: approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, a minister or the inspector, and
approval of the electors through a counter petition opportunity or assent of the electors,

section.subsandwich: the approval under paragraph (a) must be obtained before the bylaw is submitted for approval under paragraph (b).

subsection.subsectiontext: Once adopted, a bylaw must

paragraph.paragraphtext: be signed by the mayor or other presiding member of the council meeting at which it was adopted, and
be signed by the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration].

section.marginalnote: Establishment of procedures for adopting bylaws

subsection.subsectiontext: A council must, in its bylaw under section 235 [procedure bylaw], establish the procedure that, subject to this Part, is to be followed in adopting bylaws.
Subject to section 257 (2), the bylaw may permit 2 or more readings at one meeting of council.

section.sectiontext: Unless otherwise provided,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the power to adopt a bylaw under this or any other Act includes the power to repeal or amend the original bylaw,
the included power to amend or repeal must be exercised by bylaw and is subject to the same approval and other requirements, if any, as the power to adopt the original bylaw, and
the included power may be exercised in the original bylaw.

section.marginalnote: When a bylaw comes into force
section.sectiontext: A municipal bylaw comes into force on the later of

paragraph.paragraphtext: the date it is adopted by council, and
a date set by the bylaw.

section.marginalnote: Exercise of powers through municipal code

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to this Act, a council may exercise some or all of its powers under this Act by the adoption of a comprehensive general bylaw.
Without limiting the authority of a council under subsection (1), a comprehensive general bylaw under that subsection may be cited as "The (name of municipality) Municipal Code".
A comprehensive general bylaw under subsection (1) is subject to all requirements that would apply to the exercise of the powers by separate bylaws.

section.sectiontext: A printed document purporting

paragraph.paragraphtext: Subject to be a copy of a municipal bylaw, and
to be printed by authority of the council of the municipality

section.secsandwich: is proof, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, of the bylaw and of the fact of its passage.

section.marginalnote: Bylaws must be available for public inspections

subsection.subsectiontext: The bylaws of a municipality must be available for public inspection in the municipal hall during its regular office hours.

change.changenote: Section 262 (2) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-229(a), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Subsection (1) does not apply to a security issuing bylaw providing for the issue of debenture or other evidence of indebtedness to a regional district or to the Municipal Finance Authority of British Columbia.

change.changenote: Section 262 (3) (a) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-229(b), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the bylaw is a security issuing bylaw, the notice must be served at least 5 days before the hearing and not more than 10 days after the adoption of the bylaw;

change.changenote: Section 262 (3) (c) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-229(c), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

paragraph.paragraphtext: in any other case, the notice must be served at least 10 days before the hearing and not more than one month after the adoption of the bylaw.

change.changenote: Section 262 (3.1) was added by 2003-52-229(d), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).
Section 266.2 was enacted by 2003-60-32, effective May 3, 2004 (BC Reg 175/2004).
change.amennote: [Note: above was amended by 2003-60-33(b), effective May 3, 2004 (BC Reg 175/2004).]

change.changenote: Section 266.2 (1) BEFORE amended by 2004-51-25, effective May 20, 2004 (Royal Assent).

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the regulations under the Local Government Bylaw Notice Enforcement Act, a municipal bylaw may be enforced by bylaw notice under and in accordance with that Act.

change.changenote: Division 3 of Part 6, sections 266 to 270 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-230, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: A council may make bylaws for

paragraph.paragraphtext: the purposes of enforcing the bylaws of the municipality by fine, imprisonment or both, and
inflicting fines, penalties and costs.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a bylaw establishes a lawful regulation or requirement to be observed in a municipality, a person who breaches the regulation or requirement commits an offence that is punishable in the same manner as if the bylaw had expressly forbidden persons from doing or refraining from doing the act.

In a prosecution for an offence against a municipal bylaw, the justice or court may impose all or part of the penalty or punishment authorized by the bylaw, this Act or the Offence Act, together with the costs of prosecution.

If a penalty, or part of a penalty, and all costs imposed are not paid promptly, the justice or court may, by order, authorize all or part of the penalty and costs to be levied by distress and sale of the offender's goods and chattels.

If there is no distress out of which the penalty and costs or part of the penalty and all of the costs can be levied, the justice or court may commit the offender to imprisonment for the term, or part of the term, specified in the bylaw.

section.marginalnote: Inspections to determine whether bylaws are being followed
section.sectiontext: If a council has authority to direct that a matter or thing be done by a person or that regulations be observed, the council may, by bylaw, authorize officers, employees and agents of the municipality to enter at all reasonable times on any property that is subject to the direction to ascertain whether the requirement is being met or the regulations are being observed.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a council has authority to require that a matter or thing be done by a person, the council may also direct that, if the person fails to take the required action, the matter or thing is to be done at the expense of the person in default with the costs incurred by the municipality recoverable from the person as a debt.
Section 376 applies to an amount recoverable under subsection (1) that is incurred for work done or services provided to land or improvements.

change.changenote: Section 267.1 was enacted by 2003-60-32, effective January 1, 2005 (BC Reg 175/2004).
change.amennote: [Note: above (2003-60-32) was amended by 2003-60-34, effective January 1, 2005 (BC Reg 175/2004).]

change.changenote: Division 4 of Part 6, sections 271 to 280 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-230, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).

section.marginalnote: Definition of person who is a "justice"
section.sectiontext: In this Division, justice has the same meaning as in the Offence Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council or a regional district board may, by bylaw,

paragraph.paragraphtext: designate for the purpose of this section a bylaw that comes within a category of bylaws prescribed under section 280 (b),
designate as a bylaw enforcement officer a person who comes within a class of persons prescribed under section 280 (c), and
authorize the use of any word or expression on a ticket issued under subsection (2) to designate an offence against a bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a bylaw is designated under subsection (1), a bylaw enforcement officer may lay an information by means of a ticket for contravention of the bylaw.
Despite section 13 (1) of the Offence Act, an information laid by means of a ticket is valid whether or not it is taken under oath.
The use on a ticket of

paragraph.paragraphtext: any word or expression authorized by bylaw under subsection (1) (c) to designate an offence against a bylaw, or
a general description of an offence against a bylaw,

section.subsandwich: is deemed sufficient for all purposes to describe the offence designated by that word or expression or general description.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purpose of section 274 (1), after consultation with the chief judge of the Provincial Court, the council or the regional district board may, by bylaw, set a fine not greater than $500 for contravention of a bylaw.
If a minimum or maximum fine is established by a bylaw, the fine set under subsection (5) must be not less than the minimum or more than the maximum fine established by the bylaw.
When laying an information by means of a ticket, a bylaw enforcement officer must indicate on the ticket the offence charged and must sign the ticket.
The bylaw enforcement officer must serve the ticket on the person alleged to have contravened the bylaw.
Service of a ticket under subsection (2) may be effected by

paragraph.paragraphtext: serving a copy of the ticket on the person alleged to have contravened the bylaw immediately after the alleged contravention, or
causing a copy of the ticket to be served in the same manner as a summons may be served under the Offence Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: Service of a ticket under subsection (2) may be proved by

paragraph.paragraphtext: the oral evidence given under oath of the person who served it, or
the certificate of the person who served the ticket, if the certificate is endorsed on the ticket or a copy of the ticket.

subsection.subsectiontext: The certificate referred to in subsection (4) is proof of the facts stated in the certificate and of the authority of the person who signed it without further proof of the person's appointment or signature.

section.marginalnote: Choice of paying fine or disputing ticket

subsection.subsectiontext: If a fine set in accordance with section 272 (5) is indicated on a ticket for an offence charged, the person on whom the ticket is served may, within 14 days after the date of service,

paragraph.paragraphtext: pay the fine indicated on the ticket to the council or regional district board in accordance with the prescribed instructions, or
dispute the allegation contained in the ticket by

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: delivering or having delivered to the address set out in the ticket a written notice of dispute, or
appearing in person at the location set out in the ticket to give notice of dispute.

subsection.subsectiontext: A notice of dispute under subsection (1) must contain an address for the person disputing the allegation and sufficient information to identify the ticket and the alleged contravention being disputed.
For the purpose of subsection (1), a notice of dispute that is delivered by mail is deemed to have been delivered on the date on which it was mailed.
A person who pays a fine in accordance with section 274 (1) (a) is deemed to have pleaded guilty to the offence with which the person was charged and to have paid the fine imposed.

If a person who is served with a ticket pays the fine as referred to in subsection (1), no conviction need be drawn up or entered unless it is required under the bylaw contravened or by the person convicted or by a prosecutor.
If notice of a dispute is given in accordance with section 274 (1) (b), the council or regional district board must refer the ticket to the Provincial Court for a hearing.

If a ticket is referred to the Provincial Court for a hearing under subsection (1), the clerk of the court must send to the person who was served with the ticket, by ordinary mail to the person's address set out in the notice of dispute, a notice of the hearing specifying a time and place for the appearance of the person before a justice.

If a person appears before a justice at the time and place specified in the notice of the hearing referred to in subsection (2), section 58 of the Offence Act does not apply to the person and the justice has jurisdiction to hear the dispute without examining the notice of dispute or the notice of the hearing or inquiring into the service of the ticket on the person.
If a person who is served with a ticket has

paragraph.paragraphtext: appeared before a justice at the time and place specified in the notice of the hearing referred to in subsection (2), and
pleaded guilty to or been found guilty of the offence with which the person was charged in the ticket,

section.subsandwich: no conviction need be drawn up or entered unless it is required under the bylaw contravened or by the person convicted or by a prosecutor.

subsection.subsectiontext: A person is deemed to have not disputed a charge if the person fails to appear before a justice to dispute the charge

paragraph.paragraphtext: at the time and place specified in the notice of the hearing referred to in section 276 (2), or
at a new time and place set under section 279 (4).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person is deemed under subsection (1) to have not disputed a charge, a justice must examine the ticket and proceed as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the ticket is complete and regular on its face, the justice must

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: convict the person in the person's absence and without a hearing, and
impose the fine set under section 272 (5) for the offence charged;

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the ticket is not complete and regular on its face, the justice must quash the proceeding.

subsection.subsectiontext: Nothing in subsection (1) or (2) is to be construed as abrogating the right of a person to appeal the conviction under section 102 of the Offence Act.
A person served with a ticket under section 273 is deemed to have not disputed the charge if

paragraph.paragraphtext: the person does not pay the fine or dispute the charge, as provided in section 274 (1), and
at least 14 days have elapsed after the ticket was served on the person.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person is deemed under subsection (1) to have not disputed the charge, a justice, on being satisfied that the conditions set out in that subsection have been met, must examine the ticket and proceed as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the ticket is complete and regular on its face, the justice must

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: convict the person in the person's absence and without a hearing, and
impose the fine set under section 272 (5) for the offence charged;

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the ticket is not complete and regular on its face, the justice must quash the proceeding.

subsection.subsectiontext: The conditions set out in subsection (1) may be proved to the satisfaction of the justice by oral evidence given under oath or by affidavit in the prescribed form.
Nothing in subsection (1) is to be construed as abrogating the right of a person to appeal the conviction under section 102 of the Offence Act.

section.marginalnote: Time extensions if person not at fault in failing to respond or appear

subsection.subsectiontext: A person who is served with a ticket may appear before a justice if

paragraph.paragraphtext: the person has, through no fault of that person, not had an opportunity to dispute the charge, and
not more than 30 days have elapsed since the end of the period referred to in section 274 (1).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person appears before a justice under subsection (1), the justice, on being satisfied of the facts by affidavit in the prescribed form, must

paragraph.paragraphtext: strike out the conviction, if any, and
allow the person 14 days after the date on which the conviction is struck to dispute the charge in accordance with section 274 (1).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person fails to appear before a justice to dispute a charge at the time and place specified in the notice of the hearing referred to in section 276 (2), the person may, within 30 days after the date specified in the notice, appear before a justice for a determination of whether or not the failure to appear was the person's fault.
If a person appears before a justice under subsection (3) and the justice is satisfied by affidavit in the prescribed form that the failure to appear was not the person's fault, the justice must

paragraph.paragraphtext: strike out the conviction, if any, and
set a new time and place for the appearance of the person before a justice.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a conviction is struck out under subsection (2) or (4), the justice must give the person a certificate of the fact in the prescribed form.

section.marginalnote: Regulations in relation to ticket offences
section.sectiontext: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: prescribing the form and content of the tickets issued under section this Division;
prescribing, by reference to their subject matter or otherwise, categories of bylaws for the purpose of section 272 (1) (a);
prescribing classes of persons for the purpose of section 272 (1) (b);
prescribing the form of a certificate of service for the purpose of section 273 (4);
prescribing instructions for paying a fine for the purpose of section 274 (1) (a);
prescribing the form of affidavits for the purposes of section 278 (3) and 279 (2) and (4);

change.changenote: Division 5 of Part 6, sections 280.1 to 280.6 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-230, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, authorize a designated municipal officer to consolidate one or more of the bylaws of the municipality.
In consolidating a bylaw, the officer must

paragraph.paragraphtext: incorporate in it all amendments that have been made to the bylaw, and
omit any provision that has been repealed or that has expired.

subsection.subsectiontext: A printed document purporting

paragraph.paragraphtext: to be a copy of a bylaw consolidated under this section, and
to be printed by authority of the designated officer

section.subsandwich: is proof, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, of the original bylaw, of all bylaws amending it and of the fact of passage of the original and all amending bylaws.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, authorize the revision of all or any of the bylaws of the municipality.
A bylaw under subsection (1) may authorize one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: consolidating a bylaw by incorporating in it all amendments to the bylaw;
omitting and providing for the repeal of a bylaw or a provision of a bylaw that is expired, inoperative, obsolete, spent or otherwise ineffective;

omitting, without providing for its repeal, a bylaw or a provision of a bylaw that is of a transitional nature or that refers only to a particular place, person or thing or that has no general application throughout the municipality;
combining 2 or more bylaws into one, dividing a bylaw into 2 or more bylaws, moving provisions from one bylaw to another and creating a bylaw from provisions of one or more bylaws;
altering the citation and title of a bylaw and the numbering and arrangement of its provisions;
adding, changing or omitting a note, heading, title, marginal note, diagram, map, plan or example to a bylaw;
omitting the preamble and long title of a bylaw;
omitting forms or schedules contained in a bylaw that can more conveniently be contained in a resolution, and adding to the bylaw authority for forms or schedules to be established by resolution;
correcting clerical, grammatical and typographical errors;
making changes, without changing the substance of the bylaw, to bring out more clearly what is considered to be the meaning of a bylaw or to improve the expression of the law.

section.marginalnote: Revision may consolidate existing bylaws into municipal code

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to this Act, a bylaw under section 280.2 may authorize a revision to consolidate and revise bylaw provisions respecting any or all matters within the jurisdiction of the municipality into a comprehensive general bylaw.
Without limiting the authority of a council under subsection (1), a comprehensive general bylaw consolidated under that subsection may be cited as provided in section 259.1.
Changes to a comprehensive general bylaw consolidated under subsection (1) are subject to all requirements that would apply to the exercise of the powers by separate bylaws.
In order to be effective, a revised bylaw must be adopted by bylaw.

Before a bylaw under subsection (1) is given third reading, the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration] must certify that the proposed revised bylaw has been revised in accordance with the bylaw authorizing the revision.

After a proposed revised bylaw is certified under subsection (2) and before it is adopted, it may only be amended if the change made by the amendment is in accordance with the bylaw authorizing the revision.
A bylaw under subsection (1) must specify the date on which the revised bylaw is to come into force.

A revised bylaw adopted under this section is deemed to have been adopted as if all requirements respecting the approval and adoption of the bylaw provision for which a provision in the revised bylaw is substituted have been met.
When a revised bylaw comes into force, the bylaw provisions that it revises are repealed to the extent that they are incorporated in the revised bylaw.

A reference in an enactment or document to a provision of a bylaw that has been repealed under subsection (1) is deemed, in respect of any transaction, matter or thing occurring after the revised bylaw comes into force, to be a reference to the provision of the revised bylaw that has been substituted for the repealed provision.
A revised bylaw does not operate as new law but has effect and must be interpreted as a consolidation of the law contained in the bylaw provisions replaced by the revised bylaw.

To the extent that a provision of a revised bylaw has the same effect as the provision of a previous bylaw for which it is substituted, the provision of the revised bylaw operates retrospectively as well as prospectively and is deemed to have come into force on the date on which the previous bylaw provision came into force.
If a provision of a revised bylaw does not have the same effect as the provision of a previous bylaw for which it is substituted,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the provision of the previous bylaw prevails with respect to all transactions, matters and things occurring before the date on which the revised bylaw comes into force, and
the provision of the revised bylaw prevails with respect to all later transactions, matters and things.

subsection.subsectiontext: If an error is made in the revision of a bylaw and the revised bylaw has been adopted under section 280.4, the error may be corrected by bylaw in accordance with the bylaw authorizing the revision.

A bylaw under subsection (1) is deemed to have been adopted as if all requirements respecting the approval and adoption of a bylaw provision for which the provision in the revised bylaw was substituted have been met.
