division.divisiontext: Reservation and Dedication of Real Property

section.marginalnote: Power to reserve municipal land for public purpose

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, reserve for a particular municipal or other public purpose land owned by the municipality.
A reservation under subsection (1) may be removed by a bylaw adopted by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the council members.
Before adopting a bylaw under subsection (2), the council must provide the electors with a counter petition opportunity.

section.marginalnote: Power to dedicate municipal land for public purpose

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw with the assent of the electors, dedicate for a municipal or other public purpose real property owned by the municipality.
Despite subsection (1), the assent of the electors is not required for the dedication, by any means, of real property

paragraph.paragraphtext: for highways, or
for any other public purpose if the real property is 5 000 m2 or less in area.

section.marginalnote: Power to cancel the dedication of a highway

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw,

paragraph.paragraphtext: cancel the dedication of a highway or portion of a highway that has been closed to traffic under section 527 [establishing and closing highways], and
rededicate the highway or portion of a highway as a park or public square.

subsection.subsectiontext: Before adopting a bylaw under this section, the council must hold a public hearing in accordance with section 890.
On adopting a bylaw under this section, the council must file in the land title office a copy of the bylaw and a reference plan of the rededicated area.

As an exception to subsection (3), the registrar of land titles may accept an explanatory plan instead of the reference plan referred to in that subsection if the registrar is satisfied that the rededicated area is satisfactorily shown on the explanatory plan.
A bylaw under this section does not operate to effect a rededication of a highway that was dedicated by the deposit of a subdivision or reference plan in the land title office if

paragraph.paragraphtext: the owner of the land at the time the plan was deposited is the owner of all of the parcels created by the plan, and
the highway has not been developed for its intended purpose.

subsection.subsectiontext: A reservation bylaw under section 302 or a dedication bylaw under section 303 does not commit or authorize a local government to proceed with implementation of the purpose for which the property is reserved or dedicated.

All bylaws enacted or works undertaken by a local government directly affecting property that is reserved under section 302 or dedicated under section 303 must be consistent with the purpose for which the property is reserved or dedicated.

section.marginalnote: Control of Crown land parks dedicated by subdivision

subsection.subsectiontext: If land in a municipality is dedicated to the public for the purpose of a park or a public square by subdivision plan deposited in the land title office by which title is vested in the Crown, the municipality is entitled to possession and control of the land for that purpose.

If land in a municipality was dedicated as referred to in subsection (1) before this Act came into force, the municipality is deemed to have had possession and control of it for that purpose from the date it was dedicated, and continues to have that possession and control.
If a municipality

paragraph.paragraphtext: is entitled to possession and control of land under section 305.1 [Crown land parks dedicated by subdivision], or
holds title to park land under section 941 (14),

section.subsandwich: the council may, by bylaw, dispose of a portion of that land in exchange for other land suitable for a park or public square.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (1) may provide that, instead of taking land in exchange, the proceeds of the disposal are to be placed to the credit of a reserve fund under Part 13 established for the purpose of acquiring park lands.
Before adopting a bylaw under subsection (1), the council must provide a counter petition opportunity in relation to the proposed bylaw.
All land taken in exchange under this section is dedicated for the purpose of a park or public square and the title to it vests

paragraph.paragraphtext: in the case of land referred to in subsection (1) (a), in the Crown with right of possession and control in the municipality, and
in the case of land referred to in subsection (1) (b), in the municipality.

subsection.subsectiontext: Transfers under this section of land referred to in subsection (1) (a) or (b)

paragraph.paragraphtext: have effect free of any dedication to the public for the purpose of a park or a public square, and
in the case of land referred to in subsection (1) (a), have effect as a Crown grant.

change.changenote: Section 305.1 (1) BEFORE amended by 2000-7-38, effective January 1, 2001 (BC Reg 399/2000).

Before adopting a bylaw under subsection (1), the council must provide a counter petition opportunity in relation to the proposed bylaw.
All deeds executed under this section have effect as a Crown grant, free of any dedication to the public for the purpose of a park or a public square.
All land taken in exchange under this section is dedicated for the purpose of a park or public square and the title to it vests in the Crown with right of possession in the municipality.

section.marginalnote: Sale or lease of municipal forest reserve

subsection.subsectiontext: As a limitation on section 176 (1) (d) [corporate powers — property], a council must not sell or lease land set aside as a municipal forest reserve except as provided in this Division.
A council may, by bylaw, withdraw land from a municipal forest reserve if the council has provided a counter petition opportunity in relation to the proposed bylaw.
In addition to the information required by section 172.4, the notice of a counter petition opportunity under subsection (2) of this section must state

paragraph.paragraphtext: the purpose for which the council intends to withdraw the land from the municipal forest reserve, and
if this is in relation to a sale of the land, the price that is to be received.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw with the assent of the electors, lease for a term not longer than 99 years, all or part of a municipal forest reserve, subject to the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the agreement must make adequate provision for the protection of the municipal forest reserve on a sustained yield basis and for protection from fire;
the annual rental agreed on must be based on area and current values of the annual cutting;
the lessee must covenant to pay normal municipal taxes on the land, and on any structure erected or placed on the land either temporarily or permanently;
the agreement must be embodied in the bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purpose of exercising or performing its powers, duties and functions, a municipality may expropriate real property or works, or an interest in them, in accordance with the Expropriation Act.
The power under subsection (1) also applies to property outside the municipality for the purposes of

paragraph.paragraphtext: a service provided by the municipality to an area outside the municipality, or
establishing and managing quarries, sand and gravel pits to acquire material for municipal works.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a municipality expropriates real property or works under subsection (1) or any other enactment, compensation is payable to the owners, occupiers or other persons interested in the property for any damages necessarily resulting from the exercise of those powers beyond any advantage which the claimant may derive from the contemplated work.

Without limiting section 309 [expropriation power], a municipality may, for the purposes of one or more of its services, authorize its agents or employees to enter on, break up, take or enter into possession of and use real property without the consent of the owners of the property.
If a municipality exercises an authority to provide a service outside the municipality, the power under subsection (1) applies to property outside the municipality in relation to that service.

section.marginalnote: Power to expropriate water diversion licences and related works
section.sectiontext: Without limiting section 309, in addition to the rights conferred on licensees under sections 27 and 28 of the Water Act, a municipality may expropriate

paragraph.paragraphtext: a licence authorizing the diversion of water from a stream suitable for a water supply for the municipality, and
any work constructed or used under authority of the licence.

section.marginalnote: Entry on land to mitigate damage that may be caused by municipality

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may provide for entering on real property or works that the council anticipates may be injuriously affected by the exercise of any of its powers, for the purpose of carrying out, and to carry out, works of construction, maintenance or repair in mitigation of injury done or anticipated or in reduction of compensation.

Powers granted under subsection (1) may include, in any street grading works, removal of the substance of the adjacent land or the filling in of adjacent land to produce a grade uniform with the graded street.
If a municipality

paragraph.paragraphtext: exercises a power to enter on, break up, take or enter into possession of and use any property without the consent of the owners of the property, or injuriously affects property by the exercise of any of its powers, and
exercises a power referred to in paragraph (a) that does not constitute an expropriation within the meaning of the Expropriation Act,

section.subsandwich: compensation is payable for any loss or damages caused by the exercise of the power.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (1), compensation must be as determined and paid as soon as reasonably possible in an amount set

paragraph.paragraphtext: by agreement between the claimant and the municipality, or
if no agreement is reached, by the Expropriation Compensation Board.

section.sectiontext: If the current municipal revenue is not sufficient for the funds required to pay compensation in respect of property expropriated or injured or to carry out works referred to in section 311 [entry on land to mitigate damage], the council may,

paragraph.paragraphtext: by loan authorization bylaw adopted with the approval of the inspector, borrow the required sums, or
by bylaw adopted with the approval of the inspector, use money from a reserve fund to the extent required.

change.changenote: Division 4 of Part 8, sections 314 to 326 BEFORE amended by 2003-52-253, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Power to accept property on trust

subsection.subsectiontext: Without limiting section 176 [corporate powers], a council may accept any property devised, bequeathed, conveyed or otherwise transferred to the municipality, subject to any trusts on which the property is transferred.
If the sale of property is necessary to carry out the terms of a trust under which it was transferred, a council may sell the property despite any limitations or restrictions in this Act.
All money held by a municipality subject to a trust, until required for the purposes of the trust, must be invested in the manner provided for the investment of sinking funds.

If, in the opinion of a council, the terms or trusts imposed by a donor, settlor, transferor or testator are no longer in the best interests of the municipality, the council may apply to the Supreme Court for an order under subsection (5).

On an application under subsection (4), the Supreme Court may vary the terms or trusts as the court considers will better further both the intent of the donor, settlor, transferor or testator and the best interests of the municipality.
Section 87 of the Trustee Act [discharge of trustee's duty] applies to an order under subsection (5).

section.marginalnote: Power to convey land to school board in trust
section.sectiontext: Without limiting section 176 [corporate powers], a council may transfer to the board of school trustees or francophone education authority having jurisdiction in the municipality, in trust for school purposes, any land reserved or acquired by the municipality for school purposes.

change.changenote: Section 314 (4) and (5) BEFORE amended by 2009-13-195,Sch 1, effective March 31, 2014 (BC Reg 148/2013).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, in the opinion of a board, the terms or trusts imposed by a donor, settlor, transferor or testator are no longer in the best interests of the regional district, the board may apply to the Supreme Court for an order under subsection (5).

On an application under subsection (4), the Supreme Court may vary, by order, the terms or trusts that the court considers will better further both the intent of the donor, settlor, transferor or testator and the best interests of the regional district.

change.changenote: Divisions 4.1 and 4.2 of Part 8, sections 315.1 to 315.3 were added by 2003-52-253, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).
Part 9 sections 327 to 338 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-254, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A municipality must have a financial plan that is adopted annually, by bylaw, before the annual property tax bylaw is adopted.
For certainty, the financial plan may be amended by bylaw at any time.
The planning period for a financial plan is 5 years, being the year in which it is specified to come into force and the following 4 years.
The financial plan must set out the following for each year of the planning period:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the proposed expenditures by the municipality;
the proposed funding sources;
the proposed transfers between funds.

subsection.subsectiontext: The total of the proposed expenditures and transfers to other funds for a year must not exceed the total of the proposed funding sources and transfers from other funds for the year.
The proposed expenditures must set out separate amounts for each of the following as applicable:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the amount required to pay interest and principal on municipal debt;
the amount required for capital purposes;
the amount required for a deficiency referred to in subsection (9);
the amount required for other municipal purposes.

subsection.subsectiontext: The proposed funding sources must set out separate amounts for each of the following as applicable:

paragraph.paragraphtext: revenue from property value taxes;
revenue from parcel taxes;
revenue from fees and charges;
revenue from other sources;
proceeds from borrowing, other than borrowing under section 334.3 [revenue anticipation borrowing].

subsection.subsectiontext: The proposed transfers between funds must set out separate amounts for each of the following as applicable:

paragraph.paragraphtext: special funds under Part 13;
development cost charge funds;
accumulated surplus.

subsection.subsectiontext: If actual expenditures and transfers to other funds for a year exceed actual revenues and transfers from other funds for the year, the resulting deficiency must be included in the next year's financial plan as an expenditure in that year.

section.sectiontext: A council must undertake a process of public consultation regarding the proposed financial plan before it is adopted.

subsection.subsectiontext: The fiscal year for a municipality is the calendar year.
Municipal financial statements for a fiscal year must be

paragraph.paragraphtext: prepared by the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 199 [financial administration], and
presented to council for its acceptance.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (4), the financial statements must be prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles for local governments.
The inspector may require or authorize, generally or for a specified municipality, that the financial statements vary from or include additional information to the requirements of subsection (3).
By May 15 in each year, a municipality must submit to the inspector its audited financial statements for the preceding year and any other financial information required by the inspector.
By June 30 in each year, a municipality must hold a council or other public meeting for the purpose of presenting

paragraph.paragraphtext: the audited financial statements of the preceding year, and
the report under section 329.1 [reporting of remuneration and expenses].

subsection.subsectiontext: The council must give notice of the meeting by publication in a newspaper, including

paragraph.paragraphtext: the date, time and place of the meeting, and
a statement that the financial statements and any reports to be presented at the meeting are available for inspection at the municipal hall.

subsection.subsectiontext: A copy of the financial statements and reports must be available for public inspection at the municipal hall during its regular office hours from the time the notice under subsection (2) is given until June 30 in the following year.

section.sectiontext: At least once a year, a council must have prepared a report separately listing the following for each council member by name:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the total amount of remuneration paid to the council member for discharge of the duties of office, including any amount specified as an expense allowance;

the total amount of expense payments for the council member made to the council member as reimbursement for expenses incurred by the council member or as an allowance that is not reported under paragraph (a);
the total amount of any benefits, including insurance policies and policies for medical or dental services, provided to the council member or the member's dependants.

section.marginalnote: Right of elector to complain about accounting

subsection.subsectiontext: An elector may complain in writing to the council or to the municipal auditor, if the elector considers that

paragraph.paragraphtext: a disbursement, expenditure, liability or other transaction is not authorized by or under this or another Act, or
there has been a theft, misuse or other defalcation or irregularity in the funds, accounts, assets, liabilities and financial obligations of the municipality or of one of its administrative bodies.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a complaint is made under subsection (1) to the council, the council must give notice of the matter to the auditor.
If a complaint is made under subsection (1) to the municipal auditor, the auditor must give notice of the matter to the council.
A council must appoint an auditor for the municipality.
The auditor must be

paragraph.paragraphtext: a member in good standing, or a partnership whose partners are members in good standing, of the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants, or the Certified General Accountants' Association of British Columbia, or
a person certified by the board established under section 181 of the Company Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the engagement of an auditor is terminated, the auditor may appeal the decision to the inspector, who may confirm or set aside the termination.
An appeal under this section must be made in writing to the inspector within one month after the auditor is notified of the termination.
The auditor must file a copy of the notice of appeal under subsection (2) with the municipality.
The council must not appoint another auditor until the time allowed for an appeal by the auditor has elapsed or, if an appeal has been made, until the appeal has been dealt with by the inspector.
As a limitation on section 176 (1) (e) [corporate powers — delegation], a council may only delegate its powers, duties and functions under this Division to a committee of council.
Reports submitted by the auditor to a committee under this section are deemed to have been submitted to council.
The auditor for the municipality must report to the council on the annual financial statements of the municipality.
The report under subsection (1) must be in accordance with the form and the reporting standards recommended by the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants.
In addition to the report under subsection (1),

paragraph.paragraphtext: the council or the inspector may require further reports from the auditor, and
the auditor may, on the auditor's own initiative, make further reports.

subsection.subsectiontext: On request by the inspector, the auditor must forward to the inspector copies of

paragraph.paragraphtext: reports under subsections (1) and (3), and
written communications in relation to those reports from the auditor to the council, a committee of council or a municipal officer.

subsection.subsectiontext: The auditor has the power and duty to conduct the examinations necessary to prepare the reports referred to in section 331.3 [auditor's reports].
The auditor has a right of access at all reasonable times to

paragraph.paragraphtext: the records of the council and municipality,
the records of any other body that, under this or another Act, exercises the powers of the municipality, including a municipal police board, and
any computer, other data processing equipment and software that are owned or leased by the municipality or other body and used for financial recording or reporting purposes.

subsection.subsectiontext: Council members, municipal officials, employees and agents of the municipality and other persons must give the auditor any information, reports or explanations the auditor considers necessary.

An auditor who receives information from a person whose right to disclose that information is restricted by law holds that information under the same restrictions respecting disclosure that govern the person from whom the information was obtained.

section.sectiontext: Revenues from the following may be used towards the payment of municipal expenditures:

paragraph.paragraphtext: property value taxes under Division 1 of Part 10.1;
parcel taxes under Division 2 of Part 10.1;
fees and charges under Division 3 of Part 10.1;
revenues raised by other means authorized under this or another Act;
revenues received by way of agreement, enterprise, gift, grant or otherwise.

subsection.subsectiontext: A municipality must not make an expenditure other than one authorized under subsection (2) or (3).
A municipality may make an expenditure that is provided for that year in its financial plan, other than an expenditure that is expressly prohibited by this or another Act.
A municipality may make an expenditure for an emergency that was not contemplated for that year in its financial plan, other than an expenditure that is expressly prohibited by this or another Act.
In relation to the authority under subsection (3), the council must establish procedures

paragraph.paragraphtext: to authorize expenditures under that subsection, and
to provide for such expenditures to be reported to the council at a regular meeting.

subsection.subsectiontext: If an expenditure is made under subsection (3), as soon as practicable, the council must amend the financial plan to include the expenditure and the funding source for the expenditure.
For certainty, the authority under subsection (3) does not include the authority to borrow for the purpose of making the expenditure.

section.marginalnote: Limit on borrowing and other liabilities

subsection.subsectiontext: A municipality may only incur a liability under the authority of this or another Act.
Except as permitted under subsection (5), a municipality must not incur a liability that causes the aggregate liabilities for all purposes to exceed the total of

paragraph.paragraphtext: 20% of the current value, as shown on the most recent audited financial statements, of the tangible capital assets of the municipality, and
20% of the average of the converted value of land and improvements in the municipality for the current year and the 2 immediately preceding years.

subsection.subsectiontext: The following are to be excluded in determining the aggregate liabilities referred to in subsection (2):

paragraph.paragraphtext: liabilities under section 334.2 [authority to incur prescribed liabilities];
debt under section 334.3 [revenue anticipation borrowing];
debt of another public authority for which the municipality is jointly and severally liable under this or another Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: Except for a liability referred to in subsection (3) (b), a municipality must not incur a liability for which expenditures are required during the planning period for its financial plan unless those expenditures are included for the applicable year in the financial plan.
With the approval of the inspector, the aggregate liabilities of a municipality may exceed the limit under subsection (2).
A council may, under an agreement, incur a liability if

paragraph.paragraphtext: the liability is not a debenture debt, and
the period of the liability is not longer than the reasonable life expectancy of the activity, work or service under the agreement.

subsection.subsectiontext: If an agreement under subsection (1) is

paragraph.paragraphtext: for more than 5 years, or
for a period that by exercising rights of renewal or extension could exceed 5 years,

section.subsandwich: the council must not incur the liability until it has provided a counter petition opportunity in relation to the proposed liability.

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition to the information required by section 172.4, the notice of a counter petition opportunity under subsection (2) must include the nature, term and amount of the liability.
As an exception to subsection (2), a counter petition opportunity is not required for a liability to be incurred

paragraph.paragraphtext: for the supply of materials, equipment or services under an agreement referred to in section 3 of the Police Act, or
under an employment contract or collective agreement.

subsection.subsectiontext: A municipality may incur a liability that is within a class prescribed under this section.
The authority to incur a liability under this section is not authority to borrow for the purposes of the liability.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing classes of liability that are imposed by or under an enactment as liabilities to which this section applies.
A council may, by bylaw, provide for the borrowing of money that may be necessary

paragraph.paragraphtext: to meet current lawful expenditures, and
to pay amounts required to meet the municipality's taxing obligations in relation to another local government or other public body.

subsection.subsectiontext: The debt outstanding under this section must not exceed the total of

paragraph.paragraphtext: the unpaid taxes for all purposes imposed during the current year, and
the money remaining due from other governments.

subsection.subsectiontext: Before the adoption of the annual property tax bylaw in any year, the taxes in that year are deemed to be 75% of all taxes imposed for all purposes in the preceding year.
When collected, revenue from property value taxes must be used as necessary to repay money borrowed under this section.
A council may, by bylaw adopted with the approval of the inspector, contract a debt for any purpose of a capital nature.
A bylaw and the debt under this section must comply with the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the debt must not cause the aggregate liabilities under this section to exceed the amount equal to $50 multiplied by the municipal population;
the debt and securities for it must be payable no later than the lesser of

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: 5 years from the date on which the securities were issued, or
the reasonable life expectancy of the capital asset for which the debt is contracted;

paragraph.paragraphtext: the bylaw must set out

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the amount of the debt intended to be incurred, and
in brief and general terms, the purpose for which the debt is to be incurred.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by a loan authorization bylaw adopted with the approval of the inspector, incur a liability by borrowing for one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: any purpose of a capital nature;
to provide assistance within the meaning of section 181 [definition of assistance] by

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: lending to any person or public authority to which the municipality may provide assistance under Part 5 [Corporate Powers], or
guaranteeing repayment of borrowing, or providing security for the borrowing, of a person or public authority referred to in subparagraph (i),

section.parasandwich: but only if the assistance is provided under an agreement;

paragraph.paragraphtext: to comply with an order or requirement to pay money into the Supreme Court as security

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: for payment of a judgment or other debt,
for damages or costs, or
for the costs of an appeal from the decision of a court or an arbitrator;

paragraph.paragraphtext: to satisfy a judgment or other order of a court against the municipality;
to satisfy an award resulting from an arbitrator's determination of liability or quantum of damages against the municipality, including orders of the arbitrator related to that determination.

subsection.subsectiontext: A loan authorization bylaw must set out the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the total amount proposed to be borrowed under the bylaw;
in brief and general terms, each of the purposes for which the debt is to be incurred;
the amount allocated by the bylaw to each of the purposes for which the debt is to be incurred;
the maximum term for which the debentures may be issued.

subsection.subsectiontext: The power to adopt a loan authorization bylaw may not be exercised through the adoption of a comprehensive general bylaw under section 259.1 and loan authorization bylaws may not be consolidated into a comprehensive general bylaw under section 280.3.
The authority to borrow under a loan authorization bylaw ends,

paragraph.paragraphtext: in the case of a loan authorization bylaw under subsection (1) (b), at the end of the term of the agreement required by that subsection, and
in other cases, 5 years from the date of adoption of the bylaw,

section.subsandwich: for any part of the amount authorized by the bylaw that has not already been used to secure borrowing under section 335.2 [temporary borrowing under loan authorization bylaw] or included under a security issuing bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: The maximum term of a debt that may be authorized by a loan authorization bylaw is as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: in the case of a bylaw under subsection (1) (a), the lesser of

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: 30 years, and
the reasonable life expectancy of the capital asset for which the debt is contracted;

paragraph.paragraphtext: in the case of a loan authorization bylaw under subsection (1) (b), the remaining term of the agreement under which the assistance is provided;
in all other cases, 30 years.

section.marginalnote: Counter petition opportunity required for borrowings

subsection.subsectiontext: Except as provided in subsection (2), the council must provide a counter petition opportunity in relation to a proposed loan authorization bylaw.
A counter petition opportunity is not required if the money to be borrowed is for one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a purpose referred to in section 335 (1) (c) to (e) [loan authorization bylaws — borrowings for court orders and other matters];
a purpose referred to in section 313 [funding for expropriation or mitigation];
works under an order of the Inspector of Dikes;
works required to be carried out pursuant to an order under section 32 of the Waste Management Act;
works required to be carried out under the Environment Management Act pursuant to an order of the minister responsible for that Act or the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

subsection.subsectiontext: A counter petition opportunity must not be provided in relation to a loan authorization bylaw unless the necessary consent or approval required by an Act has been obtained.

In addition to the information required by section 172.4, the notice of a counter petition opportunity under this section must include the information referred to in section 335 (2) [loan authorization bylaw].
With the approval of the inspector, a loan authorization bylaw may be amended or repealed without providing a counter petition opportunity.

If a council exercises the option of seeking electors' assent to a loan authorization bylaw, rather than providing a counter petition opportunity, any number of specified services is deemed to be a single distinct purpose for the purposes of section 160 (1) [each vote must be for a distinct purpose].

section.marginalnote: Temporary borrowing under loan authorization bylaw

subsection.subsectiontext: A council that has adopted a loan authorization bylaw may, by bylaw, temporarily borrow money not exceeding the difference between the total amount authorized by the loan authorization bylaw and the amount already borrowed in relation to that bylaw.
The proceeds of the borrowing under a security issuing bylaw, or as much as may be necessary, must be used to repay the money temporarily borrowed.

A council may, by a security issuing bylaw adopted with the approval of the inspector, provide for the issue of debentures or other evidence of debt for all or part of the debt authorized by one or more loan authorization bylaws.
A security issuing bylaw must specify the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the loan authorization bylaws that authorize the borrowing;
the amount of borrowing authorized by each loan authorization bylaw;
the amount already borrowed under each loan authorization bylaw;
the amount remaining to be borrowed under each loan authorization bylaw;
the amount now being issued under each loan authorization bylaw;
the term of the debt.

subsection.subsectiontext: The proceeds of the borrowing under a security issuing bylaw must be allotted proportionately for the purposes of each loan authorization bylaw referred to in subsection (2) (a).
A security issuing bylaw must not be adopted

paragraph.paragraphtext: while any proceeding is pending in which the validity of a loan authorization bylaw containing the authority under which the security issuing bylaw is to be adopted is called into question or by which it is sought to be set aside, or
until the time for giving notice of intention to apply to set aside the loan authorization bylaw expires.

subsection.subsectiontext: A security issuing bylaw may authorize the issue of debentures under terms and conditions specified in the bylaw.

section.marginalnote: Regional district financing of municipal undertaking

subsection.subsectiontext: Except as permitted by the Municipal Finance Authority Act, a municipality must not adopt a security issuing bylaw unless the financing is to be undertaken under section 835 [financing municipal undertakings] of this Act through the Municipal Finance Authority of British Columbia.

In relation to regional district financing under section 835 for a municipality, the security issuing bylaw of the municipality is the regional district's authority to proceed under that section and must not be amended or repealed without the consent of the board.

section.marginalnote: Appeal from inspector's decision regarding borrowing bylaws

subsection.subsectiontext: If the inspector refuses to approve a loan authorization bylaw or a security issuing bylaw, the municipality may appeal to the minister.
On an appeal under subsection (1), the minister must hear and determine the matter, and may confirm or rescind the decision of the inspector.
The determination on the appeal is conclusive and binding on all parties, including the inspector.

section.sectiontext: Money held by a municipality that is not immediately required may be invested or reinvested by the council in one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: securities of Canada or of a province;
securities guaranteed for principal and interest by Canada or by a province;
securities of a municipality or regional district;
securities of the Greater Vancouver Water District, if the municipality is in or partly in the district;
securities of the Municipal Finance Authority;
investments guaranteed by a chartered bank;
deposits in a savings institution, or non-equity or membership shares of a credit union;
pooled investment funds under section 16 of the Municipal Finance Authority Act.

division.divisiontext: Restrictions on Use of Municipal Funds

section.marginalnote: Purposes for which money may be used

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to this section, money borrowed by a municipality under any Act must not be used for a purpose other than that specified in the bylaw or agreement authorizing the borrowing.

A council may, by bylaw adopted with the assent of the electors, use all or part of money borrowed for a specific purpose and not repayable in the current year for any other lawful purpose of the municipality.

If some of the money borrowed for a specified purpose remains unused after payment of the costs related to that purpose, a council may, by bylaw, provide for the use of the unused money for one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: to retire debentures issued for the purpose;
to purchase and cancel debentures issued for the purpose;
for expenditures of a nature similar to the purpose in the bylaw authorizing the money to be borrowed;
for a reserve fund for matters in paragraph (a), (b) or (c), in which case Part 13 applies.

section.marginalnote: Liabilities for use of money contrary to Act

subsection.subsectiontext: A council member who votes for a bylaw or resolution authorizing the expenditure, investment or other use of money contrary to this Act is personally liable to the municipality for the amount.

As an exception, subsection (1) does not apply if the council member relied on information provided by a municipal officer or employee and the officer or employee was guilty of dishonesty, gross negligence or malicious or wilful misconduct in relation to the provision of the information.

In addition to any other penalty to which the person may be liable, a council member who is liable to the municipality under subsection (1) is disqualified from holding municipal office for 5 years from the date of the vote.
Money due a municipality under this section may be recovered for the municipality by

paragraph.paragraphtext: the municipality,
an elector or taxpayer of the municipality, or
a person who holds a security under a borrowing made by the municipality.

change.changenote: Section 339 (1) (f) BEFORE amended by 2000-26-27, effective December 31, 2000.

paragraph.paragraphtext: a cemetery under the Cemetery and Funeral Services Act actually used and occupied for the interment of the dead or designated an approved interment area by the registrar under that Act;

change.changenote: Section 339 (1) (p) BEFORE amended by 2003-3-17, effective December 31, 2003.

paragraph.paragraphtext: sewage treatment plants, manure storage facilities, effluent reservoirs, effluent lagoons, deodorizing equipment, dust and particulate matter eliminators;

change.changenote: Heading of Part 10 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-255, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).
Division 1 of Part 10, sections 339 to 346 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-256, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Unless otherwise provided in this Act, the following property is exempt from taxation to the extent indicated:

paragraph.paragraphtext: land, improvements or both vested in, or held by, the Provincial government or the municipality;
land, improvements or both vested in, or held by, the municipality jointly with another municipality or a regional district;
land, improvements or both exempt from municipal taxation by another Act;
land, improvements or both of a public library under the Library Act;
land, improvements or both that are vested in, or held by, a municipality and occupied by a public library under the Library Act;

land, improvements or both of an Indian, in a municipality incorporated under section 12 (1), who is an owner under the letters patent, except taxation under section 359 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes];

land, improvements or both in a municipality, other than a municipality incorporated under section 12 (1), held in trust by the Crown for a band of Indians unless leased to or occupied by a person who is not a member of the band;

the land of a cemetery under the Cemetery and Funeral Services Act actually used and occupied for the interment of the dead or designated an approved interment area by the registrar under that Act, together with the improvements included as part of the cemetery under that Act, other than

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: funeral homes within the meaning of that Act,
crematoriums within the meaning of that Act, and
premises, or that part of premises, used primarily for the sale of cemetery services or funeral services within the meaning of that Act;

paragraph.paragraphtext: a building set apart for public worship, and the land on which the building stands, together with

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: any church hall considered by the council to be necessary to the exempted building, and the land on which the church hall stands, and
any area of land surrounding the exempted building, an exempted hall, or both, that the council may, by bylaw, exempt;

paragraph.paragraphtext: a building that was constructed or reconstructed with the assistance of aid granted by the Provincial government after January 1, 1947 but before April 1, 1974 and that is owned and used exclusively without profit by a corporation to provide homes for elderly citizens, together with

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the land on which the building stands, and
any area of land surrounding the exempted building that the council may, by bylaw, exempt;

paragraph.paragraphtext: a building set apart and used solely as a hospital under the Hospital Act, except a private hospital under that Act, together with

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the land on which the building stands, and
any area of land surrounding the building, not including land exempted under the Hospital Act or Hospital District Act, that the council may, by bylaw, exempt;

paragraph.paragraphtext: land and improvements for future hospital requirements that are

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: designated for the purposes of this section by the Minister of Health, and
vested in, or held by, a society or corporation that is not operated for profit and that has as an object the operation of a hospital;

paragraph.paragraphtext: a building owned by an incorporated institution of learning that is regularly giving children instruction accepted as equivalent to that given in a public school, in actual occupation by the institution and wholly in use for the purpose of giving the instruction, together with

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the land on which the building stands, and
any area of land surrounding the exempted building that the council may, by bylaw, exempt as being reasonably necessary in connection with that building;

paragraph.paragraphtext: fruit trees;

improvements, other than dwellings and the fixtures, machinery and similar things mentioned in paragraph (n), erected on farm land and used exclusively to operate a farm, up to but not exceeding an assessed value of $50 000;

fixtures, machinery and similar things located on farm land and used exclusively to operate the farm that, if erected or placed, in or on land, a building or fixture or structure in or on it, would, as between landlord and tenant, be removable by the tenant;

an improvement designed, constructed or installed to provide emergency protection for persons or domestic animals in the event of a disaster or emergency within the meaning of the Emergency Program Act;
sewage treatment plants, manure storage facilities, effluent reservoirs, effluent lagoons, deodorizing equipment, dust and particulate matter eliminating equipment;
to the extent established by subsection (3), land and improvements that were exempted for the 1996 taxation year under a pollution abatement provision, if

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the land and improvements were exempted under that provision for the 1996 taxation year on final determination under the Assessment Act, and
as applicable,

clause.clausetext: for an exemption in relation to land only, the land continues to be exclusively or primarily used for the purpose of abating pollution,
for an exemption in relation to improvements only, the improvements continue to be exclusively or primarily used for the purpose of abating pollution, or
for an exemption in relation to land and improvements, the land and improvements continue to be exclusively or primarily used for the purpose of abating pollution;

paragraph.paragraphtext: a floating dry dock, other than the onshore facilities of the floating dry dock, if the floating dry dock has a lift capacity greater than 20 000 tonnes.

subsection.subsectiontext: Septic disposal systems are not exempt from taxation under this section.
The amount of an exemption under subsection (1) (q) for a taxation year is limited to the portion of the assessed value of land and improvements that is the least of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the portion that the assessment commissioner, in his or her discretion, determines is attributable to the use of pollution abatement for that taxation year, subject to final determination under the Assessment Act;
the portion that was exempted for pollution abatement purposes for the immediately preceding taxation year on final determination under the Assessment Act;
the portion that was exempted for the 1996 taxation year on final determination under the Assessment Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section,

definition.term: final determination under the Assessment Act
definition.def: means a determination on the assessment roll for a taxation year, subject to any change that is finally determined under the Assessment Act by supplementary assessment roll, by correction of a property assessment review panel, on complaint to a property assessment review panel or on further appeal;

means section 339 (1) (q) of this Act, section 15 (1) (s) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act or section 396 (1) (e.01) of the Vancouver Charter, as those provisions read before their repeal and replacement by the Budget Measures Implementation Act, 1997.

section.marginalnote: Qualifications and exceptions to the general exemptions

subsection.subsectiontext: An exemption is not allowed under section 339 (1) (g) unless title to the land is registered in the name of

paragraph.paragraphtext: the religious organization using the building,
trustees for the use of that organization, or
a religious organization granting a lease of the building and land to be used solely for public worship.

subsection.subsectiontext: If only a portion of a parcel of land is exempt under section 339 (1) (g), (h), (i) or (k), the council must

paragraph.paragraphtext: adopt a bylaw that

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: describes the exempt land by metes and bounds, and
has attached to it as an appendix a plan showing the portion of the land exempt and the portion taxable, and

paragraph.paragraphtext: file the bylaw in the proper land title office.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a council considers that a use exists that, but for a secondary use, would otherwise qualify for exemption, the council may, by bylaw adopted by 2/3 of its members, determine the proportions of the land and improvements that are to be exempt and taxable.
A bylaw or resolution adopted under section 339 (1) or this section after October 31 in any year is not effective for taxation in the next calendar year.
An exemption under section 339 (1) (b) to (o) and the municipal property portion of section 339 (1) (a) does not include exemption from a fee or charge.
An exemption under section 339 (1) (c), (f), (g), (h) or (k) and the municipality portion of section 339 (1) (a) extends only to taxation under section 359 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes].
Section 8 of the Cemetery Company Act, R.S.B.C. 1979, c. 46, does not apply to a parcel tax under this Act.

On or before October 31 in any year, a council may, by bylaw adopted by 2/3 of its members, exempt land or improvements referred to in subsection (2), or both, from taxation under section 359 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes]

paragraph.paragraphtext: for the next calendar year, or
with the assent of the electors, for a period not longer than 10 years.

subsection.subsectiontext: The following may be exempted under subsection (1):

paragraph.paragraphtext: land or improvements owned or held, maintained and operated as a park or recreation ground or for athletic or recreational purposes by another municipality;
land or improvements owned or held by an athletic or service club or association and used principally as a public park or recreation ground or for public athletic or recreational purposes;

land or improvements not being operated for profit or gain and owned by a charitable or philanthropic organization supported in whole or in part by public funds and used exclusively for charitable or philanthropic purposes;
land or improvements owned and used exclusively by a horticultural or agricultural society;
land or improvements owned and used for water purposes by another municipality;
land or improvements, in whole or in part, owned by another municipality and used for a port or a small boat harbour, shelter or marina;
land or improvements, in whole or in part, owned by another municipality and used for an airport, seaplane base or landing area for aircraft;
land or improvements owned or held by a person or organization and operated as a private hospital licensed under the Hospital Act or an institution licensed under the Community Care Facility Act;
land or improvements, in whole or in part, for which a grant has been made, after March 31, 1974, under the Housing Construction (Elderly Citizens) Act;

land or improvements not being operated for profit or gain and owned by a charitable or philanthropic organization supported in whole or in part by public funds and used as an art gallery, museum or for other cultural purposes;

land or improvements not being operated for profit or gain and owned by a charitable or philanthropic organization supported in whole or in part by public funds and used as a search and rescue facility;
land or improvements used or occupied by a church as tenant or licensee for the purpose of public worship or for the purposes of a church hall which the council considers necessary to the church;
land acquired for water purposes by another municipality but not actually in use for any purpose;
the interest in school buildings of a non-profit organization specified by the council that the non-profit organization uses or occupies as licensee or tenant of a board of school trustees;
the interest of a francophone education authority in school buildings that the francophone education authority uses or occupies as licensee of a board of school trustees;
the interest in school buildings of a non-profit organization specified by the council that the non-profit organization uses or occupies as tenant or licensee of a francophone education authority;
the interest in municipal buildings of a non-profit organization specified by the council that the non-profit organization uses or occupies as a licensee or tenant of the municipality;
the part of a property that is taxable under section 129 of the School Act and used by a non-profit organization.

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section and section 343, eligible heritage property means property that is

paragraph.paragraphtext: protected heritage property,
subject to a heritage revitalization agreement under section 966, or
subject to a covenant under section 219 of the Land Title Act that relates to the conservation of heritage property.

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite section 182 [prohibition against assistance to business] but subject to subsection (3) of this section, for the purposes of supporting the conservation of an eligible heritage property, on or before October 31 in any year a council may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: exempt from taxation under section 359 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes] all or part of

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the eligible heritage property, and
if the eligible heritage property is a building or other improvement so affixed to the land as to constitute real property, an area of land surrounding the eligible heritage property;

paragraph.paragraphtext: limit an exemption under paragraph (a) or (b) to a specified portion of the net taxable value of the property to which the exemption applies;
make an exemption under this subsection subject to specified conditions.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (2) may provide a tax exemption

paragraph.paragraphtext: for the next calendar year, or
if a counter petition opportunity has been provided in relation to the bylaw, for a specified period not greater than 10 years.

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition to the information required by section 172.4, the notice of a counter petition opportunity under subsection (3) (b) of this section must

paragraph.paragraphtext: identify the eligible heritage property that would be subject to the bylaw, and
describe the exemption that would be made for the eligible heritage property.

subsection.subsectiontext: [Repealed 2000-7-47.]
Within 30 days after adopting a bylaw under this section, the council must give notice of the bylaw to the minister responsible for the Heritage Conservation Act in accordance with section 977.

section.marginalnote: Repayment requirement in relation to heritage exemptions

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under section 342 may provide that, if any of the following circumstances as specified in the bylaw occur, the council may require the owner of the eligible heritage property at that time to pay to the municipality the amount referred to in subsection (2):

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the eligible heritage property is destroyed, whether with or without proper authorization under the requirements of the heritage protection of the property;
if the eligible heritage property is altered by or on behalf of the owner without proper authorization under the requirements of the heritage protection of the property;
if any other circumstances specified in the bylaw occur.

subsection.subsectiontext: The amount that may be required under subsection (1) is the amount equivalent to

paragraph.paragraphtext: the total taxes exempted under the bylaw under section 342,

section.subsandwich: plus

paragraph.paragraphtext: interest from the time at which the exempt taxes would otherwise have been payable, compounded annually at the rate referred to in section 379 (1) (b) for taxes in arrear.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under section 342 that includes a provision under subsection (1) may not be adopted without the consent of the owner of the eligible heritage property to which the bylaw applies.

If a bylaw under section 342 includes a provision under subsection (1), within 30 days after the bylaw is adopted the council must have notice of the bylaw filed in the land title office in accordance with section 976.

If a bylaw under section 342 includes a provision under subsection (1) and a circumstance specified in the provision occurs, the council may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, either

paragraph.paragraphtext: require the owner to pay the amount referred to in subsection (2), or
waive the obligation of the owner to pay all or part of the amount referred to in subsection (2).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a council does not adopt a bylaw under subsection (5) (a) within one year after it becomes aware of the circumstance in relation to which the bylaw could be adopted, the council is deemed to have waived all obligation of the owner to pay the amount referred to in subsection (2).
If a council adopts a bylaw under subsection (5) (a) within the time period referred to in subsection (6), the council may

paragraph.paragraphtext: add the amount referred to in subsection (2) to the taxes for the current year payable to the municipality in relation to the eligible heritage property, or
make an agreement with the owner regarding payment of the amount referred to in subsection (2) as a personal debt to the municipality.

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section and section 343.2:

definition.def: means property that meets all the following requirements:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the property must be riparian land;
the property must be subject to a covenant under section 219 of the Land Title Act that relates to the protection of the property as riparian property;
the municipality granting the exemption under this section must be a covenantee in whose favour the covenant referred to in paragraph (b) is made;
any other requirements prescribed under subsection (6);

definition.def: means the portion of the net taxable value of the parcel of land in relation to which an exemption under subsection (2) is made that is equivalent to the ratio of

paragraph.paragraphtext: the area of the eligible riparian property that is exempted under subsection (2) (a)
the area of the parcel of land in relation to which the exemption is made.

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite section 182 [prohibition against assistance to business] but subject to subsections (3) and (4) of this section, for the purposes of supporting the conservation of an eligible riparian property, on or before October 31 in any year a council may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: exempt all or part of the eligible riparian property from taxation under section 359 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes];
limit an exemption under paragraph (a) to a specified portion of the eligible value of the property to which the exemption applies;
make an exemption under this subsection subject to specified conditions.

subsection.subsectiontext: An exemption under subsection (2) may apply only to that part of the eligible riparian property that is a riparian area.
A bylaw under subsection (2) may provide a tax exemption

paragraph.paragraphtext: for the next calendar year, or
if a counter petition opportunity has been provided in relation to the bylaw, for a specified period not greater than 10 years.

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition to the information required by section 172.4, the notice of a counter petition opportunity under subsection (4) (b) of this section must

paragraph.paragraphtext: identify the eligible riparian property that would be subject to the bylaw, and
describe the exemption that would be made for the eligible riparian property.

subsection.subsectiontext: [Repealed 2000-7-48.]
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, establish additional requirements for property to be considered eligible riparian property.

section.marginalnote: Repayment requirement in relation to riparian exemptions

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under section 343.1 may provide that, if

paragraph.paragraphtext: there is a contravention of any of the conditions of the covenant under section 219 of the Land Title Act in relation to which the exemption is given,
the covenant is discharged before the end of the period of the exemption, or
any other circumstances specified in the bylaw occur,

section.subsandwich: the council may require the owner of the eligible riparian property at that time to pay to the municipality the amount referred to in subsection (2).

subsection.subsectiontext: The amount that may be required under subsection (1) is the amount equivalent to

paragraph.paragraphtext: the total taxes exempted under the bylaw under section 343.1,

section.subsandwich: plus

paragraph.paragraphtext: interest from the time at which the exempt taxes would otherwise have been payable, compounded annually at the rate referred to in section 379 (1) (b) for taxes in arrear.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under section 343.1 that includes a provision under subsection (1) may not be adopted without the consent of the owner of the eligible riparian property to which the bylaw applies.

If a bylaw under section 343.1 includes a provision under subsection (1), within 30 days after the bylaw is adopted the council must have notice of the bylaw filed in the land title office, and for this purpose section 976 applies.

If a bylaw under section 343.1 includes a provision under subsection (1) and a circumstance specified in the provision occurs, the council may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, either

paragraph.paragraphtext: require the owner to pay the amount referred to in subsection (2), or
waive the obligation of the owner to pay all or part of the amount referred to in subsection (2).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a council does not adopt a bylaw under subsection (5) (a) within one year after it becomes aware of the circumstance in relation to which the bylaw could be adopted, the council is deemed to have waived all obligation of the owner to pay the amount referred to in subsection (2).
If a council adopts a bylaw under subsection (5) (a) within the time period referred to in subsection (6), the council may

paragraph.paragraphtext: add the amount referred to in subsection (2) to the taxes for the current year payable to the municipality in relation to the eligible riparian property, or
make an agreement with the owner regarding payment of the amount referred to in subsection (2) as a personal debt to the municipality.

section.marginalnote: Qualifications to the exemptions under sections 341, 342 or 343.1

subsection.subsectiontext: An exemption under section 341 or 342 may apply to the whole or a part of the taxable assessed value of land or improvements or both.

An exemption under section 341 (2) (b) or (c) may, in the discretion of the council, be made applicable to property the registered owner of which is a trustee for an organization that in the opinion of council would otherwise qualify for exemption.

A bylaw under section 341, 342 or 343.1 or this section ceases to apply to property the use or ownership of which no longer conforms to the conditions necessary to qualify for exemption and, after this, the property is liable to taxation.

section.marginalnote: Tax exemptions under a partnering agreement

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, exempt from taxation under section 359 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes], all or part of the land, improvements or both, owned or held by a party to a partnering agreement with the municipality, during all or part of the term of the agreement.
An exemption under this section may only be provided for that portion of the land or improvements used for a public purpose.

If the term of the exemption authorized in the bylaw is greater than 5 years, or a period that by exercising rights of renewal or extension could exceed 5 years, then the council must provide a counter petition opportunity in relation to the proposed bylaw.
An exemption under this section takes effect as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the bylaw under subsection (1) is adopted by October 31 in a year, the exemption takes effect for the following calendar year;
if the bylaw under subsection (1) is adopted after October 31 in a year, the exemption takes effect for the year following the next calendar year.

subsection.subsectiontext: An exemption under this section ceases to apply to property the use or ownership of which no longer conforms to the conditions necessary to qualify for exemption.

section.marginalnote: Exemptions for industrial or business property

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition to the provisions of any other Act, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing exemptions from property taxes under any Act, in respect of prescribed

paragraph.paragraphtext: industrial land or industrial improvements or both, or
business land or business improvements or both.

subsection.subsectiontext: Regulations under subsection (1) may be different for different classes of property.

section.marginalnote: Exemptions for community ports and airports

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition to the provisions of any other Act, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing exemptions from property taxes under any Act in respect of

paragraph.paragraphtext: prescribed land or improvements, or both, at prescribed community ports, and
prescribed improvements at prescribed community airports.

subsection.subsectiontext: Regulations under subsection (1) may be different

paragraph.paragraphtext: for different classes of property as described in the regulations,
for different community ports, and
for different community airports.

subsection.subsectiontext: An exemption under subsection (1) applies to a port or airport only for a taxation year in which it is operated as a community port or community airport, as applicable.

change.changenote: Division 2 of Part 10, sections 347 to 351 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-256, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

division.divisiontext: Golf Course and Cemetery Valuation Agreements

section.sectiontext: For the purposes of this Division:

definition.def: means land maintained as a golf course or held for cemetery purposes and not exempt from taxation under sections 339 and 340;
means an agreement under section 348.

section.marginalnote: Agreements for valuation of golf course or cemetery land

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite any Act, a council may, by agreement with the owner of land, establish an amount that, subject to this section, is deemed to be the assessed value of the land during the term of the agreement for the purposes of imposing taxes other than taxes for school purposes.
A valuation agreement must be for a term of at least 10 years.
There may be separate valuation agreements for separate parcels of land.
The actual value of the land at the date of a valuation agreement, as determined by the assessor for the assessment roll for that year, must be set out in the agreement.
A valuation agreement may be renewed in accordance with the terms of the agreement.

A valuation agreement must set out the provisions of section 349 in the form of covenants by or provisions or conditions agreed to by the municipality and the owner, or both as appropriate, together with any other covenants, provisions and conditions agreed to and not inconsistent with this Division.
The council may agree to rescind or amend an agreement made under this section, including rescission or amendment of a covenant, provision or condition included by reason of subsection (6).
Land that is the subject of a valuation agreement must be retained and maintained during the term of the agreement for the use and purpose specified in the agreement.
If, during the term of a valuation agreement, the owner sells the land, the agreement is terminated and the owner is liable to the municipality for whichever of the following is greater:

paragraph.paragraphtext: 50% of the difference between the sale price and the actual value, if the sale price is greater than the actual value;
the sum calculated under subsection (3) (a).

subsection.subsectiontext: If, during the term of a valuation agreement, the owner of the land sells part of the land, the agreement is terminated for the part sold, and the owner is liable to the municipality for an amount equal to the total of

paragraph.paragraphtext: the sum of the total taxes on all the land that is the subject of the agreement that, but for the agreement, would have been imposed by the municipality, reduced by any amounts already paid to the municipality as taxes on the land, together with accrued interest on the remainder at the rate prescribed under section 11 (3) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act,

section.subsandwich: plus

paragraph.paragraphtext: 50% of the difference between

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the sale price of the part sold, if it exceeds the amount determined under subparagraph (ii), and
the amount that bears the same proportion to the actual value of all the land subject to the agreement that the area of the land sold bears to the area of all the land.

subsection.subsectiontext: If, during the term of a valuation agreement, the owner of the land changes or permits a change of the use of all or part of the land from that specified in the agreement, the agreement is terminated for the land the use of which has changed, and the owner is liable to the municipality for taxes calculated as in subsection (3) (a).
The municipality has the first right to purchase land that is subject to a valuation agreement.
A dispute between the parties to a valuation agreement on any matter arising from the agreement must be settled under the Commercial Arbitration Act.

section.marginalnote: Further liability for 10 years after end of valuation agreement

subsection.subsectiontext: After the end of the term of a valuation agreement, if the owner of the land that was the subject of the agreement sells or changes or permits a change in the use of the land, section 349 (2) and (3) or (4) applies, as the case may be, as if the agreement were still in force, subject to subsection (2).
The owner's liability under section 349 is reduced by the proportion that the number of years that have passed since the end of the agreement bears to 10.
The assessor must continue to assess land subject to a valuation agreement as if the agreement had not been made and must maintain a record of the values assessed.
The owner of the land subject to a valuation agreement has the usual right of complaint and appeal for an annual assessment under subsection (1).

A valuation agreement is registrable in the proper land title district, and on registration constitutes a charge on the land, having preference over a claim, lien, privilege or encumbrance of any person except the Crown.

All amounts for which an owner of land becomes liable to a municipality under this Division form a charge on the land and are collectable in the same manner and with the same remedies as ordinary taxes on land and improvements under this Act.

The registrar of land titles must not transfer land subject to a valuation agreement without a certificate from the designated municipal officer showing that all obligations for amounts owing by the owner under sections 347 to 350 and the valuation agreement have been discharged.

change.changenote: Division 3 Heading, of Part 10 BEFORE amended by 2003-52-257, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).
Section 352 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-258, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite this Act, land in a municipality that is forest land as defined in the Assessment Act must be so classified by the assessor and assessed under that Act, but taxed under section 359 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes].

The exemption provided by section 15 (1) (l) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act applies to land in a municipality, but section 131 (2) of the School Act applies for the purposes referred to in section 359 (1) (b) [property taxes for other bodies] of this Act.

change.changenote: Section 353 (3) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-259(a), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Tax under subsection (2) is subject to the same remedies and penalties as taxes under Part 10.1[Taxes, Fees and Charges].

change.changenote: Section 353 (4) (b) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-259(b), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

paragraph.paragraphtext: pay the tax imposed under subsection (2) in accordance with Division 1 of Part 11 [Tax Collection — Due Dates and Tax Notices].

change.changenote: Section 353 (6) and (7) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-259(c), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Tax imposed on a utility company under subsection (2) is in place of tax that might otherwise be imposed on the specified improvements under section 359 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes], and taxes may not be imposed under that provision on the specified improvements although they may be imposed on those improvements under section 359 (1) (b) [property taxes for other bodies].
For certainty, all land and improvements of a utility company in a municipality, other than specified improvements, are subject to tax under section 359 [annual property tax bylaw].

change.changenote: Division 4 of Part 10, sections 355 to 358 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-260, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).

division.divisiontext: Tax Liability of Occupiers of Land

section.sectiontext: For the purpose of this Division, occupier means an occupier as defined in the Assessment Act.

section.marginalnote: Taxation of Crown land used by others

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to this section, land and its improvements are liable to taxation if the land is

paragraph.paragraphtext: owned in fee simple by the Crown or some person or organization on behalf of the Crown, and
held or occupied other than by or on behalf of the Crown.

subsection.subsectiontext: This section does not make the following liable to taxation:

paragraph.paragraphtext: land or improvements otherwise exempt under section 339 (1) (b) to (l);
land or improvements otherwise exempt under the municipal portion of section 339 (1) (a);
land or improvements exempted by a bylaw under section 341, 342, 343.1, 344, 344.1 or 346;
a highway occupied by

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a gas, electric light, telephone, telegraph, power, pipeline, water, motor bus, electric trolley bus, radio or television broadcasting or closed circuit television company, or
a company that, in addition to any other function, provides a service similar in nature to a service referred to in subparagraph (i).

subsection.subsectiontext: Except as provided under the Veterans' Land Act (Canada) and subsection (4), the taxes imposed on land and improvements referred to in subsection (1)

paragraph.paragraphtext: are a liability only of the holder or occupier, recoverable in the manner set out in this Act, and
are not a lien or charge on the land and improvements that are not liable to tax sale.

subsection.subsectiontext: In the case of land disposed of by the Provincial government for which the Crown grant has not been registered,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the land, together with its improvements, is liable to tax sale,
the taxes imposed are a lien and charge on the land and its improvements, and
the provisions of this Act for assessment, taxation, recovery of taxes and tax sale apply for the purposes of this subsection.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a supplementary assessment roll has been prepared under the Assessment Act for land held or occupied in the manner referred to in subsection (1),

paragraph.paragraphtext: the holder or occupier is liable to real property tax for the portion of the calendar year the land was held or occupied, and
section 373 [taxation based on supplementary roll] applies for the purposes of this subsection.

subsection.subsectiontext: This section also applies to

paragraph.paragraphtext: improvements owned, held or occupied by or leased to, a person other than the Crown, located on land the fee of which is vested in the Crown or in some other person or organization on behalf of the Crown, and
land held in trust for a band of Indians and occupied, other than in an official capacity, by a person who is not an Indian.

section.marginalnote: Taxation of municipal land used by others

subsection.subsectiontext: If the fee simple of land is vested in a municipality but the land is held or occupied other than by or on behalf of the municipality, the rules for taxation of Crown land used by others, as set out in section 356 (1), (2), (3) and (6) (a), apply to the land and its improvements and make them liable for taxation.
This section does not apply to land or improvements that are exempt from taxation by the municipality under the terms of a lease agreement entered into before July 1, 1957.

section.marginalnote: Taxation of occupier of exempt land
section.sectiontext: An occupier of land in the municipality assessed under section 27 of the Assessment Act is subject to taxation in the same manner as an occupier of land taxed under section 357.

change.changenote: Section 356 (5) (a) BEFORE amended by 2000-11-37, effective January 1, 2001.

paragraph.paragraphtext: the holder or occupier is liable to real property tax in the calendar year in which the holding or occupancy began for the portion of the calendar year the land was held or occupied, and

change.changenote: Heading of Part 10.1 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-261, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).
Division 1 of Part 10.1, sections 359 to 359.3 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-262, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Each year, after adoption of the financial plan but before May 15, a council must, by bylaw, impose property value taxes for the year by establishing tax rates for

paragraph.paragraphtext: the municipal revenue proposed to be raised for the year from property value taxes, as provided in the financial plan, and
the amounts to be collected for the year by means of rates established by the municipality to meet its taxing obligations in relation to another local government or other public body.

subsection.subsectiontext: Unless otherwise permitted by this or another Act, a property value tax under subsection (1) must be imposed

paragraph.paragraphtext: on all land and improvements within the municipality, other than land and improvements that are exempt under this or another Act in relation to the tax, and
on the basis of the assessed value of the land and improvements.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (1) (a), the bylaw may establish for each property class

paragraph.paragraphtext: a single rate for all revenue to be raised, or
separate rates for revenue to be raised for different purposes but, in this case, the relationships between the different property class rates must be the same for all purposes.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (1) (b), for each local government or other public body in relation to which the amounts are to be collected,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the bylaw must establish separate rates for each property class, and
the relationships between the different property class rates must be the same as the relationships established under subsection (3) unless otherwise required by this or another Act.
