subsection.subsectiontext: Property value taxes under subsection (1) are deemed to be imposed on January 1 of the year in which the bylaw under that subsection is adopted, unless expressly provided otherwise by the bylaw or by the enactment under which they are imposed.
The minimum amount of tax under subsection (1) in any year on a parcel of real property is $1.

If the amount of revenue raised in any year for a body under subsection (1) (b) is more or less than the amount that is required to meet the municipality's obligation, the difference must be used to adjust the rate under subsection (1) (b) for the next year.
Instead of imposing tax rates on the assessed value of land and improvements, an annual property tax bylaw may impose rates under subsection (2) or (3).

For an assessment averaging option, tax rates may be imposed on the amount determined in accordance with the following formula:
Amount = averaged land value + assessed improvements valuewhere averaged land value = the average of the assessed value of the land in the current year and the 2 preceding years;assessed improvements value = the assessed value of improvements in the current year.

For an assessment phasing option, tax rates may be imposed on the amount determined in accordance with the following formula:
Amount = (assessed land value – phasing reduction) + assessed improvements valuewhereassessed land value = the assessed value of the land in the current year;phasing reduction = the phasing percentage established by the bylaw, being not less than 50% and not more than 66%, of the difference between (a)the increase in the assessed value of the land in the current year from the previous year, and (b)the assessed value of the land in the previous year multiplied by the average percentage increase in the assessed value from the previous year to the current year of all land within the municipality included in the same property class;assessed improvements value = the assessed value of improvements in the current year.
A council must not adopt a bylaw imposing tax rates under this section unless the following requirements are met:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the council complies with the requirements of any regulations under subsection (13);
before January 1 of the year in which the bylaw is to take effect, notice of intent to consider the bylaw is provided to the inspector and to the assessment commissioner;
after January 1 of the year in which the bylaw is to take effect and at least 2 weeks before the adoption of the bylaw, a notice that

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: contains the prescribed information, and
describes the estimated effect of the bylaw on the taxation of sample properties within the municipality

section.parasandwich: is published in 2 consecutive issues of a newspaper;

paragraph.paragraphtext: the bylaw is adopted before March 31 in the year in which it is to take effect;
the bylaw establishes a procedure to allow property owners to complain to the local court of revision about errors made in applying the bylaw to their property.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to any regulations under subsection (13), a bylaw imposing tax rates under this section may

paragraph.paragraphtext: apply to one or more property classes, or

modify the averaging formula in subsection (2) or the phasing formula in subsection (3) to exempt from the bylaw or govern the application of the bylaw to particular types of property within a property class.

subsection.subsectiontext: The authority under subsection (5) (b) includes authority in relation to property with an assessed value that is different from that on the previous assessment roll because of one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: an error or omission;
a subdivision or consolidation or a new development to, on or in the land;
a change in

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: physical characteristics,
zoning,
the classification of the property under section 19 (14) of the Assessment Act, or
the eligibility of the property for assessment under section 19 (8), 23 or 24 of the Assessment Act;

paragraph.paragraphtext: any other prescribed factor.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a council adopts a bylaw imposing tax rates under this section, the following rules apply:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the assessed value or the net taxable value must continue to be the basis for determining the amount of money to be raised in the municipality for the purposes of the following:

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: section 359 (1) (b) [property taxes for other bodies];
sections 119 and 137 of the School Act;
section 17 of the Assessment Authority Act;
sections 15 and 17 of the Municipal Finance Authority Act;
section 14 of the British Columbia Transit Act;
any other prescribed enactment;

paragraph.paragraphtext: the value determined under the bylaw, and not the assessed value or the net taxable value referred to in this or any other Act, must be the basis for taxing properties within the property classes specified in the bylaw to raise the money required under the provisions referred to in paragraph (a).

subsection.subsectiontext: If

paragraph.paragraphtext: a body other than the council sets a rate under an enactment for calculating property taxes, and
the council adopts a bylaw imposing tax rates under this section,

section.subsandwich: then, despite any other Act, the council must, by resolution, substitute a rate that is sufficient to raise the same amount of revenue in the municipality for that body from each property class to which that bylaw applies as the amount that would have been raised for that body had that bylaw not been adopted.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the amount of revenue raised in any year for a body under subsection (8) is more or less than the amount that would have been raised had the council not substituted the rate, the difference must be used to adjust the rate for the next year.
If a council adopts a bylaw imposing tax rates under this section,

paragraph.paragraphtext: it must establish a local court of revision in accordance with Division 2 [Parcel Taxes], and
the local court of revision may

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: adjudicate complaints about errors made in applying the bylaw to the assessed value of any property, and
direct the collector to make any amendments to the adjusted value of the property that are necessary to give effect to the court's decision.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the assessed value of a parcel of land on the assessment roll has been adjusted under a bylaw adopted under this section, the tax notice under section 369 [general tax notices] for the parcel must include or have enclosed with it a statement

paragraph.paragraphtext: informing the owner that assessed values and tax rates have been adjusted as a result of the bylaw,
specifying the adjusted value of the land and the value of any improvements on it, and
describing the procedure for requesting the collector to correct errors and for complaining to the local court of revision.

subsection.subsectiontext: On the initiative of the collector or on the request of an owner who is notified under subsection (11) of adjustments to the assessed value of the owner's property, the collector may correct errors made in applying the bylaw to any property.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: restricting the property classes to which a bylaw imposing tax rates under this section may apply;
defining any term used in this section;

governing the way in which the averaging formula in subsection (2) or the phasing formula in subsection (3) may be modified to exempt from the bylaw or govern the application of the bylaw to particular types of property within a property class, including property referred to in subsection (6);
prescribing the information to be contained in the notice that is to be published under subsection (4) (c);
prescribing factors for the purposes of subsection (6) and enactments for the purposes of subsection (7).

subsection.subsectiontext: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting tax rates that may be established by an annual property tax bylaw, including regulations doing one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: prescribing limits on tax rates;
prescribing relationships between tax rates;
prescribing formulas for calculating the limits or relationships referred to in paragraph (a) or (b);
allowing the inspector under prescribed circumstances to vary, by order, the limits, relationships or formulas prescribed under any of paragraphs (a) to (c).

subsection.subsectiontext: Regulations under subsection (1) may prescribe different tax limits, relationships or formulas for each class of property, different municipalities or different classes of municipality and may be different for one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the taxation of land and improvements for the purposes of section 359 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes];

the taxation of land and improvements for the purposes of section 359 (1) (b) [property taxes for other bodies] or for another purpose referred to in section 359.1 (7) (a) [assessment averaging and phasing for other bodies];

the taxation of land or improvements, or both, under Part 19 [Local Improvements and Specified Areas], based on assessed value or the value determined under section 359.1 [assessment averaging and phasing].

subsection.subsectiontext: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may only make a regulation under this section after the minister has consulted with representatives of the Union of British Columbia Municipalities respecting the proposed regulation.
Taxes imposed on a parcel of land that is combined under the Assessment Act with other parcels to form one parcel are deemed to be taxes on all the land combined as one parcel.
For the purposes of assessment, taxation, recovery of taxes and tax sale, parcels combined as referred to in subsection (1) are deemed to constitute one parcel.

change.changenote: Division 2 of Part 10.1, sections 360 to 362 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-262, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, impose a parcel tax in accordance with this Division to provide all or part of the funding for a service.

Unless otherwise permitted by this or another Act, a parcel tax under this section must be imposed on all parcels within the municipality, other than those that are exempt under this or another Act in relation to the tax.
A bylaw under subsection (1) must

paragraph.paragraphtext: state the service for which the tax is imposed,
state the years for which the tax is imposed,
state the basis, as referred to in section 360.1 (2) [assessment roll bylaw — basis of taxation], on which the tax is to be imposed,
identify the assessment roll under this Division that is to be used for imposing the tax, and
impose the rates for the tax.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (1) may provide for waiving or reducing the tax if the owner or a previous owner of the parcel has

paragraph.paragraphtext: provided all or part of the service at the owner's expense, or
already paid towards the cost of the service on terms and conditions specified in the bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: The municipality must make available to the public, on request, a report respecting how parcel tax rates under this section were determined.
In each year that a parcel tax is imposed under this section, it is deemed to be imposed on January 1 of the year unless expressly provided otherwise by the bylaw under subsection (1).
A council may, by bylaw, direct the preparation of an assessment roll for the purposes of imposing a parcel tax.
A bylaw under subsection (1) must establish the basis on which a parcel tax may be imposed using the assessment roll, which may be on the basis of

paragraph.paragraphtext: a single amount for each parcel,
the taxable area of the parcel, or
the taxable frontage of the parcel.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the bylaw provides a basis under subsection (2) (b) or (c), it must establish how the taxable area or taxable frontage of a parcel is to be determined, subject to the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the methods for determination must be based on the physical characteristics of the parcel;
the basis established for one class of parcel must be fair and equitable as compared with the basis established for other classes of parcels.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (1) may establish different classes of parcels and make different provisions for different classes of parcels.
The assessment roll for a parcel tax must set out the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the parcels to be assessed;
the name and address of the owner of each parcel;
unless the tax is imposed on the basis of a single amount for each parcel, the taxable area or the taxable frontage of each parcel, as applicable;
if the name of a holder of a registered charge is included on the assessment roll under section 4 of the Assessment Act for a parcel, the name and address of that person.

subsection.subsectiontext: The collector may correct errors on the assessment roll at any time before the roll is authenticated under section 361.5 [authentication of assessment roll].
Once prepared by the collector, the assessment roll must be open for public inspection at the municipal hall during its regular office hours.

If requested by an owner, the collector must amend an assessment roll that is to be available for public inspection by omitting or obscuring the address of the owner or other information about the owner in order to protect the privacy or security of the owner.
A request under subsection (4) continues to apply to other assessment rolls under this Division until the request is rescinded.

section.marginalnote: Local court of revision required for parcel tax

subsection.subsectiontext: Before a parcel tax is imposed for the first time, a local court of revision must consider any complaints respecting the assessment roll and must authenticate the assessment roll in accordance with this Division.
A local court of revision is to consist of

paragraph.paragraphtext: the council members, or
at least 3 and not more than 5 persons appointed for that purpose, who may or may not be council members.

subsection.subsectiontext: Before taking on his or her duties, a member of a local court of revision must swear or affirm an oath in the form prescribed by regulation or established by bylaw.

section.marginalnote: Notice of sitting by local court of revision

subsection.subsectiontext: The council must

paragraph.paragraphtext: establish the time and place for the sitting of the local court of revision, and
have notice of the time and place published in a newspaper at least 2 weeks before the day of the sitting.

subsection.subsectiontext: At least 14 days before the day set for the sitting of the local court of revision, the collector must mail or otherwise deliver to the owner of every parcel of land that is to be taxed a notice stating

paragraph.paragraphtext: the service in relation to which the parcel tax is to be imposed,
the taxable area or the taxable frontage, if applicable,
the time and place of the first sitting of the local court of revision, and
that the assessment roll is available for inspection at the municipal hall during its regular office hours.

subsection.subsectiontext: The obligation to give notice under subsection (2) is satisfied if a reasonable effort was made to mail or otherwise deliver the notice.

section.marginalnote: Local court of revision to hear complaints and make corrections

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (2), a person may make a complaint to the local court of revision on one or more of the following grounds:

paragraph.paragraphtext: there is an error or omission respecting a name or address on the assessment roll;
there is an error or omission respecting the inclusion of a parcel;
there is an error or omission respecting the taxable area or the taxable frontage of a parcel;
an exemption has been improperly allowed or disallowed.

subsection.subsectiontext: A complaint must not be heard by the local court of revision unless written notice of the complaint has been given to the municipality at least 48 hours before the time set for the first sitting of the local court of revision.
The local court of revision may direct the correction of the assessment roll respecting any matter referred to in subsection (1).
As a limit on subsection (3), a correction that would

paragraph.paragraphtext: include a parcel on the assessment roll that had not been included before, or
increase the taxable area or taxable frontage of a parcel on the assessment roll

section.subsandwich: must not be directed until 5 days after a notice in accordance with subsection (5) has been mailed or otherwise delivered to the owner of the parcel.

subsection.subsectiontext: The notice under subsection (4) must state

paragraph.paragraphtext: the intention of the local court of revision, and
the time and place set for the court to give its direction.

subsection.subsectiontext: The obligation to give notice under subsection (4) is satisfied if a reasonable effort was made to deliver the notice.
The following sections of the Assessment Act apply to a local court of revision:

section.parasandwich: section 32 (3), (4) and (5) [complaints by local government or assessor];
section 35 (1) (b) and (c) and (2) [notice of hearing to complainant];

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (1), a reference in those sections to a review panel is deemed to be a reference to a local court of revision and a reference to an assessor is deemed to be a reference to the collector.
The chair of the local court of revision must review the assessment roll to confirm that the directed corrections have been made and must report this to the local court of revision.

After receiving the report of the chair, the local court of revision must identify, confirm and authenticate the assessment roll by inscribing or endorsing on it, or attaching to it, a certificate signed by a majority of the members of the court.

Within 10 days after an assessment roll is authenticated under section 361.5, the collector must mail or otherwise deliver notice of the decision made by the local court of revision, or of its refusal to adjudicate the complaint made, to

paragraph.paragraphtext: the owner of the property to which the decision relates, and
the complainant, if the complainant is not the owner.

subsection.subsectiontext: The obligation to give notice under subsection (1) is satisfied if a reasonable effort was made to deliver the notice.
Notice under subsection (1) must include a statement that the decision may be appealed to the Supreme Court in accordance with section 361.7.

section.marginalnote: Appeal to Supreme Court from local court of revision

subsection.subsectiontext: A decision of the local court of revision may be appealed to the Supreme Court by a person entitled to notice under section 361.6 or by the municipality.

In order for a person entitled to notice under section 361.6 to appeal, within 10 days after the notice is mailed or otherwise delivered to the person, the person must serve on the municipality a written notice of intention to appeal that

paragraph.paragraphtext: is signed by the person, or by the person's solicitor or an agent authorized in writing, and
sets out the grounds of appeal.

subsection.subsectiontext: In order for the municipality to appeal, within 10 days after the date on which the assessment roll is authenticated, it must serve a written notice as described in subsection (2) on the property owner affected by the appeal and, if applicable, on the complainant.
The court must set a day for hearing the appeal, notice of which must be given to the municipality, the property owner and, if applicable, the complainant.
On an appeal under this section,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the collector must produce before the court the assessment roll and all records in that officer's possession affecting the matter, and
the court must hear the appeal, including evidence adduced on oath before it, in a summary manner.

subsection.subsectiontext: The court may adjourn the hearing of an appeal under this section and defer judgment in its discretion, but so that all appeals may be determined within 30 days from the authentication of the assessment roll by the local court of revision.
If an appeal is not decided within the time referred to in subsection (6), the decision of the local court of revision stands.
A decision of the Supreme Court under this section may be appealed on a question of law to the Court of Appeal with leave of a justice of the Court of Appeal.

The collector may amend the assessment roll in relation to a matter referred to in section 361.3 (1) [complaints to local court of revision] on receiving a request under subsection (2) or on the collector's own initiative.

An owner of a parcel included on an assessment roll may request that the roll be amended under this section respecting a matter described under section 361.3 (1) [complaints to local court of revision], but only in relation to their own property.
In each year after the first year in which a parcel tax is imposed, the municipality must publish in a newspaper a notice indicating the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: that owners of parcels included on the assessment roll may request that the roll be amended respecting a matter described under section 361.3 (1) [complaints to local court of revision], but only in relation to their own property;
that the assessment roll is available for inspection at the municipal hall during its regular office hours;
the time by which a request must be made in order to be considered for that year.

subsection.subsectiontext: A request under subsection (2) must be made in writing to the municipality before the time specified in the notice.

Notice of an amendment, or a refusal to make an amendment requested under subsection (2), must be mailed or otherwise delivered to all owners of parcels in relation to which the amendment was made or the request received, and for these purposes section 361.2 (2) and (3) [notice of sitting by local court of revision] applies.

An owner referred to in subsection (5) may make a complaint on one or more of the grounds set out in section 361.3 (1) [complaints to local court of revision], but only in relation to the owner's property.
A complaint under subsection (6) is made by giving written notice of the complaint to the municipality within 30 days after the date on which the notice under subsection (5) was delivered.

If a municipality receives a complaint in accordance with subsection (7), it must hold a local court of revision, and for these purposes sections 361.1 to 361.7 [local court of revision process] apply.
If no complaints under subsection (7) are received, the assessment roll as it is amended under subsection (1) is deemed to have been authenticated by the local court of revision.

section.sectiontext: Subject to amendment on appeal under section 361.7 [appeal to Supreme Court], despite any omission, defect or error in procedure or in an assessment roll, or in a notice or the omission to deliver a notice,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the initial assessment roll, as authenticated by the local court of revision, is valid and binding on all parties concerned until amended under section 361.8 [updating assessment roll], and

any subsequent assessment roll prepared under section 361.8 [updating assessment roll] that is authenticated or deemed to be authenticated by the local court of revision under that section is valid and binding on all parties concerned until any further amendments are made under that section.

section.sectiontext: Section 359.3 [grouping of parcels] applies in relation to a tax under this Division.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, impose a fee or charge payable in respect of all or part of a service of the municipality or the exercise of regulatory authority by the municipality.

change.changenote: Section 363 (2) (a) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-264(b), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the bylaw is in relation to an authority to provide a service or regulate outside the municipality, apply outside the municipality;

change.changenote: Section 363 (3) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-264(c), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: As an exception, a council may not establish a fee or charge under this section

paragraph.paragraphtext: in relation to Part 3 [Elections] or 4 [Other Voting], or
in relation to any other matter for which another provision of this Act specifically authorizes the imposition of a fee or charge.

change.changenote: Section 363 (4) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-264(b), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A municipality must make available to the public, on request, a report respecting how a fee or charge imposed under this section was determined.

change.changenote: Section 363 (2) (f) BEFORE amended by 2014-19-86, effective May 29, 2014 (Royal Assent).

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies to amounts that are referred to in section 376 (1) [special fees and charges that may be collected as taxes].

change.changenote: Section 364 (3) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-266(b), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: An owner of land or real property aggrieved by the creation of a charge or lien under this section may, on 10 days' written notice to the municipality, apply to the Supreme Court for an order that the charge be removed or that the amount for which it was imposed be varied.

change.changenote: Heading, Part 11, BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-267, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).
Division 1 of Part 11, sections 365 to 370 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-268, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).

section.sectiontext: Property taxes under Part 10.1 are due as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: in accordance with the general tax collection scheme under section 366, if the municipality does not establish its own scheme under section 367;
if the municipality does establish a scheme under section 367, in accordance with section 368.

subsection.subsectiontext: If this section applies, property taxes for a year are due on July 2 of the year.

The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations establishing penalties and interest that must be applied by municipalities in relation to payments made after the tax due date under subsection (1).
A council may, by bylaw, establish one or more dates on which all or part of the property taxes under Part 10.1 are due.
A bylaw under subsection (1) must establish an annual time period during which owners may make elections under section 368.
A bylaw under subsection (1) may do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: establish procedures for determining the amount of taxes due on each of the due dates;
provide for

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: estimating, before the adoption of the annual property tax bylaw, the amount of taxes payable in the year, and
making adjustments to payments due after the adoption of that bylaw in order to take into account variations between the estimated and actual taxes payable;

paragraph.paragraphtext: establish discounts to be applied in relation to payments made before a tax due date established by the bylaw;
establish penalties and interest to be applied in relation to payments made after a tax due date established by the bylaw;
set terms, conditions and procedures in relation to payments, which may be different for different classes of owners as established by the bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: As a limitation on subsection (3) (a), there must not be more than 12 months between the first and last due dates for annual taxes for any year.

section.marginalnote: Owner may elect which scheme to use

subsection.subsectiontext: If a municipal tax collection scheme is established, the applicable scheme is determined in accordance with the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: if an owner has elected in accordance with subsection (2) to pay under the municipal scheme, that scheme applies;
if an owner has elected in accordance with subsection (2) to pay under the general tax collection scheme, that scheme applies;
if paragraph (a) or (b) does not apply and the municipal tax collection scheme

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: has not established due dates that are before July 2,
has not established any interest, or has established interest that does not exceed the interest for the general tax collection scheme prescribed under section 366 (2), and
has not established any penalty, or has established penalties that do not exceed the penalties for the general tax collection scheme prescribed under section 366 (2),

section.parasandwich: the municipal tax collection scheme applies;

paragraph.paragraphtext: if no other paragraph applies, the general tax collection scheme applies.

subsection.subsectiontext: An owner may make an election, or change an election, referred to in subsection (1) (a) or (b) by giving written notice of the election to the municipality within the time period established under section 367 (2) [municipal scheme].

If the land title registration of a property indicates that there is more than one registered owner of the property, a person giving notice under subsection (2) may only do so with the written consent of the number of those persons who, together with the person giving notice, are a majority of the registered owners.
As a limit on subsection (2), after an election or change has been made under this section, no further change in election may be made for the same year.

Once an election or change has been made under this section, the owner is liable to make payments in accordance with the applicable scheme until the owner has made a subsequent change in election under this section.
Each year a municipality must mail a tax notice in accordance with this section to each owner of property subject to tax under this Part.
A tax notice must include the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a short description of the property;
the taxes imposed under this Part for the current year, separately stated for

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: property value taxes imposed under section 359 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes],
each property value tax imposed under section 359 (1) (b) [property taxes for other bodies],
each property value tax collected by the municipality on behalf of another local government or other public body on the basis of tax rates imposed by the other body, and
each parcel tax imposed under section 360 [parcel tax bylaw];

paragraph.paragraphtext: other taxes or charges that are payable in relation to the property;
any credit or abatement authorized by this or another Act;
when the penalties under section 366 [general tax collection scheme] will be added if taxes are not paid;
other information that may be prescribed by regulation.

subsection.subsectiontext: The tax notice must include or have enclosed with it an application for a grant under the Home Owner Grant Act.
A tax notice under this section must also be mailed to each holder of a registered charge in relation to the property whose name is included on the assessment roll.
For the purposes of this section, the tax notice is to be mailed to the owner or other person at the address on the assessment roll.
If a number of parcels are assessed in the name of the same owner,

paragraph.paragraphtext: any number of those parcels may be included in one tax notice, and

if several of the parcels are assessed at the same value, the tax notice is sufficient if it clearly identifies the property assessed and taxed as a block, parts of a block or a series of lots, without the full description for each parcel.

subsection.subsectiontext: The obligation to give notice under this section is satisfied if the municipality made a reasonable effort to mail or otherwise deliver the tax notice.

section.marginalnote: Copies of tax notice to be sent to persons who have requested this

subsection.subsectiontext: The collector must mail or otherwise deliver a copy of a tax notice under section 369 [general tax notices] and any statement under section 382 [statement of taxes in arrear or delinquent] to all persons who have requested this during the current year in accordance with subsection (2).

In order to make a request for the purposes of this section, a person must make a written request to the municipality and include in it a description of the property for which the tax notice is requested sufficient to allow the property to be identified.
The obligation under subsection (1) is satisfied if a reasonable effort was made to mail or otherwise deliver the notice or statement.

change.changenote: Division 2 of Part 11, sections 371 to 377 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-268, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person is refunded an amount of taxes paid under this Act, the municipality must pay the person interest at the rate prescribed under subsection (2).
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe a rate of interest for the purposes of this section.

section.marginalnote: Adjustments required if assessments are set aside or varied

subsection.subsectiontext: If an assessment is set aside or varied after the annual property tax bylaw is adopted, the collector must

paragraph.paragraphtext: make the necessary adjustments to the taxes imposed on the affected property, and
report on that adjustment to the council.

subsection.subsectiontext: The amount of any tax as amended under this section is the amount of taxes imposed for the current year on the property affected and, despite the terms of a receipt given by the collector, any excess paid must be refunded and any balance unpaid is tax due and payable.
If taxes are to be imposed on the basis of a supplementary roll under the Assessment Act, 30 days' notice must be given for payment of those taxes and a penalty must not be added in that period.
The obligation to give notice under subsection (1) is satisfied if the collector made a reasonable effort to mail or otherwise deliver the notice.
Taxes imposed on the basis of a supplementary roll are a debt to the municipality and subject to all methods available to the municipality for the recovery of taxes, including tax sale.

If an assessment on a supplementary roll is set aside or the assessed value reduced under the Assessment Act, the collector must refund to an owner the excess amount of taxes, and any penalty and interest on that excess, paid by the owner, less any taxes in arrear or delinquent taxes the person owes to the municipality.

section.marginalnote: Apportionment of property value taxes if land subdivided

subsection.subsectiontext: If a plan of subdivision is deposited in the land title office after November 30 in any year and before June 1 in the next year, the collector may

paragraph.paragraphtext: apportion the taxes payable in that next year between the parcels created by the subdivision in the same proportions as taxes would have been payable in respect of the parcels had the subdivision occurred on or before November 30 in the first year, and
on making an apportionment under paragraph (a), record the apportionment in the manner that the collector considers necessary.

subsection.subsectiontext: Taxes apportioned to a parcel under subsection (1) are the taxes payable in respect of the parcel in the year for which they are apportioned.
The assessor for the area in which the land is located must provide the collector with the assessed values necessary to calculate the proportions of taxes referred to in subsection (1).

section.marginalnote: Apportionment of parcel taxes if land subdivided

subsection.subsectiontext: If a parcel of land subject to tax under Division 2 [Parcel Taxes] of Part 10.1 [Taxes, Fees and Charges] is subdivided, the collector must

paragraph.paragraphtext: apportion the taxes payable between the parcels created by the subdivision in the same proportions as taxes would have been payable in respect of the parcels had the subdivision occurred before the assessment roll was authenticated, and
on making an apportionment under paragraph (a), record the apportionment in the manner that the collector considers necessary.

subsection.subsectiontext: Taxes apportioned to a parcel under subsection (1) are the taxes payable in respect of the parcel.
An apportionment or reapportionment of a parcel tax under this section does not

paragraph.paragraphtext: require authorization or confirmation by bylaw or by a local court of revision,
operate as a new parcel tax assessment, or
in any way invalidate, reopen or affect the assessment roll other than for the land in respect of which the apportionment or reapportionment has been made.

section.marginalnote: Special fees and charges that are to be collected as taxes

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies to

paragraph.paragraphtext: fees or charges imposed under this Act for work done or services provided to land or improvements, or

amounts that the municipality is entitled to recover for work done or services provided to land or improvements under any provision of this Act that authorizes the municipality to recover amounts in the event of default by a person.

subsection.subsectiontext: An amount referred to in subsection (1)

paragraph.paragraphtext: may be collected in the same manner and with the same remedies as ordinary taxes on land and improvements under this Act, and
if it is due and payable by December 31 and unpaid on that date, is deemed to be taxes in arrear.

subsection.subsectiontext: If an amount referred to in subsection (2) (b) is a fee or charge referred to in section 363 (2) (a) [fees and charges for services outside the municipality],

paragraph.paragraphtext: the collector must promptly, after December 31, forward a statement showing the amount of the fee or charge

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: to the Surveyor of Taxes in the case of real property that is not in a municipality, or
to the applicable municipal collector in other cases, and

paragraph.paragraphtext: the Surveyor of Taxes or collector must add the amount of the fee or charge to the taxes payable on the property.

subsection.subsectiontext: If an amount is added under subsection (3) (b),

paragraph.paragraphtext: the amount is deemed to be a Provincial or municipal tax, as applicable, and must be dealt with in the same manner as taxes against the property would be under the Taxation (Rural Area) Act or this Act, and
when it is collected, the Minister of Finance and Corporate Relations or collecting municipality must pay the amount to the municipality to which it is owed.

subsection.subsectiontext: If an amount is added under subsection (3) (b) and is not paid at the time the property is sold by tax sale,

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the upset price is obtained at the time of the tax sale, the minister or municipality referred to in subsection (4) must pay out of the proceeds of the sale the amount due under this section to the municipality to which it is owed, or
if the upset price is not obtained and subsequently the property is sold, the proceeds of sale must be applied according to the respective interests in the upset price.

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite subsections (3) to (5), the municipality to which the amount is owed may bring action in a court of competent jurisdiction to recover that amount.

The rates or tolls chargeable under a municipal bylaw or under an order of the Comptroller of Water Rights under the Water Act for carriage and delivery of water for irrigation of land in a position to be supplied or served from the municipality's irrigation works, and the costs and charges for the service, are a charge on the land that is in a position to be served or on which the water is supplied or used.
The rates or tolls and costs and charges referred to in subsection (1) are taxes deemed to be imposed under this Act, and the provisions of this Act for collection and recovery of taxes apply.
This section does not limit the generality of section 376 [special fees and charges that are to be collected as taxes].

change.changenote: Division 3 of Part 11, sections 378 to 383 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-268, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Payment for taxes must be credited by the collector against the following in the indicated order:

paragraph.paragraphtext: delinquent taxes, including interest, from past years;
taxes in arrear, including interest, from the preceding year;
a penalty added in the current year;
taxes imposed under the School Act for the current year;
taxes under Part 19 [Local Improvements and Specified Areas] in the current year;
any unpaid municipal taxes for the current year.

subsection.subsectiontext: Acceptance of a payment on account of taxes does not affect the liability of a person for full payment or of the land or improvements to be sold for the amount of taxes unpaid.
The taxes for the current year on land or improvements, or both, together with any applicable penalties, that are unpaid on December 31 in the year imposed

paragraph.paragraphtext: are taxes in arrear on that date, and
bear interest from that date at a rate prescribed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council under section 11 (3) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: Taxes

paragraph.paragraphtext: imposed by a municipality under section 359 (1) (b) [property taxes for other bodies], or
collected by the municipality on behalf of another local government or other public body on the basis of tax rates imposed by the other body

section.subsandwich: that are unpaid on December 31 in the year imposed, together with any applicable penalties, become municipal taxes in arrear under subsection (1) on that date.

subsection.subsectiontext: The interest under subsection (1) (b) is part of the taxes in arrear, and the total amount of the taxes in arrear is a charge on the land or improvements, or both, as if the penalties and interest had originally formed part of the taxes imposed.
Any taxes in arrear remaining unpaid on December 31 in the year following the year in which they became taxes in arrear

paragraph.paragraphtext: are delinquent on that date, and
bear interest from that date at a rate prescribed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council under section 11 (3) of the Taxation (Rural Area) Act until paid or recovered.

subsection.subsectiontext: The added interest under subsection (1) (b) is part of the delinquent taxes and is a charge as in section 379 (3) [taxes in arrear].

section.marginalnote: Treatment of taxes on subdivision or cancellation of subdivision

subsection.subsectiontext: If a parcel of land appears on the assessment roll to have been subdivided, the collector must apportion taxes in arrear and delinquent taxes in the same proportion as the assessment for each new parcel bears to the total assessment.
The assessor for the area in which the land is located must provide the collector with the assessment apportionment required for the purpose of subsection (1).
Subsections (1) and (2) also apply if part of a parcel on which taxes are due has been sold and the transfer has been delivered to the purchaser.

If a plan of subdivision has been cancelled, the amount of any taxes in arrear or delinquent taxes against a parcel in the plan or subdivision cancelled are taxes in arrear or delinquent taxes against the parcel of land as it appears after cancellation.

section.marginalnote: Statements of taxes in arrear or delinquent

subsection.subsectiontext: No later than the date on which the tax notice under section 369 [general tax notices] is mailed, the collector must mail a statement of the amount of the taxes in arrear and of delinquent taxes to each assessed owner of

paragraph.paragraphtext: property for which there are taxes in arrear or delinquent taxes, or
property sold under section 403 [annual tax sale] but remaining subject to redemption under section 417 [redemption by owner].

subsection.subsectiontext: A statement under subsection (1) must also be mailed to each holder of a registered charge in relation to the property whose name is included on the assessment roll.
The obligation to mail a statement under subsection (1) or (2) is satisfied if a reasonable effort was made to mail or otherwise deliver the statement.
If applicable, the statement under subsection (1) must be in the form prescribed by regulation.
On demand and without charge, the collector must give the owner of real property whichever of the following is applicable to the property:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a written statement showing the amount of all unpaid taxes;
a certificate that all taxes, fees and charges imposed against the real property identified in the certificate have been fully paid.

subsection.subsectiontext: The collector must provide, to any person who requests this, a certificate showing

paragraph.paragraphtext: the amount of unpaid taxes charged against specified real property,
whether the real property has been sold for taxes, and
if the property has been sold for taxes, the time if any remaining for redemption and the amount required to redeem it.

subsection.subsectiontext: An error in a statement or certificate given under this section does not subject the municipality to damages.

change.changenote: Division 7 of Part 11, sections 396 to 402 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-268, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Taxes are a special charge on the land

subsection.subsectiontext: Taxes accrued and to accrue on land and its improvements, and a judgment under section 397 for the taxes, are a charge that

paragraph.paragraphtext: is a special charge on the land and improvements,
has priority over any claim, lien, privilege or encumbrance of any person except the Crown, and
does not require registration to preserve it.

subsection.subsectiontext: If it is necessary or advisable to protect or enforce a charge under subsection (1) by a proceeding, this may be done by order of the court, on application and on notice the court considers proper.

section.marginalnote: Liability of assessed owner and recovery by court action

subsection.subsectiontext: A person who, in any year, is an assessed owner of land, improvements or both in a municipality, or of a taxable interest in them, is liable to the municipality for

paragraph.paragraphtext: all taxes imposed by the municipality under any Act or former Act on the land, improvements or both during the year, and
all unpaid taxes imposed in a previous year.

subsection.subsectiontext: The liability referred to in subsection (1) is a debt recoverable by the municipality by action in a court of competent jurisdiction.

A copy of the tax notice under section 369 [general tax notices] that refers to the taxes payable by the person, certified as a true copy by the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration], is evidence of the debt referred to in subsection (2).

The liability must not be enforced by action against a person whose name appears on an assessment roll only as a personal representative or trustee of an estate, except to the extent and value of the assets of the estate that have come into that person's hands.

section.marginalnote: Recovery of taxes by the legal remedy known as "distress"

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite any Act, with the approval of the council, a collector may, directly or by agent, levy the amount of taxes due, with costs, by distress of one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the output of the taxed property;
goods and chattels of the person liable to pay the taxes;
any goods and chattels in British Columbia in the possession of the person liable to pay the taxes;
any goods and chattels found on the premises of the person liable to pay the taxes;

any goods and chattels found on the property of or in the possession of another occupant of the premises of the person liable to pay the taxes that would be subject to distress for rent arrears due to a landlord.

subsection.subsectiontext: The costs chargeable on distress under this section are those payable as between landlord and tenant.
A collector who makes distress must, by notice posted in at least 3 conspicuous public places in the locality where the property seized is to be sold, give at least 10 days' notice of

paragraph.paragraphtext: the time and place of the sale, and
the name of the taxpayer whose property is to be sold.

subsection.subsectiontext: At the time given in the notice under subsection (3), the collector or agent must sell at public auction the seized property or as much as may be necessary.

If there is a surplus from the sale over the amount of the taxes and costs, the surplus must be paid to the person in possession of the property when it was seized, unless claim to it is made by another person on the ground that the property sold belonged to the other person, or that the other person was entitled by lien or other right to the surplus.
If a claim is made by the person for whose taxes the property was distrained and the claim is admitted, the surplus must be paid to the claimant.
If the claim referred to in subsection (6) is contested, the surplus must be retained by the collector until the rights of the parties have been determined.
A person receiving a surplus under this section must give a receipt for it.

section.marginalnote: Power to accept real property in place of taxes

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of its members, accept, in place of all unpaid taxes, rates, interest and costs against otherwise unencumbered real property in the municipality, an absolute conveyance to the municipality of the whole of the real property from its registered owner.

Delivery of the conveyance must be made to the municipality and, after receipt, the designated municipal officer must promptly apply to the proper land title office for registration of the municipality as owner.

Registration of the municipality as owner of the land or real property is deemed to be in payment of and discharges all taxes, rates, interest and costs assessed and chargeable against the land or real property at the date of the conveyance.

section.marginalnote: Notice of delinquent taxes on Crown land
section.sectiontext: If taxes become delinquent on land that the Provincial government has agreed to sell under an agreement to purchase,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the collector must notify the minister responsible for the administration of the Land Act within 3 months after taxes with respect to the person holding the land became delinquent, and
that minister must cause a suitable notation to be made on the record of purchase and may take any other steps considered advisable.

section.marginalnote: Recovery of taxes on Crown land subject to an agreement for sale

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies if the Provincial government has agreed to sell land in a municipality on terms of deferred payment and the holder of the agreement for sale

paragraph.paragraphtext: has defaulted in payment for the land, or has abandoned the land with the title remaining in the Provincial government, and
has defaulted in payment of municipal taxes against the land.

subsection.subsectiontext: The municipal taxes referred to in subsection (1) are a first charge against the land and, following the sale of the land, the Provincial government must pay the municipal taxes out of the proceeds of the sale, subject to the limit that the amount paid must not exceed the amount received by the Provincial government for the sale.

section.marginalnote: Recovery of taxes on Crown land held under lease or licence

subsection.subsectiontext: The collector must not sell land the fee simple of which is vested in the Provincial government and which is held under lease, licence, permit or location.

Within 5 months from the date when taxes on land referred to in subsection (1) become delinquent, the collector must give written notice to the person liable for them, either by serving the notice or by sending it by registered mail, that the lease, licence, permit or location will be cancelled if the person does not pay the delinquent taxes, together with interest and all subsequent taxes, within 6 months from the date when the taxes became delinquent.
On application, the Supreme Court may order that the notice under subsection (2) may be served by substituted service in accordance with the order.
The collector must send a copy of the notice under subsection (2) to the minister responsible for the administration of the Land Act.
If payment of the delinquent taxes, with interest, and all subsequent taxes is not made within the 6 months,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the collector must forward to the minister referred to in subsection (4) a list of defaulting lessees, licensees, permittees or locators, and
that minister must at once cancel the leases, licences, permits or locations.

subsection.subsectiontext: Until the minister referred to in subsection (4) notifies the collector of cancellation under subsection (5), the collector must not cancel an amount due.
On cancellation of a lease, licence, permit or location, the minister referred to in subsection (4) must notify the collector, who must then cancel the amount due.

If good reasons are shown to the satisfaction of the minister referred to in subsection (4) that the defaulting person, from poverty, sickness or other cause, has been unable to pay the amount due within the time limit, the minister may extend the time within which payment must be made before cancellation takes effect.

section.marginalnote: Power to agree with other taxing authority

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite this Act, a council may, by bylaw, make agreements with any other authority having taxing powers in respect of land, or land and improvements, located in the municipality respecting the exercise of the powers of the municipality and of the other authority in all matters of collection of taxes, tax sales, redemptions, the disposal of reverted land, the rental of that land before disposal and similar matters.

An agreement under subsection (1) may provide for the exercise of its power by either the municipality or the other authority acting alone on the working basis of protection of the joint interests of the parties that may be mutually determined.

change.changenote: Part 13, sections 480 to 506 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-275, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003).

section.sectiontext: The municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 199 [financial administration] must keep separate accounts to show at all times

paragraph.paragraphtext: the state of each debt for which sinking fund debentures have been issued, and
the amount of money raised and appropriated for the annual sinking fund requirement for the debt.

section.marginalnote: Savings institution account for sinking fund money

subsection.subsectiontext: The municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 199 [financial administration] must deposit all money to the credit of a sinking fund in a separate account in a savings institution.
The same institution account may be used for a number of sinking fund accounts.

section.marginalnote: Application of securities held as investments from sinking funds

subsection.subsectiontext: If money in a sinking fund account is invested under section 336 [investment of municipal funds], the securities and their revenues must be held to the credit of the applicable sinking fund account.
If more than one sinking fund account is involved, the securities and revenue referred to in subsection (1) must be allocated in proportion to the money from the accounts used for the investment.

section.marginalnote: Pledging sinking fund securities for municipal borrowing

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw adopted with the approval of the inspector, borrow money by pledging as security any securities purchased and held under section 483.
An obligation given by a municipality to a lender under subsection (1) must

paragraph.paragraphtext: be in writing, in a form approved by the council and signed by the mayor and the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 199 [financial administration],
state the rate of interest, and
be due and payable on a named date in the year in which it is given.

subsection.subsectiontext: An obligation under subsection (1) may give the lender the authority considered proper by the council to sell any of the securities pledged.
The council must place all money received from borrowing under this section to the credit of the applicable sinking fund.

section.marginalnote: Directions from minister as to use of sinking fund

subsection.subsectiontext: The minister may, by order,

paragraph.paragraphtext: direct that any money to the credit of a sinking fund account, instead of being invested, be used for the purchase, payment, redemption and cancellation, at a price agreed on and stated in the order, of the municipality's outstanding sinking fund debentures specified in the order, even if they are not then due and payable, or
direct a municipality to cancel its sinking fund debentures held to the credit of a sinking fund account, even if they are not then due and payable.

subsection.subsectiontext: An order under subsection (1) must direct readjustment of the sinking fund account affected by the order.

A special assessment and a special or other rate imposed under any Act in a municipality subject to an order under this section continues valid and enforceable, except as adjusted by the order, even though the debentures for which the assessment or rate was imposed have been redeemed and cancelled under this section.

section.marginalnote: Reduction of sinking fund rates or levy

subsection.subsectiontext: If, because of an increased value of real property liable to assessment, it is found unnecessary to collect the full tax imposed by a bylaw to raise

paragraph.paragraphtext: the instalment of the sinking fund and interest required in any year, or
the instalments for future unexpired years of the debentures,

section.subsandwich: the council may, by bylaw, reduce the rate for that year or for the future years so that no more money is collected than is required.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (1) must not be adopted unless, having regard to the time the debentures have to run, a proper proportion of sinking fund and interest has been collected under the intention of the original bylaw.
If a bylaw provides for raising each year a larger sum for a sinking fund or interest than is necessary to pay off a debt, the council may, by bylaw, reduce the amount to be raised each year.
If there is a surplus in a sinking fund account above the amount required for the fund under the bylaw creating the debt, the council may, by bylaw, provide for the application of the surplus to

paragraph.paragraphtext: the payment of the amount required for the fund, or for interest on the debt, in a succeeding year, or
the payment of charges incidental to payment or remission of the principal or interest due on the debt for which the fund is held.

subsection.subsectiontext: If there is a surplus in a sinking fund account after the debt authorized by a loan bylaw is repaid, the surplus may be disposed of under section 498.

section.sectiontext: If the amount in a sinking fund does not meet requirements, the council may apply part of the current revenue to the deficiency.

section.marginalnote: Inspector may require report on sinking fund

subsection.subsectiontext: The inspector may require a municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 199 [financial administration] to submit a report showing the state of the sinking fund for any debt.

A report under subsection (1) must include full particulars of financial transactions for each sinking fund account during a specified period, and indicate the basis of valuation of securities held at the credit of each account.

section.marginalnote: Transfer of administration to Minister of Finance and Corporate Relations

subsection.subsectiontext: On receipt of evidence of inefficient or improper administration of a sinking fund account, the minister may, by order, direct that the sinking fund accounts of the municipality, and the money and securities held for them, be transferred to and administered by the Minister of Finance and Corporate Relations.
An order under subsection (1) is binding on and applies to all persons affected by it.
A council that is subject to an order under subsection (1) must remit annually to the Minister of Finance and Corporate Relations the money required annually for the funds.

section.marginalnote: Municipal financial officer must keep accounts
section.sectiontext: The municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 199 [financial administration] must keep accounts necessary to show at all times the amount of money raised, obtained and appropriated for each debt retirement fund.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may proceed under this section if

paragraph.paragraphtext: for any cause it appears expedient to provide money in advance of the requirements for retirement at maturity of outstanding municipal debentures, or
the proceeds from the sale of assets are required to be held for debt retirement.

subsection.subsectiontext: In the circumstances described in subsection (1), the council may, by bylaw, provide for the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: setting aside in each year amounts considered necessary for a proposed scheme of debt financing;
setting aside the proceeds of a sale of assets, as specified in the bylaw, for a debt retirement fund to meet in full or in part, at or before maturity, outstanding debentures issued for the assets;
the administration and investment under this Part of money set aside under the bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: The bylaw may contain directions

paragraph.paragraphtext: to impose during specified years the amounts established under subsection (2) (a), by rate sufficient in addition to other rates, and
not to impose in any future year all or part of the annual amounts required to repay the principal of outstanding debentures.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw with directions under subsection (3) (a) to impose a rate for the purposes of this section must receive the assent of the electors.
A bylaw under this section must not extend the term of a debenture debt beyond the period originally set for it.

section.sectiontext: A council may invest or reinvest all or part of the money to the credit of a debt retirement fund in the manner provided for sinking funds.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may by bylaw establish reserve funds for the following purposes:

paragraph.paragraphtext: expenditures for or in respect of capital projects and land, machinery or equipment necessary for the capital projects and extension or renewal of existing capital works;
the purchase of machinery and equipment to maintain municipal property and to protect persons and property;
depreciation and obsolescence of any machinery and equipment.

subsection.subsectiontext: Money from current revenue or, as available, from general revenue surplus, or as otherwise provided in this Act, may be paid into a reserve fund under this section.
Money set aside for the purpose of subsection (1) (c), and interest earned on it, must be expended solely to purchase machinery and equipment.
A council may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of its members, provide for the expenditure of any money in a reserve fund under subsection (1) (a) or (b) and interest earned on it.
A council may, by bylaw, establish reserve funds for enterprises owned or operated by the municipality.

Money from current revenue, as available from general revenue surplus, from the surplus from operation of the enterprise, or as otherwise provided in this Act, may be paid into a reserve fund under this section.
Money set aside in a reserve fund under this section, and interest earned on it, must be used only for

paragraph.paragraphtext: a capital expenditure for the enterprise for which it is established, and
redemption of debentures issued for the enterprise.

section.marginalnote: Reserve fund from tax sale money

subsection.subsectiontext: All money received from the sale of tax sale properties must be set aside in a reserve fund.
The municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 199 [financial administration] must deposit the money referred to in subsection (1) in a savings institution when received.
Until required under this section, the money of the reserve fund may be invested in the manner provided by section 336 [investment of municipal funds].
The money of the reserve fund under this section, and interest earned on it, may be used only for

paragraph.paragraphtext: first, bringing sinking funds up to requirements, and
then, reduction of debenture debt, capital expenditures, transfer to a debt retirement, reserve or local improvement fund or expenditures of a special nature.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw adopted by 2/3 of its members, provide for the use or expenditure of money in the reserve fund under this section.
A council may, by bylaw, establish a special reserve fund for a specified purpose that is within the powers of the municipality under this or another Act.

As an exception, the authority under subsection (1) may not be used to establish a reserve fund for a purpose for which reserve funds may be established under another section of this Act or under another enactment.
Before adopting a bylaw under subsection (1), the council must provide a counter petition opportunity in relation to the proposed bylaw.
The following may be paid into a special reserve fund:

paragraph.paragraphtext: amounts that are to be raised by a rate under section 359 (1) (a) [municipal property taxes] in respect of the special reserve fund;
amounts that may be paid into the reserve fund as otherwise provided in this Act;
amounts received by the municipality in relation to the specified purpose of the special reserve fund, subject to any terms and conditions attached to their use.

subsection.subsectiontext: Money in a special reserve fund, and interest earned on it, must be used only for the purpose for which the fund was established.
A council may, by bylaw, establish a local improvement fund.
The council may, by bylaw, set aside money for the local improvement fund out of general revenue, or as otherwise provided in this Act.

The money set aside from general revenue, money transferred to the fund under section 498, and money expended from and repaid to the fund, together with interest earned, must be used only to finance the construction of works payable by special charges under Part 19.
If the amount to the credit of a reserve or local improvement fund is greater than required, the council may, by bylaw, transfer all or part of the amount to another fund established under this Part.

As an exception, a bylaw under subsection (1) authorizing the transfer of an amount from a reserve fund that is established for the purpose of acquiring park lands may only be adopted with the approval of the minister.

section.marginalnote: Use of money if original purpose has failed
section.sectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, authorize the use, for a lawful purpose of the municipality, of money on hand that

paragraph.paragraphtext: was raised to pay interest on debentures authorized under a municipal bylaw or to repay principal of those debentures, and
the municipality is unable to use for the purpose designated in the bylaw because the bylaw is no longer in force or because all principal and interest on the debentures has been paid or provided.

subsection.subsectiontext: Money collected by a municipality for interest on a debt of the municipality or for the sinking fund or instalments of principal for a debt of the municipality must not be used for a purpose other than that for which it is collected.
Money held by a municipality subject to a trust or reserve must not be used for a purpose other than under the terms of the trust or of the bylaw creating the reserve or special fund.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the specific limitations and conditions established by or under this or another Act, a municipality may operate any service that the council considers necessary or desirable for all or part of the municipality.
The authority under subsection (1) includes the authority to operate a service in an area outside the municipality as well as in the municipality itself.
A municipal service may be operated directly by the municipality or through another public authority, person or organization.

section.marginalnote: Establishing bylaws required for most services

subsection.subsectiontext: In order to operate a service, the council must first adopt an establishing bylaw for the service.
As an exception, an establishing bylaw is not required for the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: general administration;
undertaking feasibility studies in relation to proposed services;
a service for which authority is expressly provided by another Part of this Act or by another enactment.

section.marginalnote: Consent required for services outside municipality

subsection.subsectiontext: Before establishing a service referred to in section 517 (2) [services outside municipality], the council must obtain the consent of the other affected local government as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the area is in another municipality, the consent of the council of that other municipality is required;
if the area is not in another municipality, the consent of the regional district board for the area is required.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a service referred to in subsection (1) is established, the powers, duties and functions of the municipality under this Part, and in relation to enforcement, may be exercised in relation to the service in the area in which the service is provided.

section.marginalnote: General authorities in relation to services

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under this Part may

paragraph.paragraphtext: establish different classes of persons, places, activities or things, and
make different provisions for different classes and for different areas of the municipality.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, regulate in relation to a municipal service.
A power to regulate under this Part includes the power to prohibit.
Without limiting subsection (2), a bylaw under this Part may provide for a system of licences, permits or approvals in relation to a municipal service, including one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: prohibiting any activity or thing until a licence, permit or approval has been granted;
providing for the granting and refusal of licences, permits and approvals;
providing for the duration periods of licences, permits and approvals;
providing that terms and conditions may be imposed on any licence, permit or approval, the nature of the terms and conditions and who may impose them;
setting out the conditions that must be met before a licence, permit or approval is granted, the nature of the conditions and who may impose them;
providing for the suspension or cancellation of licences, permits and approvals for

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: failure to comply with a term or condition of a licence, permit or approval, or
failure to comply with the bylaw.

section.marginalnote: Regulation of works and facilities outside the municipality
section.sectiontext: If a municipality has established works or facilities outside the municipality for the purposes of a municipal service, the council may, by bylaw, regulate the use of the works and facilities.

change.changenote: Division 2 of Part 15, sections 520 and 521 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-277, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies to municipalities with a population greater than 5 000.
Despite any Act or the letters patent incorporating a municipality, but subject to the Justice Administration Act and the Police Act, each municipality must bear the expense necessary to

paragraph.paragraphtext: generally maintain law and order in the municipality,
provide offices for the police force or police department,
provide premises as a place of detention, and
provide for the care and custody of persons held in a place of detention referred to in paragraph (c).

subsection.subsectiontext: The Minister of Finance and Corporate Relations may reimburse a municipality out of money appropriated for the purpose by paying an amount prescribed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council for the expense of the care and custody of a person who is detained in a place of detention and is within a class prescribed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

section.marginalnote: Disposal of property in police possession

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to this section, property that has come into the custody and possession of the police force or police department on behalf of a municipality may be disposed of by a person authorized by council if

paragraph.paragraphtext: the owner of the property has not been identified after reasonable effort, and
a court of competent jurisdiction has not made an order in respect of the property.

subsection.subsectiontext: Except as permitted under subsection (3), the property must not be disposed of until it has been in the possession of the police for 3 months.
The property may be disposed of at any time if

paragraph.paragraphtext: it is a perishable article,
has no apparent marketable value, or
its custody involves unreasonable expense or inconvenience.

subsection.subsectiontext: Except for property referred to in subsection (3), the municipality must provide advance notice, by publication in a newspaper, of the sale or other disposal process.
A person who receives or purchases property as provided in this section has a good and sufficient title to that article as against any former owner of it.
Unless claimed by and paid to the lawful owner of the property, the proceeds of any sale must be held for one year from the date of sale before being dealt with as directed by the council.

The municipality, a member of the council, a person in lawful custody of property referred to in subsection (1) or an officer, employee or agent of the municipality, is not liable in damages or otherwise for or in respect of any claim that may arise in respect of the property after it has been disposed of under this section.

change.changenote: Section 522 (1) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-278(a), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the Fire Services Act and the regulations under it, a council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

change.changenote: Section 522 (1) (a) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-278(b), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

paragraph.paragraphtext: authorize the fire chief to

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: inspect premises for conditions that may cause a fire or increase the danger of a fire or increase the danger to persons, and
take the measures described in the bylaw to prevent and suppress fires, including the demolition of buildings and structures to prevent the spreading of fire;

change.changenote: Section 523 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-279, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the Health Act, a council may, by bylaw,

paragraph.paragraphtext: regulate for the purposes of maintaining, promoting or preserving public health or maintaining sanitary conditions, and
undertake any other measures it considers necessary for those purposes.

subsection.subsectiontext: A provision of a bylaw under subsection (1) that regulates is not valid until approved by the Minister of Health, who may consider and deal with it accordingly.
As a limit on subsection (1), a council must not fluoridate the water supply unless the bylaw has received the assent of the electors.

change.changenote: Section 523 (1) BEFORE amended by 2008-28-151, effective March 31, 2009 (BC Reg 49/2009).

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the Health Act, a board may, by bylaw,

change.changenote: Division 5 of Part 15, sections 524 to 539 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-280, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: The right of possession of every highway in a municipality is vested in the municipality, subject to any rights in the soil reserved by the persons who laid out the highway.
Except as referred to in subsection (1), the right of possession of the municipality is not adversely affected or derogated from by prescription in favour of any other occupier.
The soil and freehold of every highway in a municipality are vested in the Provincial government.
Subsection (1) does not apply if a municipality has purchased or taken land for a highway and its title is registered in the name of the municipality.
A council may, by bylaw, dispose of a portion of a highway in exchange for land necessary for the purpose of improving, widening, straightening, relocating or diverting a highway.
Before adopting a bylaw under subsection (3), the council must have notice of its intention published in a newspaper once each week for 2 consecutive weeks.

A disposition under subsection (3) has the same effect as a Crown grant free of all rights of way, and all land taken in exchange for a portion of a highway under that subsection are public highways, and title to them vests in the Provincial government.
Under special circumstances, the minister may abandon a portion of a highway vested in the Provincial government and vest title in land comprised in that portion in a person.
A vesting under subsection (6) has the same effect as a Crown grant vesting title to the land in the person.

section.marginalnote: Agreements to reserve land for highway purposes

subsection.subsectiontext: Without limiting section 176 [corporate powers], a council may enter into an agreement with an owner of land for reserving any part of the land for highway purposes, including the condition that the land reserved must remain unencumbered by buildings or structures.
An agreement under subsection (1) has the effect of a restrictive covenant running with the land and must be registered in the land title office by the municipality.
A council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: authorize the establishment, widening, alteration, relocation or diversion of a highway or a portion of it;
close a highway, or a portion of it, to traffic;
reopen a highway or portion of it that has been closed to traffic.
