subsection.subsectiontext: At least 30 days before adopting a bylaw under subsection (1) (b), the council must publish notice of its intention in a newspaper.
Before adopting a bylaw under subsection (1) (b), the council must provide an opportunity for persons who consider they are affected by the bylaw to make representations to council.
A council may authorize a designated municipal officer or a municipal employee, at the person's discretion, to

paragraph.paragraphtext: temporarily close a highway or part of it to traffic, or
control traffic,

section.subsandwich: in connection with a construction or maintenance project on or adjacent to the highway.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw,

paragraph.paragraphtext: assign a name or number to a highway, or
change the name or number of a highway.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (1) does not have effect until a certified copy is filed in the land title office.
On receipt of a bylaw changing the name or number of a highway, the registrar of land titles must note the change on

paragraph.paragraphtext: any subdivision plan in the land title office that dedicated the highway, and
any plan filed or deposited in the land title office on which the highway is named.

section.marginalnote: Works to protect highways from water damage
section.sectiontext: Subject to Division 3 of Part 8 [Expropriation and Compensation], a council may, by bylaw, construct works through, under or over land adjoining a highway for the protection of the highway from damage by water.

section.marginalnote: Special authority in relation to highways and related matters
section.sectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: require owners or occupiers of real property to place building or structure numbers assigned by the municipality in a conspicuous place;
require owners or occupiers of real property to remove snow, ice or rubbish from sidewalks and foot paths bordering their property or from the roof or other part of a structure adjacent to a highway;
require owners of private highways to maintain them in a clean, fit and safe state and to post suitable private thoroughfare signs;
require owners of land to fence any part of it abutting on a highway.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the Highway Act, the Motor Carrier Act and the Motor Vehicle Act, a council may, by bylaw adopted with the approval of the Minister of Transportation and Highways,

paragraph.paragraphtext: regulate extraordinary traffic within the meaning of section 23 of the Highway Act, and

provide that the powers exercisable by the Minister of Transportation and Highways in respect of extraordinary traffic are to be exercised in the municipality by the council or by a designated municipal officer.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (1) may

paragraph.paragraphtext: classify highways or portions of highways, including sidewalks and boulevards, according to areas or zones in the municipality and according to widths, amount of traffic or otherwise, and
make different regulations for different classes of highways, classes of vehicles, seasons of the year and conditions of highways.

section.marginalnote: Uses of highways and public places

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite any other Act but subject to the Motor Vehicle Act, a council may, by bylaw, regulate

paragraph.paragraphtext: all uses of or involving a highway or portion of it, other than uses by extraordinary traffic referred to in section 531, and
all uses of or involving a public place.

subsection.subsectiontext: Except as permitted by a bylaw under subsection (1), a person must not excavate in, cause a nuisance on, encumber, obstruct, injure, foul or damage any portion of a highway or other public place.
Without limiting subsections (1) and (2) and in addition to the authority under section 521 [disposal of property in police possession], a council may

paragraph.paragraphtext: authorize the removal, detention or impounding of any thing or obstruction unlawfully occupying a portion of a highway or public place,
provide for a scale of fees, costs and expenses for such removal, detention or impounding, and
provide for the recovery of those fees, costs and expenses

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: from the owner of the thing or obstruction,
by its sale at public auction, or
by action in a court of competent jurisdiction.

subsection.subsectiontext: A person who is being unreasonably prevented from carrying out any work, undertaking or construction lawfully permitted on, over or under a highway or other public place may appeal to the Supreme Court.
On an appeal under subsection (4), the court may order that the applicant be permitted to carry out the work, undertaking or construction under the conditions specified in the order.

section.marginalnote: Wires, poles and structures on highways

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, require the removal of

paragraph.paragraphtext: wires,
poles, or
towers or other structures

section.subsandwich: on, in, over, under or along a highway that are considered by the council to be dangerous to the public safety.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may require a person permitted to erect poles on highways to provide reasonable accommodation on the poles for wires and equipment of the municipality on agreed terms, and section 334 [limit on borrowing and other liabilities] does not apply to the agreement.
If the parties are unable to reach an agreement referred to in subsection (2), the matters must be settled by arbitration, and for these purposes the Commercial Arbitration Act applies.
A council may allow the construction of gates across a highway

paragraph.paragraphtext: at points considered advisable within 800 m of a railway crossing, or
for the assistance of customs and other officials in the performance of their duties.

subsection.subsectiontext: A municipality is not subject to any liability by reason of the fact that gates may have been constructed across a highway or that damages may have resulted to a person by reason of their existence.
In this section and sections 536 and 537, boundary highway means a highway that forms all or part of the boundary between municipalities.
All boundary highways must be opened, maintained, kept in repair and improved by the municipalities of which they form a boundary.

The councils of the municipalities have joint jurisdiction over the boundary highway and are liable accordingly, although the highway may, in some places, deviate to be wholly or partly inside one or more of the municipalities.
A municipal bylaw respecting a boundary highway does not have effect for the highway until mutually acceptable bylaws have been adopted by the other councils with joint jurisdiction.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a work of local improvement undertaken on petition wholly at the cost of the owners of abutting property, if

paragraph.paragraphtext: the work is inside the municipality proposing to carry out the work, and
one month's notice of intention has been given to the other councils with joint jurisdiction.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a council fails to adopt an acceptable bylaw referred to in subsection (1) within 3 months of being given notice of the initial bylaw, the failure is an inability to agree within the meaning of section 537 and that section applies.

If the municipalities interested in all or part of a boundary highway are unable to agree to their joint action in opening, maintaining, repairing or improving the highway, one or more of the councils may apply to the Minister of Transportation and Highways for a decision under this section.
On an application under subsection (1), the Minister of Transportation and Highways may set the amount that each municipality is required to spend on the highway and the mode of expenditure.
A decision under this section is final and binding on the municipalities interested, and may be enforced by any municipality in a court of competent jurisdiction.

All sums of money overpaid by a municipality for opening, maintaining, repairing or improving the boundary highway may be recovered as a debt due to the municipality from a municipality in default or neglecting to make the payment directed by a decision under this section.
This section applies if 2 or more adjoining municipalities, including the City of Vancouver,

paragraph.paragraphtext: are served by a highway that transects those municipalities, and
as a result, are interested in but unable to agree on the use, location, function, maintenance, repair or improvement of the highway.

subsection.subsectiontext: The Minister of Transportation and Highways, on the minister's own initiative or on the application of one or more of the councils of the affected municipalities, may

paragraph.paragraphtext: determine the use and location of the highway or extensions,
designate the function of the highway, and
set the amount that each municipality is required to spend on the highway and the mode of expenditure.

subsection.subsectiontext: A decision of the Minister of Transportation and Highways under this section is final and binding on the affected municipalities.

Section 536 [bylaws respecting intermunicipal boundary highways] applies to a highway under this section and section 537 [disputes respecting boundary highways] applies to enforcement of the decision under this section.

If a river or stream forms all or part of the boundary between 2 or more municipalities, the councils of the municipalities may, by bylaw adopted by all councils, undertake the construction of a bridge across the river or stream.
A bridge constructed under subsection (1) must be maintained and kept in repair jointly by the municipalities, and is under their joint jurisdiction and control.
Sections 536 [bylaws respecting intermunicipal boundary highways] and 537 [disputes respecting boundary highways] apply to the construction and maintenance of intermunicipal bridges.

change.changenote: Section 540 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-281, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: A council may, by bylaw,

paragraph.paragraphtext: regulate the design and installation of drainage and sewerage works provided by persons other than the municipality, and
require owners of real property to connect their buildings and structures to the appropriate sewer or drain connections in the manner specified in the bylaw.

change.changenote: Section 541 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-281, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Watercourse may be included in drainage system
section.sectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, make a watercourse part of the municipal drainage system, whether the watercourse is on a highway or municipal or private land.

change.changenote: Section 542 (2) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-282(a), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw,

change.changenote: Section 542 (2) (a) (ii) and (iii) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-282(b), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: works to maintain the proper flow of water in a stream, ditch, drain or sewer in the municipality, or
works to reclaim or to protect part of the land mass of the municipality from erosion by action of the sea or a stream, or any other cause, and

change.changenote: Section 543 (1), (2) and (3) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-283, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purpose of constructing works referred to in subsection (2), a council may appropriate the land that constitutes the channel or bed of a stream that passes through the municipality, without compensation to the owner.
The power under subsection (1) may be exercised in relation to one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: dikes;
works to maintain the proper flow of water in a stream, ditch, drain or sewer in the municipality;
works to reclaim or to protect part of the land mass of the municipality from erosion by action of the sea or a stream, or any other cause;
works to protect all or part of the banks of the stream from erosion or damage;
works to make a watercourse part of the municipal drainage system, whether the watercourse is on a highway or municipal or private land;
works through, under or over land adjoining a highway to protect the highway from damage by water.

subsection.subsectiontext: Before exercising the power under subsection (1), the council must, by bylaw, define the channel or bed of the stream.

change.changenote: Section 544 (1), (3), (6) and (7) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-284, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies if a council considers that

paragraph.paragraphtext: the drainage of surface water from outside the municipality into or through an area inside the municipality should be prevented, diverted or improved, or
drainage of or from an area in the municipality should be prevented, continued beyond the municipality, diverted or improved,

change.subsandwich: and proposes to undertake works for these purposes.

subsection.subsectiontext: The notice under subsection (2) must state

paragraph.paragraphtext: the place in the municipality where details of the project may be inspected, and
the date by which objections to the project must be received by the municipality.

subsection.subsectiontext: The designated municipal officer must make a full report to the inspector on all objections received.
On the application of a council, the minister may authorize works proposed under this section on the terms of compensation and cost to owners of land affected that the minister considers proper.

change.changenote: Section 545 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-285, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Appeal to minister if unable to reach agreement on construction of drains

subsection.subsectiontext: A person may appeal to the minister if,

paragraph.paragraphtext: in order to provide an outlet for a surface drain, the person must continue the drain into an adjoining parcel of land or across or along a highway, and
the owner of an adjoining parcel or the council refuses to enter into an agreement under which the drain may be continued.

subsection.subsectiontext: On an appeal under subsection (1), the minister may direct the municipality to provide the necessary works and may determine by whom the cost of the works must be borne.

change.changenote: Section 546 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-286, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Liability for damage to works or watercourse

subsection.subsectiontext: A municipality may apply to the Supreme Court for an order under this section against a person who

paragraph.paragraphtext: obstructs, fills up or injures a ditch, drain, creek or watercourse constructed or improved under this Act, or
cuts, destroys or injures a dike or other drainage or reclamation work connected with it.

subsection.subsectiontext: On an application under this section, the court may order the person to undertake the restoration work directed by the court and, in addition, to pay a penalty not greater than $2 000.

change.changenote: Section 547 (2), (3), and (4) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-287, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: If the top of a dike forms a portion of a highway, it is the duty of the council to maintain it at a constant level, and to repair all injury directly or indirectly caused to the dike by its use as a highway.

For certainty, a council's duty under subsection (2) is limited to the highway as a highway and, except as otherwise required, does not extend to or include repair or maintenance of the dike as distinct from the highway.
As an exception, subsection (2) does not apply if the council has granted a diking commission the privilege of using the existing road for a dike.

change.changenote: Section 548 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-288, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may make agreements with adjoining municipalities, and also with the owner of any land, through, on or in which runs a natural stream or watercourse, for one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: constructing, enlarging or maintaining a culvert, ditch, flume, embankment or other work;
removing obstructions from the stream or watercourse to lessen or prevent the danger of flooding from it;

the granting, expending or accepting of money for the purposes referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b), even though the work may not be located in the municipality granting, expending or accepting the money or entering into the agreement.

subsection.subsectiontext: Sections 536 [bylaws respecting intermunicipal boundary highways] and 537 [disputes respecting intermunicipal boundary highways] apply to intermunicipal watercourses.

change.changenote: Section 549 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-289, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A district municipality may

paragraph.paragraphtext: collect the water from any highway by means of drains or ditches, and
convey to and discharge the water in the most convenient natural waterway or watercourse.

subsection.subsectiontext: A municipality proposing to construct ditches or drains authorized by subsection (1) must publish a notice in accordance with subsection (3) in a newspaper once a week for 4 consecutive weeks.
The notice under subsection (2) must state that

paragraph.paragraphtext: the municipality intends to undertake the works,
plans and specifications of the works may be inspected at the municipal hall, and

all claims for damages or compensation arising out of the construction, maintenance, operation or use of the works must be filed with the municipality within one month from the date of the fourth publication of the notice.

subsection.subsectiontext: No person has a claim for damages or compensation arising out of or by reason of the construction, maintenance, operation or use of the ditches or drains unless the person has filed a claim referred to in subsection (3) (c) within the time period established by that subsection.
If the municipality proceeds with the works or a portion of them, every claim must be determined in accordance with Division 3 of Part 8 [Expropriation and Compensation].

If the construction of the drains or ditches is not started within one year from the date of the fourth publication of the notice under subsection (2), the construction must not proceed unless new notice is given in accordance with that subsection.

No action arising out of, by reason of or in respect of the construction, maintenance, operation or use of a drain or ditch authorized by this section, whenever the drain or ditch is or was constructed, may be brought or maintained in a court against a district municipality.
This section does not restrict the powers of the municipality under this Act or another enactment and, in the case of a conflict, this section prevails.

change.changenote: Section 550 BEFORE amended by 2003-52-290(a), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

change.changenote: Section 550 (a) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-290(b), effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

paragraph.paragraphtext: require persons to use a waste disposal or recycling service, including requiring persons to use a waste disposal or recycling service provided by or on behalf of the municipality;

change.changenote: Section 551 BEFORE amended by 2003-52-291, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the Highway Act, a council may, by bylaw, regulate the erection, placing, alteration, maintenance, demolition and removal of a sign, sign board, advertisement, advertising device or structure, or any class of them.
For the purpose of subsection (1), a council may

paragraph.paragraphtext: classify structures, things and the whole or a portion of a highway, and
make different regulations for

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: different zones established under a zoning bylaw, and
different classes of highways and portions of them.

change.changenote: Section 551 (1) BEFORE amended by 2004-44-126, effective December 31, 2004 (BC Reg 547/2004).

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the Highway Act, a board may, by bylaw, regulate the erection, placing, alteration, maintenance, demolition and removal of a sign, sign board, advertisement, advertising device or structure, or any class of them.

change.changenote: Section 552 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-292, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Use of highways or municipal rights of way
section.sectiontext: A municipality may require a person using a highway or local government right of way to provide the municipality, if reasonably possible, with accurate plans and profiles of any of their works and facilities using the highway or right of way.

change.changenote: Section 553 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-293, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a municipal bylaw establishes

paragraph.paragraphtext: taxes, fees or charges for the supply of water for irrigation, or
other terms on which the service may be supplied or used,

section.subsandwich: the bylaw overrides the terms of any agreement respecting the carriage or supply of water for irrigation entered into by a company or other person from whom the municipality has acquired a water licence or works.

subsection.subsectiontext: An extension to a system for supplying water for irrigation must not be made for the purpose of supplying water to other land if the extension will prejudicially affect the prior rights of any parties to the use of the water intended to be conveyed and distributed by the extension.

change.changenote: Section 554 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-294, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Charges for cleaning and clearing highways

subsection.subsectiontext: The authority under Division 2 [Parcel Taxes] of Part 10.1 [Taxes, Fees and Charges] for any of the following services on any portion of a highway, sidewalk or boulevard is subject to this section:

paragraph.paragraphtext: cleaning or sweeping;
clearing snow and ice;
watering, oiling or tarring;
lighting;
supplying light in excess of that supplied at the expense of the municipality at large;
cutting grass and weeds;
trimming trees and shrubbery.

subsection.subsectiontext: A parcel tax for a service referred to in subsection (1) may be imposed

paragraph.paragraphtext: only on the parcels of land that abut on the portion of the highway, sidewalk or boulevard, and
only on the basis of taxable frontage.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council must not provide a service for which a parcel tax is to be imposed under this section unless

paragraph.paragraphtext: a sufficient petition for the service has been received, or
no sufficient petition against the service has been received within 30 days after the council gives public notice of intention to undertake the service.

subsection.subsectiontext: Division 1 [Local Improvements] of Part 19 applies for the purposes of subsection (3).

Section 622 [municipal policy that works must be undertaken as local improvements] applies to subsection (1) and, for that purpose, a service referred to in subsection (1) is deemed to be a work that may be undertaken as a work of local improvement.

change.changenote: Section 555 BEFORE amended by 2003-52-295, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: The authority of a municipality under the following provisions is subject to the applicable provisions of the Water Act:

change.parasandwich: section 529 [works to protect highways from water damage];
section 541 [watercourse may be included in drainage system];
section 543 [appropriation of stream channel or bed];

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition, the following authorities of a municipality are subject to the applicable provisions of the Water Act:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the authority to acquire, manage, extend and remove

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: works to maintain the proper flow of water in a stream as defined in the Water Act, ditch, drain or sewer in the municipality,
dikes, or
works to reclaim or to protect part of the land mass of the municipality from erosion by action of the sea or a stream as defined in the Water Act, or any other cause;

paragraph.paragraphtext: the authority to regulate a wharf, dock, warehouse or slip owned, held or managed by the municipality.

change.changenote: Part 17, sections 585 to 609 (remainder: 607 to 609) BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-296, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: As a limitation on section 176 (1) (a) and (b) [corporate powers — agreements], a council may, by bylaw adopted with the assent of the electors,

paragraph.paragraphtext: enter into or ratify or adopt agreements granting to a person an exclusive or limited franchise, for a term of years not longer than 21 years, for the operation on the highways in the municipality of motor buses, motor vehicles, tram cars, electric trolley buses or other vehicles as a public utility for the carriage of passengers, and

enter into or ratify or adopt agreements granting to a person an exclusive or limited franchise, for a term of years not longer than 21 years, to supply gas, electrical energy, water or telephone service to the inhabitants of the municipality.

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite subsection (1) (b), an agreement under that provision may, with the approval of the inspector, be renewed for one or more further terms, each of which must not be longer than 21 years.

Before approving the renewal of an agreement under subsection (2), the inspector may require that the assent of the electors be obtained or that the council provide a counter petition opportunity in relation to the proposed agreement.

For the purposes of subsections (2) and (3), a subsequent agreement to supply gas to the inhabitants of the municipality made between the parties to an agreement under subsection (1) (b), or their successors, heirs or assigns, is deemed to be a renewal of the agreement.
A bylaw under section 607 (1) (a), and an agreement made, ratified or adopted under it,

paragraph.paragraphtext: may specify how and along what routes and between what terminals motor buses, motor vehicles, tram cars, electric trolley buses or other vehicles must operate, and may reserve or create power to specify those matters from time to time,
may establish fares for the carriage of passengers, or reserve or create power to establish them, and

without limiting paragraphs (a) and (b) but subject to this Division, may specify the other terms and restrictions, including payments to or by the municipality for and in connection with the franchise.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under section 607 (1) (b), and an agreement made, ratified or adopted under it,

paragraph.paragraphtext: may specify how and where mains, poles and wires must be installed, and may reserve or create power to specify those matters from time to time,
may establish the rates for the supplying of gas, electrical energy, water or telephone service, and reserve or create power to establish them, and

without limiting paragraphs (a) and (b) but subject to this Division, may specify the other terms and restrictions, including payments to or by the municipality for and in connection with the franchise.

subsection.subsectiontext: A municipality that is party to an agreement made, ratified or adopted by a bylaw under section 607 may, by action in a court of competent jurisdiction, enforce the carrying out of the agreement and every term and provision of it, in so far as it affects that municipality, as though the agreement related solely to the municipality instituting the action.

Any other municipality that is a party to an agreement referred to in subsection (1) may apply to be added as party, either as plaintiff or defendant, to the action and, in the discretion of the court, may be added accordingly.

change.changenote: Part 19, sections 620 to 651.2 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-296, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: In this Division:

definition.def: in relation to works of constructing, enlarging or extending a sewer or water main, applies to mains through private lands as well as to mains under streets;
includes a viaduct, culvert, subway and embankment, and also includes pavement on a bridge;
includes reconstructing all or part of a work when the lifetime of the work has expired;
means a bylaw under section 623 or 624;
includes a curbing of any material

paragraph.paragraphtext: in or apart from the laying down of a pavement or sidewalk, or
with or without a projection for a gutter;

definition.def: includes an officer or person authorized or required by a council to perform a duty that is to be or may be performed by an engineer;
as applied to a work means the lifetime of the work as estimated by the engineer;
means that portion of the cost of a work that is not to be specially charged against parcels of land, but is payable by the municipality;
means that portion of the cost of a work that is to be specially charged against the land abutting directly on a work or on land immediately benefited by a work;
means any type of street surfacing;
includes laying down or constructing any description of pavement with or without curbing;
means publication by one insertion in a newspaper;
includes a common sewer, septic tank and a drain, or a combination of them;
includes a footway and a street crossing;
includes a lane, road, alley or public place, or a part of any of them;
means the assessed value of land, exclusive of improvements, according to the last authenticated real property assessment roll of the municipality;
means a service that may be undertaken as a local improvement.

section.marginalnote: Land that is exempt from taxation

subsection.subsectiontext: Land that is wholly exempt from taxation under sections 339 [general exemptions from taxation] and 340 [qualifications and exceptions] is not subject to this Division.
Despite subsection (1), the municipality must pay the amount of parcel tax that would, but for the exemption, be payable in respect of land exempt from parcel tax.
Despite subsection (1), a person who is liable for a parcel tax in respect of the land by reason of being the holder or occupier of land held in the manner referred to in

paragraph.paragraphtext: section 356 [taxation of Crown land used by others], or
section 357 [taxation of municipal land used by others]

section.subsandwich: may petition for or against undertaking a work.

subsection.subsectiontext: In computing the values of the land under section 629 [local improvement proposed on council's initiative], only the assessed value of the person's interest in it is to be used.

section.marginalnote: Municipal policy that works must be undertaken as local improvements

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw adopted with the assent of the electors, provide that all or any works that may be undertaken as local improvements must be undertaken as local improvements and not otherwise.
A requirement under subsection (1) is effective on the date on which the bylaw is adopted or on a later date specified in the bylaw.

section.marginalnote: Works that may be undertaken as local improvements

subsection.subsectiontext: On petition or on its own initiative, the council of a city, town or district municipality may, by bylaw, undertake one or more of the following as local improvements:

paragraph.paragraphtext: establishing and opening a street;
opening, widening, extending, grading, paving, altering the grade of, diverting or improving a street, including retaining walls incidental to it;
constructing a bridge as part of a street;
constructing, enlarging or extending a sewer or water system;
constructing a curbing or a sidewalk in, on or along a street, including retaining walls incidental to it;
constructing a boulevard where part of a street has been set apart for the purpose of a boulevard;
sodding a part of a boulevard or street and planting trees, shrubs and plants on and in a boulevard or street;
acquiring, establishing, laying out or improving

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a park or square having an area of not more than 1 hectare, or
a public drive;

paragraph.paragraphtext: constructing retaining walls, dikes or breakwaters along the shore of a sea or lake or the banks of a river;
constructing and erecting on a street necessary equipment, wires and works, including standards and underground conduits, to supply public lighting for the street;
constructing a conduit for wires or pipes along a street.

subsection.subsectiontext: On petition, the council of a village municipality may, by bylaw, undertake one or more of the following as local improvements:

paragraph.paragraphtext: opening, widening, extending, grading, paving, altering the grade of, diverting or improving a street;
constructing a curbing or a sidewalk in, on or along a street;
works referred to in subsection (1) (a), (f) and (g).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a municipality in the exercise of its powers acquires, by purchase, expropriation or otherwise, land or real property for a purpose or object referred to in this section, the cost must be included as part of the work.
Nothing in this section extends or applies to a work of ordinary repair or maintenance.
In addition to powers under section 623, a council may, by bylaw, undertake the construction and erection of sidewalk canopies as a local improvement.
Despite section 641,

paragraph.paragraphtext: a work undertaken under subsection (1) must be maintained and kept in repair by the municipality, and
the annual expense incurred must be specially charged against the parcels benefiting in the same proportions as provided for sharing of the cost of the work by the original construction bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, remove a work undertaken under subsection (1), subject to the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the municipality must assume all future levies relating to the work;
if levies were commuted with respect to a parcel, the commuted value of the future levies must be paid by the municipality to the owner of the parcel.

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite any other provision of this Division, instead of imposing a parcel tax, a council may apply section 646 (3) and (4), in which case the notice required under section 629 (3) and the general bylaw required under section 634 must set out the basis on which the work or service is to be charged.

section.marginalnote: Sewer, water and gas connections in relation to street paving

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies if the work to be undertaken is the paving of a street.

Before the paving is started, the council may, by bylaw without petition, authorize the making of all necessary connections from any existing sewer, water or gas main owned by the municipality to the parcels of land on either or both sides of the street.
A fee or charge must not be imposed for the renewal of an existing connection required as a result of the paving.

section.marginalnote: Sidewalk crossings and driveways provided at owner's request

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies if the work to be undertaken is paving or the construction of curbing, a boulevard or a sidewalk.

On the written request of the owner of a parcel to be served by the work, the council may, before the work is started, provide, as part of the work, for the construction of a sidewalk crossing or driveway as the council may determine, to form an approach to a particular parcel.
The cost of the sidewalk crossing or driveway must be specially charged on the particular parcel.

section.marginalnote: Time limit on effect of construction bylaw

subsection.subsectiontext: A construction bylaw ceases to have effect if the work authorized by it is not started within one year from the date of its adoption.
A construction bylaw may not be enacted after one year from the date of the municipal officer's certificate under section 632 (2) [sufficiency of petition].

section.marginalnote: General rule of separate bylaws for distinct work

subsection.subsectiontext: Except as otherwise expressly provided in this Division, every bylaw must be for a distinct and separate work.

A single bylaw may be adopted for 2 or more works referred to in section 623 that are to be undertaken and provided at the same time and by the same method and for the same properties, in which case all the works are to be considered as one work.

The power to adopt a bylaw under section 623 or 624 may not be exercised through the adoption of a comprehensive general bylaw under section 259.1 and bylaws under those sections may not be consolidated into a comprehensive general bylaw under section 280.3.

section.marginalnote: Local improvement proposed on council's initiative

subsection.subsectiontext: If a council proposes to undertake a local improvement on its own initiative, notice of this intention must be given by

paragraph.paragraphtext: publication of a notice, and
mailing the notice to the owners of the parcels liable to be specially charged.

subsection.subsectiontext: A notice under this section may relate to and include any number of different works.
A notice under subsection (1) (a) is sufficient if it sets out the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a general description of the work;
the street or place where, and the points between which, the work is to be effected;
the estimated cost of the work;
as applicable, the annual charge established under section 634 (1) (a) or the proportion of the total cost to be borne by the owners as established under section 634 (1) (b);
the number of years for which annual charges will be imposed.

subsection.subsectiontext: A notice mailed to an owner under subsection (1) (b) must include the information under subsection (3) and, in addition, must specify the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the taxable frontage or taxable area of the owner's parcel, as applicable;
as applicable, the total annual charge or estimated annual charge to be specially charged against the owner's parcel;
the commuted value of those charges.

subsection.subsectiontext: The designated municipal officer must mail a notice under subsection (1) (b) to the owner at the address as set out in the last authenticated real property assessment roll and also to any later address known to the assessor.
The obligation to give notice to an owner under this section is satisfied if a reasonable effort was made to mail or otherwise deliver the notice.

Publication and mailing of the notice may be proved by affidavit, and the affidavit, after the adoption of the construction bylaw, is conclusive evidence of publication and mailing of the notice as deposed in it.

section.marginalnote: Petition against work proposed on council's initiative

subsection.subsectiontext: A work which notice is given in accordance with section 629 may be undertaken as a local improvement unless, within one month after the publication of the notice, a majority of the owners, representing at least 50% of the value of the parcels that are liable to be specially charged, petition the council not to proceed with it.
Sections 631 and 632 apply to a petition referred to in subsection (1).

If a council has been prevented from undertaking a work because of a petition under this section, the council must not propose the same work on its own initiative within a period of one year after the presentation of the petition.

As an exception, the prohibition under subsection (3) does not prevent a council from again proposing a work on its own initiative if the work is varied from or less expensive than that originally proposed to be undertaken.

section.marginalnote: Petition to council for local improvement

subsection.subsectiontext: A petition to a council for a work is not valid unless all the following requirements are met:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the petition must be signed by 2/3 of the owners of the parcels liable to be specially charged;
the signatories must be the owners of parcels having a value of at least 50% of the value of all parcels liable to be specially charged;
a description of the parcel owned by each petitioner must be set out in the petition.

subsection.subsectiontext: A petition must be filed with the municipality, and is deemed to be presented to the council when this is done.
Before being circulated for signature, each page of a petition must contain the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a general description of the work;
the annual charge per taxable unit, or the proportion of the cost of the work which will be the owners' portion as established by bylaw under section 634;
the number of years for which annual charges will be imposed.

section.marginalnote: Determining whether a petition is sufficient

subsection.subsectiontext: The sufficiency of a petition is to be determined by the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration].
A determination under subsection (1) must be evidenced by a certificate of the municipal officer, and is then final and conclusive.

If the municipal officer determines that a petition is sufficient, it is deemed to have been and to be a sufficient petition, despite any changes made under Division 2 [Parcel Taxes] of Part 10.1 [Taxes, Fees and Charges] in the parcels to be specially charged that have the effect of increasing or reducing the number of those parcels.
If it is necessary to determine the value of a parcel and this cannot be ascertained from the real property assessment roll because the parcel was not separately assessed, or for any other reason,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the assessor must determine the value of the parcel,
the assessor's determination is final and conclusive, and
the value determined by the assessor is deemed for the purposes of this Division to be the assessed value.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a petitioner is the owner of land but does not appear by the last authenticated real property assessment roll of the municipality to be the owner, the petitioner is deemed an owner if the petitioner's ownership is proved to the satisfaction of the municipal officer.

If a petitioner is deemed to be an owner under subsection (5) and the person who appears by the last authenticated real property assessment roll to be the owner is also a petitioner, the name of the latter petitioner must be disregarded in determining whether the petition is sufficient.
If 2 or more persons are owners of a parcel,

paragraph.paragraphtext: they must be considered as one owner only,
they are not entitled to petition unless a majority of them concur, and
unless a petition is signed by a majority of them, their signatures must be disregarded in determining whether the petition is sufficient.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purpose of determining the sufficiency of a petition,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the municipal officer may have witnesses summoned and examined under oath, and
any interested person may have a subpoena to procure the attendance of a witness issued out of the Supreme Court within the territorial limits of which the municipality lies.

subsection.subsectiontext: A witness who is a resident of the municipality is bound to attend without payment of fees or conduct money, and a witness who is not a resident of the municipality is entitled to fees and conduct money under the Rules of Court.
After the municipal officer has certified the sufficiency of a petition, a person may not withdraw his or her name from the petition, and no name may be added to the petition.

section.marginalnote: Items that may be included in the cost of a work

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition to the construction costs of a work undertaken under a construction bylaw, the following may be included in the cost of the work:

paragraph.paragraphtext: engineering expenses;
cost of advertising and mailing of notices;
interest on temporary loans, and discount and expenses relating to security issuing bylaws;
compensation for land taken for the purposes of the work or injuriously affected by it, and the expenses incurred by the municipality in connection with determining the compensation.

subsection.subsectiontext: On completion of the execution and financing of a work, the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 199 [financial administration] must submit to the council a certified statement setting out the cost of the work, and that cost is as certified.

section.marginalnote: Charges for work must be established in advance

subsection.subsectiontext: A council must not undertake any class of work under this Division unless it has, by general bylaw applicable to all works of that class, done one of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: established

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the annual charge for each taxable unit, to be specially charged against parcels benefiting from or abutting that class of work and the number of years for which the annual charge is to be imposed, and
the percentage of the aggregate of the charges that will be accepted as the commuted value;

paragraph.paragraphtext: established the proportion of the cost of the class of work to be specially charged against the parcels benefiting from or abutting the work as the owners' portion of the cost of the work.

subsection.subsectiontext: A charge under subsection (1) (a) may only be established on the basis of

paragraph.paragraphtext: a single amount for each parcel, or
the taxable frontage of the parcel.

subsection.subsectiontext: An amendment to a bylaw under subsection (1) is not valid for any work for which a construction bylaw has been adopted.
The total of all charges imposable under subsection (1) (a) is deemed to be the owners' portion of the cost of the work concerned.

When a work is completed, the charges referred to in subsection (1) (a) or the proportion of the cost to be specially charged, as applicable, must be recovered by the means of a parcel tax, imposed on the basis established under subsection (2), on the parcels benefiting from or abutting the work.
As a limit on the authority under this section, if the construction of a sidewalk on one side only of a street is undertaken,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the council may recover 1/3 of the owners' portion of the cost of its construction by means of a parcel tax under subsection (5) imposed on the land abutting on the side of the street opposite to that on which the sidewalk is constructed, and
if at a subsequent time the construction of a sidewalk on the other side of that street is undertaken,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: 2/3 of the owners' portion of the cost of its construction must be recovered by means of a parcel tax under subsection (5) imposed on the land abutting on that side of the street, and
the other 1/3 of the cost must be recovered by means of a parcel tax under subsection (5) imposed on the land abutting on the other side of the street.

section.marginalnote: Requirements for adoption of construction bylaw

subsection.subsectiontext: If work is proposed to be undertaken under this Division, before adopting the construction bylaw, the council must have a report prepared stating

paragraph.paragraphtext: the lifetime of the work,
the estimated cost of the work, and
the share or proportion of the total cost that will be specially charged against the parcels benefiting from or abutting on the work.

subsection.subsectiontext: A report prepared under this section may be adopted in whole or in part or as amended by the council.

A construction bylaw must not be adopted if the total amount proposed to be borrowed under it exceeds the total amount of borrowing approved by the inspector for local improvement purposes less the amount already borrowed under authorization.
Every construction bylaw must conform with the notice under section 629 or the petition under section 631.

section.sectiontext: Persons whose parcels are subject to being specially charged under this Division may commute for a payment in cash the special charges imposed on them in accordance with terms and conditions established by bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, in accordance with Part 9 [Financial Management], borrow money that may be necessary to undertake a work, but the amount borrowed must not exceed the total cost of the work.

A construction bylaw is deemed to be a loan authorization bylaw for the purposes of borrowing under subsection (1), and compliance with sections 629 to 632 [local improvements initiation process] is deemed to be compliance with the requirement to provide a counter petition opportunity under section 335.1 [counter petition opportunity required for borrowings].

Before the completion of the works under a construction bylaw, in respect of any works undertaken or about to be undertaken, the council may borrow under a security issuing bylaw not more than 80% of the estimated cost of the works as set out in the construction bylaw.
Before the completion of the works, money required to pay the costs incurred may be borrowed temporarily under section 335.2 [temporary borrowing under loan authorization bylaw].

section.marginalnote: Payment of costs in accordance with financial plan
section.sectiontext: Instead of borrowing the amount of the municipality's portion of the cost of a work undertaken as a local improvement, the council may pay all or some of the municipality's portion in any year out of money appropriated for that purpose in its financial plan.

section.marginalnote: Payment of costs from local improvement fund

subsection.subsectiontext: If a local improvement fund has been set up in accordance with section 500, the council may, by bylaw, appropriate from it the sums considered necessary to meet the cost or the owners' portion of the cost of a work authorized by a construction bylaw.

A bylaw under subsection (1) must provide for the repayment to the local improvement fund of an appropriate share of the property value tax or parcel tax, or both, imposed sufficient to recover the money advanced, together with interest on it.

section.marginalnote: Assessment must be revised if scope of work reduced

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies if a work undertaken by local improvement under this Act or the former Local Improvement Act has been constructed or carried out in part and the council considers it inadvisable or impracticable to complete the work.
If the assessment roll prepared for the work has not been authenticated, the council may amend the construction bylaw in so far as it relates to the extent of the work.
If the assessment roll prepared for the work has been authenticated, the council

paragraph.paragraphtext: may amend the construction bylaw in so far as it relates to the extent of the work, and
must direct the collector to revise the assessment roll.

subsection.subsectiontext: On the basis of the revised assessment roll under subsection (3) (b), the council may

paragraph.paragraphtext: amend the bylaw imposing the parcel tax,
refund, by payment in cash or by credit on future municipal taxes, any taxes that

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: were imposed under the original assessment on parcels of land that are not included in the revised assessment roll, and
were or are collected from the owners of those parcels, and

paragraph.paragraphtext: order any necessary adjustments in the amount of parcel tax that was imposed on owners of parcels of land that remain on the revised assessment roll.

section.marginalnote: Duty of municipality to repair completed works

subsection.subsectiontext: After a work undertaken as local improvement has been completed, it must during its lifetime be kept in repair by and at the expense of the municipality.
Nothing in this Division

paragraph.paragraphtext: relieves a municipality from any duty or obligation to which it is subject, either at common law or under this Act or otherwise, to keep in repair the highways under its jurisdiction, or
impairs or prejudicially affects the rights of any person who is injured because the municipality failed to discharge that duty or obligation.

subsection.subsectiontext: Nothing in this section makes a municipality liable for any damage for which it otherwise would not have been liable.

section.marginalnote: Procedure to compel municipality to repair

subsection.subsectiontext: On application by an owner or occupier of land specially charged for a work undertaken as a local improvement, the Supreme Court may make an order requiring the municipality to put the work in repair if, at any time during the lifetime of the work, the municipality

paragraph.paragraphtext: fails to maintain the work in a good and sufficient state of repair, and
fails to repair the work after one month's notice in writing by the owner or occupier of a parcel specially charged requiring the municipality to do so.

subsection.subsectiontext: An order under subsection (1) has the same effect and may be enforced in the same manner as a mandatory order.
The court may determine what repairs are necessary, and may order them made in a manner, within a time and under supervision it considers proper.
On an application under subsection (1), if the court is satisfied that the work required to make the repairs that are necessary and reasonable amounts to a reconstruction of the work, the court may

paragraph.paragraphtext: determine that the work may be done as a work of local improvement, and

set the amounts payable by the municipality and by the owners of land adjacent, as in the original bylaw authorizing the work, or otherwise, in its discretion, or in the discretion of the Court of Appeal on appeal.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person under whose supervision the repairs are to be made is appointed,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the court may determine the remuneration to be paid to the person, and
the remuneration determined by the court must be paid by the municipality, and payment may be enforced in the manner and by the same process as a judgment for the payment of money.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the municipality does not comply with the court order, in addition to any other remedy to which the applicant for the order may be entitled, the court may authorize the repairs to be made by the applicant.
If repairs are made by an applicant under subsection (6),

paragraph.paragraphtext: their cost must be ascertained and determined by the court, and
payment of the cost determined by the court may be enforced in the same manner and by the same process as a judgment for the payment of money.

subsection.subsectiontext: An appeal from a decision of the court lies to the Court of Appeal with leave of a justice of the Court of Appeal.

section.marginalnote: Current assessment of special charges is not an encumbrance

subsection.subsectiontext: The special charge and the special levies on land for the cost of a work undertaken as a local improvement, whether on petition or otherwise, is not an encumbrance on the land on which the special rate is charged or chargeable

paragraph.paragraphtext: as between a vendor and a purchaser, or
respecting a covenant against encumbrances, or for the right to convey or for quiet possession free from encumbrances.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subsection (1) does not apply to any part of the special charge or special levies that is in arrear and unpaid.

section.marginalnote: Cost of work that is replaced, removed or destroyed

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies to a work undertaken as a local improvement that is replaced, removed or destroyed by a work constructed for the general benefit of a municipality.

Despite any other provision of this Act, if an assessment roll has been authenticated under this Act or confirmed under the former Local Improvement Act, the council may, by bylaw, provide that the municipality must assume all future levies relating to the owners' portion of the cost of a work undertaken as a local improvement referred to in subsection (1).

section.marginalnote: Commission may be appointed to investigate assessment roll

subsection.subsectiontext: Despite any other provision of this Act, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint a commission under Part 2 of the Inquiry Act for an assessment if

paragraph.paragraphtext: the assessment roll has been authenticated under this Act or confirmed under the former Local Improvement Act, and
it is represented to the satisfaction of the Lieutenant Governor in Council that inequalities exist in the assessment or that hardship has resulted as a consequence of the assessment.

subsection.subsectiontext: A commission under subsection (1) has the power and is charged with the duty to consider, investigate and inquire into the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the items, amount, incidence and apportionment of the cost of any work of local improvement, and of the special charges made, authorized, required or proposed to be made for it, and whether or not the special charges, either alone or together with other municipal rates or taxes, are, may or will be unduly burdensome on any parcel affected by them;
the proportion and amounts of the special charges that are paid or unpaid or which ought to be paid on any parcel affected by them;
the benefit derived or derivable from the work by the various parcels charged or chargeable for it, either generally or compared with each other;
the probable or reasonable lifetime of the work or any portion of it;
the amounts realized or not realized by the municipality on account of instalments of principal and interest in relation to any debentures issued for the cost of the work;
the probable ability or likelihood of any lot specially charged or chargeable for the work being capable of bearing its share of the special assessment;

the amount that should fairly and reasonably be charged against the various parcels abutting on or benefited by the work for the cost of the work and the expenses incurred in relation to it, considering all the circumstances;

any reductions that ought to be made from the special assessment in the case of triangular or irregularly shaped parcels, parcels located at the junction or intersection of streets or parcels wholly or partly unfit for building purposes;
the desirability or feasibility of extending the period of years over which the special charge is or may be made payable;
the debts or obligations incurred by the municipality for the work, whether under debentures, temporary loans or advances, or otherwise;
whether the municipality should bear a proportion or a further proportion of the cost of the work, or the entire cost of particular portions of the work;
whether or not parcels should be relieved from all or part of the charges;
whether the charges for the cost of the work should be spread over a larger area, and whether the method of assessment should be changed to another method;
generally, any matter or thing, fact or circumstance in relation to the work which the commissioners consider proper or relevant.

subsection.subsectiontext: The commission must

paragraph.paragraphtext: report to the Lieutenant Governor in Council the result of the investigation and inquiry, and
recommend to the Lieutenant Governor in Council, in the case of each parcel,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: any remedy, measure of relief, allowance or adjustment that should be given or made to the municipality or to the owners specially charged in order that any inequality or any hardship in the assessment or proportion of assessment as made is remedied or removed,
who should pay any charge or assessment made necessary by giving the remedy, relief, allowance or adjustment, and
in what proportions a new assessment should be made for the work.

subsection.subsectiontext: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may return the report for reconsideration, or accept and adopt the report of the commission and by order require that the council carry out and fulfil the recommendations contained in it.

On publication of an order under subsection (4) in the Gazette, the council must adopt a bylaw readjusting the charges, assessment and every matter or thing in connection with it in accordance with the report and order, and must carry out all of the terms of the report and order.
A bylaw under subsection (5) must be submitted to the inspector for approval.

After it has been approved by the inspector, a bylaw under subsection (5) must not be set aside by a court on any ground, except noncompliance with the report and order, and the bylaw is a valid and sufficient bylaw of the municipality for all purposes, and all assessments made under it are valid assessments.
On the adoption and publication of a report under subsection (4), the municipality must

paragraph.paragraphtext: promptly pay compensation to the commissioners for travelling expenses and for their services, and
pay to the Minister of Finance and Corporate Relations the amount of all other costs incidental to the work of the commission, including the costs of necessary clerical assistance.

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition to the exercise of the powers under Division 1 [Local Improvements] of this Part, a council may, by bylaw, undertake any service coming within the powers of the municipality for the special benefit of a specified area of the municipality.
A bylaw under subsection (1) must define the area of the municipality that will be benefited.

The entire cost, or a part of the cost of the service determined by the council and specified in a bylaw under subsection (1), must be borne by the owners of real property within the specified area or the users of the service, or by both.
For the purpose of subsection (3), the council may impose within the specified area one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a tax based on the assessed value of the land, or the improvements, or both;
a parcel tax;
other fees or charges provided in this Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to this section, Part 10.1 [Taxes, Fees and Charges] applies in respect of taxes, fees and charges imposed under subsection (4).
A council may, by bylaw,

paragraph.paragraphtext: provide that a parcel tax imposed under subsection (4) (b) may be commuted for payment in cash,
set terms and conditions for a commutation under paragraph (a), and
specify circumstances in which a commutation under paragraph (a) may be refused.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the Waste Management Act, before a bylaw under this section is adopted one of the following requirements must be met:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the bylaw must have received the assent of the electors;
the service to be undertaken must have been requested by a petition and, for these purposes, sections 631 [petition to council] and 632 [sufficiency of petition] apply;
the service to be undertaken must have been proposed by the council on its own initiative, and, for these purposes, sections 629 [council initiative] and 630 [petition against work] apply.

subsection.subsectiontext: The power to adopt a bylaw under subsection (1) may not be exercised through the adoption of a comprehensive general bylaw under section 259.1 and a bylaw under that subsection may not be consolidated into a comprehensive general bylaw under section 280.3.
This section applies if a municipality provides off-street parking facilities on a specified area basis under this Division.

A council may, by bylaw, provide for the application of all or part of the net current revenue derived from the operation of parking meters in the specified area to the provision of off-street parking facilities within the specified area, including the repayment of debt and interest on the provision of those facilities.

A council may, by bylaw, provide for the borrowing from any person or for the appropriation from the local improvement fund of money necessary to meet the capital cost of a service for an area established under section 646.
For the purpose of determining the capital cost of all or part of a service under this Division, either estimated or actual,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the cost factors referred to in sections 633 [items that may be included in the cost] and 634 [charges must be established in advance] as determined by the council apply, and
the capital or other cost of the service must be reduced by the amount of revenue derived from the service.

subsection.subsectiontext: Division 4 [Expenditures and Liabilities] of Part 9 [Financial Management] applies to a bylaw under subsection (1) except that, if the assent of the electors or a counter petition opportunity is required under that Division, compliance with section 646 (7) [elector assent for specified areas] is deemed to be compliance with that requirement.

Subject to subsections (4) and (5) and section 649 [enlargement or reduction of specified area] and despite section 646 (3) [who bears cost of service], if the capital cost of the service is met out of money borrowed or appropriated under subsection (1), the entire capital cost of the service must be borne by the area specified in the bylaw.

The cost of any capacity of the service in excess of that required for the specified area may be borne by the municipality unless the specified area is extended or merged and the full capacity of the service is required for the extended area or merged area, in which case the excess cost must no longer be borne by the municipality but by the extended area or merged area.
A council may, by bylaw, provide that a part of the cost of the service for a downtown revitalization project approved by the inspector is to be borne by the municipality.
Before adopting a bylaw under subsection (5), the council must provide the electors in the whole of the municipality with a counter petition opportunity in relation to the proposed bylaw.
In addition to the information required by section 172.4, the notice of a counter petition opportunity under this section must include

paragraph.paragraphtext: the total amount proposed to be borrowed,
the part of the cost of the borrowing that is to be borne by the municipality, and
the length of time for repayment.

section.marginalnote: Enlargement or reduction of specified area

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, enlarge or reduce the size of a specified area.

Section 646 (7) applies to a bylaw under subsection (1) of this section, with the modification that the requirement for assent, petition or council initiative referred to in that provision applies only in relation to the area to be included or excluded from the specified area and not to the rest of the specified area.

If a specified area has been enlarged or reduced under this section, the liabilities incurred on behalf of the area as it was before enlargement or reduction must be borne by all the owners of parcels of land in the area as enlarged or reduced.
A council may, by bylaw,

paragraph.paragraphtext: merge 2 or more specified areas defined under section 646 into one specified area for the purposes set out in the bylaws establishing them, or
if the 2 or more specified areas are not contiguous, merge them for the purpose of deeming them to be one specified area for the purposes specified in the bylaws establishing them.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (1) may merge the specified areas while providing that repayment of any debt of one or more of the former specified areas that is outstanding at the time of merger is to continue to be borne by the applicable former specified area.

If there is outstanding debt of a former specified area that is not kept separate under subsection (2), section 646 (7) applies to the bylaw under subsection (1) of this section, with the modification that the requirement for assent, petition or council initiative referred to in section 646 (7) applies separately to each specified area being merged.
Section 646 (7) does not apply to the bylaw under subsection (1) of this section if

paragraph.paragraphtext: there is no outstanding debt of any former specified area, or
the outstanding debt of each former specified area is kept separate under subsection (2).

subsection.subsectiontext: If a council has, with respect to each of any 2 or more areas specified in bylaws adopted under section 646, provided that the area may be merged with another specified area, whether contiguous or not, for the purpose of providing, consolidating or completing necessary services for the merged areas, the council may, by bylaw without the assent of the electors,

paragraph.paragraphtext: merge the areas,
provide, consolidate or complete the necessary services, and
borrow money under section 648,

section.subsandwich: as required.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, an area defined under Division 1 of this Part or section 53 of the Local Improvement Act, R.S.B.C. 1948, c. 237, and under section 65 of the Municipal Act, R.S.B.C. 1948, c. 232, is deemed to be a specified area under section 646.

section.marginalnote: Transfer or discontinuation of joint services

subsection.subsectiontext: This section applies in relation to an agreement between a municipality and a public authority

paragraph.paragraphtext: for the purpose of jointly managing facilities for pleasure, recreation and other community uses of the public, including heritage property and land to be used for the conservation of heritage property, that are on a site

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: owned or held by a party to the agreement, or
leased from the Provincial government by a party to the agreement, or

paragraph.paragraphtext: for the purpose of contributing to the cost of managing facilities referred to in paragraph (a).

subsection.subsectiontext: If

paragraph.paragraphtext: a service is provided under an agreement referred to in subsection (1) at the expense of a specified area, and
the service is discontinued or taken over by a board of school trustees or a francophone education authority,

section.subsandwich: all remaining taxes, fees or charges under this Part are payable by the municipality.

section.marginalnote: Application of Municipal Services Part to specified areas
section.sectiontext: Part 15 [Municipal Services] applies to a part of a municipality established as a specified area under this Division as if the area were the whole municipality.

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section:

definition.def: means a corporation, association or organization applying to the council for a grant of money under this section;
means an area in a municipality where business or commerce is carried on;
means a business area designated by bylaw as a business improvement area under subsection (3) (a);
means

paragraph.paragraphtext: carrying out studies or making reports respecting one or more business areas,
the improvement, beautification or maintenance of streets, sidewalks or municipally owned land, buildings or structures in one or more business improvement areas,
the conservation of heritage property in one or more business improvement areas, and
the encouragement of business in one or more business improvement areas;

definition.def: means land or improvements, or both, that fall or would fall within Class 5 or 6 of the Assessments — Classes and Percentage Levels Regulation, B.C. Reg. 438/81, as that regulation stood on January 8, 1988.

subsection.subsectiontext: As an exception to section 182 [prohibition against assistance to business], a council may grant money to an applicant that has as one of its aims, functions or purposes the planning and implementation of a business promotion scheme.
Before a council grants money under subsection (2), the council must, by bylaw, do the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: designate the appropriate business area as a business improvement area;
name the applicant to which the money will be granted;
establish the maximum amount of money to be granted;
require that the money granted must be expended only

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: by the applicant to which the money is granted, and
in accordance with the conditions and limitations set out in the bylaw and for a business promotion scheme set out in the bylaw;

paragraph.paragraphtext: require that all or part of the money granted to the applicant, as determined by the council, be recovered within the business improvement area from owners of land or improvements, or both, or from other persons from whom charges provided in this Act may be collected in the business improvement area.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purpose of a requirement under subsection (3) (e), the council may impose on taxable property within the business improvement area any or all of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a tax based on the assessed value of the land, improvements or both;
a parcel tax;
a tax based on any factor set out in the bylaw;
other fees and charges provided in this Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw imposing a tax under subsection (4) may establish different rates for different classes of business, as specified in the bylaw.

If a council enacts a bylaw under subsection (3), it must set conditions and limitations on the receipt and expenditure of money granted under subsection (2) and, without limiting this, the bylaw must require the applicant to

paragraph.paragraphtext: submit each year a budget for approval by the council,
account for the money granted to it under subsection (2) in the form and manner specified in the bylaw, and
take out and maintain insurance of the type and in the amount specified in the bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: Sections 646 (7) (b) and (c) [requirement for petition or council initiative] and 648 (2) [costs of services for specified areas] apply to a bylaw under this section and, for these purposes, a business improvement area is deemed to be a specified area and a business promotion scheme is deemed to be a service.
Section 649 [enlargement or reduction of specified area] and section 650 [merging of specified areas] apply in respect of a business improvement area as if it were a specified area.
Subject to this section, Part 10.1 [Taxes, Fees and Charges] applies in respect of taxes, fees and charges imposed under subsection (4).
A bylaw designating a business improvement area ceases to have effect on the earlier of

paragraph.paragraphtext: 20 years from the date the bylaw comes into force, and
a date specified in the bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section:

definition.def: means a corporation, association or organization applying to the council for a grant of money under this section;
means an area in a municipality where business or commerce related to a mountain resort is carried on;
means

paragraph.paragraphtext: carrying out studies or making reports respecting one or more business areas,
the improvement, beautification or maintenance of streets, sidewalks or municipally owned land, buildings or structures in one or more mountain resort business improvement areas,
the conservation of heritage property in one or more mountain resort business improvement areas, and
the encouragement of business in one or more mountain resort business improvement areas;

definition.def: means a business area designated by bylaw as a mountain resort business improvement area under subsection (3) (a).

subsection.subsectiontext: As an exception to section 182 [prohibition against assistance to business], a council may grant money to an applicant that has as one of its aims, functions or purposes the planning and implementation of a business promotion scheme.
Before a council grants money under subsection (2), the council must, by bylaw, do the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: designate the appropriate business area as a mountain resort business improvement area;
name the applicant to which the money will be granted;
establish the maximum amount of money to be granted;
require that the money granted must be expended only

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: by the applicant to which the money is granted, and
for a business promotion scheme set out in the bylaw;

paragraph.paragraphtext: require that all of the money granted to the applicant be recovered from the owners of land and improvements, within the mountain resort business improvement area, used during the year to operate a business that falls within a class of business specified in the bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purpose of a requirement under subsection (3) (e), the council may impose on land, improvements or both within the business improvement area any or all of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a tax based on the assessed value of the land, improvements or both;
a parcel tax;
a tax based on any factor set out in the bylaw;
other fees and charges provided in this Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw imposing a tax under subsection (4) may establish different rates for different classes of business, as specified in the bylaw.

If a council enacts a bylaw under subsection (3), it must set conditions and limitations on the receipt and expenditure of money granted under subsection (2) and, without restricting this, the bylaw must require the applicant to

paragraph.paragraphtext: submit each year a budget for approval by the council,
account for the money granted to it under subsection (2) in the form and manner specified in the bylaw, and
take out and maintain insurance of the type and amount specified in the bylaw.

subsection.subsectiontext: Sections 646 (7) (b) and (c) [requirement for petition or council initiative] and 648 (2) [costs of services for specified areas] apply to a bylaw under this section and, for these purposes, a mountain resort business improvement area is deemed to be a specified area and a business promotion scheme is deemed to be a service.
Section 649 [enlargement or reduction of specified area] and section 650 [merging of specified areas] apply in respect of a mountain resort business improvement area as if it were a specified area.
Subject to this section, Part 10.1 [Taxes, Fees and Charges] applies in respect of taxes, fees and charges imposed under subsection (4).
A bylaw designating a mountain resort business improvement area ceases to have effect on the earlier of

paragraph.paragraphtext: 20 years from the date the bylaw comes into force, and
a date specified in the bylaw.

change.changenote: Heading, Part 20 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-297, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).
