Heading, Division 1, of Part 20 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-298, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).
Section 652 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-299, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: In this Part, business means

paragraph.paragraphtext: carrying on a commercial or industrial undertaking of any kind, or
providing professional, personal or other services for the purpose of gain or profit,

section.secsandwich: but does not include an activity carried on by the Provincial government, by corporations owned by the Provincial government, by agencies of the Provincial government or by the Greater Vancouver Transportation Authority or any of its subsidiaries.

change.changenote: Section 653 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-299, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, regulate businesses, business activities and persons engaged in business.
A bylaw under this section may

paragraph.paragraphtext: establish different classes of businesses, business activities and persons engaged in business, and
make different provisions for different classes and different areas of the municipality.

change.changenote: Section 654 BEFORE amended by 2003-7-33, effective December 5, 2003 (BC Reg 453/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: Subject to the Holiday Shopping Regulation Act or a bylaw or order under that Act a bylaw under section 653 [authority to regulate business] may restrict the hours of operation of businesses or business activities.

change.changenote: Section 654 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-299, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: A bylaw under section 653 [authority to regulate business] may restrict the hours of operation of businesses or business activities.

change.changenote: Section 655 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-299, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Restriction on authority in relation to rental accommodations
section.sectiontext: As a limitation on sections 653 [authority to regulate business] and 658 [authority to require business licences], a municipality may not, under this Part, regulate, prohibit or require business licences for the business of renting 2 or fewer rooms, or 2 or fewer suites, in a dwelling unit if

paragraph.paragraphtext: the dwelling unit is occupied by the owner of the dwelling unit,
the dwelling unit remains as a single legal title, and
the interval at which rent is payable on the suite or rooms is one month or longer.

change.changenote: Section 656 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-299, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Limitation on authority to require examination or certification
section.sectiontext: A provision in a bylaw under section 653 [authority to regulate business] that requires an examination or certification of a person engaged in a trade or occupation does not apply to a person who has been granted a certificate or other evidence of competence for that trade or occupation under an Act of Canada or British Columbia.

change.changenote: Section 657 (2) BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-300, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Without limiting subsection (1) or section 653 [authority to regulate business], a bylaw under this section may do one or more of the following:

change.changenote: Division 2 of Part 20, sections 658 to 663 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-301, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to this Part, a council may, by bylaw, provide for a system of business licences, including one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: prohibiting a business from being carried on unless the owner or operator holds a valid licence under this Division;
providing for the granting, refusal, suspension and cancellation of licences for businesses;
providing for the duration periods of licences;
providing that terms and conditions may be imposed on any licence, the nature of the terms and conditions and who may impose them;
setting out the conditions that must be met before a licence is granted, the nature of the conditions and who may impose them.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under this section may

paragraph.paragraphtext: establish different classes of businesses,
make different provisions for different classes and different areas of the municipality, and

in relation to a provision under subsection (1) (c), provide that duration periods for different individual licences may be different based on the duration period of some other licence, permit, certificate or other authority that is required for the business or business activities to be carried on or for persons to engage in the business activities.

subsection.subsectiontext: An application for a business licence may be refused in any specific case, but

paragraph.paragraphtext: the application must not be unreasonably refused, and
the council or designated municipal officer must give reasons for the refusal.

subsection.subsectiontext: In the case of a refusal by a designated municipal officer, the officer must notify the applicant of the right to a reconsideration by council.

section.marginalnote: Suspension or cancellation of business licence

subsection.subsectiontext: A business licence may be suspended or cancelled for reasonable cause.
Without limiting subsection (1), any of the following circumstances may constitute reasonable cause:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the holder fails to comply with a term or condition of the licence;
the holder is convicted of an offence indictable in Canada;
the holder is convicted of an offence under an Act or municipal bylaw in respect of the business for which the holder is licensed or with respect to the premises named in the licence;
the holder is deemed, under this Act or the Offence Act, to have pleaded guilty to an offence referred to in paragraph (c);

the holder has ceased to comply with a bylaw or has otherwise ceased to meet the lawful requirements to carry on the business for which the holder is licensed or with respect to the premises named in the licence;
in the opinion of the council, the holder has engaged in misconduct that warrants the suspension or cancellation of the licence, if the misconduct is

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: in respect of the business,
in or with respect to the premises named in the licence, or
in respect of that business or another business, or in or with respect to the premises of that business or other business, carried on by the holder inside or outside the municipality.

subsection.subsectiontext: Before suspending or cancelling a business licence, the council must give the licence holder notice of the proposed action and an opportunity to be heard.

A suspension under this section is for the period determined by the council, and the council may impose additional conditions on the licence that relate to the reasons for the suspension and apply after the period of suspension.

Despite section 193 (1) [restriction on delegation of hearings], a bylaw under section 192 [delegation of council authority] may authorize a designated municipal officer to exercise the powers of the council under this section.
In the case of a suspension or cancellation under subsection (5), the designated municipal officer must notify the holder of the right to a reconsideration by council.
The obligations under subsections (2) and (6) are satisfied if a reasonable effort was made to mail or otherwise deliver the notices.

section.marginalnote: Right to reconsideration of delegated decisions
section.sectiontext: If a designated municipal officer exercises a delegated authority to grant, refuse, suspend or cancel business licences, the applicant or licence holder who is subject to the decision is entitled to have the council reconsider the matter.

subsection.subsectiontext: Two or more municipalities may, by bylaw adopted by the councils of each of the participating municipalities, establish an intermunicipal business licence scheme.
An intermunicipal business licence scheme may provide that one or more of the municipalities may exercise its authority under this Part in another municipality participating in the scheme.

section.marginalnote: Offence to carry on business without a licence
section.sectiontext: A person who carries on a business for which a business licence is required, without holding a valid business licence for the business, commits an offence and is liable to the penalties provided in section 4 of the Offence Act.

change.changenote: Section 664 definition of "licence year" BEFORE amended by 2006-3-12, effective November 1, 2006.

definition.def: means the period from March 1 to the last day of February of the following year;

change.changenote: Section 665 BEFORE amended by 2015-23-19, effective May 14, 2015 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to the Motor Carrier Act and despite any other Act relating to a municipality, this Division applies to all municipalities.

change.changenote: Section 670 (2) BEFORE amended by 2006-3-13, effective November 1, 2006 .

subsection.subsectiontext: A licence issued during January and February must be issued for the following licence year and is a valid and subsisting licence from the date of issue until the end of the following licence year.

change.changenote: Section 680 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-302, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: Subject to section 679 but without limiting that section, a council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: prohibit the operation of a public show, exhibition, carnival or performance of any particular kind or in any particular location, or both;

prohibit for all or defined parts of the municipality the operation of a public poolroom, billiard hall, cabaret, skating rink, bowling alley, dance hall or other place of amusement, including halls and other buildings where public dances are held;
require that all bread sold or intended to be sold or offered for sale in the municipality

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: be of a weight specified in the bylaw,
be distinctly labelled with its weight, the name and address of its baker or manufacturer and, in the case of an incorporated company, with the name of its manager, and
be wrapped,

section.parasandwich: except that this paragraph does not apply to bread sold in premises owned by the bakery that baked the bread;

paragraph.paragraphtext: subject to the Milk Industry Act,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: regulate the delivery of milk and milk products to consumers by means of vehicles, and
establish the hours for delivery in various months of the year and prohibit delivery at other times;

paragraph.paragraphtext: provide for the seizure and forfeiture of bread and other things intended for human consumption when of light weight or short measurement or made contrary to a bylaw;
in relation to premises in which rooms or suites are let for lodging or living purposes,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: require operators of the premises to maintain a register of persons living there,
regulate the mode of registration, and
require that the register be produced at the request of an employee of the municipality authorized by the council,

section.parasandwich: except that this paragraph does not apply to the operator of premises having not more than 2 rooms available for letting;

paragraph.paragraphtext: require all licensed persons purchasing, taking in barter or receiving used or second hand goods

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: to notify the chief constable having jurisdiction in the municipality within 24 hours after purchasing, taking or receiving them, and
not to alter the form of, or to sell, exchange or otherwise dispose of, those goods within 72 hours after the hour of purchasing, taking or receiving them;

paragraph.paragraphtext: regulate all vehicles, vessels or other things in which anything is exposed for sale or marketed in a street or public place;
in relation to millwood, sawdust, earth, sand and gravel,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: regulate their delivery,

prohibit their delivery within the municipality except in accordance with the bylaw, which may be different for different commodities, for inspection, measurement, marking, numbering, covering and approval of the vehicle or container in which delivery is made, and the display on a vehicle of its cubic or other capacity and the name of the owner, and
provide for the appointment of officials to inspect and carry out other duties under the bylaw in relation to the vehicles or containers;

paragraph.paragraphtext: regulate and require compulsory measurement or weighing of butter, potatoes, milk, cordwood, firewood, coal and other articles of food and fuel sold or exposed for sale.

change.changenote: Section 692 (2) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-303, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: The building code and other regulations under subsection (1) apply to all municipalities and to regional districts or parts of them not inside a municipality, and has the same force and effect as a validly enacted bylaw of the municipality.

change.changenote: Section 692 (3) BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-303, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A provision of a municipal bylaw that purports to deal with matters regulated under this section, and that is inconsistent with the code or other regulations, is of no force and effect and is deemed to be repealed.

paragraph.paragraphtext: establishing a Provincial building code for British Columbia governing standards for the construction and demolition of buildings;
adopting by reference, with the changes the minister considers necessary, all or part of any building code or standards for the construction or demolition of buildings;

change.changenote: Section 692 (2) BEFORE amended by 2008-8-5(c), effective March 31, 2008 (Royal Assent).

subsection.subsectiontext: The building code and other regulations under subsection (1) apply to all municipalities and to regional districts or parts of them not inside a municipality, and have the same force and effect as a validly enacted bylaw of the municipality or regional district, as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing a Provincial building code for British Columbia governing standards for the construction, alteration, repair or demolition of buildings;
amending, adding to or varying for the purpose of this section the building code established under this section;
adopting by reference, with the changes the minister considers necessary, all or part of any building code or standards for the construction, alteration, repair or demolition of buildings;
regulating building generally for matters not included in the building code;

exempting certain persons, buildings, classes of buildings, materials or areas either generally or for certain periods of time from the building code or regulations, and making other regulations for the persons, buildings, classes of buildings, materials or areas exempted;
providing for the administration of the building code and other regulations under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the regulations under subsection (1) apply to all municipalities and to regional districts or parts of them not inside a municipality, and have the same force and effect as a validly enacted bylaw of the municipality or regional district, as applicable.

The minister may, by regulation, provide that all or part of the building code or other regulations under subsection (1) do not apply to a municipality or regional district or a part of a regional district not inside a municipality.
Subject to an agreement described in subsection (1) applies to the treaty lands of treaty first nations.

If under the final agreement of a treaty first nation the government is required to negotiate and attempt to reach agreement with the treaty first nation enabling the treaty first nation to establish standards for buildings or structures that are different from or in addition to the standards established by the building code established under subsection (1), the minister, on behalf of the government, may enter into an agreement reached in the negotiation.
The designated official may issue a directive respecting the building code or other regulations under subsection (1) apply.
The designated official must make reasonable efforts to notify all persons affected by a directive.
The minister may designate a person in the ministry of the minister as the designated official for the purposes of (7).
If there is a conflict between the building code or other regulations under subsection (1) and a directive, the building code or other regulations prevail.

change.changenote: Section 693 BEFORE repealed by 2015-2-55, effective September 18, 2015 (BC Reg 172/2015).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Building Code Appeal Board is continued consisting of the following members appointed by the minister after a merit based process:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one member designated as the chair;
other members appointed after consultation with the chair.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A majority of the appeal board is a quorum.
If a dispute arises on the interpretation or application of the codes referred to in section 692, a party to the dispute may refer the question to the appeal board for determination.
The appeal board must determine any question of interpretation or application of the codes referred to in section 692.
The decision of the appeal board is final and binding.
Sections 1 to 8 and 10 of the Administrative Tribunals Act apply to the appeal board.

In (12), decision maker includes a member of the appeal board or other officer who makes a decision in an application or a person who conducts a dispute resolution process in relation to an application.

Subject to subsection (12), no legal proceeding for damages lies or may be commenced or maintained against a decision maker or the appeal board in a matter before the appeal board because of anything done or omitted

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the performance or intended performance of any duty under this Act, or
in the exercise or intended exercise of any power under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (11) does not apply to a person referred to in that subsection in relation to anything done or omitted by that person in bad faith.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the Health Act, the Fire Services Act and the regulations under these Acts, a council may, for the health, safety and protection of persons and property, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: regulate the construction, alteration, repair or demolition of buildings and structures;

regulate the installation, alteration or repair of plumbing including septic tanks and sewer connections, heating, air conditioning, electrical wiring and equipment, gas or oil piping and fittings, appliances and accessories of every kind;

require contractors, owners or other persons to obtain and hold a valid permit from the council, or the authorized official, before starting and during the construction, installation, repair or alteration of gas or oil pipes and fittings, plumbing, heating, sewers, septic tanks, drains, electrical wiring, oil burners, tanks, pumps and similar works and buildings and structures of the kind, description or value described in the bylaw;

require that, before occupancy of a building or part of it after construction, wrecking or alteration, or a change in class of occupancy of a building or part of it, an occupancy permit be obtained from the council or the authorized official;
prescribe conditions generally governing the issue and validity of permits, inspection of works, buildings and structures;
establish areas to be known as fire limits and, for those areas,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: regulate the construction of buildings in respect of precautions against fire, and
discriminate and differentiate between areas in the character of the buildings permitted;

paragraph.paragraphtext: regulate the seating arrangements and capacity of churches, theatres, halls and other places of public amusement or resort;
regulate or prohibit the moving of a building from one property to another in the municipality;
require the fencing of private swimming pools or other pools, existing or prospective, according to specifications set out in the bylaw;
regulate the construction and layout of trailer courts, manufactured home parks and camping grounds and require that those courts, parks and grounds provide facilities specified in the bylaw;
provide that a trailer or manufactured home must not be occupied as a residence or an office unless its construction and facilities meet the standards specified in the bylaw;

require the installation of smoke alarms in existing buildings and structures and, in relation to this, establish standards and specifications for required smoke alarms and their installation, to the extent that the requirements of the bylaw do not exceed those established by the building regulations under section 692;
require the maintenance of smoke alarms installed as required by regulation under section 692 or by bylaw under paragraph (l) and, in relation to this, establish standards for their maintenance;

require the maintenance of "residential premises" and "residential property", as defined in the Residential Tenancy Act, that are subject to a "tenancy agreement" as defined in that Act, in accordance with the standards specified in the bylaw, to the extent that the standards do not exceed those established by the building code for British Columbia established by the minister under section 692.

subsection.subsectiontext: If requested by an applicant, the building inspector must give written reasons for his or her refusal to issue a building permit.
An occupancy permit under subsection (1) (d) may be withheld until the building or part of it complies with the health and safety requirements of the bylaws or of any statute.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council or an official authorized by the council may, as a condition of issuing a permit or authorizing the moving of a building under section 694, require a person to provide security by, at the person's option, an irrevocable letter of credit or the deposit of securities in a form satisfactory to the local government, in an amount stated in the permit or authorization.

Security under this section may only be used by the municipality to repair or replace

paragraph.paragraphtext: a highway, including sidewalks and boulevards,

section.subsandwich: that has been altered or damaged by an activity related to the subject matter of the permit or authorization.

section.sectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, do one or both of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: require applicants for building permits, in circumstances as specified in the bylaw that relate to

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: site conditions,
the size or complexity of developments, or
aspects of developments,

section.parasandwich: to provide the municipality with a certification by a professional engineer or architect that the plans submitted with the application for the permit, or specified aspects of those plans, comply with the then current Provincial building code and other applicable enactments respecting safety;

paragraph.paragraphtext: authorize building inspectors for the municipality to require applicants for building permits to provide the municipality with a certification referred to in paragraph (a) if a building inspector considers that this is warranted by

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the site conditions,
the size or complexity of the development, or
an aspect of the development to which the permit relates.

section.marginalnote: Demolition or repair of unsafe buildings, structures and excavations

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, authorize

paragraph.paragraphtext: the demolition, removal or bringing up to a standard specified in the bylaw of a building, structure or thing, in whole or in part, that contravenes a bylaw or that the council believes is in an unsafe condition, or
the filling in, covering over or alteration in whole or in part of an excavation that contravenes a bylaw or that the council believes is in an unsafe condition.

subsection.subsectiontext: At least 30 days before the contemplated action is taken under the bylaw, the council must give written notice of this to the owner, tenant or occupier of the real property affected by the bylaw, either by serving the notice or by sending it by registered mail.
On application, the Supreme Court may order that the notice under subsection (2) may be served by substituted service in accordance with the order.
An appeal lies to the Supreme Court against the contemplated action.
Notice of an appeal must be given to the municipality within 10 days from the date of the notice to the owner, tenant or occupier.
The Supreme Court must hear and finally determine the matter, making the order it believes proper.
An appeal from a decision of the Supreme Court lies to the Court of Appeal with leave of a justice of the Court of Appeal.

section.marginalnote: Building inspector may require engineering report

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, construction means

paragraph.paragraphtext: the new construction of a building or structure, or
the structural alteration of or addition to an existing building or structure,

section.subsandwich: but does not include the repair of an existing building or structure.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a building inspector considers that construction would be on land that is subject to or is likely to be subject to flooding, mud flows, debris flows, debris torrents, erosion, land slip, rockfalls, subsidence or avalanche, the building inspector may require the owner of land to provide the building inspector with a report certified by a professional engineer with experience in geotechnical engineering that the land may be used safely for the use intended.
As an exception, subsection (2) does not apply if there are no bylaws under section 694 (1) (a) in effect.
If a professional engineer with experience in geotechnical engineering determines that land may not be used safely for the use intended, a building inspector must refuse to issue a building permit.

A building inspector may issue a building permit in accordance with subsection (6) if a professional engineer with experience in geotechnical engineering determines and certifies that the land may be used safely for the use intended, subject to conditions contained in the engineer's report with respect to

paragraph.paragraphtext: the siting, structural design and maintenance of buildings, structures or works,
the maintenance or planting of vegetation,
the placement and maintenance of land fill, or
other conditions respecting the safe use of the land, buildings, structures or works.

subsection.subsectiontext: A building permit under subsection (5) must be issued on the condition that

paragraph.paragraphtext: the owner of the land covenants with the municipality or regional district to use the land only in the manner determined and certified by the engineer as enabling the safe use of the land for the use intended,
the covenant contains conditions respecting reimbursement by the covenantor for any expenses that may be incurred by the covenantee as a result of a breach of a covenant under paragraph (a), and
the covenant be registered under section 219 of the Land Title Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: On application of an owner, a council or board may, by resolution, direct its building inspector to issue a building permit but subject to the condition that a covenant referred to in subsection (6) be entered into and registered.

section.marginalnote: Note against land title that building regulations contravened

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition to any other action that a building inspector is authorized or permitted to take, a building inspector may recommend to the council that it consider a resolution under subsection (3) if, during the course of carrying out duties, the building inspector

paragraph.paragraphtext: observes a condition, with respect to land or a building or structure, that the inspector considers

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: results from the contravention of, or is in contravention of, a bylaw or regulation under this Part or under any other enactment relating to the construction or safety of buildings or structures, and
as a result of that condition, a building or structure is unsafe or is unlikely to be usable for its expected purpose during its normal lifetime, or

paragraph.paragraphtext: discovers that

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: something was done with respect to a building or structure or the construction of a building or structure that required a permit or an inspection under a bylaw, regulation or enactment referred to in paragraph (a) (i), and
the permit was not obtained or the inspection not satisfactorily completed.

subsection.subsectiontext: A recommendation under subsection (1) must be given in writing to the designated municipal officer, who must

paragraph.paragraphtext: notify the registered owner of the land to which the recommendation relates, and
after notice under paragraph (a), place the matter before the council.

subsection.subsectiontext: After hearing the building inspector and the owner, the council may confirm the recommendations of the building inspector and pass a resolution directing the designated municipal officer to file a notice in the land title office stating that

paragraph.paragraphtext: a resolution relating to that land has been made under this section, and
further information about it may be inspected at the municipal hall.

subsection.subsectiontext: The designated municipal officer must ensure that all records are available for the purpose of subsection (3) (b).

If the registrar of land titles receives a notice under subsection (3) and payment of the prescribed fee, the registrar must make a note of the filing against the title to the land that is affected by the notice.
The note of a filing of a notice under this section is extinguished when a new title to the land issues in consequence of the deposit of a plan of subdivision or a strata plan.

In the event of any omission, mistake or misfeasance by the registrar or an employee of the registrar in relation to the making of a note of the filing under subsection (5) after the notice is received by the land title office,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the registrar is not liable nor is the Provincial government liable vicariously, and
the assurance fund or the Attorney General as a nominal defendant is not liable under Part 20 of the Land Title Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: Neither the building inspector nor the municipality is liable for damage of any kind for the doing of anything, or the failure to do anything, under this section or section 701 that would have, but for this subsection, constituted a breach of duty to any person.
[Repealed 2000-7-63.]

section.marginalnote: Cancellation of note against land title

subsection.subsectiontext: On receiving a report from a building inspector that the condition that gave rise to the filing of the notice under section 700 (3) has been rectified, the designated municipal officer must file a cancellation notice and, on receiving the notice, the registrar of land titles must cancel the note against the title to which it relates.
An owner of land with respect to which a notice has been filed under section 700 (3), may apply to the council for a resolution that the note be cancelled.
After hearing an applicant under subsection (2), the council may pass a resolution directing the designated municipal officer to file a cancellation notice.

If a resolution has been passed under subsection (3), the designated municipal officer must file a cancellation notice in the land title office and, on receiving the notice, the registrar of land titles must cancel the note against the title to which it relates.

If the council does not pass a resolution under subsection (3), the owner may apply to the Supreme Court and notify the municipality to attend before the court to show cause why the note should not be cancelled.

On an application under subsection (4), after reviewing any evidence that the owner and the municipality may adduce, the court may make an order directing the registrar to cancel the note made under section 700 (3) and, on receiving the order, the registrar of land titles must cancel the note accordingly.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: regulate or prohibit the keeping of dogs, horses, cattle, sheep, goats, swine, rabbits or other animals and define areas in which they may be kept or may not be kept;
regulate or prohibit the keeping of poultry, pigeons, doves or other birds and define areas in which they may be kept or may not be kept;
regulate or prohibit the moving and keeping of bees and define areas in which they may be kept or may not be kept;

regulate or prohibit kennels or other places for the keeping, training, care, breeding, treatment, hospitalization or boarding of dogs, cats, fur bearing animals or other animals, whether domesticated or undomesticated and, in relation to this,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: define areas in which those places are permitted or are not permitted, and
define for different species of animals what constitutes a kennel and what is deemed a fur bearing animal;

paragraph.paragraphtext: in relation to cattle within the meaning of subsection (3), regulate or prohibit

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the running of cattle on a highway or public place,
the straying of or trespassing by cattle on a highway or public place or private property, and
the grazing of cattle on unfenced land, unless they are securely tethered;

paragraph.paragraphtext: in relation to cattle within the meaning of subsection (3) that are subject to a bylaw under paragraph (e), provide for the impounding of those cattle;

regulate or prohibit the running of poultry or rabbits on a highway or public place, or the straying of or trespassing by poultry or rabbits on a highway or public place or private property, and the grazing of poultry or rabbits on unfenced land, and provide for the impounding of the poultry or rabbits.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (1) may be applicable to all or any defined area of the municipality and the regulations may be different for different areas.
For the purpose of subsection (1) (e) and (f), "cattle" includes any horse, mule, swine, sheep, goat, cow or other animal of the bovine species.

change.changenote: Section 704 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-315, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: require owners or occupiers of buildings to prevent pigeons or other birds from perching, roosting or nesting on the buildings, and regulate the feeding of pigeons or other birds by persons other than their owners;
offer bounties for the destruction of beasts and birds of a noxious or destructive character;
regulate the sale of animals, and the driving of animals through the municipality;
prohibit cruelty to animals, and provide for the destruction of any animal suffering from an incurable disease;
require that the owner, possessor or harbourer of a dog, or any class of dog, must keep it, as the bylaw directs,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: effectively muzzled while at large or on a highway or public place, or
on leash or under control of a competent person while on a highway or public place.

change.changenote: Section 705 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-315, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Without limiting section 703 [keeping of animals], a council may, by bylaw, regulate the keeping of dogs by requiring persons who own, possess or harbour a dog to hold a licence for the dog.
A bylaw under subsection (1) may

paragraph.paragraphtext: require a separate dog licence for each dog, and
vary the amount of the fee according to the sex, age, size or breed of the dog.

subsection.subsectiontext: A licence issued under this section is for the calendar year in which the licence is issued.

change.changenote: Section 706 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-315, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: The council of a municipality that imposes a fee to issue a licence for a dog may, by bylaw,

paragraph.paragraphtext: provide for the payment of compensation, on a scale set out in the bylaw, to the owner of any domestic animal defined in the Livestock Protection Act that is killed or injured by a dog over the age of 4 months, the owner of which is unknown, and, after diligent inquiry cannot be found, and
provide for the maximum sum that is available in any one year for the purposes of compensation under this section.

subsection.subsectiontext: The scale of compensation under subsection (1) (a) must not be less than that provided in rural areas by regulations under the Livestock Protection Act.

change.changenote: Section 707 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-316, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: provide for the seizure, impounding and detention of unlicensed dogs, and of dogs, horses, cattle, poultry, rabbits and other animals unlawfully at large;
establish, maintain and operate facilities as pounds;
regulate and establish the fines and fees, including damages for trespassing on private property, to be levied and collected by pound keepers;
provide for the sale or destruction of animals and birds impounded if the fines, fees and other charges are not paid within a reasonable time.

subsection.subsectiontext: Pounds may be established under subsection (1) (b) outside the municipality but, before adopting the applicable bylaw, the council must obtain the consent of the other affected local government as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: if the area outside the municipality is another municipality, the consent of the council of that other municipality is required;
if the area outside the municipality is not another municipality, the consent of the regional district board for the area is required.

subsection.subsectiontext: The powers under subsection (1) may be exercised jointly with an improvement district or with the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, or both.
If subsection (3) applies, the Livestock Protection Act operates only in so far as it does not conflict with this Act or a bylaw adopted under this Act.

change.changenote: Section 707.1 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-316, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section:

definition.def: means

paragraph.paragraphtext: a municipal employee, officer or agent designated by the council as an animal control officer for the purposes of this section, or
a peace officer;

definition.def: means an animal kept as a pet or as a guide animal;
means a dog that

paragraph.paragraphtext: has killed or seriously injured a person,
an animal control officer has reasonable grounds to believe is likely to kill or seriously injure a person, or

while in a public place or while on private property, other than property owned or occupied by the person responsible for the dog, has killed or seriously injured a companion animal or a domestic animal;

definition.def: means a domestic animal as defined in the Livestock Protection Act;
includes impound and detain.

subsection.subsectiontext: In addition to the authority under section 707 (1) (a) but subject to this section, an animal control officer may seize a dog if the officer believes on reasonable grounds that the dog is a dangerous dog.

Before exercising a power under subsection (2), in the case of a dog that has acted as described in paragraph (a) or (c) of the definition of "dangerous dog", the animal control officer must consider whether the dog was acting while in the course of

paragraph.paragraphtext: attempting to prevent a person from committing an unlawful act, or
performing law enforcement work.

subsection.subsectiontext: An animal control officer may enter a place to exercise the power under subsection (2),

paragraph.paragraphtext: in any case, with the consent of the owner or occupier of the place,
in any case, in accordance with a warrant under subsection (5) or (6), or
if the circumstances referred to in subsection (7) apply, in accordance with that subsection.

subsection.subsectiontext: If satisfied by evidence given under oath or affirmation that there are reasonable grounds to believe that

paragraph.paragraphtext: there is in a place a dog, and
the dog is a dangerous dog,

section.subsandwich: a justice may, by warrant, authorize an animal control officer to enter and search the place and to seize the dog.

subsection.subsectiontext: If

paragraph.paragraphtext: it is impracticable for an animal control officer to appear personally before a justice to apply for a warrant in accordance with subsection (5), and
the officer believes on reasonable grounds that the circumstances referred to in subsection (5) (a) and (b) apply,

section.subsandwich: the officer may apply for a warrant in accordance with section 22 [telewarrants] of the Offence Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (8), an animal control officer may, without a warrant, enter and search any place except a dwelling house and seize a dog, if the officer believes on reasonable grounds that

paragraph.paragraphtext: the dog is a dangerous dog,
the dog presents an imminent danger to the public, and
the purpose of seizing the dog cannot reasonably be accomplished if the officer is required to obtain a warrant.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (7), an animal control officer who is not a police officer must be accompanied by a police officer.

In addition to the authority under section 8 of the Livestock Protection Act, in relation to a dog that the animal control officer has reasonable grounds to believe is a dangerous dog, the animal control officer may apply to the Provincial Court for an order that the dog be destroyed in the manner specified in the order.

A dog that has been seized under this section may not be impounded for more than 21 days unless proceedings under subsection (9) of this section or section 8 of the Livestock Protection Act are commenced within that time.

change.changenote: Division 2 of Part 22, sections 708 to 715 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-317, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw applicable to all or part of the municipality, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: prohibit the cutting and removal of trees;
regulate the cutting and removal of trees;
prohibit the damaging of trees;
regulate activities that may damage trees;
require the replacement, in accordance with the bylaw, of trees that have been cut, removed or damaged in contravention of a bylaw under this subsection or a permit referred to in section 709 (1);
require the maintenance of replacement trees required under paragraph (e) or by permit referred to in section 709 and of significant trees identified under section 710;
require specified amounts of cash deposits, letters of credit or other forms of security for the replacement of trees under paragraph (e) and their maintenance under paragraph (f);
specify circumstances in which assessments or inspections of trees or sites may be undertaken by the municipality;
establish exemptions from the application of a bylaw under this subsection.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under this section may be different in relation to one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: different areas of the municipality;
different species of trees;
different classes of trees;
different sizes of trees;
different significant trees identified under section 710.

subsection.subsectiontext: Interest on security under subsection (1) (g) becomes part of the security.
Security under subsection (1) (g) may be used for the purposes referred to in that subsection, but any amount not required for those purposes must be returned to the person who provided the security.

section.marginalnote: Regulation of tree cutting and removal

subsection.subsectiontext: Without limiting the generality of section 708 (1) (b), a bylaw under that section may do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: require permits to cut or remove trees;

establish terms and conditions for the granting, refusal and use of these permits, which may include requirements for the replacement of trees that are cut or removed or that are damaged in the course of these actions;
require applicants for these permits to provide plans identifying

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the trees proposed to be cut or removed,
the trees proposed to be retained, and
the trees proposed to be provided in replacement of the trees that are to be cut or removed;

paragraph.paragraphtext: establish circumstances in which a permit under this section may be cancelled.

subsection.subsectiontext: A fee for a permit under subsection (1) must not include charges for an assessment or inspection required as a condition of the permit or authorized under section 708 (1) (h) or 713 (1).

A council may, by bylaw, identify trees that the council considers significant because of their importance to the community, including importance for heritage or landmark value or as wildlife habitat.

The council may provide for the placement of a plaque or other marker indicating a tree identified under subsection (1), subject to the requirement that permission for this be obtained from the owner of the real property on which the marker is placed.
A council may, by bylaw, require the owner or occupier of real property to trim, remove or cut down a tree, hedge, bush or shrub on the property if the council considers that it is

paragraph.paragraphtext: a hazard to the safety of persons,
likely to damage public property, or
seriously inconveniencing the public.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under section 708 (1) (a) or (b) does not apply to a tree that is subject to a bylaw under this section.

section.marginalnote: Removal or replacement of trees at owner's expense

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may take action under this section if a person does not comply

paragraph.paragraphtext: with a requirement of a bylaw under section 708 (1) (e) or a permit referred to in section 709 (1) to provide replacement trees, or
with a requirement of a bylaw under section 711 to trim, remove or cut down trees, hedges, bushes or shrubs.

subsection.subsectiontext: In the circumstances described in subsection (1), the council may serve the person with notice that the municipality will be entitled to take the required action at the expense of the person given the notice if the person does not take that required action,

paragraph.paragraphtext: in the case of a requirement referred to in subsection (1) (a), within 30 days of service, or
in the case of a requirement referred to in subsection (1) (b), within 5 days of service.

subsection.subsectiontext: The Supreme Court may, on application, order that the notice under subsection (2) may be served by substituted service in accordance with the order.

If the person given notice does not take the required action within the time period referred to in subsection (2), the municipality, by its employees or others, may enter the real property and effect that action at the expense of the person given notice.

In addition to the authority under section 708 (1) (h), a council may direct that an assessment or inspection of specified trees or sites be undertaken by the municipality for the purposes of this Division.

The municipality, by its employees or others, may enter onto real property and make an assessment or inspection authorized under subsection (1) or section 708 (1) (h) or required as a condition of a permit referred to in section 709 (1).

section.marginalnote: Limits on powers under this Division

subsection.subsectiontext: If a bylaw under section 708 would have the effect on a parcel of land of

paragraph.paragraphtext: preventing all uses permitted under the applicable zoning bylaw, or
preventing the development to the density permitted under the applicable zoning bylaw,

section.subsandwich: the bylaw does not apply to the parcel to the extent necessary to allow a permitted use or the permitted density.

subsection.subsectiontext: As an exception to subsection (1), a bylaw that has an effect referred to in that subsection applies without limit to a parcel if the council, by resolution, commits the municipality to

paragraph.paragraphtext: pay compensation to the owner of the parcel for any reduction in the market value caused by the prohibition, or
provide, by development permit, development variance permit or otherwise, alternative means for the parcel to be used for a permitted use or developed to the permitted density.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (2) (a), the compensation must be as determined and paid as soon as reasonably possible in an amount set

paragraph.paragraphtext: by agreement between the owner and the municipality, or
if no agreement is reached, by the Expropriation Compensation Board.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (2) (b), the council may issue a development permit or development variance permit on its own initiative without an application from the owner.

Except as provided in subsection (2), no compensation is payable to any person for a reduction in the value of any interest in land that results from a bylaw under this Division or the issuance or refusal of a permit under this Division.
A bylaw or permit under this Division does not apply to land and the trees on it if the land is land to which section17 of the Forest Land Reserve Act applies.

section.sectiontext: If a council delegates powers, duties or functions under this Division, the owner or occupier of real property that is subject to a decision of a delegate is entitled to have the council reconsider the matter.

change.changenote: Section 716 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-318, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the Cemetery and Funeral Services Act, a council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: lay out, regulate and manage cemeteries, including the construction of crematoriums or columbariums;
regulate the interment or other disposition of the dead;
prohibit the violation of cemeteries and damage to vaults, monuments, gravestones or graves;

establish the terms and conditions under which, and the fees for which, persons may acquire the right to make use of areas or plots in a municipal cemetery for the interment or other disposition of the dead;
establish, set aside and maintain a maintenance fund for the upkeep and care of a cemetery and the burial plots in it and, in relation to this,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: determine what proportion of the fees for each burial plot must be paid into the maintenance fund, and
accept voluntary payments from a person having the right to use an area or plot or from other persons or municipalities interested.

subsection.subsectiontext: All money received by a municipality for a maintenance fund under subsection (1) (f) must be held and invested as trust funds to be devoted solely to the purposes for which they were received.

change.changenote: Section 718 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-318, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw,

paragraph.paragraphtext: appoint, employ and pay night patrollers for the purpose of

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: patrolling at night, or between certain hours of the night, an area in the municipality defined by the bylaw, and
guarding and protecting the property within the area, and

paragraph.paragraphtext: levy by special rate on all the land and improvements within the limits defined by the bylaw, except vacant lots, for the expenses of or incidental to the employment of the night patrollers, in the same manner and at the same time as payment of the other rates or taxes in the municipality is enforced.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (1) must not be adopted except on petition for it signed by at least 2/3 of the owners who

paragraph.paragraphtext: on its adoption would become liable to be charged with the expenses to be incurred under it, and
represent in value at least 2/3 of the assessed real property liable to be charged with the expenses.

subsection.subsectiontext: A petition under subsection (2) must not be received and acted on by the council unless

paragraph.paragraphtext: it is proved, by the affidavit of a reliable and competent witness, that

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: all the signatures on it are the genuine signatures of the persons whose signatures they purport to be, and
its contents were made known to each person signing it before signature, or

paragraph.paragraphtext: its sufficiency has been determined by the municipal officer assigned responsibility under section 198 [corporate administration] in the manner for a petition for a work of local improvement.

change.changenote: Section 720 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-318, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, regulate bicycles by requiring persons who own a bicycle used on a highway to hold a licence for the bicycle.
A licence issued under this section is for the calendar year in which the licence is issued.

change.changenote: Section 721 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-318, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may provide by regulation for the imposition of a charge on each parcel of land in an area to be rehabilitated under the Agricultural and Rural Development (BC) Act.

A charge under subsection (1) must be imposed on the basis of area and must be a deferred diminishing charge collectable only under the regulation on sale of the land or at the end of a period of years, as set out in the regulations.

A registrar of land titles must not accept for registration a document purporting to transfer or charge land in an area of a municipality or improvement district rehabilitated under the Public Works Agreement Act or the Agricultural and Rural Development (BC) Act without a certificate from the designated municipal officer or the improvement district officer assigned responsibility under section 738.2 that charges under subsection (1) have been paid in full.
Subsections (1) to (3) do not apply to an agreement made by the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food with a corporation under section 5 of the Agricultural and Rural Development (BC) Act.

change.changenote: Section 721 (3) BEFORE amended by 2000-7-64, effective January 1, 2001 (BC Reg 399/2000).

subsection.subsectiontext: A registrar of land titles must not accept for registration a document purporting to transfer or charge land in an area of a municipality or improvement district rehabilitated under the Public Works Agreement Act or the Agricultural and Rural Development (BC) Act without

paragraph.paragraphtext: a certificate from the designated municipal officer or the improvement district secretary that charges under subsection (1) have been paid in full, or
the written approval of the inspector.

change.changenote: Section 722 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-318, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Wild flowers, auctions and athletic contests
section.sectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, regulate or prohibit one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the sale of wild flowers;
sales by auction in a public market;
boxing, wrestling, jujitsu and other professional athletic contests where an athletic commission has not been established.

change.changenote: Section 722.1 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-318, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, establish an athletic commission consisting of 3 members appointed annually.
A council may, by bylaw, provide that an athletic commission is to have one or more of the following powers within the municipality:

paragraph.paragraphtext: to regulate and supervise professional boxing, wrestling and like activities, contests and exhibitions;

in addition to any other tax or fee payable under this Act and for the purpose of providing funds for the commission's proper expenses, to require persons conducting events referred to in paragraph (a) to pay to the commission for each event the fee set by the council;
to specify equipment to be used in and to establish rules for the conduct of professional boxing and wrestling and any other professional contests within the jurisdiction of the commission;
to pass on and approve contracts for the contests or exhibitions as a condition of their being held;
to issue permits to persons conducting professional athletic contests or exhibitions as a condition of their being held;
to issue permits to boxers, wrestlers and other participants in professional athletic contests or exhibitions as a condition of their participating in them;
before issuing any permit, to require the applicant to give the security the commission determines for the faithful performance of the applicant's obligations as specified by the commission;
to prohibit a person from participating in or conducting a contest or exhibition, or from advertising them, unless the person has been granted a permit for the purpose;
to investigate the conduct of participants in the contests or exhibitions or of persons conducting them, and particularly with respect to alleged breaches of the bylaw or rules made under it;

in relation to breaches of the bylaw or rules made under it, to impose reasonable fines for misconduct, or to prohibit those participants or persons from taking part in contests or exhibitions in the municipality for reasonable periods;

whether or not a penalty has been imposed, to restrain a person conducting a contest or exhibition or participating in it without the prescribed permit, by action in the Supreme Court brought by the commission in its name without the Provincial government being made a party to the action.

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, provide that a decision of the commission under subsection (2) is subject to appeal to the council.
Security under subsection (1) (g) may be enforced by and in the name of the commission for the benefit of all persons entitled to claim under it.

change.changenote: Section 723( 4) BEFORE amended by 2002-26-7, effective June 20, 2003 (BC Reg 232/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A provision in a bylaw under subsection (2) that prohibits the removal of soil has no effect until the provision is approved by the minister with the concurrence of the Minister of Energy, Mines and Petroleum Resources.

change.changenote: Section 723 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-319, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Removal and deposit of sand, gravel and other soil

subsection.subsectiontext: In ths section, soil includes sand, gravel, rock and other substances of which land is composed.
A council may, by bylaw, regulate or prohibit

paragraph.paragraphtext: the removal of soil from, and
the deposit of soil or other material on

section.subsandwich: any land in the municipality or in any area of the municipality.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (2) may make different regulations and prohibitions for different areas.
A provision in a bylaw under subsection (2) that prohibits the removal of soil has no effect until the provision is approved by the minister with the concurrence of the Minister of Energy and Mines.

A provision in a bylaw under subsection (2) that prohibits the deposit of soil or other material and that makes reference to quality of the soil or material or to contamination, has no effect until the provision is approved by the minister with the concurrence of the Minister of Environment, Lands and Parks.
A council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: require the holding of a permit for

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the removal of soil from, or
the deposit of soil or other material on

section.parasandwich: any land in the municipality or in any area of the municipality;

paragraph.paragraphtext: impose rates or levels of fees for a permit referred to in paragraph (a);
impose rates or levels of fees for the activities referred to in paragraph (a).

subsection.subsectiontext: Fees under subsection (5) (b) or (c) may vary according to the quantity of soil removed or the quantity of soil or other material deposited, and the rates or levels of fees may be different for different areas of the municipality.
A bylaw under subsection (5) (b) or (c) has no effect until it is approved by the minister.

change.changenote: Section 723 (7) BEFORE repealed by 2014-14-29, effective May 29, 2014 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (5) (b) or (c) has no effect until it is approved by the minister.

change.changenote: Section 724 BEFORE amended by 2003-52-320, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: regulate or prohibit the making or causing of noises or sounds in or on a highway or elsewhere in the municipality

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: that disturb, or tend to disturb, the quiet, peace, rest, enjoyment, comfort or convenience of the neighbourhood, or of persons in the vicinity, or
that the council believes are objectionable or liable to disturb the quiet, peace, rest, enjoyment, comfort or convenience of individuals or the public;

paragraph.paragraphtext: prevent or prohibit persons from shouting, using megaphones and making other noise in, at or on streets, wharves, docks, piers, steamboat landings, railway stations or other public places;
prevent charivaries and similar disturbances of the peace.

subsection.subsectiontext: Regulations and prohibitions under subsection (1) (a) may be different for different areas of the municipality.

change.changenote: Section 725 BEFORE amended by 2003-52-321, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: prevent, abate and prohibit nuisances, and provide for the recovery of the cost of abatement of nuisances from the person causing the nuisance or other persons described in the bylaw;
prohibit persons from

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: causing or permitting water, rubbish or noxious, offensive or unwholesome matter to collect or accumulate around their premises, or
depositing or throwing bottles, broken glass or other rubbish in any open place;

paragraph.paragraphtext: for the purpose of preventing unsightliness on real property,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: prohibit persons from placing graffiti on walls, fences or elsewhere on or adjacent to a public place, and
prohibit the owners or occupiers of real property from allowing their property to become or remain unsightly;

paragraph.paragraphtext: for the purpose of remedying unsightliness on real property, require the owners or occupiers of real property, or their agents, to remove from it unsightly accumulations of filth, discarded materials, rubbish or graffiti;
require the owners or occupiers of real property, or their agents, to clear the property of brush, trees, noxious weeds or other growths;
require the owners or occupiers of real property, or their agents, to prevent infestation by caterpillars and other noxious or destructive insects and to clear the property of such insects;
in relation to the emission of smoke, dust, gas, sparks, ash, soot, cinders, fumes or other effluvia,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: require the owners or occupiers of real property, or their agents, to eliminate or reduce the fouling or contaminating of the atmosphere through those emissions,
prescribe measures and precautions to be taken for the purpose of subparagraph (i), and
establish limits not to be exceeded for those emissions;

paragraph.paragraphtext: require manufacturers and processors to dispose of the waste from their plants in the manner directed by the bylaw;

prohibit the posting, exhibiting or distributing of placards, play bills, posters, advertising, writings or pictures, or the writing of words, or the making of pictures or drawings that are indecent or may tend to corrupt or demoralize, on walls, fences or elsewhere, on or adjacent to a highway or public place;
prevent vice, drunkenness, profane swearing or indecent, obscene, blasphemous or grossly insulting language or other immorality and indecency;
regulate the bathing or washing of the person in any public waters in or near the municipality;
regulate or prohibit mushroom growing;
prohibit the carrying on of a noxious or offensive trade, business or manufacture.

subsection.subsectiontext: In relation to a requirement under subsection (1) (d), (e) or (f), the bylaw may provide that, if a person fails to comply with the requirement, the municipality, by its employees or other persons, at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner, may enter on the property and effect the compliance at the expense of the person who has failed to comply.
A bylaw under subsection (1) (l) may be applicable throughout the municipality or any defined area of it and may make different regulations for different areas.

change.changenote: Section 725.1 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-322, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.sectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, prohibit a person from

paragraph.paragraphtext: polluting, or
obstructing or impeding the flow of

section.secsandwich: a stream, creek, waterway, watercourse, waterworks, ditch, drain or sewer, whether or not it is located on private property.

change.changenote: Section 726 (1) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-323, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: In relation to fire alarm systems and security alarm systems, a council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

change.changenote: Section 726 (1) (b) (i) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-323, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: by the owner or occupier of real property to which services are provided by or on behalf of the municipality, including policing services under section 3 (2) of the Police Act, in response to a false alarm of a system, or

change.changenote: Section 726 (3) (a) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-323, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

paragraph.paragraphtext: grant additional powers to municipalities, including the City of Vancouver, to enact bylaws establishing specified prohibitions, restrictions, requirements and conditions regarding

change.changenote: Section 727 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-324, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Removal of dangerous buildings and other structures

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may

paragraph.paragraphtext: declare that a building, structure or erection of any kind, or a drain, ditch, watercourse, pond, surface water or other matter or thing, in or on private land or a highway, or in or about a building or structure, is a nuisance, and

order that it be removed, pulled down, filled up or otherwise dealt with by its owner, agent, lessee or occupier, as the council may determine and within the time after service of the order that is stated in the order.

subsection.subsectiontext: The council must give notice of an order under subsection (1) to the following persons, either by serving the order or by sending the order by registered mail:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the owner of the land where the nuisance exists;
all other persons who are recorded in the land title office as having an interest in the land;
the agent, if known, of the registered owner of the land;
the lessee or occupier of the land.

subsection.subsectiontext: On application, the Supreme Court may order that service required by subsection (2) may be made by substituted service in accordance with the order.

If the owner, agent, lessee or occupier fails to comply with an order within the time period established under subsection (1) (b), the municipality may, by its employees and others, enter on the property and undertake the work required to comply with the order at the expense of the person defaulting.
If a nuisance declared under subsection (1) is a building, structure or erection,

paragraph.paragraphtext: after the end of 60 days from the date of the mailing of the notice to the owner under subsection (2), and
after the end of the period stated in the order,

section.subsandwich: the council may dispose of the building, structure or erection, or any part or material in it, by auction sale, by public or private tender, or otherwise.

subsection.subsectiontext: From the proceeds of a sale or other disposal under subsection (5), there must be deducted for municipal use the actual costs, including incidental expenses, incurred by the municipality in carrying out the order, and the remainder of the proceeds must be paid by the municipality to the owner or other person lawfully entitled.
This section applies to any building, structure or erection of any kind that the council believes is so dilapidated or unclean as to be offensive to the community.

change.changenote: Section 727.1 BEFORE repealed by 2003-52-324, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

section.marginalnote: Authority to require unsanitary conditions to be remedied

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to the Health Act, a council may, by bylaw, require a person to remedy or remove an unsanitary condition for which the person is responsible, or which exists on property owned, occupied or controlled by the person.

A bylaw under subsection (1) may provide that, if a person fails to comply with the requirement, the municipality, by its employees or other persons, at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner, may enter on the property and effect the compliance at the expense of the person who has failed to comply.

change.changenote: Section 728 BEFORE re-enacted by 2003-52-325, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: A council may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

paragraph.paragraphtext: regulate or prohibit the discharging of firearms, including air guns, air rifles, air pistols and spring guns;
regulate or prohibit the use of bows as defined in the Wildlife Act;

regulate or prohibit the use of any explosive agent for blasting, regulate persons engaged in blasting and require persons engaged in blasting to give security for damage to persons who, or whose property, may be injured by it;
regulate or prohibit the exploding of firecrackers or other fireworks;
subject to the Fireworks Act, regulate or prohibit the sale or disposal to any person of firecrackers and other fireworks of every nature or kind.

subsection.subsectiontext: A bylaw under subsection (1) (a) to (d) may be applicable throughout the municipality or any defined area of it and may make different regulations for different areas.

Despite a bylaw under subsection (1) (d), a council may authorize the issuance of a permit to a person or organization for the purpose of the observance or celebration of a special event or festival by the use of firecrackers or other fireworks of any kind, and may specify terms and conditions.

Section 729 definitions of "assessor", "board of trustees" and "collector" were added by 2000-7-66, effective January 1, 2001 (BC Reg 399/2000).
Section 731 (7) was added by 2000-7-68, effective January 1, 2001 (BC Reg 399/2000).
Section 731 (3) BEFORE amended by 2008-42-56, effective May 29, 2008 (Royal Assent).

subsection.subsectiontext: If it appears to the Lieutenant Governor in Council that an improvement district will undertake the functions of an existing development district, another improvement district or a water users' community, the Lieutenant Governor in Council

paragraph.paragraphtext: may transfer to the improvement district any asset, right, claim, charge or liability of the development district, other improvement district or water users' community, and dissolve the development district, other improvement district or water users' community, and

specify that the bylaws of the dissolved development district, improvement district or water user's community continue in force in the area that was formerly inside its boundaries, until amended or repealed by the trustees of the improvement district that has undertaken its functions.

change.changenote: Section 731 (4.1) was added by 2008-42-56, effective May 29, 2008 (Royal Assent).
Section 732 (1) BEFORE repealed by 2007-6-18, effective March 29, 2007 (Royal Assent).

subsection.subsectiontext: If

paragraph.paragraphtext: the council of a municipality in which the area is located approves, or
in the absence of a municipality, the board of the regional district in which the area is located approves,

change.subsandwich: the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by letters patent, incorporate an area of land comprising 2 or more parcels, whether contiguous or not, and its owners into a mountain resort improvement district, under a name and with objects that appear advisable and with powers considered necessary to carry out those objects.

change.changenote: Section 732 (4) BEFORE amended by 2008-42-57, effective May 29, 2008 (Royal Assent).

subsection.subsectiontext: If it appears to the Lieutenant Governor in Council that a mountain resort improvement district will undertake the functions of an existing improvement district or a water users' community, the Lieutenant Governor in Council

paragraph.paragraphtext: may transfer to the mountain resort improvement district any asset, right, claim, charge or liability of the other improvement district or water users' community, and dissolve the other improvement district or water users' community, and

may specify that the bylaws of the dissolved improvement district or water users' community continue in force in the area that was formerly inside its boundaries until amended or repealed by the trustees of the mountain resort improvement district that has undertaken its functions.

change.changenote: Section 732 (5.1) was added by 2008-42-57, effective May 29, 2008 (Royal Assent).
Section 733 (3) BEFORE amended by 2004-66-150, effective January 20, 2005 (BC Reg 16/2005).

change.changenote: Section 733 (4) (a) BEFORE amended by 2004-66-152(a), effective January 20, 2005 (Bc Reg 16/2005).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the registrar of land titles is not liable nor is the Provincial government liable vicariously, and

change.changenote: Section 733 (4) (a.1) was added by 2004-66-152(b), effective January 20, 2005 (BC Reg 16/2005).

paragraph.paragraphtext: the assurance fund or the Attorney General as a nominal defendant is not liable under Part 20 of the Land Title Act.

change.changenote: Section 734 BEFORE re-enacted by 2008-42-58, effective May 29, 2008 (Royal Assent).

section.marginalnote: Amendment or recall of letters patent

subsection.subsectiontext: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may

paragraph.paragraphtext: amend the letters patent of an improvement district in any respect, or
recall the letters patent and issue others in their place.

subsection.subsectiontext: Unless expressly provided in the amending or new letters patent, the amendment, recall or reissue does not impair or prejudice the assets, rights, claims and financial obligations of the improvement district.

change.changenote: Section 735 BEFORE re-enacted by 2008-42-59, effective May 29, 2008 (Royal Assent).

section.sectiontext: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may dissolve an improvement district and may make a disposition of its assets that appears equitable.

change.changenote: Section 735.1 was enacted by 2008-42-59, effective May 29, 2008 (Royal Assent).
Section 735.2 was enacted by 2008-42-59, effective May 29, 2008 (Royal Assent).
Section 738 (5) BEFORE repealed by 2000-7-69, effective January 1, 2001 (BC Reg 399/2000).

subsection.subsectiontext: The trustees may

paragraph.paragraphtext: appoint a secretary and other officers and employees as they consider necessary,
establish the salaries or wages of the persons appointed, and
in the discretion of the trustees, dismiss an appointed person.

change.changenote: Sections 738.1 to 738.5 were added by 2000-7-70, effective January 1, 2001 (BC Reg 399/2000).
Section 738.4 (3) BEFORE amended by 2003-52-327, effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 465/2003, repealing BC Reg 428/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to a contract of employment, the appointment of an improvement district officer may be terminated by the board of trustees as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: on reasonable notice, if the termination is approved by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the votes cast by the trustees;
without notice, for cause, if the termination is approved by a majority of the votes cast by the trustees.
